('5', 0, 1, 2, 45) 1. LETTER TO CHHAGANLAL GANDHI
('5', 0, 2, 3, 76) [JOHANNESBURG,] November 6, 1905
('5', 0, 3, 4, 109) MY DEAR CHHAGANLAL, Your letter to hand.
('5', 0, 3, 5, 150) I am returning the letter addressed to Revashankar.
('5', 0, 3, 6, 202) I shall ask Abhechand to take the papers back.
('5', 0, 3, 7, 249) He has gone to Pretoria.
('5', 0, 3, 8, 274) You have done well in writing about Kitchin.
('5', 0, 3, 9, 319) Your argument is not wrong.
('5', 0, 3, 10, 347) The facilities we have provided him are, generally speaking, too many.
('5', 0, 3, 11, 418) The money is being paid to him not for his proficiency but because of my folly; and because there was no other way of correcting my mistake.
('5', 0, 3, 12, 559) I did allow him to leave; but he pleaded with me that he was not in a position to do any other work, since he could not start work afresh in Johannesburg.
('5', 0, 3, 13, 714) Indubitably, he did wind up the big business he had.
('5', 0, 3, 14, 767) Under these circumstances, I could not bring myself to discharge him.
('5', 0, 3, 15, 837) So the best way I could find was to give him as much in salary as would meet his normal expenses.
('5', 0, 3, 16, 935) However, either of us is free to terminate the arrangement by giving a month’s notice.
('5', 0, 3, 17, 1022) It means that, if the condition of the press gets worse and it does not show any income, I can dispense with his services at a month’s notice.
('5', 0, 3, 18, 1165) Even if the condition improves, there is no stipulation about paying him more than £10, nor is it necessary.
('5', 0, 3, 19, 1274) There is, therefore, no reason to believe that he will always draw the same salary.
('5', 0, 3, 20, 1358) We need not suppose that he and Polak will not be able to pull on together when the latter comes.
('5', 0, 3, 21, 1456) If they cannot, Kitchin will have to leave.
('5', 0, 3, 22, 1500) Polak will take at least two and a half years to go to Phoenix; it is, therefore, unnecessary for the present to think of that far off eventuality.
('5', 0, 3, 23, 1648) I envisage the possibility of a great change in our condition during that period.
('5', 0, 3, 24, 1730) There was no other alternative when we gave Kitchin a house and land.
('5', 0, 3, 25, 1800) His heart is in Phoenix.
('5', 0, 3, 26, 1825) He no doubt likes the life there.
('5', 0, 3, 27, 1859) Please do not hesitate when you have to do something for him.
('5', 0, 3, 28, 1921) We have to take into consideration the virtues of a man; we cannot bother ourselves about his drawbacks.
('5', 0, 3, 29, 2026) We have to be satisfied if, by putting ourselves out, others can be made happy or can benefit.
('5', 0, 3, 30, 2121) There is no difficulty in giving two acres of land to any of you who wants it, that is, yourself, West, Bean or Anandlal.
('5', 0, 3, 31, 2243) I think I have already explained this to you.
('5', 0, 3, 32, 2289) Polak also has asked for two acres.
('5', 0, 3, 33, 2325) This much I believe: if Kitchin stays, his nature will change and he will do his work well.
('5', 0, 3, 34, 2417) If, on the other hand, his nature does not improve, he will give in of his own accord.
('5', 0, 3, 35, 2504) Do ask for further clarification, if
('5', 1, 0, 1, 2541) 2 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 1, 1, 2, 2581) you need it.
('5', 1, 1, 3, 2594) Always write to me unhesitatingly.
('5', 1, 1, 4, 2629) Gokuldas is good by nature; but he has become very selfish and narrow minded because of his upbringing in the country.
('5', 1, 1, 5, 2748) He seems to be prejudiced against you.
('5', 1, 1, 6, 2787) In spite of my repeated attempts to persuade him I find that the idea that “maternal uncle is crazy” is deep rooted in his mind due to the arrogant impetuosity of youth.
('5', 1, 1, 7, 2957) His mind is set more on making money.
('5', 1, 1, 8, 2995) We have to be very careful and see that his leanings become pure.
('5', 1, 1, 9, 3061) You may watch him and guide him.
('5', 1, 1, 10, 3094) I believe he will put in hard work.
('5', 1, 1, 11, 3130) He will not take anything from the press at present; at the same time, he will not work the whole day.
('5', 1, 1, 12, 3233) I have told him that he is still a student and has to behave accordingly.
('5', 1, 1, 13, 3307) He will, therefore, work for some time in the press, some time on the land and the rest he will devote to studies.
('5', 1, 1, 14, 3422) It is necessary for him to have a good knowledge of Gujarati, English and Tamil.

('5', 1, 1, 27, 4045) I still feel that it will be better if you three brothers live together.
('5', 1, 1, 28, 4118) But if there is even the least possibility of bitterness resulting from doing so, you have not to act on my suggestions.
('5', 1, 1, 29, 4239) Gokuldas, of course, will stay with you.
('5', 1, 1, 30, 4280) Is Orchard still there in the house or has he left?
('5', 1, 1, 31, 4332) I have sent the Tamil material, but I find that there will be some difficulty for me in the matter.
('5', 1, 1, 32, 4432) I saw that the man who did the translation has very little knowledge of the language.

('5', 2, 7, 13, 5822) BRITISH INDIANS, TRANSVAAL, TENDER TO HIS GRACIOUS MAJESTY HUMBLE CONGRATULATIONS ON HIS SIXTY FIFTH BIRTHDAY.
('5', 2, 8, 14, 5933) Indian Opinion, 11 11 1905
('5', 2, 9, 15, 5960) 3. LONG LIVE THE KING EMPEROR
('5', 2, 10, 16, 5990) Thursday, the 9th instant, was the sixty fifth birthday of His Majesty the King Emperor.
('5', 2, 10, 17, 6079) Loyal congratulations were offered from all parts of his vast dominions.
('5', 2, 10, 18, 6152) No monarch of modern times has commanded the admiration and love of his subjects as King Edward has.
('5', 2, 10, 19, 6253) When he ascended the throne, his position was a most difficult one, since he had to succeed Victoria the Good; but, during the short space that he has occupied his supreme position, he has carried out the traditions left by that noble lady, and has shown that, even in a country constitutionally governed, the King has many opportunities of serving his subjects, in a way possible only to one who, like His Majesty, combines a real appreciation of the dignity of his exalted station with a more than ordinary ability.
('5', 2, 10, 20, 6771) By his sound judgment and tact, he has materially assisted in promoting the world’s peace, and the prosperity of the British Empire.
('5', 2, 10, 21, 6904) He has endeared himself to his subjects the world over because, being lord of all, he has made himself the servant of all.
('5', 2, 10, 22, 7027) In the whole history of the world, no throne has
('5', 2, 11, 23, 7076) 1 The cable was sent by the Transvaal British Indian Association through the Colonial Secretary.
('5', 3, 0, 1, 7173) 4 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 3, 1, 2, 7213) been so firmly established in the hearts of the people as that of the King Emperor today.
('5', 3, 1, 3, 7303) That he may live long to add lustre to that throne is the earnest prayer of British Indians, the humblest of his subjects but not the least in loyalty and devotion.
('5', 3, 1, 4, 7468) Indian Opinion, 11 11 1905
('5', 3, 2, 5, 7495) 4. AN INDIAN DELEGATION TO ENGLAND
('5', 3, 3, 6, 7530) The general election for the Imperial Parliament is now pending.
('5', 3, 3, 7, 7595) It may come upon us any day.
('5', 3, 3, 8, 7624) Mr. Chamberlain has expressed his opinion that the sooner it comes, the better.
('5', 3, 3, 9, 7704) The most interesting feature to an Indian is the delegation that has gone to England, on behalf of India, to plead the Indian cause before the British electorate.
('5', 3, 3, 10, 7867) Some knowledge about those who compose the delegation and its purpose may not be out of place even for our European readers in South Africa.
('5', 3, 3, 11, 8008) The Honourable Professor Gokhale and Mr. Lajpat Rai 1 are in London as the delegates sent by the National Congress, and towering above the two is Mr. Dadabhai Naoroji, the Grand Old Man of India.
('5', 3, 3, 12, 8204) He is not sent specially, but he is there living a life of self imposed exile, a life of self sacrifice extending over an unbroken period of half a century.
('5', 3, 3, 13, 8361) Of him, Mr. Gokhale has said:
('5', 3, 4, 14, 8391) What a life it has been!
('5', 3, 4, 15, 8416) Its sweet purity, its simplicity, its gentle forbearance, its noble self denial, its abounding love, its strenuous pursuit of high aims— as one contemplates these one feels as though one stood in a high presence.
('5', 3, 4, 16, 8629) Surely there must be hope for a people that could produce such a man, even if, as Mr. Ranade 2 once said, he be only one in three hundred millions.
('5', 3, 4, 17, 8777) Such is the towering personality of Dadabhai, who is always in London to counsel Indian patriots and guide them by his advice.
('5', 3, 4, 18, 8904) In Mr. Gokhale, yet quite young, is centred the hope of India.
('5', 3, 4, 19, 8967) He has won many laurels, and has many more to win.
('5', 3, 4, 20, 9018) Young as he is, he has made for himself a name in the Imperial Legislative Council at Calcutta.
('5', 3, 4, 21, 9114) Even those who differ from him have to acknowledge his patriotism and earnest eloquence.
('5', 3, 4, 22, 9203) He is not to be matched in mastery
('5', 3, 5, 23, 9238) 1 (1865 1928), known as the “Lion of the Punjab”, was deported by the British Government in 1907 and lived for some years in the U.S.A; President of the Congress session at Calcutta in 1920. Sustained injuries at the hands of the police during the boycott of the Simon Commission and succumbed to them.
('5', 3, 5, 24, 9541) 2 Judge of the Bombay High Court and social reformer, whom Gokhale regarded as his teacher.
('5', 4, 0, 1, 9633) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 5
('5', 4, 1, 2, 9678) of figures, and he has sanctified a life of love by a free gift of his services to the Fergusson College at Poona for twenty years.
('5', 4, 1, 3, 9810) Mr. Lajpat Rai, from the Punjab, is no less noble in mind.
('5', 4, 1, 4, 9869) He is the recognised leader of the Punjab.
('5', 4, 1, 5, 9912) He has been devoting his earnings and his energy to the promotion of the work of the Arya Samaj, which has been recently made familiar to our readers.
('5', 4, 1, 6, 10063) 1 Hardly had he finished the self imposed work of relieving the distress in the Kangra District, owing to the terrible earthquake, than, at the call of duty, he left for England.
('5', 4, 1, 7, 10242) As the Honourable Mr. Gokhale could not join him in England in time, he went over to America, and popularized traditions of India to the great American people.
('5', 4, 1, 8, 10402) This is what the Boston Transcript says of him:
('5', 4, 2, 9, 10450) It is not many weeks since Colonel Young husband declared in London that, in all that relates to the spiritual and intellectual life, we Anglo Saxons are to sit as learners at the feet of the Hindus and other Orientals.
('5', 4, 2, 10, 10670) They have for ages cultivated, and still cultivate, as the highest and most important of human interests, that which we leave to an hour or so of quiet once a week in a church.
('5', 4, 2, 11, 10847) The handsome and accomplished young Hindu, Mr. Rai...how magnificent is the beauty and vitality of a high class Hindu...the delegate from the Indian National Congress, who spoke twice here this week, is on his way to England.
('5', 4, 2, 12, 11073) Such leaders, then, are at present in England to plead for India.
('5', 4, 2, 13, 11139) They are there to tell the British electorate that India needs better representation and better service at the hands of the rulers.
('5', 4, 2, 14, 11271) In the words of Mr. Schwann, M. P., the delegates are charged
('5', 4, 3, 15, 11333) with the task of voicing the hopes, the fears, the aspirations, and the desires for reform of the Indian people.
('5', 4, 3, 16, 11446) There was a desire among the Indian people for better education, for a land settlement varying with the varying needs of different parts of India, and for more self government, because the people whom Mr. Gokhale represented thought that many of the Indian people were quite qualified to take part in their own government.
('5', 4, 3, 17, 11769) The delegation and many other things, which are at present happening in India, are unmistakable signs of the times.
('5', 4, 3, 18, 11885) The Colonial statesmen may not misinterpret them or ignore them.
('5', 4, 3, 19, 11950) If they would seek the protection of the British flag, they must count upon India asan integral part of the Empire, and, as such, entitled to every consid eration.
('5', 4, 3, 20, 12114) It will very largely depend upon the spirit that guides British, Colonial and Indian statesmen, whether the Empire is to remain firmly

('5', 5, 2, 4, 12524) 5. IMMIGRATION ACT OF NATAL
('5', 5, 3, 5, 12552) We draw the attention of Mr. Harry Smith, the Principal Immigration Restriction Officer, to a free translation we have given in another column of hardships that Indian passengers are alleged to have had to undergo on board the s.
('5', 5, 3, 6, 12782) Somali.
('5', 5, 3, 7, 12790) If the allegations 1 are at all true, they show a very serious state of affairs.
('5', 5, 3, 8, 12871) The passenger who has made the complaint which is before us has signed it, and he was severely cross examined before we decided to take it and give it publication.
('5', 5, 3, 9, 13035) We are aware that Mr. Harry Smith is just as eager as we are to avoid any unnecessary hardships to the passengers who may be affected by the Immigration Act.
('5', 5, 3, 10, 13193) We, therefore, feel certain that we have only to draw his attention to this complaint to insure a thorough investigation.
('5', 5, 3, 11, 13315) We might mention that this is not the first occasion on which we have received complaints of this nature, but hitherto we have not thought fit to publish them or to do anything more than suggest to the complainants to forward their complaints to the proper quarters; but the facts that have come to us this time have been so well and earnestly put that we consider it to be our duty to draw public attention to them.
('5', 5, 3, 12, 13732) We shall be happy to give an equally prominent publication to anything that the Immigration authorities may have to say either in contradiction, explanation, or justification.
('5', 5, 3, 13, 13908) Indian Opinion, 11 11 1905
('5', 5, 4, 14, 13935) 6. RED TAPE
('5', 5, 5, 15, 13947) The Natal Mercury has rendered a public service in publishing correspondencen which throws a great deal of light on the working of the Immigration Restriction Act.
('5', 5, 5, 16, 14111) It appears that a well educated Indian, Mr. E. Vaz, was, on the 30th September last, on going to see a friend off by one of the German steamers, prevented from going to the steamer.
('5', 5, 5, 17, 14293) The friend also, whom Mr. Vaz was to see off, although he produced his second class ticket, was not allowed to board the steamer.
('5', 5, 5, 18, 14423) Both of them were, it is complained, roughly
('5', 5, 6, 19, 14468) 1 Twenty seven persons who had reached Natal Port on October 25, were detained on board in an ill ventilated hold for three days, most of them without food or water.
('5', 5, 6, 20, 14634) Vide “Treatment of Indians at the Point”, 18 11 1905
('5', 6, 0, 1, 14687) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 7
('5', 6, 1, 2, 14732) handled by the constable on duty.
('5', 6, 1, 3, 14766) Mr. Vaz thereupon wrote to the Superintendent of Water Police, who told him that the constablewas carrying out his instructions.
('5', 6, 1, 4, 14895) He then approached the Colonial Office, and the Colonial Office, too, returned the same stereotyped answer, adding that instructions were from the Immigration Restriction Department.
('5', 6, 1, 5, 15078) Mr. Vaz then applied to the Principal Immigration Restriction Officer, who put the finishing touch by declining to inform Mr. Vaz of the instructions, saying: “I do not feel called upon to answer inquiries from outside as to inter departmental arrangements.” Rough treatment is not denied.
('5', 6, 1, 6, 15368) The action of the constable is throughout upheld, and when the public want to know what regulations there are which they have to obey, they are told it is not their business!
('5', 6, 1, 7, 15543) This is a new method of administration.
('5', 6, 1, 8, 15583) Hitherto, the people who have to obey laws have been acquainted with the nature of such laws, but now the Government has decided that the Immigration Department is to work its regulations in secrecy, and to expect the public, who are affected thereby, to guess what they are likely to be and obey them.
('5', 6, 1, 9, 15886) We mention the Government specially, because Mr. Harry Smith has evidently written under inspiration.
('5', 6, 1, 10, 15988) So far as we know, he has never withheld information from the public.
('5', 6, 1, 11, 16058) What advantage the Government wishes to gain by keeping its precious regulations secret we do not know, but we do know that the action of the constable was undoubtedly illegal, and the attempt made by the Government to bolster up an illegality by withholding information from the complainant is, to say the least of it, highly un British.
('5', 6, 1, 12, 16397) We congratulate our contemporary on having given publicity to what is nothing short of a scandal, and, what is more, for dealing with it strongly in an editorial note.
('5', 6, 1, 13, 16565) Indian Opinion, 11 11 1905
('5', 6, 2, 14, 16592) 7. RUSSIA AND INDIA
('5', 6, 3, 15, 16612) The present unrest in Russia has a great lesson for us.
('5', 6, 3, 16, 16668) The Czar of Russia 1 today wields the most autocratic power in the world.
('5', 6, 3, 17, 16742) The people of Russia suffer numerous hardships.
('5', 6, 3, 18, 16790) The poor are crushed by the weight of taxes; the soldiers put down the people, who have to submit to all the whims of the Czar.
('5', 6, 3, 19, 16918) Intoxicated with power, the officers do not care for the welfare of the people.
('5', 6, 3, 20, 16998) Their only function, they think, is to add to their own power and wealth.
('5', 6, 3, 21, 17072) Entirely against
('5', 6, 4, 22, 17089) 1 Czar Nicholas II, (1868 1918), came to the throne in 1894.
('5', 7, 0, 1, 17150) 8 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 7, 1, 2, 17190) the people’s will, the Czar declared war against Japan, 1 causing a river of blood of Russian soldiers to flow.
('5', 7, 1, 3, 17302) The wealth acquired by the sweat of thousands of labourers was thrown into the sea of Japan.
('5', 7, 1, 4, 17395) The Russian people have suffered all this for years, but they have now reached the limit of their patience.
('5', 7, 1, 5, 17503) They have struggled hard to end this tyranny, but in vain.
('5', 7, 1, 6, 17562) They rose in rebellion and killedthe Czars, but they could not secure justice.
('5', 7, 1, 7, 17641) This time they have found another remedy which, though very simple, is more powerful than rebellion and murder.
('5', 7, 1, 8, 17753) The Russian workers and all the other servants declared a general strike and stopped all work.
('5', 7, 1, 9, 17848) They left their jobs and informed the Czar that, unless justice was done, they would not resume work.
('5', 7, 1, 10, 17950) What was there even the Czar could do against this?
('5', 7, 1, 11, 18002) It was quite impossible to exact work from people by force.
('5', 7, 1, 12, 18062) It is not within the power of even the Czar of Russia to force strikers to return at the point of the bayonet.
('5', 7, 1, 13, 18173) The Czar has therefore proclaimed to the people that they will be granted a share in government and that he will not make any laws without their consent.
('5', 7, 1, 14, 18327) It is difficult to say what the ultimate result of this will be; but even if the Czar does not keep his word, it will not prove that the course adopted by the people was wrong.
('5', 7, 1, 15, 18504) It will only show that the people were not firm enough in applying the remedy.
('5', 7, 1, 16, 18583) For even the most powerful cannot rule without the co operation of the ruled.
('5', 7, 1, 17, 18661) If the Russian people succeed, this revolution 2 in Russia will be regarded as the greatest victory, the greatest event of the present century.
('5', 7, 1, 18, 18805) In the caption to this article we have put Russia and India together.
('5', 7, 1, 19, 18875) We have therefore to justify it by showing how India is concerned with the events in Russia.
('5', 7, 1, 20, 18968) There is much similarity between the governance of India and that of Russia.
('5', 7, 1, 21, 19045) The power of the Viceroy is no way less than that of the Czar.
('5', 7, 1, 22, 19108) Just as the people of Russia pay taxes, so also do we; just as the Russian taxpayer has no control over the use of the money thus raised, so also the Indians have none; as in Russia, so in India, the military is all powerful.
('5', 7, 1, 23, 19334) The only difference is that the power of the state is rather more brusquely exercised in Russia than in India.
('5', 7, 1, 24, 19445) We, too, can resort to the Russian remedy against tyranny.
('5', 7, 1, 25, 19504) The movement in Bengal for the use of swadeshi goods is much like the Russian movement.
('5', 7, 1, 26, 19592) Our shackles will break this very day, if the people of India become united and patient, love their
('5', 7, 2, 27, 19692) 1 The Russo Japanese War was declared in February 1904; the Russians were defeated and peace was signed on September 5, 1905. 2 The revolution of 1905 which Lenin later described as a rehearsal for the 1917 Revolution.
('5', 8, 0, 1, 19911) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 9
('5', 8, 1, 2, 19956) country, and think of the well being of their motherland disregarding their self interest.
('5', 8, 1, 3, 20047) The governance of India is possible only because there exist people who serve.
('5', 8, 1, 4, 20126) We also can show the same strength that the Russian people have done.
('5', 8, 1, 5, 20196) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 11 11 1905
('5', 8, 2, 6, 20239) 8. SIR T. MUTTUSWAMI AIYER, K. C. I. E. Sir T. Muttuswami Aiyar was born in a poor family at Tanjore on January 28, 1832. Having lost his father at a very early age, Muttuswami had to earn his own living.
('5', 8, 2, 7, 20444) He therefore took up the job of a village clerk on one rupee a month.
('5', 8, 2, 8, 20514) This went on till 1846. During this time, a gentleman named Muttuswami Naicker was struckby the boy’s intel ligence and industry.
('5', 8, 2, 9, 20644) Once it happened that Naicker received news of the river embankment near a village having given way.
('5', 8, 2, 10, 20745) He sent for his clerk, but the latter being absent, the boy Muttuswami answered the call.
('5', 8, 2, 11, 20835) Asked by Naicker to make inquiries about the mishap, Muttuswami went round the whole place and brought all the news.
('5', 8, 2, 12, 20952) Mr. Naicker did not quite believe him, but, being in a hurry, he passed on the boy’s report.
('5', 8, 2, 13, 21045) Later, Mr. Naicker was much pleased to know that the facts collected by Muttuswami were quite accurate.
('5', 8, 2, 14, 21149) Not being satisfied with the kind of life he was leading, Muttuswami resolved to rise higher and started going to school whenever he could find the time.
('5', 8, 2, 15, 21303) Mr. Naicker, who noticed this, kept him for 18 months in a Mission school at Negapatam, and then sent him to a High School in Madras.
('5', 8, 2, 16, 21437) He also gave him a letter of recommendation to Raja Sir T. Madhav Rao.

('5', 13, 3, 13, 32510) The Elphinstones are a well known family in Scotland.
('5', 13, 3, 14, 32564) Towards the end of the eighteenth century, a scion of this family, Mountstuart Elphinstone, landed at Calcutta as an employee of the East India Company, at the early age of sixteen.
('5', 13, 3, 15, 32746) Political distur bances were frequent in India.
('5', 13, 3, 16, 32794) The country was in the grip of one such in 1796. Vazir Ali, the deposed Nawab of Ayodhya, was under surveillance at Benares.

('5', 13, 3, 19, 33035) Elphinstone, who was there at the time, also bravely defended himself.
('5', 13, 3, 20, 33106) In 1800, there was trouble near Poona, and Elphinstone was posted there.
('5', 13, 3, 21, 33179) By this time, he had acquired a good knowledge of languages, and had pleased General Wellesley 2 by his valour in war.

('5', 13, 3, 23, 33378) In 1809, Elphinstone was deputed to the court of the Amir of Kabul.

('5', 15, 5, 18, 37915) 17. THE POLL TAX
('5', 15, 6, 19, 37932) It would be unwise for us to give publicity to the complaints that have come to us from hundreds of Indians in connection with the imposition of the poll tax.
('5', 15, 6, 20, 38091) Personally, we consider that every good citizen should share the troubles that the Colony is passing through, and one of the best and most practical methods of doing so is to contribute specially to the Colonial revenue.
('5', 15, 6, 21, 38312) The Government has seen fit to pass the poll tax measure, and everyone, no matter to what community he belongs, should bow to it and pay the toll with what cheerfulness he can.
('5', 15, 6, 22, 38489) It is not a matter for mathematical calculation and of considering the question of poor people having to
('5', 15, 7, 23, 38594) 1 Sir Arthur Lawley was appointed Governor of Madras on November 24, 1905.
('5', 16, 0, 1, 38669) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 17
('5', 16, 1, 2, 38715) pay the same as the rich man.
('5', 16, 1, 3, 38745) A poll tax has always been an unpo pular measure and, in its incidence, it falls very heavily upon the poorest members of the community.
('5', 16, 1, 4, 38882) It is by no means a new thing or a new experience in South Africa, but was an annual contribution exacted in the Transvaal, though not very rigorously, even when the country was at the height of its prosperity.
('5', 16, 1, 5, 39093) In a time of depression such as the present, when work is scarce and ready money scarcer, it is no small thing for a poor working man with a wife and family to give even a single sovereign in one lump sum.
('5', 16, 1, 6, 39299) It is obviously the poorer classes only that feel the burden of a poll tax.
('5', 16, 1, 7, 39375) There are thousands of Indians to whom the sum of one pound is no small matter.
('5', 16, 1, 8, 39455) Take, for instance, the case of those who have just become free from indenture, and have chosen to settle in the Colony.
('5', 16, 1, 9, 39576) As the price for permission to remain in the Colony, they, including their children, have to pay an annual tax of £3 each, and they would now be called upon to pay an additional £1. On the face of it, therefore, to exact contribution from such men would be highly unjust.
('5', 16, 1, 10, 39848) The position of many small Indian farmers would be almost the same.
('5', 16, 1, 11, 39916) They have to toil hard and long for their daily bread.
('5', 16, 1, 12, 39971) To dignify them by the name farmers is, in fact, totally wrong, for, as a matter of fact, they are labourers pure and simple.
('5', 16, 1, 13, 40097) It has often [been] argued that the Indian does not contribute sufficient[ly] to the revenue of the Colony.
('5', 16, 1, 14, 40205) Those who have said so have advanced the argument in a thoughtless manner.
('5', 16, 1, 15, 40280) No country in the world taxes labour, for labour itself is a contribution of the very best kind.
('5', 16, 1, 16, 40377) It is upon labour that the prosperity of a country depends.
('5', 16, 1, 17, 40437) There is no doubt that the poll tax is calculated mostly to affect the natives of the soil and Indians.
('5', 16, 1, 18, 40541) Our Transvaal contemporaries have seen the point without any difficulty.
('5', 16, 1, 19, 40614) The Europeans have been brought in order to give the measure an appearance of being general legislation, but we have no desire to look at it from that point of view.
('5', 16, 1, 20, 40780) The measure has been passed, and though we cannot congratulate the Government upon it any more than it can congratulate itself, we all have to bow to the decision.
('5', 16, 1, 21, 40944) At the same time, we commend to the earnest attention of the authorities and the public generally the special article on the poll tax published in this issue.
('5', 16, 2, 22, 41103) But whatever may have been the intentions of the legislators, it is not for us to complain, though, in our opinion, this conception of the measure, as also the facts we have shown above, prove unmistakably that the Government will have to use a large amount of discretion in excusing from payment those who really cannot afford to pay.
('5', 16, 3, 23, 41439) 1 Not reproduced here
('5', 17, 0, 1, 41461) 18 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 17, 1, 2, 41502) that reason, it is very necessary that the rules already published for collecting the tax should be revised, and the collectors given the authority, at their discretion, to excuse the poorest in the community from payment.
('5', 17, 1, 3, 41725) The collecting of such a tax is, undoubtedly, a matter of mutual understanding between the Government and the communities affected thereby; otherwise, as one of the expressive Native speakers said at the meeting recently held by the Chief Magistrate,“The Government will have to line the roads of the Colony with gaols for the accommodation of the defaulters.” Indian Opinion, 25 11 1905
('5', 17, 2, 4, 42113) 18. MR. HARRY SMITH AND INDIANS
('5', 17, 3, 5, 42145) We published last week a letter from the Immigration Restriction Officer in reply to our editorial note 1 on the alleged ill treatment of Indian passengers on board the Somali.
('5', 17, 3, 6, 42322) We are thankful to Mr. Smith for having given a prompt reply, but we must confess that it is disappointing.
('5', 17, 3, 7, 42430) Evidently, the facts stated by our correspondent, and supported by another correspondent, are, in the main, true.
('5', 17, 3, 8, 42544) Mr. Smith has divided our correspondent’s compl aints under six heads, three of which relate to arrangements on board the steamer, for which Mr. Smith refuses to accept any responsibility whatsoever, saying that it is the shipping company that is res ponsible as carriers.
('5', 17, 3, 9, 42817) Technically, Mr. Smith is, no doubt, right, but as the Principal Officer responsible for the proper conduct of all who are affected by the Immigration Restriction Act, we venture to think that it is not possible for him thus to slur over what are, undoubtedly, hardships arising out of the enforcement of the Act.
('5', 17, 3, 10, 43131) Indeed, if the argument advanced by Mr. Smith were to hold good, he might disclaim liability with reference to treatment under the other heads also, for he is certainly not required, according to the letter of the law, to see that the passengers, who may be cooped up by the steamship company in the hold, get proper food or are allowed to communicate with those on shore, because communications with the ship will be controlled by the shipowners; but, Mr. Smith has not seen fit to take up such an untenable position.
('5', 17, 3, 11, 43650) The complaint has to be taken as a whole and treated as such, and, again it has to be treated, not in a cold blooded manner, but in the humane, sympathetic spirit which we have almost invariably found in Mr. Smith.
('5', 17, 3, 12, 43865) The letter, therefore, has come to us as a shock.
('5', 17, 3, 13, 43915) We miss therein the humanity of
('5', 17, 4, 14, 43947) 1 Vide “Immigration Act of Natal”, 11 11 1905
('5', 18, 0, 1, 43993) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 19
('5', 18, 1, 2, 44039) the man, and find the cold bloodedness of a calculating head of a department, which is not to be ruffled by any amount of human suffering.
('5', 18, 1, 3, 44178) Law or no law, we claim from an official of Mr. Harry Smith’s temperament a large measure of liberal treatment.
('5', 18, 1, 4, 44290) Assuming, then, that the truth of the complaint is borne out, is it not possible for the Immigration Department to come to an understanding with the shipping companies (and such things have been done before now, in spite of their being unnecessary, according to the strict letter of law), whereby the inconvenience can be mitigated, if not entirely removed?
('5', 18, 1, 5, 44648) After all, the passengers placed in the hold were mere suspects, many of them probably had the right to land in the Colony.
('5', 18, 1, 6, 44772) Many of themhad the right to receive a safe passage through the Colony, and the Immigration Department was, therefore, intimately connected with their proper treatment whilst their cases awaited examination.
('5', 18, 1, 7, 44980) There would have been nothing extraordinary if the passengers had been kept under surveillance in a different manner.
('5', 18, 1, 8, 45098) Why, again, were they refused visiting passes on their asking, and had [they] to get the intervention of a lawyer?
('5', 18, 1, 9, 45213) A merciful working of the law, we are free to admit, may entail a little more expense, exercise of extra patience and waste of valuable time, but we think that all this expenditure will be small, compared to the comfort which would thereby be secured for the passengers.
('5', 18, 1, 10, 45484) There is also a question raised, as a side issue, in Mr. Smith’s letter, which requires prompt attention.
('5', 18, 1, 11, 45590) There are evidently some departmental instructions given to the under officials, of which the public have no knowledge.
('5', 18, 1, 12, 45710) It would tend to a smooth working of the law, if the public were acquainted with these instructions, seeing that they are intimately related to them.
('5', 18, 1, 13, 45860) With reference to the last paragraph of Mr. Smith’s letter, that the Immigration and Police Officers are as much amenable to law as anyone else, it is obvious that the average poor Indian immigrant can scarcely be expected to take these cases to court.
('5', 18, 1, 14, 46113) The point is that it should be some one’s duty to protect them against insult or unfair treatment.
('5', 18, 1, 15, 46212) The sensitiveness of many Indians [is] affected by the Act we admit, but we are not surprised at it.
('5', 18, 1, 16, 46313) That it sometimes unconsci ously leads them into a kind of exaggeration is also probably true, but men placed in the same position that the Indians are in South Africa, have been known to go much further than the Indians have ever done or are likely to do.
('5', 18, 1, 17, 46570) An officer who has continuously to discharge an irksome duty of restraining natural liberty is likely, by habit, to attribute as a vice that which is merely a most natural result of the working of the human mind under galling restraints, and it is as well even for the most discerning men to bear this in mind, if even a fair
('5', 19, 0, 1, 46896) 20 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 19, 1, 2, 46937) measure of justice is to be given to a people placed in the peculiar condition in which the Indians are.

('5', 19, 2, 4, 47069) 19. BADRUDDIN TYABJI 1
('5', 19, 3, 5, 47092) Badruddin Tyabji’s is a famous name throughout India, particularly in the Bombay Presidency where he is known to all.
('5', 19, 3, 6, 47210) He revealed his ability at a very early age and was a very good student at school.
('5', 19, 3, 7, 47293) His career as a student was so bright that his elders decided to send him to England.
('5', 19, 3, 8, 47379) Sir Pherozeshah and Badruddin were of the same age and were contemporaries at school.
('5', 19, 3, 9, 47465) Mr. Badruddin was perhaps the first Indian from the Bombay Presidency to go to England.
('5', 19, 3, 10, 47553) He excelled in studies, won many laurels in England and then returned to Bombay.
('5', 19, 3, 11, 47634) He earned a great reputation as an able barrister and was always compared to great English barristers.
('5', 19, 3, 12, 47737) He successfully fought cases in which he had to confront the famous barristers Enstey and Inverarity.
('5', 19, 3, 13, 47839) During the period of his practice at the Bar, there was hardly a big case in which he was not engaged by one or the other party.
('5', 19, 3, 14, 47968) With his power of oratory and legal acumen, he pleased the judges and won over the members of the jury.
('5', 19, 3, 15, 48072) He went many times to Kathiawar to fight big State cases, most of which he won.
('5', 19, 3, 16, 48152) His greatest case was perhaps the defence of Nawabzada Nasuralla Khan.
('5', 19, 3, 17, 48223) The Collector of Surat, Mr. Lely, had charged the Nawabzada with having offered him a bribe of Rs. 10,000. Mr. Lely gave very strong evidence in the case.
('5', 19, 3, 18, 48378) Mr. Slater, the Chief Presidency Magistrate of Bombay, gave a harsh judgement, sentencing the Nawabzada to six months’ imprisonment.
('5', 19, 3, 19, 48511) Mr. Badruddin, who was engaged in the appeal against this judgement, argued the law points so ably that Justice Parson quashed the sentence pronounced on the Nawabzada by the lower court and passed severe strictures against Mr. Lely.
('5', 19, 3, 20, 48745) Mr. Badruddin had, no doubt, won many cases before, but his fame spread all the more with this victory, which saved a member of a noble family from confinement and disgrace.
('5', 19, 3, 21, 48919) Some time later the Government of Bombay offered Mr. Badruddin a seat on the High Court Bench, which he accepted.
('5', 19, 3, 22, 49033) Though the judges’ monthly salary was Rs. 3,750, Justice Badruddin was certainly a loser.
('5', 19, 3, 23, 49123) His income from legal practice was, it is said, about Rs. 100,000 a year.
('5', 19, 3, 24, 49197) His work as a judge is considered to be of a very high order.
('5', 19, 3, 25, 49259) His judgments show independence of mind and give satisfaction to all the
('5', 19, 4, 26, 49332) 1 (1844 1906)
('5', 20, 0, 1, 49346) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 21
('5', 20, 1, 2, 49392) lawyers as well as the parties.
('5', 20, 1, 3, 49424) Just as Justice Tyabji has earned a name in scholarship and the legal profession, so has he won fame in public life too.
('5', 20, 1, 4, 49545) He has done much for the spread of education in India, particularly among Muslims.
('5', 20, 1, 5, 49628) He always encourages the education of women.
('5', 20, 1, 6, 49673) His wife and daughters are all well educated.
('5', 20, 1, 7, 49719) He has taken an active part in the politics of the country and has done much work in collaboration with Justice Ranade.
('5', 20, 1, 8, 49839) He was a prominent worker of the Indian National Congress, and has also presided over it.

('5', 20, 2, 16, 50334) 20. DEPUTATION 2 TO LORD SELBORNE
('5', 20, 3, 17, 50368) Before presenting a statement on the position of British Indians in the Transvaal, Gandhiji addressed His Excellency as follows: [JOHANNESBURG,] November, 29, 1905 Before beginning to deal with the subject matter of this deputation, I have to tender our respectful thanks to Your Excellency for having spared the time amidst the many calls upon it to receive this deputation.
('5', 20, 3, 18, 50744) As Your Excellency has personally interested yourself in every question submitted to you, it was felt that we should, instead of simply sending memorials, seek the opportunity of expressing our sentiments and feelings in a more tangible manner.
('5', 20, 3, 19, 50989) Before I deal with the statement I am to hand to Your Excellency, I have been asked to mention two matters that have occurred during your recent tour through the Transvaal.
('5', 20, 3, 20, 51162) Your Excellency is reported to have said at Potchefstroom that “no non refugee British Indians would be allowed to enter the Colony
('5', 20, 4, 21, 51294) 1 In 1887, at Madras 2 The deputation, which was led by Gandhiji, consisted of Messrs Abdul Gani, Chair man, British Indian Association; Haji Habib, Secretary, Pretoria Committee; E. S. Coovadia, Moonsamy Moonlight and Ayob Haji Beg Mahomed.
('5', 20, 4, 22, 51536) It waited on Lord Selborne at 3 p.m.
('5', 20, 4, 23, 51573) on November 29, 1905.
('5', 21, 0, 1, 51595) 22 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 21, 1, 2, 51636) until the Representative Assembly has considered the question next year”.
('5', 21, 1, 3, 51710) If the report is correct, it would, as I hope to show this afternoon, be a very grave injustice to the vested rights of the Indian community.
('5', 21, 1, 4, 51852) At Ermelo, Your Excellency is reported to have used the expression “coolie store keepers”.
('5', 21, 1, 5, 51943) This expression has given very great offence to the British Indians in the Colony, but the British Indian Association has assured them that the expression has probably not been used by Your Excellency, or, if it has, Your Excellency is incapable of giving thereby any intentional offence to British Indian store keepers.
('5', 21, 1, 6, 52264) The use of the word “coolie” has caused a great deal of mischief in Natal.
('5', 21, 1, 7, 52339) At one time, it became so serious that the then Justice Sir Walter Wragg had to intervene, and to put down the use of that expression in connection with any but indentured Indians, it having been even imported into the Court of Justice.
('5', 21, 1, 8, 52576) As Your Excellency may be aware, it means “labourer” or “porter”.
('5', 21, 1, 9, 52642) Used, therefore, in connection with traders, it is not only offensive, but a contradiction in terms.
('5', 21, 2, 10, 52743) THE PEACE PRESERVATION ORDINANCE
('5', 21, 3, 11, 52776) Coming to the statement that the British Indian Association is submitting to Your Excellency, I would take first the Peace Preservation Ordinance.
('5', 21, 3, 12, 52923) Soon after the Transvaal became part of the British Dominions, the services rendered during the war by the dhooly bearers that came with Sir George White, and those renderedby the Indian Ambulance Corps in Natal, were on many people’s lips.
('5', 21, 3, 13, 53164) Sir George White spoke in glowing terms of the heroism of Prabhu Singh who, perched up in a tree, never once failed to ring the gong as a notice to the inhabitants each time the Boer gun was fired from the Umbulwana Hill.
('5', 21, 3, 14, 53386) General Buller’s despatches, 1 praising the work of the Corps, were just out, and the administration was in the hands of the military officers who knew the Indians.
('5', 21, 3, 15, 53551) The first batch of refugees, therefore, who were waiting at the ports, entered the country without any difficulty, but the civilian population became alarmed, and called for the restriction of the entry of even the refugees.
('5', 21, 3, 16, 53776) The result was that the country was dotted with Asiatic offices, and from that time up to today, the Indian community has known no rest; whereas aliens, in every sense of the term, as a rule got their permits at the ports on application there and then, the Indian, even though a refugee, had to write to the supervisors of Asiatics, who
('5', 21, 4, 17, 54113) 1 According to Sir Redveers Henry Buller, after the British repulse at Spion Kop, during the Boer War, the Indian Ambulance Corps volunteers had worked within the firing line, though not bound to take the risk.
('5', 21, 4, 18, 54324) Vide Vol. III, pp.
('5', 22, 0, 1, 54343) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 23
('5', 22, 1, 2, 54389) had to refer the applications to the Colonial Office before permits were issued.
('5', 22, 1, 3, 54470) The process took a very long time, from two to six months, and even one year and more, and then, too, the Colonial Office had laid down a rule that only so many permits should be issued to British Indian refugees per week.
('5', 22, 1, 4, 54693) The result of this mode of operation was that corruption became rampant, and there grew up a gang of permit agents who simply fleeced innocent refugees; and it was a matter of notoriety that each refugee who wanted to enter the Transvaal had to spend from £15 to £30 and more.
('5', 22, 1, 5, 54970) The matter came to the notice of the British Indian Association, repeated representa tions were made, and ultimately the Asiatic offices were wiped out.
('5', 22, 1, 6, 55123) The mode of granting permits was, however, unfortunately still kept up, and the Chief Secretary for Permits has been always subject to instructions from the Colonial Office.
('5', 22, 1, 7, 55297) Thus, the Peace Preservation Ordinance, which was intended to apply to dangerous characters and political offenders, under the influence of the Colonial Office, had become an Indian Immigration Restriction law, as it remains to this day.
('5', 22, 1, 8, 55535) Under the present regime, too, therefore, it is a most difficult matter for even bona fide refugees to get permits and it is only in rare cases that it is possible to get them, except after a delay of months.
('5', 22, 1, 9, 55744) Everyone, no matter what his status may be, has to make an application on a special form, give two references, and put his thumb impression upon the form.
('5', 22, 1, 10, 55899) The matter is then investigated, and the permit is granted.
('5', 22, 1, 11, 55959) As if this were not enough, owing to the charges made by Mr. Loveday and his friends, the Chief Secretary for Permits received instructions to insist on European references.
('5', 22, 1, 12, 56133) This was tantamount to the denial of the right of British Indian refugees to enter the country.
('5', 22, 1, 13, 56229) It would be hard to find twenty Indians who would be known to respectable Europeans by name as well as appearance.
('5', 22, 1, 14, 56344) The British Indian Association had to correspond with the Government and, in the meantime, the issue of permits was suspended, and it has been only lately realised that the insisting upon European references was a serious injustice.
('5', 22, 2, 15, 56577) THE ENTRY OF CHILDREN
('5', 22, 3, 16, 56599) But still the difficulties, apart from the necessity for European references, are there.
('5', 22, 3, 17, 56688) Male children, under 16 years of age, are now called upon to take out permits before they can enter the Colony, so that it has been not an uncommon experience for little children of 10 years of age and under to be torn away from their parents at the border towns.
('5', 22, 3, 18, 56952) Why such a rule has been imposed we fail to understand.
('5', 22, 3, 19, 57008) THE HIGH
('5', 22, 4, 20, 57017) COMMISSIONER: Have you ever known a case where the parents have stated beforehand that they have children and which children have been refused permission to come in ?
('5', 23, 0, 1, 57184) 24 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 23, 1, 2, 57225) MR. GANDHI: Yes; and the parents have been obliged to make affidavits before the children have been allowed to come in.
('5', 23, 1, 3, 57345) If the parents have the right to enter, so far as I am aware, every civilised country has admitted the right of minor children also to enter with them and, in any case, children under 16 years, if they cannot prove that their parents are dead or that their parents have been resident in the Transvaal before the war, are not allowed to enter or remain in the Colony.
('5', 23, 1, 4, 57712) This is a very serious matter.
('5', 23, 1, 5, 57743) As Your Excellency is aware, the “joint family” system prevails all over India.
('5', 23, 1, 6, 57823) Brothers and sisters and their children live under the same roof from generation to generation, and the eldest member in the family is nominally, as well as in reality, the supporter and the bread earner.
('5', 23, 1, 7, 58028) There is, therefore, nothing unusual in Indians bringing the children of their relatives into the country, and it is submitted that it will be a very serious injustice if such children, who have hitherto been left unmolested, are either deported from the Colony or are prevented from entering the Colony.
('5', 23, 1, 8, 58333) The Government, again, intend to require the female relatives of resident Indians also to be registered in the same manner as the males.
('5', 23, 1, 9, 58470) The British Indian Association has sent an emphatic protest against any such measure, and has even submitted that it would be prepared to fight the question in a court of law, as, according to the advice given to it, wives of resident Indians are not required to take out registration certificates and pay £3.
('5', 23, 2, 10, 58780) THE ENTRY OF SPECIAL CLERKS, ETC.
('5', 23, 3, 11, 58814) No new permits are granted by the Government, no matter how necessary it may be in certain cases.
('5', 23, 3, 12, 58912) We were all extremely pleased to read in the papers Your Excellency’s emphatic declaration that the vested interests of the Indians who are already settled in the country should not be disturbed or touched.
('5', 23, 3, 13, 59119) There are merchants who have constantly to draw upon India for confidential clerks, in order to enable them to carry on their business.
('5', 23, 3, 14, 59255) It is not easy to pick out reliable men from the resident population.
('5', 23, 3, 15, 59325) That is the experience of merchants all over, and belonging to all communities.
('5', 23, 3, 16, 59405) If, therefore, new Indians are absolutely shut out of the country until the establi shment of Representative Government, it will seriously interfere with these vested interests; and, in any case, it is difficult to see why men of attainments and education, whether they be refugees or not, should not be able to have their permits on application.
('5', 23, 3, 17, 59752) And in spite of all these hardships, our anti Indian friends are never tired of saying the country is flooded with British Indians who were never in the Transvaal.
('5', 23, 3, 18, 59916) They have made a point of saying that every Indian who was before in the country was registered.
('5', 23, 3, 19, 60013) I hardly think it is necessary
('5', 24, 0, 1, 60044) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 25
('5', 24, 1, 2, 60090) for me to dilate upon this matter, as Your Excellency has been told that all the facts with reference to this charge are wrong, but I may be pardoned for referring Your Excellency to a case that happened in 1893. Shire and Dumat were large contractors of labour.
('5', 24, 1, 3, 60353) They brought into the country at one time 800 Indian labourers.
('5', 24, 1, 4, 60417) How many more they brought I do not know.
('5', 24, 1, 5, 60459) The then State Attorney insisted that they should take out registration certificates and pay £3 each.
('5', 24, 1, 6, 60561) Shire and Dumat tested the matter in the High Court, and the then Chief Justice Kotze held that these men were not, in terms of the law, called upon to pay £3, as they did not enter for “purposes of trade”, and that he could not help the Government, even if the men, after the contract was over, subsequently remained in the country.
('5', 24, 1, 7, 60895) That is only one instance, which cannot be gainsaid, in which hundreds of Indians remained in the country without paying £3 each.
('5', 24, 1, 8, 61025) The British Indian Association has always submitted, and that from personal experience, that hundreds of Indians, who did not take out trade licences, remained in the country without ever registering themselves and paying £3.
('5', 24, 2, 9, 61251) BAZAARS AND LOCATIONS
('5', 24, 3, 10, 61273) Coming to Law 3 of 1885, it has been often urged that Indians, after the establishment of British government in this country, have received relief with reference to trade licences.
('5', 24, 3, 11, 61454) Nothing, however, can be further from the truth.
('5', 24, 3, 12, 61503) Before the war, we were able to trade anywhere we liked, as against tender of payment of licence money.
('5', 24, 3, 13, 61607) The long arm of the British Government was then strong enough to protect us, and up to the very eve of the war, in spite of the constant threats of the then Government to prosecute British Indians who were trading, no action was taken; It is true that now, owing to the decision of the Supreme Court, Indian trade is unfettered, but that is in spite of the Government.
('5', 24, 3, 14, 61976) Up to the very last moment the Government declined to come to the rescue, and a notice was published called the “Bazaars Notice” which stated that, after a certain date, every Indian, who did not hold a licence to trade at the outbreak of war outside Locations, would be expected not only to remove to Locations, but to trade there also.
('5', 24, 3, 15, 62314) After the notice was published, Locations were established in almost every town, and when every effort to get justice at the hands of the Government was exhausted, as a last resort, it was decided to test the matter in a court of law.
('5', 24, 3, 16, 62549) The whole of the Government machinery was then set in motion against us.
('5', 24, 3, 17, 62622) Before the war a similar case was fought, and the British Government aided the Indians to seek an interpretation of the law, which we have now received from the present Supreme Court.
('5', 24, 3, 18, 62806) After the establishment of the British Government, all
('5', 25, 0, 1, 62861) 26 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 25, 1, 2, 62902) these forces were against us.
('5', 25, 1, 3, 62932) It is a cruel irony of fate, and there is no use disguising the fact that we have felt it most keenly; and this, I may state, as has now transpired, in spite of the fact that the then Attorney General told the Government that the interpretation they sought to place upon the law was bad, that if it went to the Supreme Court the matter would be decided in favour of British Indians.
('5', 25, 1, 4, 63315) If, therefore, British Indians have not been sent to Locations and are free to trade anywhere they like and to live where they like—as I say, it is because it is notwith standing the intentions of the Government to the contrary.
('5', 25, 1, 5, 63544) 1 In every instance, Law 3 of 1885 has been, so far as the Indians are concerned, most strictly interpreted against us, and we have not been allowed advantage of any loop holes that are left in it in our favour.
('5', 25, 1, 6, 63756) For instance, British Indians are not debarred from owning landed property in “streets, wards, or locations that may be set apart” by the Government.
('5', 25, 1, 7, 63906) The Government have resolutely declined to consider the words “streets and wards” and have simply clung to the word Locations; and these Locations, too, have been established miles away.
('5', 25, 1, 8, 64093) We have pleaded hard saying that the Government have the power to give us the right to ownership of land in streets and wards, that they should make use of that power in our favour, but the plea has been in vain.
('5', 25, 1, 9, 64306) Even land which is being used for religious purposes, the Government would not transfer in the names of the Trustees, as in Johannesburg, Heidelberg, Pretoria and Potchefstroom, although the Mosque premises are good in every respect from a sanitary standpoint.
('5', 25, 1, 10, 64567) It is time, we therefore submit, that some relief was granted to us while new legislation is under consideration.
('5', 25, 2, 11, 64681) CLASS LEGISLATION
('5', 25, 3, 12, 64699) As to the new legislation to replace Law 3 of 1885, the dispatch drawn by Sir Arthur Lawley has caused us a very great deal of pain.
('5', 25, 3, 13, 64832) It insists on legislation affecting British Indians or Asia tics, as such.
('5', 25, 3, 14, 64907) It also insists on the principle of compulsory segreg ation, both of which are in conflict with the repeated assurances given to British Indians.
('5', 25, 3, 15, 65053) Sir Arthur Lawley, I wish to say with the greatest deference, has allowed himself to be led astray by what he saw in Natal.
('5', 25, 3, 16, 65177) Natal has been held up as an example of what the Transvaal would be, but the responsible politicians in Natal have always admitted that Indians have been the saving of the Colony.
('5', 25, 3, 17, 65357) Sir James Hulett 2 stated before the Native Affairs Commission that the
('5', 25, 4, 18, 65429) 1 This should perhaps read: ‘I say it is not because of, it is notwithstanding, the in tensions of the Government to the contrary.’ 2 Vide “Sir J.L. Hulett and Indian Traders”, 24 9 1903
('5', 26, 0, 1, 65616) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 27
('5', 26, 1, 2, 65662) Indian, even as a trader, was a desirable citizen, and formed abetter link between the white wholesale merchant and the Native.
('5', 26, 1, 3, 65790) Sir Arthur Lawley had also stated that, even if promises were made to British Indians, they were made in ignorance of the facts as they now are and, therefore, it would be a greater duty to break them than to carry them out.
('5', 26, 1, 4, 66015) With the greatest deference, I venture to submit that this is a wrong view to take of the promises.
('5', 26, 1, 5, 66115) We are not dealing with promises that were made fifty years ago, though we undoubtedly rely upon the Proclamation of 1858 as our “Magna Charta”.
('5', 26, 1, 6, 66260) That Proclamation has been re affirmed more than once.
('5', 26, 1, 7, 66315) Viceroy after Viceroy has stated emphatically that it was a promise [to be?] acted upon.
('5', 26, 1, 8, 66404) At the conference of the Colonial Premiers, Mr. Chamberlain laid down the same doctrine and told the Premiers that no legislation affecting British Indians as such would be countenanced by Her late Majesty’s Government, that it would be putting an affront quite unnecessarily on millions of the loyal subjects of the Crown, and that, therefore, the legislation that was passed could only be of a general character.
('5', 26, 1, 9, 66819) It was for that reason that the first Immigration Restriction Act of Australia was vetoed.
('5', 26, 1, 10, 66910) It was for the same reason that the first Natal Franchise Act was vetoed, and it was for the same reason that the Colony of Natal, after submitting a draft Bill applicable to Asiatics as such, had to draft another measure.
('5', 26, 1, 11, 67133) These are matters not of years gone by but of recent years.
('5', 26, 1, 12, 67193) It cannot be said that there are today any new facts that have come to light to change all this.
('5', 26, 1, 13, 67290) Indeed, even immediately before the war, declarations were made by ministers that one of the reasons [for the war] was to protect the rights of British Indians.
('5', 26, 1, 14, 67451) Last, but not least, Your Excellency, too, gave expression to similar sentiments on the eve of the war.
('5', 26, 1, 15, 67555) Though, therefore, the manner in which Sir Arthur Lawley has approached the question is, in our humble opinion, very unjust and inconsistent with the British traditions, we, in order to show that we wish to co operate with the white Colonists, have submitted that, even though no such law existed before, there may now be an Immigration Act after the basis of the Cape or Natal, except that, as to the educational test, the great Indian languages should be recognised and that the already established British Indian merchants should have facilities afforded to them for importing temporarily men whom they may require in their businesses.
('5', 26, 1, 16, 68194) That will at once do away with the fear of what has been termed an Asiatic invasion.
('5', 26, 1, 17, 68279) We have also submitted that with reference to trade licences which have caused so much grumbling, the power should be given to the Local Boards or Town Councils to regulate the issue of any new licences subject to the control of the Supreme Court.
('5', 26, 1, 18, 68527) All the existing licences should be taken out of the operation of any such statute, because they represent
('5', 27, 0, 1, 68634) 28 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 27, 1, 2, 68675) vested interests.
('5', 27, 1, 3, 68693) We feel that, if these two measures were passed and Law 3 of 1885 were repealed, some measure, and only some measure, of justice would be done to Indians.
('5', 27, 1, 4, 68848) We submit that we ought to have perfect freedom of owning landed property and of living where we like under the general municipal regulations as to sanitation and appearance of buildings, and,during the time that the legislation is being formed, the Peace Preservation Ordinance should be regulated in accordance with the spirit of such regulation and liberal interpretation should be placed upon Law 3 of 1885. It seems to me to be foreign to the nature of the British Constitution as I have been taught from my childhood, and it is difficult for my countrymen to understand that, under the British flag which protects aliens, its own subjects should be debarred from holding a foot of landed property so long as good use is made of it.
('5', 27, 1, 5, 69586) Under the conditions, therefore, submitted by the Association, it ought to be possible for the Government to free the Statute book of the Colony from legislation that, necessarily, insults British Indians.
('5', 27, 1, 6, 69792) I do not wish to touch on such questions as foot path regulations when we have to consider the question of bread and butter and life and death.
('5', 27, 1, 7, 69936) What we want is not political power; but we do wish to live side by side with other British subjects in peace and amity and with dignity and self respect.
('5', 27, 1, 8, 70091) We, therefore, feel that the moment His Majesty’s Government decide to pass legislation differentiating between class and class, there would be an end to that freedom which we have learned to cherish as a priceless heritage of living under the British Crown.
('5', 27, 2, 9, 70350) THE STATEMENT 1
('5', 27, 3, 10, 70366) There are, besides laws affecting Coloured people and, therefore, British Indians, the Peace Preservation Ordinance and Law 3 of 1885 as amended in 1886. The Peace Preservation Ordinance, as its name implies, although framed to keep out of the Colony dangerous characters, is being used mainly to prevent British Indians from entering the Transvaal.
('5', 27, 3, 11, 70716) The working of the law has always been harsh and oppressive— and this in spite of the desire of the Chief Secretary for Permits that it should not be so.
('5', 27, 3, 12, 70870) He has to receive instructions from the Colonial Office, so that the harsh working is due, not to the chief officer in charge of the Department, but to the system under which it is being worked.
('5', 27, 3, 13, 71065) (a) There are still hundreds of refugees waiting to come.
('5', 27, 4, 14, 71123) 1 This was published in the Indian Opinion of December 2, 1905, while the foregoing, the address by Gandhiji, appeared on December 9.
('5', 28, 0, 1, 71257) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 29
('5', 28, 1, 2, 71303) (b) Boys, with their parents or without, are required to take out permits.
('5', 28, 1, 3, 71378) (c) Men with old £ 3 registrations, coming into the country without permits, are, though refugees, being sent away and required to make formal application.
('5', 28, 1, 4, 71534) (d) Even wives of Transvaal residents are expected to take out permits if they are alone, and to pay £ 3 registration, whether with or without their husbands.
('5', 28, 1, 5, 71693) (Correspondence is now going on between the Government and the British Indian Association on the point.)
('5', 28, 2, 6, 71798) (e) Children under 16, if it cannot be proved that their parents are dead, or are residents of the Transvaal, are being sent away, or are refused permits, in spite of the fact that they may be supported by their relatives who are their guardians, and who are residing in the Transvaal.
('5', 28, 3, 7, 72084) (f) No non refugee British Indians are allowed to enter the Colony, no matter what their station may be in life.
('5', 28, 3, 8, 72197) (The last prohibition causes serious inconvenience to the established merchants, who, by reason thereof, are prevented from drawing upon India for confidential managers or clerks.)
('5', 28, 4, 9, 72378) LAW 3 OF 1885
('5', 28, 5, 10, 72392) In spite of the declarations of Her late Majesty’s ministers, and assurances of relief after the establishment of civil government, this law remains on the Statute book and is being fully enforced, though many laws, which were considered to be in conflict with the British constitution, were repealed as soon as British authority was proclaimed in the Transvaal.
('5', 28, 5, 11, 72755) Law 3 of 1885 is insulting to British Indians and was accepted totally under a misapprehension.
('5', 28, 5, 12, 72851) It imposes the following restrictions on Indians.
('5', 28, 6, 13, 72901) (a) It prevents them from enjoying burgher rights.
('5', 28, 6, 14, 72952) (b) It prohibits ownership of fixed property, except in streets, wards, or Locations set apart for the residence of Indians.
('5', 28, 6, 15, 73077) (c) It contemplates compulsory segregation in Locations of British Indians for purposes of sanitation.
('5', 28, 6, 16, 73180) And (d) it imposes a levy of £ 3 on every Indian who may enter the Colony for purposes of trade or the like.
('5', 29, 0, 1, 73289) 30 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 29, 1, 2, 73330) It is respectfully submitted, on behalf of the British Indian Association, that the Peace Preservation Ordinance should be so administered that (a) it should facilitate the entry of all refugees without delay; (b) children under 16 should be exempt from any restriction whatsoever, if they have their parents or supporters with them; (c) female relatives of British Indians should be entirely free from interference or restriction as to the rights of entry; and (d) a limited number of Indians though not refugees, should, on the application of resident traders who may satisfy the Permit Officer that they require the services of such men, be granted permits for residence during the period of their contract of service; and (e) Indians with educational attainments should be allowed to enter the Colony on application.
('5', 29, 1, 3, 74151) Both Law 3 of 1885 and the Peace Preservation Ordinance, and all other colour legislation affecting British Indians, should be repealed so soon as possible and they should be assured as to (a) their right to own landed property; (b) [their right] to live where they like, subject to the general sanitary laws of the Colony; (c) exemption from any special payment; and (d) generally, freedom from special legislation and enjoy ment of civil rights and liberty in the same manner and to the same extent as the other Colonists.
('5', 29, 1, 4, 74676) Though the British Indian Association does not share the fear of the European inhabitants that an unrestricted immigration from India will swamp the latter, as an earnest of its intention to work in harmony with them and to conciliate them, it has all along submitted that (a) the Peace Preservation Ordinance should be replaced by an immigration law of a general character, on the Cape or the Natal basis, provided that the educational test recognise the great Indian languages, and that power be given to the Government to grant residential permits to such men as may be required for the wants of Indians who may be themselves already established in businesses; (b) a Dealers’ Licences Law of a general character may be passed, applicable to all sections of the community, whereby the Town Councils or Local Boards could control the issue of new trade licences, subject to appeal to the Supreme Court to review the decisions of such councils or local boards.
('5', 29, 1, 5, 75637) Under such a law, whilst the then existing licences would be fully protected, except when the premises licensed are not kept in a sanitary condition; all new
('5', 30, 0, 1, 75795) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 31
('5', 30, 1, 2, 75841) applicants would have to be approved of by the Town Councils or the Local Boards, so that the increase of licences would be largely dependent upon the bodies above named.

RETRENCHMENT AND THE POLL TAX At a meeting of the Durban Town Council on Tuesday last, the Mayor reported having interviewed the heads of all the municipal departments employing Native and Indian labour, and discussed with them the reduction of all Native and Indian wages by an amount equal to 10 per cent.
('5', 30, 2, 5, 76364) of the monthly wage.
('5', 30, 2, 6, 76385) This has been approved by the Council and comes into force as from the 10th November.
('5', 30, 2, 7, 76471) It seems evident that neither the Council nor the heads of the departments have considered the additional misery that this measure will mean to those unfortunate men affected by it.
('5', 30, 2, 8, 76653) Practically all the free Indians employed by the Corporation come from the indentured class, and these have to pay an annual tax of £ 3 for the privilege of being a “ free” British subject in a British Colony, and beyond this (a very large drain on a poor man) there is to be a further annual tax of £ 1. How these men are to bear this additional burden and pay their taxes, perhaps the authorities know.
('5', 30, 2, 9, 77058) The least we can say is that this method of retrenchment reflects no credit on the humanity of the Council, and that the moment for putting it into force is singularly inopportune.
('5', 30, 2, 10, 77239) At the same meeting, the Council decided to raise the salary of the Borough Electrical Engineer’s assistant to £ 400 per annum.
('5', 30, 2, 11, 77367) This method of retrenchment applies to the Colony as a whole.
('5', 30, 2, 12, 77429) In this connection, we may quote our vigilant contemporary, Trade and, Transport:
('5', 30, 3, 13, 77511) The Gazette has not yet stated that among the Civil Servants chosen by Government to help the Colony out of a financial slough by an acceptance of a reduction in pay, there was one who point blank declined to do so, and that in consequence the Government, instead of insisting, yielded to this individual’s unwillingness to share with his fellows a common burden, and even went so far as to give him a substantial increase of salary instead, the excuse for such magnanimity being certain alleged conspicuous services rendered in connection with an undertaking quite beyond the sphere of duties properly belonging to the favoured one’s special department.
('5', 30, 3, 14, 78166) If the Durban Town Council had retrenched by adequately reducing first of all the high salaries of those heads of departments who have been willing to see the Natives and Indians reduced, the
('5', 31, 0, 1, 78358) 32 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 31, 1, 2, 78399) paltry £ 3,000 per annum, saved by taxing their very poorest employees, could easily have been made up.
('5', 31, 1, 3, 78503) At the worst, it would have been a hardship felt by but few, instead of, as now, by many.
('5', 31, 1, 4, 78593) But it is the old story: For, whosoever hath, to him shall be given, and he shall have more abundance; but whosoever hath not, from him shall be taken away even that he hath.

('5', 31, 3, 13, 79874) Sir Arthur Lawley is to fill the place vacated by Lord Ampthill, who has endeared himself to the people of the Madras Presidency.
('5', 31, 3, 14, 80004) We hope that Sir Arthur will continue the traditions he inherits.

('5', 32, 1, 4, 80682) 25 of 1875 was specially passed to increase “the maximum strength of the Volunteer Force in the Colony by adding thereto a force of Indian Immigrants Volunteer Infantry”.

('5', 34, 2, 5, 84886) 28. THE HEROIC SONG OF BENGAL
('5', 34, 3, 6, 84916) Every Western nation has its national anthem.
('5', 34, 3, 7, 84962) They sing it on important occasions.
('5', 34, 3, 8, 84999) The British anthem, God Save the Sing, is well known.
('5', 34, 3, 9, 85053) The Englishman is inspired with heroism when he sings it.
('5', 34, 3, 10, 85111) Germany, too, has its famous anthem.
('5', 34, 3, 11, 85148) La Marseillaise of France is of such a high order that the French go into ecstasies when it is sung.
('5', 34, 3, 12, 85249) Having realized this, Bankim Chandra, the Bengali poet, thought of composing a song for the Bengali people.
('5', 34, 3, 13, 85357) The song, Bande Mataram, composed by him has become very popular throughout Bengal.
('5', 34, 3, 14, 85441) Mammoth meetings have been held in Bengal in connection with the swadeshi movement where millions of people gathered together and sang Bankim’s song.
('5', 34, 3, 15, 85591) The song, it is said, has proved so popular that it has come to be our national anthem.
('5', 34, 3, 16, 85679) It is nobler in sentiment and sweeter than the songs of other nations.
('5', 34, 3, 17, 85750) While other anthems contain sentiments that are derogatory to others, Bande Mataram is quite free from such faults.
('5', 34, 3, 18, 85866) Its only aim is to arouse in us a sense of patriotism.
('5', 34, 3, 19, 85921) It regards India as the mother and sings her praises.
('5', 34, 3, 20, 85975) The poet attributes to Mother India all the good qualities one finds in one’s own mother.
('5', 34, 3, 21, 86065) Just as we worship our mother, so is this song a passionate prayer to India.
('5', 34, 3, 22, 86142) The words used are mostly Sanskrit, but easy to understand.
('5', 34, 3, 23, 86202) The language, though Bengali, is simple enough for everyone to understand.
('5', 34, 3, 24, 86277) The song is of such a high order that we print it in the Gujarati script below 1, and in the Devanagari script in the Hindi columns.

('5', 35, 1, 2, 86504) 29. LORD SELBORNE AND BRITISH INDIANS
('5', 35, 2, 3, 86542) Elsewhere will be found a report of the interview 1 that a deputation, on behalf of the British Indian Association of the Transvaal, had with Lord Selborne, on Wednesday, the 29th ultimo.
('5', 35, 2, 4, 86730) The British Indian Association has done well in placing the position so fully before Lord Selborne.
('5', 35, 2, 5, 86830) It could not but have struck His Excellency, as it strikes us, that the case put before him on behalf of British Indians in the Transvaal is extremely moderate and reasonable.
('5', 35, 2, 6, 87006) In fact, His Excellency admitted the “extreme reasona bleness” of the statement that any restrictions,to be effective, must be such as are, in the strictest sense only, necessary.
('5', 35, 2, 7, 87186) Examined from that standpoint, two things stand out prominently in the statement submitted to His Excellency by the deputation.
('5', 35, 2, 8, 87314) The Indians recognise the existence of prejudice against them in the Transvaal and also recognise that it is largely due to a fear (whether that be unreasonable or reasonable, it is not necessary to inquire into for present purposes) of unfair competition on the part of Indian traders and undue influx of Indians into the country, and they propose to meet both objections in a manner that cannot but commend itself to all who are not blinded to a sense of justice by overpowering prejudice.
('5', 35, 2, 9, 87806) If legislation restricting immigration on general lines were passed, on the Cape or Natal basis, with a proviso in favour of Indian languages, as an education test, it should meet all reasonable requirements.
('5', 35, 2, 10, 88015) With a spirit of self sacrifice, not to be ordinarily expected, the British Indian Association has gone further, and has suggested that control over all new trade licences shall be given to the Local Boards or Town Councils, subject to revision by the Supreme Court of the Colony.
('5', 35, 2, 11, 88296) Here, then, is what ought to be an acceptable olive branch offered to the anti Indian agitators in the Transvaal.
('5', 35, 2, 12, 88410) They are the men who cry out against Indian licences, and they are the men who either elect municipal representatives or are themselves such representatives.
('5', 35, 2, 13, 88568) The Indian trading community relies so much upon their sense of justice and fair play that it does not hesitate to intrust its future to them.
('5', 35, 2, 14, 88711) More it cannot be expected to do; and if anything more is done, it in spite of such advances, class legislation be deliberately undertaken, the whole of the “extreme reasonableness” will have been in vain, and, as said by the deputation, there will be an end to that freedom which Indians had learned to cherish as the priceless heritage gained to them by living under the British flag.
('5', 35, 2, 15, 89098) The working of the Peace
('5', 35, 3, 16, 89123) 1 Vide “Deputation to Lord Selborne”, 29 11 1905

('5', 36, 6, 16, 91289) 1 This was quoted by Dadabhai Naoroji in his letter of January 1, 1906, to the Secretary of State for India.

('5', 37, 0, 1, 91447) 38 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 37, 1, 2, 91488) 31. THE IMMIGRATION ACT AT THE CAPE We reproduce in another column a very important test case on the Immigration Act at the Cape.
('5', 37, 1, 3, 91618) The British Indians at the Cape will have to be very careful as to how the Act is being worked.
('5', 37, 1, 4, 91714) One Narotam Lalu, who has been a resident for nine years in Natal, was prevented from entering the Cape on the ground that he was not domiciled in South Africa.
('5', 37, 1, 5, 91875) His claim to previous domicile was rejected, although he held a domicile certificate from Natal, because he did not have his wife and children with him, or in South Africa.
('5', 37, 1, 6, 92048) The authorities at the Cape have instructed their officials that, unless applicants show that they possess immovable property in South Africa, or have their families in South Africa, their claims are to be rejected.
('5', 37, 1, 7, 92264) Mr. Justice Maasdorp has given a fairly full judgment.
('5', 37, 1, 8, 92319) He lays down that the requirement as to the presence of wife and children in South Africa, although it is a very great fact in support of domicile, is not absolutely essential.
('5', 37, 1, 9, 92496) The learned judge has also laid down that a certificate of domicile from Natal is no proof of former domicile, because that is a question for a judge or some judicial authority to decide.
('5', 37, 1, 10, 92684) The net effect of the judgment is that Indians who can prove long residence in South Africa and an intention of remaining in South Africa will be able to establish their claim to domicile.
('5', 37, 1, 11, 92873) This is so far satisfactory, but they will not be able, as was very reasonably supposed, to enter the Cape without any trouble on production of a certificate of domicile from Natal.
('5', 37, 1, 12, 93055) Now the law of the Cape recognises domicile in any part of South Africa, and in the interests of a just administration of the law it is very necessary that documents given by the Natal Government should be recognised at the Cape also, otherwise it would lead to endless complications and troubles.
('5', 37, 1, 13, 93353) As counsel for the applicant stated, the law as to domicile is practically the same in Natal as at the Cape.
('5', 37, 1, 14, 93462) There is, therefore, absolutely no reason why certificates of domicile granted in Natal, which, as everyone knows, are issued after very careful scrutiny, should not be accepted for the Colony of the Cape of Good Hope.
