('5', 37, 2, 16, 93708) 32. THE C. S. A. R. AND PASSENGER TRAFFIC In the Transvaal Government Gazette for the 8th instant is published a Bye law for regulating passenger traffic on the Central South African Rail ways.
('5', 37, 2, 17, 93902) The Bye law is a result of the investigation
('5', 38, 0, 1, 93947) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 39
('5', 38, 1, 2, 93993) carried out by Lord Selborne on the complaint of the Rand Pioneers 1, as also the Coloured people’s deputation that waited on His Excellency some months ago.
('5', 38, 1, 3, 94151) The Bye law is purely impersonal, and, on the face of it, seems to be perfectly inoffensive.
('5', 38, 1, 4, 94244) It states that passengers are to
('5', 38, 2, 5, 94277) conform to any instructions given by the station master, guard or other official authorities for the purposes, as to the compartment in which they shall travel or the seats they are to occupy, and no person shall remain in any compartment or seat if requested by such official to vacate the same.
('5', 38, 2, 6, 94574) If the circumstances necessitate any passenger having to travel in a compartment of inferior class to that for which he holds a ticket, the difference in the fare shall be refunded by the Railway Department, on application to the Traffic Manager.
('5', 38, 2, 7, 94821) Refusal to comply with the Bye law carried with it a penalty not exceeding 40s.
('5', 38, 2, 8, 94901) or seven days’ imprisonment.
('5', 38, 2, 9, 94930) The Railway authorities have always possessed these powers, but the Bye law emphasizes the fact.
('5', 38, 2, 10, 95027) In its practical effect, it means that Coloured passengers may have to travel in an inferior compartment to that for which they may hold tickets.
('5', 38, 2, 11, 95173) Whether it will be mischievous in its working or not will very largely depend upon those who will be authorised to regulate traffic, and a very great measure of tact will have to be exercised if inconvenience and rough treatment are to be avoided.

('5', 45, 4, 5, 111026) Last week our Cape Correspondent dealt with the question of Indian traders.
('5', 45, 4, 6, 111102) We need hardly inform our readers that special correspondents do not necessarily represent the views or the polity of this journal.
('5', 45, 4, 7, 111234) As a rule, we make it a point to give all sides of the question.
('5', 45, 4, 8, 111299) There would have been no occasion for emphasizing this fact, had it not been that our Cape Correspondent has dealt with the question of Indian traders at length.
('5', 45, 4, 9, 111461) We hold that the petty Indian traders have been of benefit to the Colony, and we share the view recently expressed by Sir James Hulett, and some years ago by Sir Walter Wragg, the late Sir Henry Binns and others, that they consider the petty Indian trader is a much better man than his fellow trader of the same class, and that he supplies a much felt want.
('5', 45, 4, 10, 111819) Any restriction, therefore, on his liberty would be a very serious injustice to him, and it should be the duty of the Indians at the Cape to fight strenuously against any attempt that may be made in that direction.

('5', 46, 6, 20, 114518) Indian Opinion, 23 12 1905

('5', 47, 1, 2, 114996) 42. A RETROSPECT Each year at this period it has been our practice to take stock of the position of Indian affairs in South Africa, which justifies the existence of this journal, and to better which is its main purpose.
('5', 47, 1, 3, 115216) We wish it was in our power to present to our readers a cheering balance sheet, but such cannot be, in the nature of the circumstances.
('5', 47, 1, 4, 115352) It is for the Indian to toil, suffer and wait, and we cannot report that he has been able, during the past year, to throw off any of his burdens.
('5', 47, 1, 5, 115498) Whether we look at Natal, the Transvaal, the Cape, or the Orange River Colony, it is not possible to recall anything that may be considered in the light of an achievement.
('5', 47, 1, 6, 115670) The record we have to present is a record of prevention of further losses.
('5', 47, 1, 7, 115745) The strength of the community has been spent in repelling encroachments.
('5', 47, 1, 8, 115818) In Natal, as if Indians had not had enough of trouble from man, Nature herself has proved unkind.
('5', 47, 1, 9, 115916) The disastrous flood claimed the largest number of victims from the Indian community.
('5', 47, 1, 10, 116002) The total number of deaths due to that calamity will, perhaps, never be known.
('5', 47, 1, 11, 116081) It, however, showed what Indians were capable of doing.
('5', 47, 1, 12, 116137) Practically the whole of the relief work was undertaken, and efficiently performed, by the leaders of the community.
('5', 47, 1, 13, 116254) In civil matters—political liberty the Indian in Natal has not as of old, the Dealers’ Licences Act continues to be the greatest source of trouble.
('5', 47, 1, 14, 116402) The two cases of Messrs Hoondamal 1 and Dada Osman 2 stand out prominently in this connection.
('5', 47, 1, 15, 116497) They show most clearly the precarious position that every Indian merchant holds in Natal.
('5', 47, 1, 16, 116587) The Municipal Laws Consolidation Bill deprives the Indian of the municipal franchise.
('5', 47, 1, 17, 116673) The Poll tax measure, though applicable to all, is calculated most seriously to affect the Indian.
('5', 47, 1, 18, 116772) The Immigration Restriction Act is being very rigorously enforced, and, as our columns have borne witness lately, the lot of an Indian passenger coming by the steamers from India is by no means enviable.
('5', 47, 1, 19, 116976) At the Cape, the Government has been strengthening its grip upon Indians by putting a wrong interpretation upon the restrictive clauses of the Immigration Act.
('5', 47, 1, 20, 117136) The term “domicile” has been interpreted so as to exclude even Indian traders of old standing.
('5', 47, 1, 21, 117231) Happily, the Supreme Court has come to the rescue, and has made it possible for such men to re enter the Colony or to remain there.
('5', 47, 2, 22, 117363) 1 Vide “Hoondamal’s Licence”, 15 10 1904; 26 11 1904 & “The Hoondamal Licence Again”, 17 12 1904 2 Vide “Dada Osman’s Case”, 14 9 1898
('5', 48, 0, 1, 117498) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 49
('5', 48, 1, 2, 117544) In the Transvaal, where the chief struggle is going on, the position is as indecisive as it was last year.
('5', 48, 1, 3, 117651) Lord Selborne has not been able to give the Indian deputation that waited on him any definite answer, though he has promised to redress the grievances regarding the operation of the Peace Preservation Ordinance.
('5', 48, 1, 4, 117863) As for the Orange River Colony, Lord Selborne’s reply, given some months ago to a representation from the British Indian Association, 1 shows that that Colony is not yet to open its gates to Indians, no matter who they may be.
('5', 48, 1, 5, 118090) In its communal life, however, the Indian population has shown distinct signs of progress.
('5', 48, 1, 6, 118181) There is an anxiety to work in greater harmony; an anxiety to give the Indian youth a better education.
('5', 48, 1, 7, 118285) In the person of Mr. Bernard Gabriel, we have the first Colonial born Indian to have received a liberal education, and to have returned a barrister from England.
('5', 48, 1, 8, 118447) The community has a right to expect him to give a good account of himself.
('5', 48, 1, 9, 118522) The visit of Professor Parmanand and the welcome given to him are an indication of the desire of the community to have in its midst more Indians of culture and education.
('5', 48, 1, 10, 118693) It is to be hoped that, in the near future, this will be translated into action, and that there will be a concentrated effort to supply from within the educational needs of the community.
('5', 48, 1, 11, 118881) The retrospect is gloomy enough, and yet it is not without relieving features.
('5', 48, 1, 12, 118960) Attempts to degrade the community by establishing the principle of compulsory segregation, although often renewed, have hitherto failed.
('5', 48, 1, 13, 119097) There has been, on the part of the Press, greater willingness to ventilate Indian grievances.
('5', 48, 1, 14, 119191) The question of Indian volunteering, first started by us, has been favourably received by it.
('5', 48, 1, 15, 119285) The revelations regarding the condition of indentured Indians, before the Prisons Commission in Natal, have received some publicity from the Natal Press, and though these are incidents which, by themselves, signify very little, they unmistakably point to the fact that the community has to proceed along the lines laid down by it when the struggle first commenced, namely, to continue it with reasonab leness, as acknowledged by Lord Selborne, with patience, and
('5', 48, 2, 16, 119748) 1 Vide “Address to Lord Selborne”, 14 10 1905 and “Potchefstroom Indians’ Statement”, 14 10 1905

('5', 49, 3, 4, 119935) 43. THE ORANGE RIVER COLONY
('5', 49, 4, 5, 119963) We wish to call the attention of the responsible authorities to certain draft Ordinances that are published in the Orange River Colony Government Gazette for the 15th December, 1905, and to certain Town Regulations.
('5', 49, 4, 6, 120179) The first Ordinance is entitled “to amend the Laws relating to Passes”, and it requires every male Coloured person to hold a pass for a certain period, renewable from time to time.
('5', 49, 4, 7, 120360) Another Ordinance is “to regulate and control the procuring and engaging of coloured people to do work or labour within or beyond the borders of the Orange River Colony”.
('5', 49, 4, 8, 120531) The method, according to which the framers of the Ordinance would “procure” Coloured labour, is by licensing labour agents, who may employ “runners or messengers to procure, ply, or seek for coloured labourers”.
('5', 49, 4, 9, 120743) The messengers are to hold 5/ permits.
('5', 49, 4, 10, 120782) There are sections governing the issue of licences to such labour agents, and the usual safeguard against abuse of such licences or misrepresentations by labour agents.
('5', 49, 4, 11, 120951) It has, we suppose, become a recognised thing in South Africa for such labour agents to be appointed for “inducing Kaffirs to work”.
('5', 49, 4, 12, 121084) Some call such a system a gentle coaxing; others call it a modified form of forced labour.
('5', 49, 4, 13, 121175) We cannot question the policy that has been sanctioned for a long time, and its criticism does not lie within our domain.
('5', 49, 4, 14, 121297) Unfortunately, the term “Coloured person” is, in the Orange River Colony, interpreted invariably to mean “all coloured persons, who, in accordance with laws or customs, are called Coloured persons, or are treated as such, of whatsoever race ornationality they may be”.
('5', 49, 4, 15, 121566) It, therefore, includes Asiatics, Malays and others.Both the above mentioned Ordinances on that account are open to very serious objections, and we cannot understand why the studied insult implied should be irritatingly kept up.
('5', 49, 4, 16, 121795) Lord Selborne, in his reply to the British Indian Association, has admitted that there are very few Asiatics in the Orange River Colony.
('5', 49, 4, 17, 121932) Why, then, should the offensive definition be maintained?
('5', 49, 4, 18, 121990) If it is, in practice, inoperative, the only reason for its existence can be for the wanton pleasure of the inhabitants of the Orange River Colony, who wish to triumph over this implied degradation of the Asiatic races.
('5', 49, 4, 19, 122210) It is these gentlemen who were pleased, in the Republican days, to describe Indians as those who considered their women as soulless, and as being a people known for the loathsome diseases from which they suffered.
('5', 49, 4, 20, 122424) Must the authorities
('5', 50, 0, 1, 122445) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 51
('5', 50, 1, 2, 122491) continue to feed the flame of such unreasoning, ignorant prejudice?
('5', 50, 1, 3, 122559) We have referred to Town Regulations, and we find the old story repeated for the Municipalities of Dewetsdorp and Brandford—both of them townships bearing glorious names.
('5', 50, 1, 4, 122730) These Regulations are of the same type as those which we have reproduced often in these columns.
('5', 50, 1, 5, 122827) They are framed to control the movement of Coloured people, even the possession by them of cattle, horses, mules, sheep or goats!
('5', 50, 1, 6, 122957) No Coloured man “may run on the Town Commonage more than four cattle, horses, or mules, and eight sheep or goats, for which he shall pay monthly 1/ per head for large stock, and three pence per head for sheep or goats”.
('5', 50, 1, 7, 123177) No Coloured inhabitant of the Location may have a stranger coming to him without notice being given to the Town Clerk, nor may an entertainment or a gathering be held without such permission.
('5', 50, 1, 8, 123369) He may not walk even within the Location after eleven o’clock at night, “except for urgent reasons”.
('5', 50, 1, 9, 123470) We have said enough to revive our readers’ recollections of similar by laws for other townships.
('5', 50, 1, 10, 123567) Are these by laws, we ask once more, necessary for the protection of the predominant race, so far as British Indians are concerned ?
('5', 50, 1, 11, 123700) Indian Opinion, 30 12 1905
('5', 50, 2, 12, 123727) 44. DISUNITY AND RIOTS IN THE HEIDELBERG COMMUNITY
('5', 50, 3, 13, 123778) The Muslim community in Heidelberg has for some time past been divided over the question of the local mosque, and this has led to the formation of two factions.
('5', 50, 3, 14, 123939) Though the dispute was taken to a law court, where it was decided, unity in the community has not been restored.
('5', 50, 3, 15, 124052) This is a matter for great sorrow.
('5', 50, 3, 16, 124087) That a quarrel regarding a mosque should be taken to a court of law is, we believe, in itself a thing to be ashamed of.
('5', 50, 3, 17, 124207) But it is worse when the dispute continues even after it has been to the court.
('5', 50, 3, 18, 124287) We are not going to adjudge who is at fault.
('5', 50, 3, 19, 124332) We would only say to both the parties that such a quarrel is a stain on the whole community.
('5', 50, 3, 20, 124425) We in this country are closely watched by all.
('5', 50, 3, 21, 124472) It would be, we believe,a disservice to ourselves if we expose our faults in public under such circumstances.
('5', 50, 3, 22, 124582) We still hope the members of both the parties will take thought and end the dispute.
('5', 50, 3, 23, 124667) We give below a translation of a Special Correspondent’s report published in the Transvaal Leader of the 23rd instant, which will show how serious the matter is:
('5', 51, 0, 1, 124829) 52 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 51, 1, 2, 124870) Our Heidelberg Correspondent has sent us a telegram regarding the serious developments among the Arabs 1 there.
('5', 51, 1, 3, 124982) Fortunately, the damage is not so great as was apprehended, though the dispute was serious.
('5', 51, 1, 4, 125074) The peace of a quiet town like Heidelberg was disturbed at noon as a result of the misbehaviour of the Arabs.
('5', 51, 1, 5, 125184) The quarrel started at a meeting of the trustees of the mosque held in the court building.
('5', 51, 1, 6, 125275) At last, it became so serious that the police had to be called in to prevent bloodshed.
('5', 51, 1, 7, 125363) The news having spread through the town, many onlookers collected in the Market Square to see the murderous rioting.

('5', 51, 1, 9, 125615) For a time, the situation appeared very serious.
('5', 51, 1, 10, 125664) Sticks and brickbats were freely used.
('5', 51, 1, 11, 125703) The meeting became a pandemonium.
('5', 51, 1, 12, 125737) From words, they came to blows.
('5', 51, 1, 13, 125769) It is impossible to imagine what would have happened, had not the police arrived in time.
('5', 51, 1, 14, 125859) An Arab’s head was broken.
('5', 51, 1, 15, 125886) The police thereupon cleared the room of all the men.
('5', 51, 1, 16, 125940) Before the might of the police the excited Arabs scattered like straw before the wind.
('5', 51, 1, 17, 126027) For a time it appeared that the police intervention had put an end to the strife.
('5', 51, 1, 18, 126109) But on coming out, the Arabs started rioting again; and all efforts to quench the conflagration were in vain.
('5', 51, 1, 19, 126219) One can only guess how the rioting started.
('5', 51, 1, 20, 126263) But the matter must have been serious, for our Correspondent says that the conflagration has not yet subsided.
('5', 51, 1, 21, 126374) The police still remain posted near the Town Hall.
('5', 51, 1, 22, 126425) There is thus no cause for fear.
('5', 51, 1, 23, 126458) The quarrel is confined to the Arabs only and the white population need not be alarmed.
('5', 51, 1, 24, 126546) Both the parties say, however, that they will fight it out in the open.
('5', 51, 1, 25, 126618) All was quiet last night, but the quarrel has not subsided and the danger of further disturbances persists.

('5', 51, 1, 27, 126766) We have to hang our head from shame even while translating this.
('5', 51, 1, 28, 126831) We hope the Heidelberg people will realize their folly, feel ashamed of themselves and return to normal.

('5', 52, 2, 5, 127279) In the context of the discussion that is at present going on about the spread of education among the Kaffirs, Mr. Tengo Jababun is actively working for the founding of a huge college for Natives in South Africa.
('5', 52, 2, 6, 127491) The object of his tour is twofold: firstly, to collect a big fund for the college, and secondly, to obtain signatures on a petition emphasizing the need for such a college and requesting the Government for assistance.
('5', 52, 2, 7, 127709) Mr. Tengo Jababun interviewed the Editor of the Transvaal Leader who has published his statement in full.
('5', 52, 2, 8, 127815) Mr. Tengo hopes to raise £ 50,000 from among the Kaffirs and to get 2,00,000 signatures from them for his petition.
('5', 52, 2, 9, 127931) Mr. Tengo hopes to acquire the present Government school for Kaffirs and the adjoining site at Lovedale and there build a big institution for imparting higher education to the Kaffirs.
('5', 52, 2, 10, 128116) Out of the 836 Kaffirs from Lovedale who passed the Cape University examinations during 1886 1900, 13 boys passed the Matriculation Examination.
('5', 52, 2, 11, 128261) In all, 768 Kaffir teachers have been trained by the Lovedale Institute.
('5', 52, 2, 12, 128334) During this period, the Kaffirs in Lovedale paid £ 63,734 towards fees and other expenses.

('5', 53, 3, 4, 129019) TO THE PRIVATE SECRETARY
('5', 53, 4, 5, 129044) TO HIS EXCELLENCY THE HIGH COMMISSIONER FOR SOUTH AFRICA JOHANNESBURG
('5', 53, 5, 6, 129114) SIR, I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 20th ultimo with reference to certain Draft Ordinances published in a recent issue of the Government Gazette for the Orange River Colony.
('5', 53, 5, 7, 129320) I venture to invite His Excellency’s attention to the fact that it is not stated in my letter of the 22nd ultimo that the Ordinances referred to do not apply to British Indians.
('5', 53, 5, 8, 129498) The contention of my Association is that the Ordinances in question do apply to British Indians in theory but they do not in practice, and it is for that very reason, that the definitions [are] taken from the old law that my Association submits it is an unnecessary insult to the Indian community to retain the definitions.
('5', 53, 5, 9, 129822) A continuous inclusion of British Indians in the term “coloured persons”, as it is understood in the Orange River Colony and other parts of South Africa, has resulted in very serious injustice being done to them.
('5', 53, 5, 10, 130035) My Association, therefore, humbly ventures to think that in all new legislation at any rate the definition should be amended so as to avoid the offence which the community, represented by my Association, feels so keenly.
('5', 53, 5, 11, 130256) Moreover, I would venture to invite His Excellency’s attention to the fact that there is already on the Statute book of the Orange River Colony special legislation affecting Asiatics and, therefore, British Indians.
('5', 53, 6, 12, 130472) I have the honour to remain,
('5', 53, 8, 13, 130501) Yours obedient servant, ABDUL GANI CHAIRMAN, BRITISH INDIAN ASSOCIATION Indian Opinion, 29 1 1906

('5', 54, 3, 4, 130703) DEAR MR. NAZAR, I have been discussing with Chhaganlal the question of Tamil and Hindi editing.

('5', 56, 2, 5, 135469) 50. THE STATUS OF BRITISH INDIANS
('5', 56, 3, 6, 135503) As anticipated by us, the Indian National Congress did its duty towards Indians in South Africa, by passing a resolution, at its recent sitting at Banaras on the subject of the treatment of British Indians in this sub continent, praying, as a means of extorting relief, for the suspension of the supply of indentured labour to Natal, until the “most Colony sees its way to redress[ing] the existing intolerable disabilities and recognises Indians as equally [sic] members of the Empire.
('5', 56, 3, 7, 135990) We heartily congratulate Congress on thus once again publicly drawing attention to the subject, and supporting Lord Curzon’s policy in this matter as declared by him in his last Budget speech at Simla.
('5', 56, 3, 8, 136192) Those who have kept themselves informed of affairs in India will have noticed that, specially since 1897, the entire Indian popula tion, Anglo Indian as well as Indian and the whole Indian Press, English and vernacular, have voiced persistently the sentiments to which the Congress resolution gives expression.Unfortunately,the system of government in India is such as to give very few opport unities for the responsible officers to publiclyannounce their opinions on public matters, however serious they may be; and the natural result is that it is very difficult to know them.
('5', 56, 3, 9, 136771) It is for this reason, chiefly, that we find members of both Houses in England putting questions to the Secretary of State for India, and thus obtaining glimpses of what may be in the mind of the Government of India; and Indians in South Africa owe no little gratitude to such champions of their cause as the East India Association, Sir M. ('5', 57, 1, 5, 139125) But there is one point about this matter—and that the chief one —which has not been sufficiently emphasised.
('5', 57, 1, 6, 139234) It would seem that the treatment of British Indians in South Africa has not been raised above the arena of mere bargaining, and the rights of Indians as British subjects, apart from the special services in the terms of their indenture, appear to be ignored so far as possible by the Natal Government, and not adequately insisted on by the Government of India.
('5', 57, 1, 7, 139594) Lord Curzon recognised that the need of indentured labour “might prove a powerful lever in our hands in securing better treatment for Indians generally in South Africa”; but, as we have said, this would be extorting relief and not securing it on high Imperial grounds.

('5', 57, 1, 9, 140031) The position of British Indians would be a truly sorry one if that were so.
('5', 57, 1, 10, 140107) But such a thing would be too anomalous under the British flag.

('5', 58, 2, 4, 140756) 51. INDIANS IN THE O. R. C. Lord Selborne has sent the British Indian Association a prompt and courteous reply to its representation 1, protesting against the definition of the term “coloured person” in certain draft ordinances recently published in the O. R. C. Government Gazette.
('5', 58, 2, 5, 141039) We venture to think that Lord Selborne has misread the representation of theAssociation, which has not stated that “none of the ordinances referred to would apply to British Indians”.
('5', 58, 2, 6, 141223) It has said that, “in practice”, they will not apply.
('5', 58, 2, 7, 141277) The two statements are quite different.
('5', 58, 2, 8, 141317) His Excellency has, moreover, justified the definition of “coloured person” on the ground that it is a legacy from the old Government.
('5', 58, 2, 9, 141452) But British Indians object to the definition for that very reason.
('5', 58, 2, 10, 141519) Their position is this.
('5', 58, 2, 11, 141543) The ordinances will not in practice apply to them.
('5', 58, 2, 12, 141594) The Boer Government insulted the Indians by classing them with the Kaffirs.
('5', 58, 2, 13, 141670) Now there is no occasion to perpetuate a needless insult.
('5', 58, 2, 14, 141728) The argument seems to be unanswerable.
('5', 58, 2, 15, 141767) It is a pity that His Excellency, in spite of his wish not to offend, has not seen his way to grant the very reasonable request of the Association.

('5', 60, 4, 9, 145096) 55. PAYMENT OF THE POLL TAX
('5', 60, 5, 10, 145124) The Poll Tax, as was to be expected, does not seem to be paid with much enthusiasm, judging by the meagre response to date.
('5', 60, 5, 11, 145248) The trouble will begin towards the end of next month.
('5', 60, 5, 12, 145302) The authorities will not have an easy task in discriminating between those who can pay and those who cannot.
('5', 60, 5, 13, 145411) But one thing, at all events, seems clear: the Government appear determined to squeeze blood out of stones.
('5', 60, 5, 14, 145519) Some time ago, an Indian approached the Colonial Secretary, asking if Government would be prepared to extend the time of payment in the case of those who were dependent upon their meagre crops to provide the necessary sovereign, and received a reply that they were not prepared to do so, but suggesting that such people could raise a loan on the security of their crops.
('5', 60, 5, 15, 145890) One would have thought that, in a civilised country, a man who was living such a hand to mouth existence that he had no money left after planting his crops would not be expected to pay the tax.
('5', 60, 5, 16, 146084) But such a sorry condition appears to the authorities to be comparative affluence.
('5', 60, 5, 17, 146167) There is evidently something very rotten in a State that has to descend to such depths as these.
('5', 60, 5, 18, 146264) The authorities might have gone a step further and suggested that the poorest man could raise the money to pay the tax by mortgaging his body for dissection purposes.
('5', 60, 5, 19, 146431) But we might point out that, according to section 14(4) of the Act,
('5', 60, 6, 20, 146499) any person who shall prove that he is unable through poverty to pay the tax shall be excused therefrom for the time being, but this excuse shall not prevent a subsequent prosecution or action if such person shall afterwards become able to pay the tax and fails to do so.
('5', 60, 6, 21, 146770) It appears, therefore, that persons so placed as the correspondent referred to can plead poverty and pay the tax later from the proceeds of their crops.
('5', 60, 6, 22, 146923) There will be no need whatever to go the length of
('5', 61, 0, 1, 146974) 62 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 61, 1, 2, 147015) raising a loan on the growing crop (and paying usurious interest), since the Act provides for this very contingency.
('5', 61, 1, 3, 147132) Indian Opinion, 20 1 1906
('5', 61, 2, 4, 147158) 56. MANSUKHLAL HIRALAL NAZAR 1
('5', 61, 3, 5, 147189) It was in the dark days of December, 1896, that Mansukhlal Hiralal Nazar landed in Durban, a perfect stranger.
('5', 61, 3, 6, 147300) He intended to live a quiet life, but a patriot of his type was not able to sit still when he saw his countrymen needing the help of a guiding hand during those trying times.
('5', 61, 3, 7, 147475) The Durban Demonstration 2 was then brewing.
('5', 61, 3, 8, 147520) Meetings were held in the Town Hall to protest against the immigration of Indians.
('5', 61, 3, 9, 147603) The Indian passengers on board the Naderi and the Courland were threatened with dire results if they attempted to land on the shores of Natal.
('5', 61, 3, 10, 147746) It was then that Mr. Nazar arrived on the scene, and was hailed as a deliverer by the Indian community.
('5', 61, 3, 11, 147850) Not a soul knew who he was, but his magnetic personality and the authoritative manner in which he spoke about the duty of the people at the time attracted the leaders to him immediately, and it is difficult to say what the Indian community would have done had Mr. Nazar not arrived at the time.
('5', 61, 3, 12, 148145) He remained closely closeted with Mr. Laughton, who was acting as counsel for the community, and I have it from Mr. Laughton’s own lips that Mr. Nazar’s assistance and his suggestions at the time proved to him of the utmost value.
('5', 61, 3, 13, 148376) From that day to the date of his death, Mr. Nazar placed the public cause before his own; his dream of leading a private life was never realised, and though people were never allowed to know it, for the cause of his countrymen Mr. Nazar has died a pauper.
('5', 61, 3, 14, 148632) For days together he used to live away from Durban, in a secluded home in Sydenham, 3 existing on nothing but a little milk and a few biscuits, and time alone will show the nature and value of the unostentatious services rendered by Mr. Nazar.
('5', 61, 3, 15, 148876) He was born in the early ’sixties, and belonged to a family of noble traditions and to one of the most cultured castes in India, namely, the Kayastha division.
('5', 61, 3, 16, 149036) As is shown by his family name, the Nazars, in the early days, must have served the Mogul emperors as trusted officials.
('5', 61, 3, 17, 149157) The late Mr. Hiralal Nazar, the father of the subject of this memoir, was one of the earliest products of English education in the Western presidency, 4 and was a tried servant of the Government.
('5', 61, 4, 18, 149353) 1 Died on January 20, 1906 2 Vide “Memorial to Secretary of State for the Colonies”, 15 3 1897
('5', 61, 5, 19, 149448) 3 A suburb of Durban 4 Bombay
('5', 62, 0, 1, 149478) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 63
('5', 62, 1, 2, 149524) He was a civil engineer, and, by his ability and strength of character, inspired so much confidence, that the Government allowed him to possess a knowledge of the secret defences in the fortress at Bombay.
('5', 62, 1, 3, 149730) Mr. Nazar was very nearly related to the late Justice Nanabhai Haridas.
('5', 62, 1, 4, 149802) He was educated in Bombay, and having passed his matriculation examination with distinction, he prosecuted his further studies at the Elphinstone College at Bombay.
('5', 62, 1, 5, 149967) As a rule, he was easily first in his class, and gave promise of a brilliant career, but being of a restless turn of mind, he never finished his studies.
('5', 62, 1, 6, 150121) He imbibed from Mr. Dadabhai Naoroji and the other Indian patriotic giants of the time the idea of using his life for the service of his country, and he was, therefore, instrumental in establishing an Un[der] graduates’ Association which vied with the older established Graduates’ Association, under the brilliant chairmanship of Sir Pherozeshah Mehta.
('5', 62, 1, 7, 150474) 1 Memorials that were drafted by Mr. Nazar and presented to the Government about University Reform showed Mr. Nazar’s brilliant penmanship and his political turn of mind.
('5', 62, 1, 8, 150645) He also studied for four years at the Grant Medical College, and was thereby able to receive a fair amount of knowledge of medicine which was very useful to him in after life.
('5', 62, 1, 9, 150821) Mr. Nazar did not wish to accept any service, and belonging to the Hon.
('5', 62, 1, 10, 150893) Mr. Dadabhai Naoroji’s school of thought, he considered that the salvation of India must come both from within and from without, and that education was not to be used as a means for obtaining position nor was it to be ; divorced from commerce.
('5', 62, 1, 11, 151137) He and his talented brothers, therefore, set out for England, and threw themselves into the commercial strife with great energy, but Mr. Nazar was always a politician first and everything else afterwards.
('5', 62, 1, 12, 151342) He, therefore, continued his public work in London.
('5', 62, 1, 13, 151394) He identified himself with many useful institutions, and was elected a delegate to the Oriental Congress that was held in Christiania.
('5', 62, 1, 14, 151529) 2 He came into contact with the late Professor Max Muller and many other Orientalists, and by his accurate knowledge of Oriental literature, commanded their admiration.
('5', 62, 1, 15, 151698) But Mr. Nazar was also something more.
('5', 62, 1, 16, 151737) He was a journalist of a very high type.
('5', 62, 1, 17, 151778) He used, at one time, to be very inti mately connected with the Advocate of India to which he contributed not a little, free of charge.
('5', 62, 1, 18, 151914) He used to correspond with many well known news papers in India as if he was preparing for a similar career in Natal.
('5', 62, 1, 19, 152032) Not having succeeded so well as he wished to in his commercial affairs in Europe, all over which he had travelled morethan once, he migrated to South Africa.
('5', 62, 1, 20, 152190) The story of his work in

('5', 63, 1, 2, 152303) Natal, which he made his home, is soon told.

('5', 63, 1, 4, 152441) In 1897, he was sent to England as a special delegate to voice the grievances of the British Indians.

('5', 63, 1, 20, 153844) When the Natal Indian Ambulance Corps 3 was raised, everybody advised him, because of the heart disease from which he then suffered, that it was not necessary for him to take an active part in the work of the Corps, but he would not listen, and volunteered his services as a member, and it was there that he used his knowledge of medicine to good purpose.
('5', 63, 1, 21, 154200) Without him this journal would never have come into being.
('5', 63, 1, 22, 154259) In the initial stages of its struggle, Mr. Nazar took up almost the whole of the editorial burden, and if it is known for its moderate policy and sound views, the fact is due, to a very large extent, to the part that Mr. Nazar played in connection with it.
('5', 63, 1, 23, 154516) An Indian reading this account will understand thoroughly what Mr. Nazar was, when I state that he was a real Yogin, a cosmopolitan Hindu, knowing no distinction as to caste or creed, recognising no religious differences.
('5', 63, 1, 24, 154738) His one solace in life was the
('5', 63, 2, 25, 154769) 1 (1840 1900); authority on Indian affairs and leading member of the British Committee; 2 A member of the Indian Civil Service, and administrator in the Punjab 3 Organised by Gandhiji during the Boer War, 1899 1902; Vide “Indian Ambulance corps in Natal”, 14 3 1900

('5', 64, 1, 3, 155117) He was imbued with its philosophy.
('5', 64, 1, 4, 155152) He knew the Sanskrit text almost by heart, and the writer of this memoir is personally aware that amid his sorest trials—and he had his full share of them—he was in a position to preserve fairly perfect equanimity under the inspiration of that teaching.
('5', 64, 1, 5, 155406) To an orthodox Hindu, some of his ways would appear to be strange, but Mr. Nazar was undoubtedly a strange mixture.

('5', 64, 2, 15, 156547) We have no fault whatever to find with his method of dealing with the subject, but we would point out the inaccuracies that appear in the portion of his article wherein he refers to the question of British Indians in the Transvaal.
('5', 64, 2, 16, 156779) Mr. Massingham is apparently of the opinion that Law 3 of 1885 does not forbid them to hold land.
('5', 64, 2, 17, 156877) In this contention, of course, he is quite wrong.
('5', 64, 2, 18, 156927) Mr. Massingham commits the further error of supposing that Indians are “still allowed a share of the town foot paths”.
('5', 64, 2, 19, 157046) This is technically incorrect, for, by reason of a well known judicial decision, no Indian has the right to use any municipal foot path, and may, at the will of the first policeman, be curtly ordered into the middle of the road.

('5', 65, 2, 4, 157736) 58. SIR DAVID HUNTER
('5', 65, 3, 5, 157757) It is with pleasure that we note Sir David Hunter intends to continue to make Natal his home, and that he has expressed his willingness to put his own wishes aside and entertain the idea of entering Parliament when he returns from his tour, should his fellow citizens ask him to do so.
('5', 65, 3, 6, 158043) That they will request him to represent them is certain, for, on all hands, Sir David’s special fitness for parliamentary service is acknowledged.
('5', 65, 3, 7, 158190) Although the Indian residents of Natal will have no vote in his election, their voice will none the less be raised to support him.
('5', 65, 3, 8, 158321) Indians owe much to Sir David, for, in his position as General Manager of the Natal Government Railways, they have always found him not merely courteous but always considerate also.
('5', 65, 3, 9, 158503) It is chiefly [due] to his sense of justice that Indians have the ordinary conveniences on the railways, instead of being compelled to travel only in a third class compartment, as was desired by many people in the Colony; and, if their treatment by some of the railway officers is not all that it might be, it is not the fault of Sir David.
('5', 65, 3, 10, 158844) He has also taken an active and practical interest in Indian education.
('5', 65, 3, 11, 158916) Sir David is a fine type of the British gentleman, and the Colony has only honoured itself in honouring him.
('5', 65, 3, 12, 159025) We wish Sir David a pleasant voyage, a pleasant tour, and a speedy return.

('5', 66, 6, 10, 160342) TO THE COLONIAL SECRETARY PRETORIA
('5', 66, 7, 11, 160377) SIR, My Association has been informed from various sources that, after the change of the Permit Office, 2 the following innovations have been made, without any warning to the Indian community, whether through my Association or otherwise.
('5', 66, 7, 12, 160615) The age of minority of children who may wish to enter this country has been reduced from under sixteen to under twelve.
('5', 66, 7, 13, 160735) Affidavits of guardians are not accepted; that is to say, only those whose parents are residents of the Transvaal are allowed to come.
('5', 66, 7, 14, 160870) Witnesses for refugees outside Pretoria are now being examined by Resident Magistrates in the various districts, with the result that the applications of many refugees have, for the present, been indefinitely hung up.
('5', 66, 7, 15, 161088) My Association respectfully protests against the Indian community being thus taken unawares with reference to the above innovations.
('5', 66, 7, 16, 161221) My Association has, as a rule, been at least kept informed of any contemplated changes, and, in some cases, the Government have been good enough to even consult my Association.
('5', 66, 7, 17, 161398) It has come to my Association, therefore, as a disagreeable surprise that serious
('5', 66, 8, 18, 161480) 1 In the Russo Japanese War; vide “Russia and India”, 11 11 1905
('5', 66, 9, 19, 161545) 2 Vide “Transvaal Indians and Permits”, 17 2 1906
('5', 67, 0, 1, 161595) 68 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 67, 1, 2, 161636) changes affecting the Indian community have been made in the Permit Regulations, without any notice whatsoever, and then, too, the Indian community is allowed to know these things only through actual instances.
('5', 67, 1, 3, 161847) As to the innovations themselves, it is submitted on behalf of my Association that they are calculated to do very serious harm to the community.
('5', 67, 1, 4, 161992) It is difficult to understand why the age of minority has been still further reduced.
('5', 67, 1, 5, 162078) My Association invites your attention to the fact that nowhere else in the British dominions have children under sixteen been prevented from entering British domin ions where their parents have been allowed the right of entry.
('5', 67, 1, 6, 162305) It is a matter of the gravest importance to the Indian community that the domiciled Indians should be able to bring in their children without any difficulty.
('5', 67, 1, 7, 162463) Why a child of thirteen years or fifteen years should, for instance, be prohibited from joining his parents, and receiving, say, his education under them, it is difficult to unde rstand.
('5', 67, 1, 8, 162650) My Association further draws your attention to the factthat the rule does not apply to the non Asiatic communities in the Transvaal.
('5', 67, 1, 9, 162783) As to the second innovation, hitherto orphans have been allowed to join their guardians.
('5', 67, 1, 10, 162872) Under the new rule, such children will be prevented from entering the Transvaal.
('5', 67, 1, 11, 162953) My Association need hardly point out that such a rule cannot but cause very great hardship.
('5', 67, 1, 12, 163045) As regards the third innovation, if the Resident Magistrates are to carry on investigations, it will cause almost interminable delay.
('5', 67, 1, 13, 163179) There are refugees whose applications have been pending even for the last nine months, and if all such applications are to be referred to Resident Magistrates in the various districts, enormous delay will be caused.
('5', 67, 1, 14, 163395) Moreover, there will be no continuity of procedure as to the evidence to be taken, if each town is treated separately.
('5', 67, 1, 15, 163514) My Association further submits that, when witnesses reside outside Pretoria, it will expedite matters considerably, and secure uniformity of procedure, if the same official were to be appointed for the examination of witnesses throughout.
('5', 67, 1, 16, 163753) My Association further begs to point out that it is necessary, in the interests of Justice, that there should be a periodical visit by an official to attend to those requiring permits in Johannesburg, seeing that nearly seventy five per cent.
('5', 67, 1, 17, 163996) of the refugees are destined for Johannesburg or the surrounding districts.
('5', 67, 1, 18, 164072) Whilst the central offices may remain in Pretoria, the mechanical work of issuing permits and taking thumb impressions should, in the humble opinion of my Association, so far as the Johannesburg refugees are concerned, be done in Johannesburg.
('5', 68, 0, 1, 164316) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 69
('5', 68, 1, 2, 164362) Nothing has yet been known with reference to the question of whether Indian women are or are not to hold separate permits.
('5', 68, 1, 3, 164485) My Association submits that the matters referred to herein are of very vital importance, and trusts that they will receive the attention they deserve.
('5', 68, 1, 4, 164636) I respectfully request an early reply.
('5', 68, 2, 5, 164675) I have the honour to remain ,
('5', 68, 4, 6, 164705) Your obedient servant, ABDUL GANI CHAIRMAN, BRITISH INDIAN ASSOCIATION Indian Opinion, 17 2 1906
('5', 68, 5, 7, 164802) 62. LETTER TO TOWN CLERK
('5', 68, 6, 8, 164827) JOHANNESBURG, February 10, 1906
('5', 68, 7, 9, 164859) TO THE TOWN CLERK JOHANNESBURG SIR, The attention of my Association has been drawn to certain recommendations made by the Manager of the Johannesburg Tramway system, for adoption by the Town Council, as regards the use of the electric tram cars by the Coloured people.
('5', 68, 7, 10, 165128) My Association ventures to think that, in making these recommendations, the Manager has taken no note of the sentiments of the Coloured community or rather the British Indian community, with which my Association is concerned.
('5', 68, 7, 11, 165354) My Association feels that the recommendations are scarcely meant to supply the want of British Indians.
('5', 68, 7, 12, 165458) If Coloured servants may use the roofs of the tram cars when they accompany their masters, it is very difficult to see why other Coloured people may not use them.
('5', 68, 7, 13, 165621) The suggestion to run special tram cars is hardly feasible, as the Coloured community will not then be able to have the same kind of service as the European community.
('5', 68, 7, 14, 165789) The recomm endation that trailer cars should be attached to the ordinary cars, for the use of Coloured people as well as for carrying parcels, is, in the humble opinion of my Association, highly insulting.
('5', 68, 7, 15, 165995) My Association submits that British Indians are entitled to the same facilities as any other community in Johannesburg, I with reference to the use of the tram cars.
('5', 68, 7, 16, 166161) At the same time, my Association fully recognises the
('5', 69, 0, 1, 166215) 70 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 69, 1, 2, 166256) prevalent prejudice and, therefore, suggests that the inner portion of the tram cars may be reserved for Europeans only.
('5', 69, 1, 3, 166377) That would leave the roofs free to the other communities.
('5', 69, 1, 4, 166435) Indeed, there is no reason why compartments may not be made even in the inner portions of the tram cars, but failing that, my Association trusts that the suggestion above made will be accepted by the Town Council.
('5', 69, 1, 5, 166649) I am to place on record that, as the position stands at present, Coloured people are by law perfectly free to make use of the municipal tram cars.
('5', 69, 1, 6, 166796) It is only their forbearance which prevents them from making use of the cars.
('5', 69, 1, 7, 166874) I have the honour to remain, Sir, Your obedient servant, ABDUL GANI CHAIRMAN, BRITISH INDIAN ASSOCIATION The following are the recommendations of the General Manager above referred to:
('5', 69, 2, 8, 167059) 1. That Coloured people should be allowed to travel on the same cars as white persons when they are domestic servants and are with their master or mistress, and that they be required to sit only on the top of the car and occupy the back seats arranged at the head of each staircase, viz., on the four seats at each end.
('5', 69, 2, 9, 167379) To be charged ordinary fares.
('5', 69, 3, 10, 167409) 2. That, where traffic is sufficient on any route to pay to run special cars for Coloured people, arrangements be made for Asiatics to occupy the inside of the cars and Kaffirs the outside, or vice versa.
('5', 69, 3, 11, 167614) This to be experimented
('5', 69, 4, 12, 167638) with on the Fordsburg and Newtown lines.
('5', 69, 5, 13, 167679) 3. Should it be found later that the Coloured traffic is not sufficient to enable special cars to be run at a profit, experiments be made with single deck trailer cars coupled on to ordinary cars, and that this trailer type of car and also ordinary cars used for Coloured people be used for the parcels delivery business, which it is proposed to inaugurate at a later date.

('5', 69, 6, 15, 168079) 63. LORD SELBORNE ON CHRISTIANS AND MAHOMEDANS Lord Selborne is reported to have said at a Church meeting recently:
('5', 69, 7, 16, 168195) It seems to me that men of our race forget two things, and they are thereby often accused of caring much less about religion than they really do.
('5', 69, 7, 17, 168341) They are too careless about those observances which mark their religion, and they are too shy to let it be known, publicly, on which side they stand.
('5', 70, 0, 1, 168491) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 71
('5', 70, 1, 2, 168537) often happened to me that a friend of mine travelling in the East has been struck with the Mahomedan, who, wherever he is at a certain time of the day, will spread out his carpet and kneel down and pray; and he has argued from that that the Mahomedan is a much better man than the Christian.
('5', 70, 1, 3, 168829) The conclusion is not borne out by facts.
('5', 70, 1, 4, 168871) The probability was that the Mahomedan was a much worse man than most Christians; but he grasped one fact, which we are too apt to forget: that if a man wants to have an influence in the world he must not be afraid of public opinion, and he must not hesitate to let it be known on which side he stands.
('5', 70, 1, 5, 169174) If His Excellency has been correctly reported, we fear he has been guilty of a grave indiscretion.
('5', 70, 1, 6, 169273) “The probability was that the Mahomedan was a much worse man than most Christians” is not a statement that should be made by the King Emperor’s representative in speaking of the King Emperor’s Mahomedan subjects.
('5', 70, 1, 7, 169486) Owing to his position, His Excellency has not the same liberty of speech that can be claimed by lesser mortals, and a remark of this nature coming from him is calculated to cause pain to many followers of the Prophet.
('5', 70, 1, 8, 169704) But indiscretion is not characteristic of Lord Selborne’s public utterances, and it is only fair to point out that he may have been badly reported, and that, instead of saying, “The probability was”, he may have said, “It was possible” In the latter case, the remark would be quite unexceptionable.
('5', 70, 1, 9, 170003) Up to the present, however, we have not heard that His Excellency has corrected the statement.

('5', 74, 5, 13, 176745) 68. A REPLY TO “THE LEADER”
('5', 74, 6, 14, 176773) JOHANNESBURG, February 16, 1906
('5', 74, 7, 15, 176805) TO THE EDITOR The Leader
('5', 74, 8, 16, 176830) SIR, I take the liberty of offering a few remarks on your leaderette concerning the letter of my Association addressed to the Town Clerk, 1 on the question of the use of the tram cars by my countrymen.
('5', 74, 9, 17, 177032) 1 Vide “Letter to Town Clerk”, 10 2 1906
('5', 75, 0, 1, 177073) 76 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 75, 1, 2, 177114) have written in anger and have used threats.
('5', 75, 1, 3, 177159) I cannot do either, but will venture to place some facts before you for your acceptance or refutation: (1) My Association never contended that all Indians should be allowed to make use of the tram cars.
('5', 75, 1, 4, 177362) The right is claimed only for those who are well and cleanly dressed.
('5', 75, 1, 5, 177432) (2) Whatever may be the position in India, I need hardly demonstrate to you that no man is born a “coolie”, and that the only test, so far as the use of the tram cars is concerned, can be the personal appearance of the passengers.
('5', 75, 1, 6, 177663) (3) Does it not appear to you a little preposterous to raise the question of equality between the two races on the tramway question?
('5', 75, 1, 7, 177796) (4) My Association has emphatically disclaimed any intention toseek the contact of any unwilling Europeans, even with the most cultured Indians, and has, therefore, suggested that the inner portion of the cars may be reserved exclusively for Europeans.
('5', 75, 1, 8, 178049) The roofs of the cars, it is contended, may, without infringing upon the sacred doctrine of “inequality”, be legitimately used by Indians who are properly dressed.
('5', 75, 1, 9, 178213) (5) The point made by my Association about forbearance is quite logical.
('5', 75, 1, 10, 178286) “The will of the people”, so far as it has been reduced to law, as my Association has been advised, leaves it open to Indians to claim the right of riding on the tram cars.
('5', 75, 1, 11, 178459) The claim, therefore, as it is legal, can hardly be considered to be “absurd”.
('5', 75, 1, 12, 178538) In this connection, may I ask you a few questions?
('5', 75, 1, 13, 178589) Is it logical for the white people in the Transvaal, as soon as they go to Cape Town or Natal, to ride side by side with Coloured people?
('5', 75, 1, 14, 178727) Is it logical that Coloured servants who may not belong to “the higher castes”, whatever that phrase may mean, should ride on the tram cars?
('5', 75, 1, 15, 178868) Is it logical, as Mr. Soutter said at the Town Council meeting, that white men who drive in dog carts should sit next to their Coloured drivers?
('5', 75, 1, 16, 179013) My Association takes its stand upon the policy outlined by Mr. Chamberlain before the Conference of Colonial Premiers 1 at the time of the Diamond Jubilee.
('5', 75, 1, 17, 179169) The Right Hon.
('5', 75, 1, 18, 179184) Gentleman said:
('5', 75, 2, 19, 179200) We also ask to bear in mind the traditions of the Empire, which makes no distinction in favour of or against race or colour, and to exclude, by reason of their colour or by reason of their race, all Her Majesty’s Indian subjects, or even all Asiatics, would be an act so offensive to those peoples, that it would be most painful to Her Majesty to have to sanction it....
('5', 75, 2, 20, 179571) It is not because a man is of a different colour from ours that he is necessarily an undesirable
('5', 75, 3, 21, 179668) 1 In 1897;
('5', 76, 0, 1, 179679) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 77
('5', 76, 1, 2, 179725) immigrant, but it is because he is dirty, or he is immoral, or he is a pauper, or he has some other objection which can be defined in an Act of Parliament, and by which exclusion can be managed with regard to all those whom you really desire to exclude.

('5', 76, 2, 4, 180065) 69. TRANSVAAL INDIANS AND PERMITS
('5', 76, 3, 5, 180099) The lot of the British Indian in the Transvaal is undoubtedly very uncertain and very unhappy.
('5', 76, 3, 6, 180194) The letter we reproduce in another column, 1 addressed by the Chairman of the British Indian Association to the Colonial Secretary of the Transvaal, is painful reading.
('5', 76, 3, 7, 180363) The permit regulations in connection with Indians have been changed from time to time,much to their inconvenience.
('5', 76, 3, 8, 180478) The latest instance, however, is in the nature of a “surprise packet”.
('5', 76, 3, 9, 180549) The regulations referred to in the letter in question, according to Mr. Abdul Gani, have been sprung upon the community without any notice, and these regulations are, if the information given to Mr. Abdul Gani be true, applicable to all Indians.
('5', 76, 3, 10, 180795) The result will be that those who have arrived in South Africa, without notice of any such regulations, will be adversely affected.
('5', 76, 3, 11, 180927) Natal may afford them no protection, nor may the Cape.
('5', 76, 3, 12, 180982) They will have come with the deliberate intention of entering the Transvaal, and if the regulations in question are to be enforced, and are to have retrospective effect, they will cause illness, trouble, expense, and worry to the persons concerned.
('5', 76, 3, 13, 181231) The least that one expects in a British colony, or any British dominion, is that laws are framed with due deliberation and after fair warning.
('5', 76, 3, 14, 181374) Even the self governing colonies of the Cape or Natal, when they passed the Immigration Restriction Laws, gave fair warning to the people concerned, and then, after the legislation was passed, it was not rigorously enforced immediately.
('5', 76, 3, 15, 181611) They gave the steamship companies, and the community affected thereby, time to study the legislation in its actual working.
('5', 76, 3, 16, 181735) The Cape authorities have only just given notice of their intention to fully enforce the laws, that is to say, two years after they were passed.
('5', 76, 3, 17, 181880) In the Transvaal, they evidently believe in “rushing” things.
('5', 76, 3, 18, 181942) The Peace Preservation Ordinance is a
('5', 76, 4, 19, 181980) 1 Vide”Letter to Colonial Secretary”, 9 2 1906
('5', 77, 0, 1, 182027) 78 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 77, 1, 2, 182068) relic of the martial law period and, therefore, gives arbitrary authority to the Government.
('5', 77, 1, 3, 182161) The use of such authority, during the period of war, is often justifiable, but when there is peace in the Transvaal, to invoke the assistance of that Ordinance against an inoffensive community, in the manner described in the letter to which we have referred, savours very much of Russian methods rather than of methods that are associated with the British Constitution.
('5', 77, 1, 4, 182531) When we come to examine the regulations themselves, they are without doubt very irksome.
('5', 77, 1, 5, 182620) The age of minority for children seems to have been suddenly reduced to under twelve years, and henceforth orphans, whose relatives may be settled in the Transvaal, will not be allowed to enter the Transvaal at all.
('5', 77, 1, 6, 182836) Moreover, in the regulations, instead of the same official examining the witnesses who may be produced in support of the claim of a refugee, the authority to do so will be relegated to magistrates in the various districts, and all refugees, even after investigation is completed, will have to go to Pretoria in order to perform the mechanical act of receiving their permits.
('5', 77, 1, 7, 183211) His Excellency Lord Selborne said only the other day to the Indian deputation that all restrictive regulations had to be reasonable in order to be acceptable and effective.
('5', 77, 1, 8, 183384) Can such regulations as these, by any conceivable stretch of the imagination, be held to be reasonable ?
('5', 77, 1, 9, 183489) Indian Opinion, 17 2 1906
('5', 77, 2, 10, 183515) 70. JOHANNESBURG TRAMS AND INDIANS
('5', 77, 3, 11, 183550) Elsewhere will be found printed a letter addressed to the Town Clerk, 1 Johannesburg, by the Chairman of the British Indian Association at Johannesburg, with reference to the proposed regulations for the use of the electric tram cars by Coloured people.
('5', 77, 3, 12, 183804) We have no hesitation in endorsing Mr. Abdul Gani’s plea.
('5', 77, 3, 13, 183862) The recommendations made by the General Manager are very arbitrary, and the fact that they have been withdrawn temporarily need not lull Indians into a false sense of security, for they have been withdrawn, not because the Town Council is actuated by any greater regard for Indians than the General Manager, but because the time, so it is said, is not ripe, as the tram cars are not to run for some time.
('5', 77, 3, 14, 184267) The use of the public tram cars in Johannesburg, as elsewhere, is a question, not merely of sentiment, but of pecuniary importance.
('5', 77, 3, 15, 184399) Indian businessmen, and other Coloured people, have as great a right to public conveyances as any other community of Johannesburg.
('5', 77, 3, 16, 184530) They form part of the body politic; they are called upon to bear the
('5', 77, 4, 17, 184599) 1 Vide “Letter to Town Clerk”, 20 2 1906
('5', 78, 0, 1, 184640) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 79
('5', 78, 1, 2, 184686) burdens of citizenship by way of payment of taxation, etc., and the Johannesburg municipality finds it difficult to deprive them of the right of using the municipal tram cars.
('5', 78, 1, 3, 184862) Any regulations that may be passed will have to be sanctioned by the Lieutenant Governor; and let us hope that, should the regulations, to which we have drawn public attention, be ever sent to His Excellency, he will have no hesitation in exercising his right of veto.

('5', 81, 5, 10, 192146) Send only those about which you are doubtful.
('5', 81, 5, 11, 192192) It will suffice to observe the following rules in most cases: (1) we should as a rule publish all letters against us, for instance, those of Habib Motan and Haji Habib; (2) we should be chary of long harangues; (3) we should consider who the correspondent is.
('5', 81, 5, 12, 192452) If we feel that his contribution must be accepted, it should be abridged, if lengthy; (4) we should take letters giving local news.

('5', 82, 5, 19, 194409) 75. BRITISH INDIANS IN SOUTH AFRICA 1
('5', 82, 6, 20, 194447) STATEMENT REGARDING BRITISH INDIANS IN THE TRANSVAAL AND THE ORANGE RIVER COLONY JOHANNESBURG, February 22, 1906 Now that the new Government has been established, the Letters Patent have been withdrawn, and a new Constitution is being drawn up, both with [regard to] the Transvaal and the Orange River Colony, it seems to me imperatively necessary to place the Indian question
('5', 82, 7, 21, 194824) 1 This statement was sent by Gandhiji to Dadabhai Naoroji, who forwarded a copy to the Secretary of State for India on March 20.
('5', 83, 0, 1, 194953) 84 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 83, 1, 2, 194994) prominently before the new Government.
('5', 83, 1, 3, 195033) It is felt that the ordinary clauses about the right of veto being reserved for the Crown, and any class legislation being reserved forRoyal sanction, are not enough.
('5', 83, 1, 4, 195200) Seeing that there is intense prejudice against Coloured people, almost bordering on mania, these time honoured clauses, which are only on the rarest occasions put into operation, can never meet the case.
('5', 83, 1, 5, 195404) If responsible Government is granted without due regard for the protection of British Indians, their position under it would be infinitely worse than it is today.
('5', 83, 1, 6, 195567) Experience of Natal shows that disfranchisement of a class in a community enjoying self government means its complete effacement.
('5', 83, 1, 7, 195697) Only those members are elected who would represent the feeling of the electors.
('5', 83, 1, 8, 195777) Some effective representation must, therefore, be granted to British Indians, or the civil rights of the resident Indian population should be otherwise fully protected.
('5', 83, 1, 9, 195946) The position in the Transvaal is becoming daily worse.
('5', 83, 1, 10, 196001) Permit restrictions are applied only to Indians and are exceedingly irksome, as will appear from the pages of Indian Opinion.
('5', 83, 1, 11, 196127) The Railway administration have now begun to prohibit Coloured people from making use of certain train services entirely.
('5', 83, 1, 12, 196249) It can easily be imagined what it must mean to British Indian traders who require to use the trains constantly.
('5', 83, 1, 13, 196361) Johannesburg is a place of big distances.
('5', 83, 1, 14, 196403) There has just been established an electric tram service.
('5', 83, 1, 15, 196461) Coloured people, who can ill afford cab fares, are practically prohibited from using these tram cars.
('5', 83, 1, 16, 196563) These are not sentimental matters but are such as to affect the British Indian community vitally.
('5', 83, 1, 17, 196661) Unless a firm stand is taken up by the Home Government, at the rate at which things are now going, what little Indians enjoyed under Boer rule will be lost.
('5', 83, 1, 18, 196818) The prohibition against ownership of land, special registration fee of £3, foot path regulation, etc., still continue to disfigure the Statute book of the Transvaal.
('5', 83, 1, 19, 196984) As to the Orange River Colony, the old law prohibiting the entry of any Indians, except such as accept domestic service, is still prevalent, and by laws are being framed all over that Colony further restricting the movements of those who may be in that Colony.

('5', 84, 6, 23, 198910) 77. THE KING’S SPEECH
('5', 84, 7, 24, 198932) Perhaps within the memory of living men, the King’s Speech has never been looked forward to with so much anxiety or
('5', 84, 8, 25, 199048) 1 This is not available.
('5', 85, 0, 1, 199073) 86 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 85, 1, 2, 199114) expectation, according to the persons concerned, as that which was delivered during the current week by King Edward at the opening of the Imperial Parliament, and there is no doubt that it is a pronouncement of far reaching importance.
('5', 85, 1, 3, 199350) The anxiety of those who fear the Liberal policy will be deepened, and the expectations of those who had hoped much of the liberals will, so far as promises are concerned, be satisfied.
('5', 85, 1, 4, 199536) India will be disappointed.
('5', 85, 1, 5, 199564) The only mention there is to be found about India is that the papers in connection with the army administration will be published.
('5', 85, 1, 6, 199695) There is no reference to the partition of Bengal; none, if the cablegram sent gives a full summary, regarding famine; but we have every reason to believe that, with a Radical Premier 1 at the helm, and with a statesman of Mr. John Morley’s ability at the head of the India Office, India will not be altogether neglected.
('5', 85, 1, 7, 200016) The subject, however, of immediate importance to us is how far the withdrawal of the Letters Patent and the proposed immediate grant of Responsible Government, both to the Transvaal and the Orange River Colony, will affect the position of British Indians in those parts of South Africa.
('5', 85, 1, 8, 200303) The Constitution, it is but fair to assume, to be drafted by the Liberal Ministers, will be as favourable as possible to the white settlers.
('5', 85, 1, 9, 200444) It cannot be otherwise.
('5', 85, 1, 10, 200468) They will be given fullest possible control over their internal affairs.
('5', 85, 1, 11, 200541) The same Liberal principles should also dictate a policy of full protection for the rights of weaker parties, and the first consideration, therefore, we take it, should be given to the question of Indian representation.
('5', 85, 1, 12, 200761) Under a fully representative government, to leave the Indians totally unrepresented will be to hand them over to the tender care of legislators, who will have no mercy for them, because they will have no interest in the welfare of their proteges.
('5', 85, 1, 13, 201008) The result of non representation, in spite of the late Sir John Robinson’s eloquent plea 2, that under such a system every member would be a member for Indians, has been very unfavourable in Natal.
('5', 85, 1, 14, 201206) If the constitution that will be drafted leaves the Indians out of consideration, there will be an end to all expectation of justice ever being received in the two Colonies mentioned.
('5', 85, 1, 15, 201390) There is a wave of agitation hostile to Indian interests passing through the Transvaal.
('5', 85, 1, 16, 201478) The Orange River Colony simply shuts its gates in the faces of Indians, and if the control of legislation regarding them is given over to responsible legislators in the respective Colonies, all the difficulties that are now being
('5', 85, 2, 17, 201708) 1 Sir Henry Campbell Bannerman, Prime Minister of England, 1905 8 2 Vide “The Plague”, 9 7 1903
('5', 86, 0, 1, 201804) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 87
('5', 86, 1, 2, 201850) experienced by Indians will be accentuated.
('5', 86, 1, 3, 201894) There will be reserved in the two constitutions the time honoured veto, and the clause regarding non European races; but in practice these reservations have proved very ineffective, as British Ministers have always felt reluctant to advise His Majesty to exercise the veto.
('5', 86, 1, 4, 202168) Under the circumstances, if Indians are to be considered as a part of the Empire, equally important as the other races, we consider it to be imperatively necessary that their claims, as indeed also those of the other weaker races, should be specifically guarded.
('5', 86, 1, 5, 202431) Indian Opinion, 24 2 1906
('5', 86, 2, 6, 202457) 78. BRITISH INDIANS IN THE TRANSVAAL The lot of the British Indian is by no means enviable.
('5', 86, 2, 7, 202549) He is being hemmed in on all sides by restrictions of the most galling nature.
('5', 86, 2, 8, 202628) If he is a domiciled resident of the Transvaal and wishes to enter this country, he is met with disappointment at every step, and he is in a position to make good his claim only if he has an abundance of patience and money.
('5', 86, 2, 9, 202852) Before he can get a permit to reside in the country, he is driven about from pillar to post.
('5', 86, 2, 10, 202945) He has to submit to a most searching investigation, and his word is accounted for nothing, so that he has to supplement it by evidence of witnesses and of documents, before he can set his foot upon the sacred soil of the Transvaal.
('5', 86, 2, 11, 203177) If he happens to have his wife with him, he is called upon to prove that he is her husband.
('5', 86, 2, 12, 203269) If he has his children with him, no matter how young they may be, they must have separate permits, and he must prove that he is their father.
('5', 86, 2, 13, 203411) If his children are not under twelve, they cannot accompany him on any account whatsoever.
('5', 86, 2, 14, 203502) These are the preliminaries an Indian has to undergo before he is allowed to re enter the Transvaal, which is his place of adoption.
('5', 86, 2, 15, 203635) What does he find after he reaches the country?
('5', 86, 2, 16, 203683) The report of the Johannesburg Town Council meeting, in connection with the electric tram cars, shows clearly what is in store for him.
('5', 86, 2, 17, 203819) If he were a servant of a white master, he would be allowed to make use of the tram cars, otherwise he is not to be allowed to make use of the ordinary cars.
('5', 86, 2, 18, 203977) The speeches made at the Town Council meeting make very fine reading, but they are also very painful.
('5', 86, 2, 19, 204079) On a matter of simple convenience for travelling, the whole of the question of equality of races was raised by several speakers.
('5', 86, 2, 20, 204208) If a Coloured man makes any attempt to get justice, the cry is immediately raised that he wants to claim equality with the white men in the Transvaal.
('5', 86, 2, 21, 204359) The position is simply ludicrous.
('5', 86, 2, 22, 204393) Here is a vigorous community in Johannesburg.
('5', 86, 2, 23, 204439) It is full of enterprise, pluck, and resource.

('5', 87, 1, 3, 204639) The people of Johannesburg are afraid that their predominance and superiority will be in danger if Coloured people travel on the same cars with themselves.
('5', 87, 1, 4, 204795) This reminds us of the scare of a mutiny that used to exist when Lord Ellenborough was the Governor General of India.

('5', 88, 2, 7, 207745) 79. A RESTRICTION WAVE
('5', 88, 3, 8, 207768) It seems that, all the world over, different States are pursuing a policy of restriction.
('5', 88, 3, 9, 207858) Thirty years ago, the then President 1 of the American Republic laid down the doctrine that everyone was welcome to America, and that on his putting his foot on American soil, he became a citizen.
('5', 88, 3, 10, 208055) Today, America follows a different policy.
('5', 88, 3, 11, 208098) Even England has considered it necessary to restrict immigration of aliens, and we read, in the cablegrams in the daily newspapers, that several Jews, who fled from Russian oppression, were only the other day prevented from entering England, and that one of them said that, rather than return to Russia, to avoid which he had spent his last penny, he would kill himself.
('5', 88, 3, 12, 208469) The Natal Government Gazette of the 13th inst.
('5', 88, 3, 13, 208516) published a translation of an Order by the German South West African Protectorate.
('5', 88, 3, 14, 208599) Under it ‘immigration into the German South West African Protectorate may be prohibited by the competent authorities”, if an immigrant is, amongst other things, a Coloured man; there are the other usual prohibitive clauses.
('5', 88, 3, 15, 208823) Thus, the colour problem is making itself felt in one way or another throughout Africa.
('5', 88, 3, 16, 208911) It is useful to recall, in this connection, the fact that it was the GermanEmperor who, some time ago, gave currency to the idea that in the victory of Japan lay the germs of an attempt to secure yellow predominance.
('5', 88, 3, 17, 209128) Though it is still accepted in certain quarters on the Continent, the general notion is that the German Emperor was indiscreet in having made such an utterance, and that there Was no such fear.
('5', 88, 3, 18, 209322) At the same time, if there is to be war against colour As such on the part of the great European nations, it is impossible to say that Japan, at any rate, will always sit still under the open insult offered to her citizens.
('5', 88, 3, 19, 209546) It would be illogical for Europe to accept Japan as afirst class power and at the same time treat her inhabitants as if they
('5', 88, 4, 20, 209671) 1 Ulysses Seymour Grant (1822 85), 18th President of the United States, 1869 77. The 15th amendment to the Constitution adopted on March 30, 1870 provides that suffrage should not be restricted on account of race, colour or previous condition of servitude.

('5', 89, 2, 4, 210013) 80. A PERMIT PILLORY
('5', 89, 3, 5, 210034) We hear and read so much about the difficulties that are placed in the way of the poor refugees getting their permits to enter the Transvaal, that we have decided from next week to open a column under the above heading, wherein we shall be pleased to publish the names of all those British Indian refugees whose applications are more than two months old, and who are still without their permits.
('5', 89, 3, 6, 210430) Not that we consider two months to be at all a reasonable time required for consideration of such applications, but as we hear that there are many applications which are over six months old, we have decided to choose the greater evil, and give it publicity.
('5', 89, 3, 7, 210688) Comparatively, applications two months old may, at present, be considered normal, but as for older applications, we have no hesitation in saying that their very age shows an utter want of regard on the part of the authorities for the interests of the refugees.
('5', 89, 3, 8, 210949) We would, therefore, ask all those who are suffering from the vagaries of the permit administration in the Transvaal to help themselves by supplying us with their names, addresses, and the dates of their applications.
('5', 89, 3, 9, 211167) We do not say that all these men are bona fide refugees, but we do say that they are all entitled to a definite, clear answer, so that they may not have to remain in a state of suspense.
('5', 89, 3, 10, 211354) In some cases, we understand, they are holders of registration certificates issued to them under the old Dutch Government.
('5', 89, 3, 11, 211477) They are now exiles from their own adopted land.
('5', 89, 3, 12, 211526) Lord Selborne has made two promises, one to the white community, namely, that no non refugee Indian will be allowed to settle in the Transvaal.
('5', 89, 3, 13, 211670) This promise is being religiously observed.
('5', 89, 3, 14, 211714) The other promise was made by His Excellency to the Indian community, namely, that all applications of the refugees will receive the earliest attention, and that they will receive full facilities for entering the country.
('5', 89, 3, 15, 211936) If the information at our disposal be correct, the latter promise has still to be redeemed.
('5', 89, 3, 16, 212028) We hope that our readers will help us to clear up a situation that has become intolerable.
('5', 89, 3, 17, 212119) Indian Opinion, 24 2 1906

('5', 91, 3, 4, 213820) TRAMWAY CASE
('5', 91, 4, 5, 213833) The tramway has become nowadays a subject of much discussion among the Indians of Johannesburg.
('5', 91, 4, 6, 213929) Many Indians live at Fordsburg, and there is an electric tram service between that place and the Market Square.
('5', 91, 4, 7, 214041) The people, therefore, naturally ask why Indians should not be allowed to use the tram.
('5', 91, 4, 8, 214129) The authorities too find it difficult to prevent the Coloured people from using the tram car.
('5', 91, 4, 9, 214223) The proposals put forward by the Johannesburg Committee have been brushed aside, and tram cars with the label saying that they are open to use by Coloured people are now being run.
('5', 91, 4, 10, 214404) On the one hand, the whites say that they have an aversion to travelling with Indians, while, on the other, one finds many whites sitting with Coloured people in tram cars with the above label.
('5', 91, 4, 11, 214598) Arrangements are in progress to file a test case in this regard in the name of Mr. Coovadia.
('5', 91, 4, 12, 214691) With a view to making a test case, Mr. Coovadia accompanied by Mr. MacIntyre 2 boarded a tram car without the above label.
('5', 91, 4, 13, 214814) He was allowed to travel in that one; but, as he was boarding another, the conductor told him that he could have a seat only if he was a servant of Mr. MacIntyre; but that he would not be allowed to do so as a private gentleman.
('5', 91, 4, 14, 215043) The matter is being discussed in the Press also.
('5', 91, 4, 15, 215092) Mr. Daruwala addressed a letter to The Star, to which a white gentleman wrote a perverse reply.
('5', 91, 4, 16, 215188) To this Mr. Daruwala has sent a good rejoinder.
('5', 91, 4, 17, 215236) Moreover, two other whites have written on the subject, one supporting and the other opposing Mr. Daruwala.
('5', 91, 5, 18, 215344) RESPONSIBLE GOVERNMENT FOR THE TRANSVAAL
('5', 91, 6, 19, 215385) The British whites have been agitated over the news that the Transvaal would shortly get responsible government.
('5', 91, 6, 20, 215498) For it is feared that responsible government will mean greater power for the Dutch, which will adversely affect the mining interests.
('5', 91, 6, 21, 215632) However, the building activity in Johannesburg, which continues unabated, shows that the people here are not discouraged and are still clinging to the country in the hope that they will prosper.
('5', 91, 6, 22, 215827) Trade is very sluggish and will become yet more sluggish.
('5', 91, 6, 23, 215885) Formerly, the Kaffirs and the Dutch made
('5', 91, 7, 24, 215926) 1 These despatches were published regularly in Indian Opinion as from its Johannesburg correspondent.
('5', 91, 7, 25, 216028) 2 A Scottish theosophist clerk articled to Gandhiji
