('5', 92, 1, 2, 216126) many money transactions every Saturday.
('5', 92, 1, 3, 216166) The Dutch are now reduced to poverty and the Kaffirs do not now spend as freely as before.
('5', 92, 2, 4, 216257) REPRESENTATION TO LORD SELBORNE
('5', 92, 3, 5, 216289) The British Indian Association has addressed Lord Selborne on permits, the tramway and the railway.
('5', 92, 3, 6, 216389) To this he has replied personally over his own signature, saying that he would write again after a full inquiry into all the three questions.
('5', 92, 3, 7, 216531) It is to be hoped that Lord Selborne will do something to redress these grievances.
('5', 92, 4, 8, 216615) MALAY LOCATION
('5', 92, 5, 9, 216630) The condition of the Malay Location has become disgraceful.
('5', 92, 5, 10, 216690) The place is full of filth.
('5', 92, 5, 11, 216718) People stint and huddle together in single rooms.
('5', 92, 5, 12, 216768) The latrines and the courtyards stink badly.
('5', 92, 5, 13, 216813) Plague is sure to break out under these conditions, if it should rain continuously for a long time.
('5', 92, 5, 14, 216913) The matter needs to be seriously considered by thoughtful men.
('5', 92, 5, 15, 216976) It would not be enough for people to keep their own houses clean, but they should persuade others also to do likewise.
('5', 92, 5, 16, 217095) If they do not, they will not only lose the Malay Location as they did the Indian Location, but they will be required to go and live in Klipspruit, thirteen miles away.
('5', 92, 5, 17, 217264) It is no use expecting that the authorities will take special care to keep the Location clean.
('5', 92, 5, 18, 217359) If anything, it is in their interest that our houses remain as unclean as possible, so that they can accuse us of uncleanliness and have us removed.
('5', 92, 6, 19, 217508) NEW MOSQUE AT JOHANNESBURG
('5', 92, 7, 20, 217535) For many years now there has been only one mosque in Johannesburg for Indian Muslims.
('5', 92, 7, 21, 217621) But the Surati Memons have raised a large fund and bought a piece of land in their locality, where preparations are going on for building another mosque.
('5', 92, 8, 22, 217775) TRAM CARS
('5', 92, 9, 23, 217785) Dr. Krause, a member of the Town Council here, met his voters recently and told them that he would, if he could, prevent Indians and other Coloureds from using the tram cars; but that was not legally possible, and so he could not oppose their using the trams.

('5', 93, 2, 3, 218156) DURBAN, [February 28, 1906] We the members of the Natal Indian Congress cannot allow the occasion of your impending departure for India to pass without placing on record our sense of regard for the work you have done during your presidency of the Congress for the Indian community.
('5', 93, 2, 4, 218438) You succeeded a President, who, by his energy, had done a great deal of work for the Congress, and we have no hesitation in saying that the mantle fell worthily on your shoulders.
('5', 93, 2, 5, 218618) You have contributed not a little to the financial stability which the Congress at present enjoys.
('5', 93, 2, 6, 218717) During your presidency we have fought many a political battle, and we have found you always a willing leader amidst all the troubles.
('5', 93, 2, 7, 218851) You have presided over the deliberation[s] of the Congress meeting[s] always with tact and prudence, and you have always responded, in your capacity as leader of the community, to the many calls on your purse.
('5', 93, 2, 8, 219061) As you are now going to India to enjoy well earned rest, we wish you and yours may have a happy and successful sojourn in the land of our birth.
('5', 93, 2, 9, 219206) And we hope that you will soon be amongst us again and resume your work for the good of our community.

('5', 95, 0, 1, 222436) 96 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 95, 1, 2, 222477) 87. INDIANS AND RESPONSIBLE GOVERNMENT 1
('5', 95, 2, 3, 222518) The Transvaal would receive the fullest and most complete form of Responsible Government; therefore, the competence of the Transvaal to decide whether it would allow Chinese labour on the mines and farms and exercise control over the industry generally was indisputable; but it was essential that it should not inherit the present Ordinance.
('5', 95, 2, 4, 222860) It would beimpolitic and disrespectful to insert in the new Constitution any disability that would seem to suggest that we expect the Transvaal to act contrary to our notions of fight, but it was proposed, under the power that was reserved in the Constitution of every self government Colony, to instruct the Governor that any measure dealing with imported labour must be reserved for the consideration and assent of the Imperial Parliament.
('5', 95, 2, 5, 223302) Legislation corresponding to the present Ordinance might be vetoed, though he did not anticipate such a contingency.
('5', 95, 2, 6, 223419) These are the expressions used by Mr. Asquith during the Chinese debate, and they place the position of the Home Government regarding a question analogous to the Indian question in a nutshell.
('5', 95, 2, 7, 223612) The Chinese Labour Ordinance is in conflict with the Imperial traditions; so is the Indian legislation, only the latter is much more objectionable and easier to do away with, in that it is an inheritance from the Dutch Government, whereas the former is a creation of the now defunct British Government, yet there is no hesitation, on the part of the Liberal Chancellor of the Exchequer, in saying that it should not be left to the incoming Responsible Government in the Transvaal as a legacy.
('5', 95, 2, 8, 224105) It then, “the fullest and most complete form of Responsible Government” is to be granted to the Transvaal, it follows that a clean slate should be presented to it, so far as anti Asiatic legislation is concerned.
('5', 95, 2, 9, 224318) As Sir William Wedderburn most clearly put it to Mr. Chamberlain two years ago, it is the duty of the Imperial Government to do away with such measures of the Dutch Government as contributed to provoke the war, and then leave it open to the Transvaalers to bring in any legislation they choose for the consideration of the Home Government.
('5', 95, 2, 10, 224658) Unless the suggestion be adopted, the only other manner in which the Indian position can be saved is to insert a protective clause in the new Constitution, in addition to the general clause as to the right of veto.
('5', 95, 2, 11, 224873) To do so would, in the words of Mr. Asquith, be impolitic and disrespectful, as it would be suggestive of a charge against the Transvaal of wishing to “act contrary to” Imperial “notions of right”.
('5', 95, 2, 12, 225071) If a policy of laissez faire
('5', 95, 3, 13, 225100) 1 This was also published in India, 6 4 1906.
('5', 96, 0, 1, 225146) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 97
('5', 96, 1, 2, 225192) be followed regarding this question by the Imperial Government, and anti Indian legislation be not repealed before the grant of Responsible Government, it would be quite competent for the latter to refuse to blot out what the Crown Government dared not touch.
('5', 96, 1, 3, 225452) It is better, even at the risk of repetition, to examine the Indian position.
('5', 96, 1, 4, 225530) Indians have always asked for the repeal of Law 3 of 1885 and other laws and by laws which are specifically aimed at Asiatics, but they have always qualified this demand by an emphatic declaration that they do not wish to flood the country, as it has been said, with Indians, nor do they wish to usurp the trade, especially the Kaffir trade, from the whites.
('5', 96, 1, 5, 225889) They have asked for a fair field and no favour.
('5', 96, 1, 6, 225937) To show their bona fides, they have accepted the principle of restrictive legislation of a general character.
('5', 96, 1, 7, 226047) An Immigration Restriction Act, on the lines adopted by the Cape or Natal, so long as it recognises the principal Indian languages, and leaves it open to import men necessary for the conduct of existing businesses, will completely meet the case, so far as the entry of new men is concerned.
('5', 96, 1, 8, 226338) With reference to trade, Indians have suggested that control over new trade licences should be given to the local bodies, their decisions to be subject to review by the Supreme Court.
('5', 96, 1, 9, 226522) This is the farthest limit to which restriction can be legitimately carried.
('5', 96, 1, 10, 226599) It is trade jealousy and the spectre of an Indian invasion that are at the bottom of anti Asiatic agitation.
('5', 96, 1, 11, 226708) These two “dangers” being removed, there can be no justification for any further curtailment of the liberty of the Indian, or for subjecting him to “unnecessary affront”.
('5', 96, 1, 12, 226879) It would certainly be inconsistent with British notions of right to continue to deprive Indians of the right to own landed property, to move about freely, and otherwise to treat them as helots.
('5', 96, 1, 13, 227073) Indian Opinion, 3 3 1906
('5', 96, 2, 14, 227098) 88. INDIAN TRADERS AT THE CAPE We gladly make room for our Cape correspondent’s letter, in reply to our remarks on his strictures on the petty Indian traders at the Cape, published in these columns some time ago.
('5', 96, 2, 15, 227311) We certainly think that the testimony of Sir James Hullett 1 is as applicable to the Cape as it is to Natal.
('5', 96, 2, 16, 227420) The Indian is just the same there as in Natal, and if his trade has benefited Natal generally, it cannot be otherwise at the Cape, where the material conditions are of a similar nature.
('5', 96, 2, 17, 227606) But the chief point we have all along urged is that many of the charges brought against Indian traders by their detractors cannot be sustained.
('5', 96, 2, 18, 227750) We have
('5', 96, 3, 19, 227758) 1 Vide”Memorial to Colonial Secretary”, 3 9 1904
('5', 97, 0, 1, 227807) 98 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 97, 1, 2, 227848) never advocated the policy of flooding any part of South Africa with Indian or any other traders, but we do believe that it is a question capable of adjustment, without restrictive legislation.
('5', 97, 1, 3, 228042) It would certainly help to[wards] a solution, if our correspondent could prepare a comparative statement of the European and the Indian traders in the various districts of the Cape Colony.
('5', 97, 1, 4, 228231) From the information at our disposal, we think that the latter are in a hopeless minority.

('5', 97, 2, 6, 228347) 89. INDIAN TRAVELLERS ON THE C. S. A. R. 1
('5', 97, 3, 7, 228390) A correspondent writes to us in the Gujarati columns that by the train that left Johannesburg for Durban on the evening of the 26th February last, he saw seven Indian passengers, including an Indian lady, accommodated in a single second class compartment.
('5', 97, 3, 8, 228646) He states further that an eighth passenger was added at Germiston, much to the discomfort of the other passengers.
('5', 97, 3, 9, 228761) An ordinary second class compartment is hardly capable of holding more than six Passengers for a night journey— we under stand that the passengers travelling by the night trains are entitled, for long journeys, to sleeping accommodation.
('5', 97, 3, 10, 228999) Our correspondent does not state whether there was an unusual rush on the occasion alluded to by him.
('5', 97, 3, 11, 229101) But be that as it may, we cannot help questioning the propriety of herding together so many passengers when one of them happens to belong to the opposite sex.
('5', 97, 3, 12, 229260) Even an Indian lady is entitled to some consideration in such matters.
('5', 97, 3, 13, 229331) The Indian public have a right to expect the accommodation they pay for.
('5', 97, 3, 14, 229404) It will be a mockery to give them second or first class facilities in name only and deny them in reality.
('5', 97, 3, 15, 229510) We draw the attention of the railway authorities to the complaint made by our correspondent and we do not doubt that they will take the necessary steps to avoid a recurrence of such complaints.
('5', 97, 3, 16, 229704) Indian Opinion, 3 3 1906

('5', 98, 2, 5, 230327) 91. JOHANNESBURG LETTER March 3, 1906
('5', 98, 3, 6, 230365) TRAM CASE By the time this letter appears in print, the tram test case 1 will have been decided.
('5', 98, 3, 7, 230462) After some difficulty, the Crown counsel has admitted the affidavit made by Mr. Coovadia, and issued a summons to the conductor who prevented him from boarding the tram car.
('5', 98, 3, 8, 230636) The case will come up for hearing on March 7. Meanwhile, the contro versy about the tram service is still going on in the Press.
('5', 98, 3, 9, 230765) A white gentleman has sent an insolent reply to Mr. Daruwala, saying that the whites would never allow the Coloured people to sit with them in the trams.
('5', 98, 3, 10, 230919) Others have also written to say that, if the Coloured people were allowed to use the trams, it would be to admit their equality with the whites.
('5', 98, 3, 11, 231064) A couple of persons have been gratuitously writing to the Press in this fashion.
('5', 98, 3, 12, 231145) Meanwhile, the whites use without aversion the tram cars that are especially run for the Coloured people.
('5', 98, 3, 13, 231251) Such is the city’s charm!
('5', 98, 3, 14, 231277) CHINESE LABOUR At present all the people here are exercised over the question whether the Chinese would be allowed to stay on or be driven out.
('5', 98, 3, 15, 231421) Cablegrams from England show that orders have been issued by the Government to send back those Chinese who are not satisfied with their lot in the Colony.
('5', 98, 3, 16, 231576) This has created a panic among the miners and they have tightened their purse strings, with the result that all trade has now become slack.
('5', 98, 3, 17, 231716) Moreover, the Kaffir rebellion in Natal has had its effect on the Kaffirs here.
('5', 98, 3, 18, 231796) There is, therefore, no hope 2 left from any quarter.
('5', 98, 3, 19, 231850) DEPUTATION TO COLONIAL SECRETARY A deputation in connection with permits for the Indians will wait upon the Colonial Secretary.
('5', 98, 3, 20, 231978) It is expected that some relief will certainly be forthcoming.
('5', 98, 3, 21, 232041) An officer is likely to be stationed at Johannesburg to issue permits, etc.

('5', 99, 3, 11, 232888) JOHANNESBURG, Sunday, [March 4, 1906]
('5', 99, 4, 12, 232926) MY DEAR CHHAGANLAL, Do not fail in the slightest degree in doing your duty.
('5', 99, 4, 13, 233002) It is absolutely necessary to bring the accounts up to date.
('5', 99, 4, 14, 233063) The balance sheet should be made up.
('5', 99, 4, 15, 233100) You should take Mr. Bean’s help in correspondence; associate Hemchand with Gujarati.
('5', 99, 4, 16, 233185) It is not at all necessary to keep him in Durban.
('5', 99, 4, 17, 233235) I shan’t be able to send Kalyandas for the present.
('5', 99, 4, 18, 233287) Most likely Brian Gabriel will come.
('5', 99, 4, 19, 233324) It will be good if he does.
('5', 99, 4, 20, 233352) The shortage of men we are experiencing will then cease.
('5', 99, 4, 21, 233409) You alone know best how to lighten your burden.
('5', 99, 4, 22, 233457) It will be enough if you go to Durban only for a day [in the week].
('5', 99, 4, 23, 233525) The main work is the collection of outstandings.
('5', 99, 4, 24, 233574) You should have the same arrangement in the Gujarati section as you have in the English.
('5', 99, 4, 25, 233663) The leading article should come first, followed by the smaller leaders.
('5', 99, 4, 26, 233735) After that should come the translations of articles on important subjects, etc., followed by letters like the “Johannesburg Letter” and last of all, Reuter’s Telegrams.
('5', 99, 4, 27, 233904) The article on the Kaffir rebellion which you had placed first ought not to be there; it should have appeared in the news section.
('5', 99, 4, 28, 234035) As I have entrusted the question of the Kaffir rebellion to you, I do not pay any attention to it.
('5', 99, 4, 29, 234134) But you should study the subject well.
('5', 99, 4, 30, 234173) If you make notes, you will be able to give a column or more of the latest news on Thursday.
('5', 99, 4, 31, 234266) In accordance with the above arrangement, “The Natal Indian Congress” will be the leading article this time.
('5', 99, 4, 32, 234375) We should give the Gujarati “contents” at the end.

('5', 103, 1, 2, 239759) did say that nobody, because he taught or did anything, need feel that he was to go as soon as he finished it, that everybody should consider himself absolutely safe in the Press, so long of course as the Press was not actually starved.
('5', 103, 1, 3, 239996) I do not know whether Mr. Mannering was at that time on the pay basis or whether he was a schemer, but the assurance was not given after Mr. Mannering left the scheme and returned again.
('5', 103, 1, 4, 240183) I believe that when he was taken over I told Chhaganlal—the letter 1 must be in his possession— that if Mr. Mannering was taken back, he should do so on a monthly basis.

('5', 103, 1, 7, 240635) All I wanted to convey was that there was not the slightest intention of driving anyone out when others were raised to take his place.
('5', 103, 1, 8, 240770) To that opinion I adhere even now.
('5', 103, 1, 9, 240805) I do not know what Mr. Mannering intends doing, but so far as I am concerned, I am quite willing that he should remain on at £8 per month, at least up to the end of this year.
('5', 103, 1, 10, 240981) I know that you think that he should get a higher wage, and if the schemers agree, I have not the slightest objection; also if the schemers consent to it, you may treat this letter as binding on me and Mr. Mannering may rest assured that no matter what changes my personal opinions may undergo, he should consider himself a fixture, at least up to the end of this year.
('5', 103, 1, 11, 241351) I am writing to Mr. Mannering also separately in the matter.

('5', 108, 3, 4, 249227) 101. LETTER TO COLONIAL SECRETARY
('5', 108, 4, 5, 249261) [DURBAN, Before March 10, 1906]
('5', 108, 5, 6, 249293) TO THE COLONIAL SECRETARY MARITZBURG,
('5', 108, 6, 7, 249331) SIR, The Committee of the Natal Indian Congress has read with pain and anxiety Government Notice No.
('5', 108, 6, 8, 249432) 150 published in the Natal Government Gazette dated the 27th ultimo, imposing certain fees in connection with various passes and certificates issued under the Immigration Restriction Act No.
('5', 108, 6, 9, 249623) 30 of 1903 as amended by Act 3 of 1906. Our Committee ventures respectfully but strongly to protest against the tariff of fees mentioned in the Notice.
('5', 108, 6, 10, 249775) It is submitted that the fees amount to a tax on British Indians who are entitled to remain in the Colony or to pass through it.
('5', 108, 6, 11, 249904) It is well known that the Act is enforced very largely, if not entirely against British Indians.
('5', 108, 6, 12, 250001) The various passes and certificates issued there under are granted more in the interest of those who desire their enforcement than of those to whom the provisions are applied.
('5', 108, 6, 13, 250177) Our Committee, with the greatest deference, thinks that the fees sought to be imposed are extortionate.
('5', 108, 6, 14, 250281) Our Committee reminds the Government of the fact that, during the lifetime of the late Right Honourable Harry Escombe, an attempt was made to impose a fee of £1 for visitors’ passes.
('5', 108, 6, 15, 250464) A respectful representation was sent thereupon protesting against the imposition and the late Right Honourable Gentleman immediately withdrew the Notice regarding the imposition.
('5', 108, 6, 16, 250643) At that time the Certificate of Domicile was free from the £l fee.
('5', 108, 6, 17, 250710) Our Committee, moreover, draws your attention to the fact that British Indians who may be residing in the inland colonies are at least entitled to a passage through Natal without having to pay a charge of £1 for the privilege of passing through the Colony.
('5', 108, 6, 18, 250967) Indeed, even from a selfish standpoint, the fact that such Indians bring to the Natal Government Railways a certain amount of revenue
('5', 109, 0, 1, 251101) 110 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 109, 1, 2, 251143) should weigh with the Government in not imposing a prohibitive fee.
('5', 109, 1, 3, 251211) Act 3 of 1906 contemplates a reasonable charge of £1. My Committee submits that a charge of £1 for a visiting or embarkation pass or a Certificate of Domicile can never be considered reasonable, and if the wife of a domiciled British Indian is entitled to remain in the Colony or to enter it, and if an Indian who can satisfy the educational test is also, as of right, entitled to enter the Colony, it seems, in the humble opinion of our Committee, not only hard but insulting that either the wife of a domiciled Indian or an educated Indian himself should have to pay what is after all a tax of 5/ for not being a prohibited immigrant within the meaning of the Act.
('5', 109, 1, 4, 251878) Our Committee does not understand the term transit pass.
('5', 109, 1, 5, 251935) Our Committee ventures to trust that the Government will be pleased to withdraw the Notice and allow the charges hitherto imposed to stand.
('5', 109, 1, 6, 252075) Our Committee hopes that your early attention will be given to the complaint as the matter is rather urgent.
('5', 109, 2, 7, 252184) We have the honour to remain,
('5', 109, 4, 8, 252214) your obedient servants, O. H. A. JOHARI M. C. ANGLIA
('5', 109, 5, 9, 252267) JOINT HON.
('5', 109, 5, 10, 252278) SECRETARIES, N. I. C. Indian Opinion, 10 3 1906
('5', 109, 6, 11, 252326) 102. “INFLUX OF ASIATICS”
('5', 109, 7, 12, 252352) The Congress of the Associated Chambers of Commerce of South Africa, that met in Durban last week, has again passed a resolution about Indians.
('5', 109, 7, 13, 252496) Mr. E. F. Bourke, of Pretoria, moved
('5', 109, 8, 14, 252533) that this Congress of Chambers of Commerce of South Africa views with alarm the increasingly detrimental effect upon the commerce of the whole of South Africa because of the continual influx of Asiatics, and desires to express its conviction that it is imperative, in the interests of the white population of South Africa, that concerted action should be taken by the various Governments with the least possible delay.
('5', 109, 8, 15, 252952) Mr. G. Mitchell moved that the word “continual” be omitted, and the resolution was passed without it.
('5', 109, 8, 16, 253054) A resolution of this nature, passed by an important body like the Congress of the Associated Chambers, ought to carry weight, and it is to be feared that, althoughthe resolution is without foundation in fact, it will be used as
('5', 110, 0, 1, 253282) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 111
('5', 110, 1, 2, 253329) an authoritative expression of opinion on the part of the Chambers of Commerce in South Africa.
('5', 110, 1, 3, 253425) If the resolution were examined calmly, it would be found that the influx of Asiatics could not detrimentally affect the commerce of the whole of South Africa, for Indian immigrants would, after all, be consumers, no matter how humble they may be; but we imagine that the framers of the resolution intended to say that the increase of Indian traders, due to the influx of Indians, had such an effect.
('5', 110, 1, 4, 253826) Although both the question of influx and that of Indian trade have been fully examined in these columns more than once, we propose again to deal with them in order to show how ill informed the speakers were as to the true position.
('5', 110, 1, 5, 254058) So far as the Cape Colony and Natal are concerned, there is, as the Immigration Office records show from day to day, a most effective barrier set against Indian immigration, and the manner of enforcing the restrictions is daily being made more irksome.
('5', 110, 1, 6, 254311) From the letter 1 we reproduce in another column from Professor Parmanand, it will appear that the Immigration Officers are no respecters of persons.
('5', 110, 1, 7, 254461) The learned Professor, whose fame and name preceded him, was subjected to an educational test before he was allowed to set foot on the ground at Port Elizabeth.
('5', 110, 1, 8, 254622) Could severity go any further?
('5', 110, 1, 9, 254653) The Orange River Colony does not come into the calculation at all, as nobody has ever suggested that there is any Indian population or Indian trade worthy of the name in that Colony, and yet we find the resolution applying to the whole of South Africa.
('5', 110, 1, 10, 254906) With reference to the Transvaal, Lord Selborne, as well as other Government officials, has more than once stated, in emphatic terms, that no non refugee British Indians are being allowed to enter the Transvaal.
('5', 110, 1, 11, 255117) Our permit pillory 2 will bear witness to this.
('5', 110, 1, 12, 255165) One of the speakers said that the fact of the Advisory Boards having been appointed showed that an influx was going on.
('5', 110, 1, 13, 255285) May we inform him that the Boards have been established, not because an influx has been going on, but in answer to the agitation that was set up by certain interested parties in the Transvaal, and in total disregard of the feelings and convenience of Indian refugees.
('5', 110, 1, 14, 255553) The Boards could not act any more effectively than the permit officers have hitherto done.
('5', 110, 1, 15, 255644) The same speaker went on to say that he could “give evidence that the Government knew of certain Asiatics coming in unlawfully”.
('5', 110, 1, 16, 255773) Either the statement is true, or it is untrue.
('5', 110, 1, 17, 255820) If it be
('5', 110, 2, 18, 255829) 1 Not reproduced here 2 Vide “ A Permit Pillory”, 24 2 1906
('5', 111, 0, 1, 255889) 112 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 111, 1, 2, 255931) true, it is a duty the speaker owes to the Government, as well as to the Indian public, that he should give detailed information with names; if it be untrue, as an honourable man he should withdraw it.
('5', 111, 1, 3, 256133) Serious statements of that nature, without any facts to support them, made before a public body like the Congress of Associated Chambers of Commerce, cannot be allowed to pass unchallenged, and westate emphatically that there has been no such unlawful influx of Indians into the Transvaal, as has been suggested by the speaker.
('5', 111, 1, 4, 256461) We would here draw the attention of the public to the fact that the British Indian Association at Johannesburg invited public enquiry into the matter, which the Government did not grant, as the Government was fully convinced that there was no such influx.
('5', 111, 1, 5, 256717) With reference to the so called increase in Indian trade in Natal, there is a most effective and tyrannical check actually exercised over Indian licences.
('5', 111, 1, 6, 256872) As the members of the Congress must have known, the Natal Dealers’ Licenses Act places every Indian trader absolutely at the mercy of the Licensing Officer.
('5', 111, 1, 7, 257029) They must also have known that two respectable Indians 1, traders of long standing, have been wantonly deprived of their licences, although they were, as a matter of fact, not even competing with Europeans in their trade.
('5', 111, 1, 8, 257251) In the Transvaal, the position is no better, if only because the Indian population of the Transvaal is not so large as the Indian population of Natal, and also because even refugees find it difficult to enter that Colony.
('5', 111, 1, 9, 257473) At the same time, we are free to admit that the decision of the Supreme Court in the test case has undoubtedly, to a certain extent though not in any appreciable degree, increased the number of Indian licences, but Indians have showed their extreme moderation by suggesting that, as against repeal of Law 3 of 1885 and all class legislation, they would be prepared to accept the principle of control over new trade licences by the municipal bodies.
('5', 111, 1, 10, 257922) It is worthy of note that, of the eight speakers who are reported to have taken part in the debate on the resolution, there were only two from Cape Town, and they did not appear to have brought forward any facts or figures to show that Indian trade was in any way affecting European trade.
('5', 111, 1, 11, 258212) Thus, examined from every point of view, the resolution is totally unnecessary, and certainly not based upon facts.
('5', 111, 1, 12, 258328) The only real remedy which lies at their door, the people of the Transvaal have hitherto declined to accept.
('5', 111, 1, 13, 258437) It is also worthy of note that, out of the eight speakers, there were five from the Transvaal; and evidently the resolution was passed, not in the interests, as it has been said in the
('5', 111, 2, 14, 258622) 1 Dada Osman and Hoondamal; vide Dada Osman’s case “, 15 9 1898 and “Indian Licences: Need for vigilance —I”, 18 2 1905
('5', 112, 0, 1, 258742) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 113
('5', 112, 1, 2, 258789) body of it, of South Africa generally, but in the interests of the Transvaal only.
('5', 112, 1, 3, 258872) Indian Opinion, 10 3 1906
('5', 112, 2, 4, 258898) 103. A CONTRAST
('5', 112, 3, 5, 258914) We have drawn attention to Professor Parmanand’s hardships, whilst he was passing through the Cape Colony, in our remarks on the proceedings of the Congress of Associated Chambers of Commerce.
('5', 112, 3, 6, 259107) 1 Professor Parmanand, it would appear, was unnecessarily subjected to the indignity of an examination, before he was allowed to land at East London.
('5', 112, 3, 7, 259257) A letter from Mr. Omar Haji Amod Johari, which we publish in another column, 2 shows what even the most respectable Indians have to undergo in South Africa.
('5', 112, 3, 8, 259414) Mr. Johari is a leader among Indians in South Africa.
('5', 112, 3, 9, 259468) He represents the well known firm of E. Aboobaker Amod & Bros., of Natal.
('5', 112, 3, 10, 259542) He is a cultured Indian, and has travelled in Europe and America.
('5', 112, 3, 11, 259608) All this was of no consequence to the permit officer at Volksrust, who, not being satisfied with having examined his permit, had the effrontery to ask Mr. Johari to put his thumb impress on his book.
('5', 112, 3, 12, 259808) We confess that we fail to see the reason for this procedure.
('5', 112, 3, 13, 259870) Well may Mr. Johari ask whether he is to be treated as a criminal, without being guilty of any offence, save that of wearing a brown skin.
('5', 112, 3, 14, 260009) And yet, when it was a Japanese subject who was treated rudely only the other day, a howl of public indignation went up throughout South Africa, and our contemporary, The Transvaal Leader, in an angry editorial, after having severely censured the authorities for the delay in granting a permit to Mr. Nomura and for subjecting him to the offensive process of giving his thumb impression, offered a public apology to the gentleman on behalf of the people of the Transvaal.
('5', 112, 3, 15, 260481) We believe that Mr. Nomura was entitled to the apology.
('5', 112, 3, 16, 260537) But we cannot help contrasting the attitude of the public towards that incident, and the incidents to which we are now drawing attention.
('5', 112, 3, 17, 260675) We fear that there will not be even so much as one feeble voice raised in favour of Professor Parmanand or Mr. Johari.
('5', 112, 3, 18, 260794) The moral is obvious.
('5', 112, 3, 19, 260816) Mr. Nomura belonged to an independent nation in alliance with Great Britain.
('5', 112, 3, 20, 260893) Messrs Parmanand and Johari are only British Indians, after all.
('5', 112, 3, 21, 260958) But a little reflection should show that a British subject is deserving
('5', 112, 4, 22, 261030) 1 Vide the preceding item.
('5', 112, 5, 23, 261057) 2 Not reproduced here
('5', 113, 0, 1, 261079) 114 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 113, 1, 2, 261121) of at least as much solicitude on the part of the public, and that persistence in such a policy as this to which we draw attention cannot but lead eventually to the disruption of the Empire.
('5', 113, 1, 3, 261312) India Opinion 10 3 1906
('5', 113, 2, 4, 261336) 104. A CRYING SHAME
('5', 113, 3, 5, 261356) The Natal Government Gazette for the 27th February last contains a notice under the Immigration Restriction Act.
('5', 113, 3, 6, 261469) It seeks to impose sundry fees for the various documents which people, who are affected by it, have to take out.
('5', 113, 3, 7, 261582) A nominal fee we do not mind, though we question the legality of even a trivial charge.
('5', 113, 3, 8, 261670) But the notice in question is nothing short of a shameful attempt to replenish the empty treasury of Natal.
('5', 113, 3, 9, 261778) A certificate of domicile, a visiting pass or an embarkation pass are to cost £1 each.
('5', 113, 3, 10, 261865) A certificate of ability to pass the educational test, a wife’s exemption certificate and a transit pass (whatever the latter may mean) are to cost five shillings each.
('5', 113, 3, 11, 262034) Thus, although an Indian may be entitled by law to enter Natal or to remain in this Colony, he cannot henceforth do so without paying a price for it.
('5', 113, 3, 12, 262184) An imposition of the above kind was attempted in 1897, but the late Rt.
('5', 113, 3, 13, 262256) H. Escombe 1 saw the reasonableness of the protest of the Natal Indian Congress against it, and withdrew the tax immediately.
('5', 113, 3, 14, 262382) It does not appear to have struck the authors of this notice that, in seeking to exact the high fees from the Indians, they will not necessarily decrease the deficit of the Colony.
('5', 113, 3, 15, 262563) An Indian living in the Transvaal wishes to return to India.
('5', 113, 3, 16, 262624) He can only do so by going through the Cape, Durban or Delagoa Bay.
('5', 113, 3, 17, 262692) The Durban route is the most popular.
('5', 113, 3, 18, 262730) The Indian passenger traffic is no mean thing.
('5', 113, 3, 19, 262777) It behoves the Natal Government to take care that, in trying to exact an additional pound from an Indian, they do not kill the goose that lays the golden egg of Trans Natalian Indian passenger traffic.
('5', 113, 3, 20, 262979) So much for an appeal to selfishness.
('5', 113, 3, 21, 263017) On the ground of justice, the case is overwhelmingly in favour of the Indian.
('5', 113, 3, 22, 263095) The Immigration Act is supposed to apply to all, irrespective of nationality.
('5', 113, 3, 23, 263173) In effect, it is enforced chiefly, if not solely, against Indians.
('5', 113, 3, 24, 263240) The charges sought to be imposed by the notice, therefore, constitute special taxation on the Indian community.
('5', 113, 3, 25, 263352) We sympathise with the Government in their financial embarrassment, but
('5', 113, 4, 26, 263424) 1 Sir Harry Escombe, (1838 99), leading advocate of the Natal Supreme Court, sometime Attorney General, and Prime Minister of Natal, 1897
('5', 114, 0, 1, 263562) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 115
('5', 114, 1, 2, 263609) can scarcely approve of the method they have adopted of filling the State coffers.
('5', 114, 1, 3, 263692) Indian Opinion, 10 3 1906
('5', 114, 2, 4, 263718) 105. A POLL TAX GRIEVANCE
('5', 114, 3, 5, 263744) Our Gujarati columns show that much irritation is caused to Indian payers of the poll tax, owing to the alleged difference between the treatment of European and Indian payers.
('5', 114, 3, 6, 263920) One of the aggrieved parties states:
('5', 114, 4, 7, 263957) When a European goes to pay the poll tax, he does not have to stop even five minutes, whereas an Indian has to devote practically the whole day, before the money is taken from him and he is dispensed with.
('5', 114, 4, 8, 264163) If it be true that the intending Indian tax payers have to pass very nearly a day before they can pay the tax and get the receipt, there is something very bad about the arrangements made by the Government, and the attention of the authorities is drawn to the complaint.
('5', 114, 4, 9, 264433) Indian Opinion, 10 3 1906
('5', 114, 5, 10, 264459) 106. INDIAN PASSENGERS BY THE GERMAN EAST AFRICA LINE
('5', 114, 6, 11, 264513) More than one correspondent draws attention, through our Gujarati columns, to the inconvenience that was felt by the passengers on board the steamer Somali during her last voyage to Durban.
('5', 114, 6, 12, 264703) One of them writes:
('5', 114, 7, 13, 264723) On board the Somali, which left on the 20th January, passengers had to
('5', 114, 8, 14, 264794) undergo many difficulties about cooking, etc.
('5', 114, 8, 15, 264840) The crew on board were totally careless as to the comfort of the passengers, and the Captain, on the complaints being taken to him, did not listen.
('5', 114, 8, 16, 264988) We draw the attention of the Agents of the German East Africa Line to the allegations above made.
('5', 114, 8, 17, 265086) We shall be pleased to publish any explanation that they may have to give.
('5', 114, 8, 18, 265161) In any case, we trust that full investigation will be made; and in view of the fact that Indians give very considerable support to the line, even a policy of selfishness will dictate consideration towards Indian passengers.

('5', 115, 1, 2, 265453) 107. THE NATAL INDIAN CONGRESS
('5', 115, 2, 3, 265484) Great changes have come about in the s et up of the Natal Indian Congress.
('5', 115, 2, 4, 265559) After having occupied the presidential chair of the Congress for eight years, Mr. Abdul Kadir has left for India.
('5', 115, 2, 5, 265673) May his wishes be fulfilled, and may he return here safely!
('5', 115, 2, 6, 265733) The Indian community has conferred on him great honour, which he amply deserves.
('5', 115, 2, 7, 265814) 1 In honouring him, the community has honoured itself.
('5', 115, 2, 8, 265869) A number of speakers rightly emphasized the philanthropy of Mr. Abdul Kadir.
('5', 115, 2, 9, 265946) Mr. Abdul Kadir maintained the dignity of the Chair with solemnity and modesty.
('5', 115, 2, 10, 266026) He did much to put the Congress on a firm footing.
('5', 115, 2, 11, 266077) Whatever honour is done him must, therefore, be deemed inadequate.
('5', 115, 2, 12, 266144) With the departure of Mr. Abdul Kadir, Mr. Adamji Mian Khan relinquished the office of Joint Honorary Secretary.
('5', 115, 2, 13, 266257) Mr. Adamji is one of the very few educated persons among businessmen in the Indian community.
('5', 115, 2, 14, 266351) He has been serving the Congress ever since its inception.
('5', 115, 2, 15, 266410) In 1896, when the condition of our people was very critical, Mr. Adamji worked with great zeal, tact and humility.
('5', 115, 2, 16, 266525) During his tenure of office, there was great enthusiasm among the members of the Congress.
('5', 115, 2, 17, 266616) Mr. Adamji was mainly responsible for collecting £1,000 during that brief period.
('5', 115, 2, 18, 266698) Moreover, he took the same keen interest in political matters also.
('5', 115, 2, 19, 266766) When the residents of Durban staged a demonstration 2 against the steamers, Courland and Naderi, Mr. Adamji acted with patience and firmness.
('5', 115, 2, 20, 266908) Later when the late Mr. Nazar and Mr. Khan relinquished their office as Congress Secretaries, Mr. Adamji Mian Khan was elected Joint Secretary along with Mr. Omar Haji Amod Zaveri.
('5', 115, 2, 21, 267089) Since then, he served the Congress, along with Mr. Zaveri, until last week.
('5', 115, 2, 22, 267165) The reasons why Mr. Adamji resigned are, first, his indifferent health and, secondly, his desire to give Surati brethren an opportunity of holding office.
('5', 115, 2, 23, 267320) We regret Mr. Adamji Mian Khan’s ill health and pray to the Almighty that he may soon be restored to health.
('5', 115, 2, 24, 267429) The second reason which has led Mr. Adamji to resign his office does him greater credit.
('5', 115, 2, 25, 267518) The well being of his country has always been the uppermost thought in his mind.
('5', 115, 2, 26, 267599) Mr. Dowd Mahomed has succeeded Mr. Abdul Kadir as President, and Mr. Mahomed Cassim Anglia has taken the place of Mr. Adamji.
('5', 115, 2, 27, 267725) The largely attended meeting at the Congress Hall
('5', 115, 3, 28, 267775) 1 Vide “Address to Abdul Kadir”, 28 2 1906
('5', 115, 4, 29, 267818) 2 On January 13, 1897. Vide “Memorial to Secretary of State for the Colonies”, 15 3 1897
('5', 116, 0, 1, 267907) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 117
('5', 116, 1, 2, 267954) greeted them with loud acclamation.
('5', 116, 1, 3, 267990) In the trading community here, the Suratis preponderate, and it is in the fitness of things that two Surati gentlemen should be elected simultaneously to these high offices.
('5', 116, 1, 4, 268164) It will indeed be difficult to maintain the traditions built up by such able men as Mr. Abdul Kadir and Mr. Adamji, but we expect that both the [newly elected] gentlemen will play their part ably.
('5', 116, 1, 5, 268361) Mr. Dowd Mahomed has been a leading member of the Congress from the beginning.
('5', 116, 1, 6, 268440) He has rendered good service to the Congress.
('5', 116, 1, 7, 268486) He was the first to be elected an office bearer of that body.
('5', 116, 1, 8, 268548) His ability known to all.

('5', 117, 2, 3, 270311) Mr. John Morley has spoken on the Indian question.
('5', 117, 2, 4, 270362) Replying to Mr. Roberts, he said that the partition of Bengal had already been accomplished.
('5', 117, 2, 5, 270455) It was impolitic to have offended people over the matter of fixing boundaries.
('5', 117, 2, 6, 270534) There was no need, however, to make changes in what had already been done.
('5', 117, 2, 7, 270609) It was necessary that the agitation that had disturbed the administration should now subside.
('5', 117, 2, 8, 270703) The time for granting the people a share in the government of the country had not yet come.
('5', 117, 2, 9, 270795) These words of Mr. Morley are disappointing.
('5', 117, 2, 10, 270840) They mean that the people of Bengal will not get justice.
('5', 117, 2, 11, 270898) Of course, if Mr. Morley had been at the helm of affairs at the time, the partition would not have come about.
('5', 117, 2, 12, 271009) From this it appears that the hope that Mr. Morley would act boldly and fearlessly and do what was necessary has been belied.
('5', 117, 2, 13, 271135) In effect, therefore, for the duration of his career, it is only when new laws are enacted that attention will be paid to the feelings of the Indian people.
('5', 117, 2, 14, 271292) Moreover, his statement that our people are not fit to take part in the governance of the country might be construed to mean that we are not yet fit for self government.
('5', 117, 2, 15, 271462) At the same time, it would not be proper to infer from a statement of this kind that India would notreceive any benefits from Mr. Morley.
('5', 117, 2, 16, 271600) However, Mr. Morley’s views are similar to those of the average Anglo Indian; and they are likely to change only if we put in the requisite effort.
('5', 117, 2, 17, 271748) It will be futile to hope that he would exert himself in our favour as he did for Ireland.

('5', 118, 6, 21, 273857) TRAM TEST CASE
('5', 118, 7, 22, 273872) The tram test case was heard by Magistrate Kar last Wednesday.
('5', 118, 7, 23, 273935) The plaintiff, Mr. Coovadia, was represented by Mr. Gandhi, and the respondent by Mr. Hile, the Town Council advocate.
('5', 118, 7, 24, 274054) The Crown Counsel, Mr. Blaine, appeared on behalf of the Government.
('5', 118, 7, 25, 274123) He conducted the case well without discriminating between the white and
('5', 118, 8, 26, 274195) 1 The Gujarati original has: “This has resulted in the Government cutting its own foot with an axe.”
('5', 119, 0, 1, 274296) 120 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 119, 1, 2, 274338) the Coloured.
('5', 119, 1, 3, 274352) During his examination, Mr. Coovadia deposed that the respondent forbade him to travel by the tram and asked him to use the tram reserved for the Coloureds; the case was, therefore, brought to court.
('5', 119, 1, 4, 274552) On the Counsel for the Town Council admitting the said facts, it was not considered necessary to record Mr. MacIntyre’s evidence.
('5', 119, 1, 5, 274682) The respondent argued that he had orders from the Town Council not to admit Indians or other Coloured persons into the tram unless they were servants accompanying their white masters, and that he had accordingly refused admission to the plaintiff.
('5', 119, 1, 6, 274930) In his address to the court, Mr. Blaine said that, according to the bye laws of the Johannesburg Tramway, Indians were entitled to travel by any tram car, and that the respondent was, therefore, guilty.
('5', 119, 1, 7, 275133) In his address, Mr. Hile admitted that the tramway bye laws did not prohibit Indians from travelling by any tram car.
('5', 119, 1, 8, 275251) But there was a regulation, introduced by the Sanitary Committee [of the Town Council] during the Boer regime, which made it an offence for any Coloured person to use a tram, a bus or a cab reserved for the whites.
('5', 119, 1, 9, 275466) By virtue of that regulation, still unrepealed, an Indian could be refused a seat in a tram.
('5', 119, 1, 10, 275559) To this Mr. Blaine replied that the said regulation was no longer applicable and that Indians were entitled, by virtue of the bye law passed by the Council, to travel in the tram.
('5', 119, 1, 11, 275739) Mr. Kar has deferred judgment in the case till Monday.
('5', 119, 1, 12, 275794) If it is announced on Monday, I shall communicate it.
('5', 119, 1, 13, 275848) According to news subsequently received, we have won the tram case and the Municipality has preferred an appeal.
('5', 119, 2, 14, 275961) RESPONSIBLE GOVERNMENT FOR THE TRANSVAAL
('5', 119, 3, 15, 276002) The agitation for responsible government is still continuing in Johannesburg.
('5', 119, 3, 16, 276080) The Boer People’s Committee and the leaders of the Responsible and Progressive Parties met at the residence of Sir George Farrar with the object of arriving at a unanimity of views.
('5', 119, 3, 17, 276262) What transpired at the meeting is not so far known; but it is believed that they could not reach an agreement and dispersed without taking a decision.
('5', 119, 3, 18, 276413) Meanwhile, a huge movement is in progress here.
('5', 119, 3, 19, 276461) It has been decided to send a deputation of whites to England and a mass petition to King Emperor Edward, to which thousands of signatures are being obtained.
('5', 119, 3, 20, 276620) The demand of the signatories is that, in any future constitution [for the Transvaal], there should be provision for equal rights to all voters and the number of members to be elected should be proportionate to the strength of the voting population.
('5', 119, 3, 21, 276870) The object of this petition is to increase the power of the British [in public affairs], for the Boer population is smaller than the British.

('5', 121, 1, 2, 279020) 113. “LEGALIZED ROBBERY” 1
('5', 121, 2, 3, 279047) We publish in another column a special report 2 of a case that was argued on Monday last before the Supreme Court of the Transvaal.
('5', 121, 2, 4, 279179) Our correspondent has called it “legalized robbery” and we have no hesitation in adopting the title for this note.
('5', 121, 2, 5, 279294) Law 3 of 1885 has formed the subject matter of many complaints on the part of the British Indian Association, but we cannot think of any case so cruel or harsh and so unjust as the one reported by our correspondent.
('5', 121, 2, 6, 279510) A law under which such a glaring wrong can be perpetrated must, to say the least of it, be utterly inhuman.
('5', 121, 2, 7, 279618) Mr. Leonard, in his eloquent address, evidently thought of the inhumanity of the law when he asked the judges to put a humane interpretation upon it, and if possible to give the unfortunate victims justice.
('5', 121, 2, 8, 279825) The late Mr. Aboobaker Amod was one of the first Indian settlers in South Africa.
('5', 121, 2, 9, 279907) He was one of the foremost Indian merchants, and held very considerable landed property in Natal and in other parts of South Africa.
('5', 121, 2, 10, 280040) He was respected, and very properly so, both by Europeans and the Indians of his time.
('5', 121, 2, 11, 280127) He was cultured in every sense of the term.
('5', 121, 2, 12, 280171) He held some landed property in the Transvaal.
('5', 121, 2, 13, 280218) He made a will bequeathing it to his brother and his son, both of whom are well known and well educated.
('5', 121, 2, 14, 280323) It has now become possible to rob the heirs of what has been left to them by the testator, and in spite of their wishes to the contrary, the judges of the Supreme Court of the Transvaal were unable to right the wrong.
('5', 121, 2, 15, 280541) It is hardly possible to get a purer or a more independent bench of judges than the people of the Transvaal have in their Supreme Court.
('5', 121, 2, 16, 280678) They are not carried away by the slightest prejudice, and we have known them to have given fearless decisions before now.
('5', 121, 2, 17, 280800) The cause was represented by the ablest lawyer in South Africa, who put his whole heart into it, and yet the judges have not been able, as they virtually admitted, to do justice.
('5', 121, 2, 18, 280979) The cause is not far to seek.
('5', 121, 2, 19, 281009) Law 3 of 1885 was passed by a legislature that had no regard for the feelings of British Indians, or, for that matter, any Coloured people.
('5', 121, 2, 20, 281149) It was manifestly un British and in breach of all the known rules of civilisation.
('5', 121, 2, 21, 281232) It was an item of discussion at the Bloemfontein Conference 3 that preceded the Boer War, and when the late President
('5', 121, 3, 22, 281350) 1 This was also published in India, 13 4 1906. 2 Not reproduced here 3 Held in 1899 when Lord Milner, Governor of the Cape, and Paul Kruger, President of the Transvaal, discussed, among other things, the controversial subject of franchise for non Dutch white settlers in the Transvaal.

('5', 122, 2, 7, 282566) 114. THE POLL TAX
('5', 122, 3, 8, 282584) A correspondent from Ladysmith writes in the Gujarati columns:
('5', 122, 4, 9, 282647) In the Government Gazette dated the 28th February, there is a notice about the poll tax which states that those, other than Natives, who do not pay the tax before that day, shall be liable to a penalty.
('5', 122, 4, 10, 282850) This has caused terror amongst the Indians.
('5', 122, 4, 11, 282894) Those living in the town of Ladysmith have already paid the tax, but the poor Indians, who have just emerged from their indenture and who are living on farms and in distant places, cannot realise the thing, and have not been able to pay the poll tax.
('5', 122, 4, 12, 283145) These men have to be informed.
('5', 122, 4, 13, 283176) The sergeant in charge receives the poll tax, gives them a receipt, and then takes them before the Magistrate and the men are fined.
('5', 122, 4, 14, 283309) If they do not pay the fine,
('5', 122, 5, 15, 283338) they have to go to gaol.
('5', 122, 5, 16, 283363) An instance happened in my presence.
('5', 122, 5, 17, 283400) An Indian named Motai was living five to seven miles from Ladysmith.
('5', 122, 5, 18, 283469) He was informed by a friend that he should pay the tax.
('5', 122, 5, 19, 283525) He, therefore, mortgaged his ear rings for one pound, at an interest of half a crown per month, and paid the tax.
('5', 122, 5, 20, 283639) He got the receipt and was taken to the Magistrate.
('5', 122, 5, 21, 283691) He was fined ten shillings.
('5', 122, 5, 22, 283719) Where is he to get the money from ?
('5', 122, 5, 23, 283755) He had a pass.
('5', 122, 5, 24, 283770) He has left it in the Court and has promised to bring the fine.
('5', 122, 5, 25, 283834) Up till now, nearly twelve to fifteen men have been fined.
('5', 122, 5, 26, 283893) We bring the above to the notice of the Government.
('5', 122, 5, 27, 283945) If the information given by our correspondent be true, it reflects the greatest discredit on those who are concerned with the collection of the poll tax.
('5', 122, 5, 28, 284099) To make the poor people not only pay the tax, but when they come to pay it, to impose on them a fine seems to us to be the height of injustice.
('5', 122, 5, 29, 284243) The penalty clause, we should imagine, is applicable, not to those who pay the tax willingly, but to those who
('5', 123, 0, 1, 284354) 124 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 123, 1, 2, 284396) want to avoid payment.
('5', 123, 1, 3, 284419) The daily newspapers report that Indians have been paying the tax with the greatest despatch.
('5', 123, 1, 4, 284513) As our correspondent points out, it is cruel to expect those who are living in out of the way places to go to the paying booths before the advertised time and pay the money.
('5', 123, 1, 5, 284687) We have no doubt that many of them do not know anything about their liability, and if, as our correspondent points out, it is true that the men have to be informed, it is only reasonable to expect the Government to instruct their officers to take the money from those who may pay, and not arrest the men, and have them fined for an alleged contravention of the poll tax act.
('5', 123, 1, 6, 285062) We have trust enough in the humanity of the Government to feel that they will stop the injustice that is being perpetrated in the name of law.

('5', 123, 2, 8, 285231) 115. A PLEA FOR INDIAN VOLUNTEERING.
('5', 123, 3, 9, 285268) The Natal Native trouble 1 is dragging on a slow existence.
('5', 123, 3, 10, 285328) There can be no doubt that the imposition of the poll tax is itself the immediate cause, though probably the trouble has been brewing for a long time.
('5', 123, 3, 11, 285479) Whosesoever the mistake may be, report has it that it I s costing the Colony two thousand pounds per day.
('5', 123, 3, 12, 285585) The white colonists are trying to cope with it, and many citizen soldiers have taken up arms.
('5', 123, 3, 13, 285679) Today, perhaps, no further assistance is necessary, but this trouble ought to suggest reflections to the Government, as also to every thinking colonist.
('5', 123, 3, 14, 285832) There is a population of over one hundred thousand Indians in Natal.
('5', 123, 3, 15, 285901) It has been proved that they can do very efficient work in time of war.
('5', 123, 3, 16, 285973) 2 The suspicion that they were worthless in emergencies has been dispelled.
('5', 123, 3, 17, 286049) In the face of these incontrovertible facts,is it prudent for the Government to allow a source of strength, which always lies at its disposal, to run to waste?
('5', 123, 3, 18, 286209) Our contemporary, The Natal Witness, has recently written a very thoughtful editorial on the Indian question, and has shown that, some day or other, the question of Indian representation must be seriously taken up by the colonists.
('5', 123, 3, 19, 286441) We agree with the view, though Indians do not aspire to any political power in the Colony.
('5', 123, 3, 20, 286532) All they require is a guarantee of full civil rights under the general laws of the Colony.
('5', 123, 3, 21, 286623) This should be the birthright of every British subject living in a British territory.
('5', 123, 3, 22, 286709) Refusal to accept anybody as an immigrant is, in certain
('5', 123, 4, 23, 286766) 1 The Zulu revolt led by Bambata; vide “Speech at Congress Meeting”, 28 4 1906 2 The reference is to the role of the Indian Ambulance Corps during the Boer War; vide “Indian Ambulance Corps”, 13 12 1899
('5', 124, 0, 1, 286969) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 125
('5', 124, 1, 2, 287016) circumstances, justifiable, but imposition of disabilities upon well behaved and physically sound immigrants can never be justified either on economic or political grounds.
('5', 124, 1, 3, 287189) Whilst, therefore, the question of Indian representation is undoubtedly very important, we consider that the question of Indian volunteering is more important because it is more practicable.
('5', 124, 1, 4, 287380) There is, it is nowadays fully recognised, work in the field which does not require the bearing of arms, but which is just as useful and quite as honourable as the shouldering of a rifle.
('5', 124, 1, 5, 287568) If the Government, instead of neglecting Indians, were to employ them for volunteering work, they would add appreciably to the utility of the Militia, and would always be able in times of trouble to rely upon Indians giving a good account of themselves.
('5', 124, 1, 6, 287822) The Government, we doubt not, recognise that it is impossible for them to drive Indians out of the country.
('5', 124, 1, 7, 287930) Why not, then, make the best of the material at hand, and convert a hitherto neglected community into a permanent and most valuable asset of the State ?

('5', 124, 2, 9, 288109) 116. AN INTER STATE NATIVE COLLEGE
('5', 124, 3, 10, 288144) A considerable amount of enthusiasm has been evoked by the movement that was initiated some months ago by Mr. Tengo Jabavu, Editor of Imvo, with the object of creating an Inter State Native College with the present Lovedale Institute as its nucleus.
('5', 124, 3, 11, 288394) Both Mr. Jabavu and Mr. K. A. Hobart Houghton, organising secretary of the movement, have been touring South Africa, their purpose being the threefold one of enlisting the sympathetic co operation of the various South African Governments, creating a healthy Native opinion on the subject by means of careful explanation and illustration, and, perhaps, most important of all, the collection of funds to enable serious work to be commenced in the near future.
('5', 124, 3, 12, 288852) We have already in these columns drawn attention to the excellent and instructive programme carried out by Mr. Booker T. Washington at the Tuskegee Institute in America.
('5', 124, 3, 13, 289022) 1 It is proposed to develop the work to be undertaken by the new College on the same lines of industrial training as in the American Institute.
('5', 124, 3, 14, 289166) All this can do nothing but good, and it is not to be wondered at that an awakening people, like the great Native races of South Africa, are moved by something that has been described as being very much akin to religious fervour.
('5', 124, 3, 15, 289396) To them undoubtedly the work must be sanctified and hallowed, for it opens
('5', 124, 4, 16, 289471) 1 Vide “From Slave to College President”, 10 9 1903

('5', 125, 1, 2, 289565) up a means to advancement of thought and gives a great impetus to spiritual development.

('5', 125, 1, 4, 289843) British Indians in South Africa have much to learn from this example of self sacrifice.
('5', 125, 1, 5, 289931) If the Natives of South Africa, with all their financial disabilities and social disadvantages, are capable of putting forth this local effort, is it not incumbent upon the British Indian community to take the lesson to heart, and press forward the matter of educational facilities with far greater energy and enthusiasm than have been used hitherto?

('5', 125, 2, 8, 290449) 117. SIR WILLIAM GATACRE
('5', 125, 3, 9, 290474) We regret to note the death of Major General Sir William Gatacre in Egypt from fever following on sunstroke.
('5', 125, 3, 10, 290583) Sir William had a peculiar claim upon the gratitude of British Indians.
('5', 125, 3, 11, 290655) He was the Chairman of the first Plague Committee formed at Bombay, and by his tactful and delicate handling of most difficult matters, practically all friction and bitterness were avoided.
('5', 125, 3, 12, 290845) He was a striking example of what is best in the Anglo Indian character, represented so excellently by such gallant and courteous exponents of British rule as Mountstuart Elphinstone, Munro, Tod, Sleeman, Forbes, Lawrence, and many another.
('5', 125, 3, 13, 291086) Whilst Britain can produce noble gentlemen of the calibre of the late Sir William Gatacre, there is yet room for hope that India will receive that sympathetic treatment at the hands of her rulers of which she stands so much in need.

('5', 128, 5, 18, 297626) This week there was a very big fire here in Rissik Street, in which much valuable material for manufacturing motor cars, etc., was destroyed.

('5', 129, 4, 12, 299034) VICARIOUS LIABILITY
('5', 129, 5, 13, 299054) An interesting suit was recently heard in the law court here.
('5', 129, 5, 14, 299116) Dr. Kincaid Smith’s motor car was being driven by his chauffeur and an engineer, named Mr. Clark Dacurtey 2, was at the time riding his bicycle.
('5', 129, 5, 15, 299261) Dr. Smith’s chauffeur turned the car slightly in from his side of the road and collided with Mr. Dacurtey’s bicycle, knocking him down.
('5', 129, 5, 16, 299397) He was hurt and had to be removed to hospital.
('5', 129, 5, 17, 299444) Dr. Smith was not in the car when the accident occurred.
('5', 129, 5, 18, 299501) Mr. Dacurtey filed a suit in the High Court here claiming £2,000 as damages.
('5', 129, 5, 19, 299578) Justice Bristow, giving judgment, awarded £750 to Mr. Dacurtey; but while doing so, the honourable judge remarked that, though Dr. Smith himself was not at fault, he had to suffer vicariously for the fault of his employee.
('5', 129, 5, 20, 299801) People ought to be very careful while employing a person.
('5', 129, 5, 21, 299859) If the servant commits a fault resulting in injury to a third party, the damage has to be made good by the employer.
('5', 129, 5, 22, 299976) Had the offence been committed by Dr. Smith’s servant while he was not going on his master’s business, Dr. Smith would not have been obliged to pay.
('5', 129, 5, 23, 300125) This case has a lesson for persons engaging servants, especially chauf feurs, who often make mistakes either through insolence or lack of sufficient ability, and for this the masters have to suffer.

('5', 131, 1, 2, 302000) 122. THE EARLY CLOSING ACT OF NATAL
('5', 131, 2, 3, 302036) The effects of the Early Closing Act are now beginning to be felt.
('5', 131, 2, 4, 302103) We have never held that an Early Closing Act would not be justifiable under any circumstances.
('5', 131, 2, 5, 302198) On the contrary, we conceive that a wel thought out measure would always be of great benefit to the community at large; but the present Act has been framed without sufficient consideration for the consumers, or for the small retail traders.
('5', 131, 2, 6, 302439) The result has been to cause much inconvenience to poor householders and a very great loss to the small traders.
('5', 131, 2, 7, 302552) The only persons that could possibly benefit are large retail houses.
('5', 131, 2, 8, 302622) We entirely endorse the remarks made by The Natal Mercury representative when he says that
('5', 131, 3, 9, 302713) the small trader is gradually being swamped by the large houses, the number of which can be counted on one’s fingers.
('5', 131, 3, 10, 302831) It would be a misfortune, indeed, if legislation of this type is allowed to force good colonists to the wall and deprive them of an honest livelihood.
('5', 131, 3, 11, 302982) The remedy suggested is suspension of the Act Experience has shown that the shops ought to be allowed to keep open later than half past Eve, and that Saturday closing is a serious mistake.
('5', 131, 3, 12, 303171) The Natal Witness has taken up, in connection with this matter, that may be reasonably termed a somewhat spiteful attitude.
('5', 131, 3, 13, 303295) It concludes some remarks on the subject by saying
('5', 131, 4, 14, 303346) it is a well known fact that the Arab and Indian merchants in the town have been hard hit.
('5', 131, 4, 15, 303437) Let the Europeans bear this well in mind.
('5', 131, 4, 16, 303479) Our contemporary urges the Europeans not to agitate against the Act, on the sole ground of its having adversely affected Indian trade.
('5', 131, 4, 17, 303614) In it haste to see the Indian injured, The Witness has entirely forgotten that, in injuring the Indian, the small white traders, who alone can feel the competition of Indian traders, will not only be injured, but will be wiped out entirely, for whilst the frugal habits of the Indian may enable him to tide over the difficulty, the white petty traders, who notoriously fail to save, will be entirely helpless.
('5', 131, 4, 18, 304024) The real remedy is not to kill the small white retailer, so that the Indian will be hit but in having reasonable closing hours for both European and Indian traders, so that they may get a chance of earning a living after the large retail houses have closed.
('5', 131, 4, 19, 304282) The latter will always be obliged to close much earlier than the small retailers.
('5', 131, 4, 20, 304364) The Witness, by having taken a prejudiced view of the situation, has also fallen into the error of supposing that the saving of expenses of electric light to the shopkeepers is any gain.
('5', 131, 4, 21, 304551) We give The Witness the credit for
('5', 132, 0, 1, 304586) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 133
('5', 132, 1, 2, 304633) understanding that no shopkeeper would pay for the electric current, if he could not more than make up for the expense by the profits he Would Gain from the trade he would be doing during those hours.
('5', 132, 1, 3, 304834) Indian Opinion, 24 3 1906
('5', 132, 2, 4, 304860) 123. THE COLOURED PEOPLE’S PETITION
('5', 132, 3, 5, 304896) We have been favoured with a copy of the petition of Coloured British subjects “resident in the Colonies of the Cape of Good Hope, the Transvaal, and the Orange River Colony” addressed to the King Emperor.
('5', 132, 3, 6, 305102) It seems that the petition is being widely circulated, and signatures are being taken of all the Coloured people in the threeColonies named.The petition is non Indian in character, although British Indians, being Coloured people, are very largely affected by it.
('5', 132, 3, 7, 305365) We consider that it was a wise policy, on the part of British Indians throughout South Africa, to have kept themselves apart and distinct from the other Coloured communities in this country.
('5', 132, 3, 8, 305556) It is true that British Indians and other Coloured people have much in common regarding their grievances, but they have little in common regarding the points of view from which each section can urge its claim.
('5', 132, 3, 9, 305766) Whereas British Indians may, and do effectively, use the Proclamation of 1858 in support of their claims, the other Coloured people are not in a position to do so; and whilst some sections of the Coloured people can claim full rights as to property and movement in the Orange River Colony, British Indians have no footing whatsoever.
('5', 132, 3, 10, 306100) Similarly, in the Transvaal, many sections of other Coloured people are capable of owning landed property, but British Indians are debarred from doing so under Law 3 of 1885. Whilst, therefore, the Indian and non Indian sections of the Coloured communities should, and do, remain apart, and have their separate organisations, there is no doubt that each can give strength to the other in urging their common rights.
('5', 132, 3, 11, 306516) Hence we have no hesitation in welcoming the document before us.
('5', 132, 3, 12, 306581) We must congratulate the framers of the petition on having confined themselves to the barest facts.
('5', 132, 3, 13, 306681) It has always appeared to us that the case for the Coloured people in South Africa is so overwhelmingly strong and just that a statement of facts in connection with it is more eloquent than any other form of pleading.
('5', 132, 3, 14, 306899) The petition has left many things unsaid, but the deductions to be drawn from the statements made therein are plain enough.
('5', 132, 3, 15, 307023) The petitioners have shown clearly that, in one part of South Africa, namely, in the Colony of the Cape of Good Hope, they have enjoyed the franchise ever since the
('5', 133, 0, 1, 307188) 134 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 133, 1, 2, 307230) commencement of representative institutions, and they show also that, even in 1892, when there was a revision of the Franchise Act, there was no alteration made imposing disqualification on colour; and, as a result, there are, at the present day, at the Cape, 14,000 qualified Coloured voters on the register.
('5', 133, 1, 3, 307540) The petitioners go on to say that they have
('5', 133, 2, 4, 307584) looked upon the possession of that right as an inducement to obtain the necessary property and education test, and have, they humbly submit, exercised that right with dignity and propriety, and in the interests of the whole community without respect of creed or colour.
('5', 133, 2, 5, 307854) But, they add, as soon as they migrate either to the Orange River Colony or the Transvaal Colony, they and their descendants come under the ban of disqualification on the ground of colour.
('5', 133, 2, 6, 308043) The petitioners have rightly made the franchise the greatest plank in their programme, because, in their own language,
('5', 133, 3, 7, 308162) deprived of these rights, Your Majesty’s coloured subjects are deprived also, to a great extent, of the means of publicly ventilating, and obtaining redress by constitutional means, of any grievances that they may suffer from, and those grievances are not such as can be rectified by recourse to a court of law.
('5', 133, 3, 8, 308474) The truth of this statement can be verified from scores of illustrations.
('5', 133, 3, 9, 308548) In a country enjoying popular institutions, it is a bad day for those who have no voice in the choice of popular representatives; and through no fault of theirs or of their representatives, the disfranchised gradually go under, because under self government, self interest becomes predominant.
('5', 133, 3, 10, 308842) British Indians have, in order that they may never be misunderstood, made it clear that they do not aspire to any political power, but they have found to their cost that, in Natal as elsewhere, as they have no voice in the election of popular representatives, their civil liberty has suffered very considerably.
('5', 133, 3, 11, 309154) The Coloured petition is a weighty document.
('5', 133, 3, 12, 309199) It is being numerously signed, and it is to be hoped that its prayer will receive the attention and consideration which it undoubtedly deserves.
('5', 133, 3, 13, 309344) The Liberal Ministers have more than once avowed their desire to help the weaker members of the Empire.
('5', 133, 3, 14, 309448) In granting the Constitution to the new Colonies, they have an unfettered discretion and a unique opportunity of putting their principles into practice.
('5', 133, 4, 15, 309601) Indian Opinion, 24 3 1906
('5', 134, 0, 1, 309627) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 135
('5', 134, 1, 2, 309674) 124. THE COLOURED PEOPLE’S PETITION
('5', 134, 2, 3, 309710) We print in this issue a report of the meeting held by the Coloured people at Pretoria.
('5', 134, 2, 4, 309798) We also publish a translation of the petition submitted by them.
('5', 134, 2, 5, 309863) We use the term “Coloured people” 1 because, if translated as “black people”, it would include the Kaffirs also.
('5', 134, 2, 6, 309976) There were no Kaffirs present at the meeting.
('5', 134, 2, 7, 310022) It mainly consisted of the people known as “Cape boys”.
('5', 134, 2, 8, 310078) And there were those who had a white father or mother.
('5', 134, 2, 9, 310133) Some Malays also joined it.
('5', 134, 2, 10, 310161) This Association of Coloured People does not include Indians who have always kept aloof from that body.
('5', 134, 2, 11, 310265) We believe that the Indian community has been wise in doing so.
('5', 134, 2, 12, 310329) For, though the hardships suffered by those people and the Indians are almost of the same kind, the remedies are not identical.
('5', 134, 2, 13, 310457) It is therefore proper that the two should fight out their cases, each in their own appropriate way.
('5', 134, 2, 14, 310558) We can cite the Proclamation of 1857 2 in our favour, which the Coloured people cannot.
('5', 134, 2, 15, 310646) They can use the powerful argument that they are the children of the soil.
('5', 134, 2, 16, 310721) They can also argue that their way of life is entirely European.
('5', 134, 2, 17, 310786) We can petition the Secretary of State for India, whereas they cannot.
('5', 134, 2, 18, 310857) They belong largely to the Christian community and can therefore avail themselves of the help of their priests.
('5', 134, 2, 19, 310969) Such help is not available to us.
('5', 134, 2, 20, 311003) The Coloured people have evidently started a big struggle; hence the need for these comments.
('5', 134, 2, 21, 311097) In their meeting at Pretoria, they transgressed the limits of propriety and used insulting language about Lord Milner, and this hasbeen severely criticised by The Times of Natal.
('5', 134, 2, 22, 311276) The President of the meeting declared that, just as the Boers lost their kingdom by committing outrages against the Coloured people, even so the British would lose theirs if the atrocities continued, implying thereby that the Coloured people would rise against them.
('5', 134, 2, 23, 311543) But then they have not the strength even to confront the whites.
('5', 134, 2, 24, 311608) A man should always measure his strength before embarking on a task.
('5', 134, 2, 25, 311677) The petition prepared by the Coloured people is very good.
('5', 134, 2, 26, 311736) They have stated all the facts necessary and nothing besides.
('5', 134, 2, 27, 311798) Their facts are so eloquent that it is hardly necessary to adduce any argument in support.
('5', 134, 2, 28, 311889) They have shown that they have so far enjoyed full rights in the Cape Colony, and ask why they should not have the same rights in the Transvaal and the Orange River Colony.
('5', 134, 3, 29, 312062) 1 Gandhiji has transliterated the term in Gujarati.

('5', 135, 1, 3, 312273) This is a very desirable and necessary move.

('5', 135, 2, 11, 312812) 125. A WORD TO THE MUSLIM COMMUNITY IN HEIDELBERG
('5', 135, 3, 12, 312862) We have published a number of letters on the dissensions persisting in the Muslim community in Heidelberg.
('5', 135, 3, 13, 312969) We have allowed both sides to state their points of view fully.
('5', 135, 3, 14, 313033) To publish further correspondence on the subject will serve only to keep the quarrel alive.

('5', 135, 3, 19, 313465) We appeal to both the parties to remove the causes of dissension and live together in peace and amity.
('5', 135, 3, 20, 313568) It is the duty of their leaders to see this done.
('5', 135, 3, 21, 313618) In this country we have so many hardships to suffer that they should not be aggravated by internal dissensions and difficulties.
('5', 135, 3, 22, 313747) If people learn to give and take and be patient, the quarrel will soon come to an end.
('5', 135, 3, 23, 313834) We earnestly hope therefore that the leaders of the two sides will come together, remove the discord within the Heidelberg community and restore unity.

('5', 136, 1, 2, 314166) 126. SMALLPOX IN THE CAPE
('5', 136, 2, 3, 314192) News has been received from the Cape that smallpox has started amongst the non whites there.
('5', 136, 2, 4, 314285) The Cape leaders should investigate the matter and take effective measures.
('5', 136, 2, 5, 314361) It is easy to deal with smallpox by following a few rules.
('5', 136, 2, 6, 314420) The danger of the infection spreading can largely be avoided by segregating the patient in a separate room and carefully nursing him there.
('5', 136, 2, 7, 314560) Nothing is to be gained by concealing such diseases; for, ultimately, it is the community in which such cases occur that has to suffer.
('5', 136, 2, 8, 314696) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 24 3 1906
('5', 136, 3, 9, 314738) 127. PLAGUE IN SYDNEY
('5', 136, 4, 10, 314760) News received by cablegram states that five cases of plague have occurred in Sydney.
('5', 136, 4, 11, 314845) Another cablegram during the week mentions two cases on board a steamer, and adds that these were among the Coloured people.
('5', 136, 4, 12, 314970) Sydney is doubtless far away, but experience shows that, whenever cases of plague occur outside India, they occur simultaneously in many places.
('5', 136, 4, 13, 315115) Moreover, in a country where they are always looking hard for plague cases to be used as an argument against us, it is necessary for us to act warily.
('5', 136, 4, 14, 315266) We have often pointed out that the main causes of plague are uncleanliness and impure air.
('5', 136, 4, 15, 315357) We should therefore bear in mind the following instructions: houses should be kept clean; no filth should be allowed to accumulate in latrines; each time faeces should be covered over with ashes or sand; floors should be washed clean with disinfectant liquids; plenty of fresh air and light should be freely let into the house; and simple food should be eaten regularly.
('5', 136, 4, 16, 315728) One need not entertain any fear if one follows these directions.
('5', 136, 4, 17, 315793) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 24 3 1906

('5', 138, 8, 17, 318318) HUMBLY SHEWETH THAT l.
('5', 138, 8, 18, 318341) Your petitioner is a British Indian subject.
('5', 138, 8, 19, 318386) 2. Your petitioner has been domiciled in South Africa for the last 24 years.
('5', 138, 8, 20, 318463) 3. Your petitioner opened business in Vryheid in the year 1896 as a General Dealer at what was then known as the Indian Location.

('5', 139, 1, 4, 319172) 7. Your petitioner had a stock of soft goods and groceries valued at about £3,000. 8. Such was your petitioner’s position when Vryheid was annexed to Natal.
('5', 139, 1, 5, 319329) 9. The terms of annexation provide for the retention of Law 3 of 1885, as amended in 1886, which is known as the anti Asiatic Law of the Transvaal.
('5', 139, 1, 6, 319477) 10. According to the interpretation put upon the Law by the Supreme Court of the Transvaal, 1 British Indians are not restricted to any area as to their trade, and are free to take out trade licences in the same manner as other British subjects.
('5', 139, 1, 7, 319723) 11. The Vryheid Local Board, however, refused to renew your petitioner’s licence in respect of the premises above mentioned, and offered to allow your petitioner to trade in Vryheid if he removed to a new site fixed by the Board at a Location.
('5', 139, 1, 8, 319967) 12. The said site is far away from Vryheid and totally unsuitable for trade.
('5', 139, 1, 9, 320044) 13. It is impossible for your petitioner to carry on his business in a place which is away from the business portions of the town.
('5', 139, 1, 10, 320175) 14. Your petitioner has built up an excellent goodwill in connection with his said premises.
