('5', 139, 1, 13, 320520) 17. Your petitioner is, therefore, subject to twofold restrictions— namely, the Transvaal Law, as also the Natal Law—which make the position of British Indians in Vryheid worse than in the Transvaal, or in other parts of Natal.
('5', 139, 1, 14, 320748) 18. In accordance with Act 18 of 1897, your petitioner had to apply for his licence to the Licensing Officer, who is also the Town Clerk, and who, therefore, takes his instructions from the Local Board.
('5', 139, 1, 15, 320951) 19. The Licensing Officer refused to grant a renewal.
('5', 139, 1, 16, 321005) 20. Your petitioner, therefore, appealed to the Local Board in terms of the Law.

('5', 140, 1, 2, 321183) 21. The Local Board, which mainly consists of rival traders and members prejudiced against your petitioner, has confirmed the decision of the Licensing Officer.
('5', 140, 1, 3, 321344) 22. The following are the reasons given by the Licensing Officer for his refusal: 1.The Licensing Officer has no power to issue licences for premises on the Town Lands, and far less for such Town Lands as have not been formerly leased by the Local Board.
('5', 140, 1, 4, 321599) 2. I refused the Licence in the second place because by issuing the same I would act in direct opposition to Government Notice No.
('5', 140, 1, 5, 321730) 191, Government Gazette, of the 14th March, 1905, and the laws thereunder proclaimed to be in force in the Northern Districts, which distinctly prohibit the issuing of licences to Indians, except in Locations.
('5', 140, 1, 6, 321940) 3. I refused the Licence because in so doing I acted in the best interests and with the expressed feelings of the whole community, with the exception, perhaps, of the applicant’s Attorney.
('5', 140, 1, 7, 322129) This will more fully appear from copy of the record hereto attached.
('5', 140, 1, 8, 322198) 23. The first reason given by the Licensing Officer is entirely misleading in that your petitioner has been refused a licence to trade anywhere except in Locations.
('5', 140, 1, 9, 322363) 24. The second reason is also bad in accordance with the decision of the Supreme Court of the Transvaal above referred to.
('5', 140, 1, 10, 322486) 25. The third reason is the only real reason, that is to say, that your petitioner is a British Indian.
('5', 140, 1, 11, 322590) 26. There is no appeal under the said Act 18 of 1897 to the Supreme Court of the Colony, the decision of the Local Board being considered final.
('5', 140, 1, 12, 322735) 27. ('5', 141, 0, 1, 323459) 142 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('5', 141, 1, 4, 323849) 32. Your petitioner further submits that the manifest injury he has sustained ought not under the British Constitution to remain without a remedy.

('5', 141, 2, 8, 324379) 131. THE EARLY CLOSING ACT
('5', 141, 3, 9, 324406) A mountain is being made out of a molehill by some writers in the Natal Press on the Early Closing Act.
('5', 141, 3, 10, 324510) Many of them chuckle with delight that at last they are in a position to hurt the Indian trader.
('5', 141, 3, 11, 324607) Our contemporary, The Natal Advertiser, thinks with us that the Early Closing Act is not likely to detrimentally affect the Indian community, without more seriously affecting petty white traders.
('5', 141, 3, 12, 324803) Had it stopped there, we should have nothing to say, but it goes on to suggest that
('5', 141, 4, 13, 324887) a mass meeting should be called in the Town Hall, both of traders and working men, to consider this subject, and to devise some means for putting an effective check on this Asiatic immigration and competition.
('5', 141, 4, 14, 325097) If this were done, we have no doubt that the real facts of the situation would come out in a way that would astonish some people and lead to some really effective and useful action being taken.
('5', 141, 4, 15, 325291) This, we think, is no matter for playing with; it is a matter of self preservation, a matter of real life and death to the white people of all classes in Natal.
('5', 141, 4, 16, 325452) We propose calmly to consider the suggestion.
('5', 141, 4, 17, 325498) We have no objection to a mass meeting being held in the Town Hall; but will it attain the object desired by our contemporary?
('5', 141, 4, 18, 325625) Have the masses ever entered into a calm discussion of any subject?
('5', 141, 4, 19, 325693) A mass meeting can only give strength to a movement which is based on facts,
('5', 142, 0, 1, 325770) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 143
('5', 142, 1, 2, 325817) but it never sifts and finds true facts.
('5', 142, 1, 3, 325858) It is guided often by invective and appeals to passions.
('5', 142, 1, 4, 325915) Mass meetings, therefore, become dangerous when they are called upon to deal with a situation which has not been ascertained.
('5', 142, 1, 5, 326041) We will accept the premise that the question is one of “self preservation and of real life and death to the white people”.
('5', 142, 1, 6, 326164) Facts, therefore, have to be found and effective action taken thereon.
('5', 142, 1, 7, 326235) Now, one fact is absolutely clear, namely, that the Indian trader is entirely at the mercy of the Licensing Officer and Local Boards.
('5', 142, 1, 8, 326369) Another fact, too, is quite clear, that in several cases Licensing Officers and Local Boards have acted in a most arbitrary and high handed manner.
('5', 142, 1, 9, 326517) A third fact is that Mr. Harry Smith is watching with ever increasing vigilance the entry of every Indian immigrant into the Colony, and not an Indian is allowed to enter, either through the port or through the land border of the Colony, unless he can prove former domicile.
('5', 142, 1, 10, 326792) What more can be required ?
('5', 142, 1, 11, 326820) If it is a question of the working of these two laws, then certainly a mass meeting will not serve the purpose.
('5', 142, 1, 12, 326932) A commission of enquiry is the only remedy, and we would welcome it with open arms.
('5', 142, 1, 13, 327016) If it be really felt by the European population in Natal that the Indian trader is flourishing, that he is competing unfairly and that the stringent laws are not being stringently enforced, a small committee of impartial men would soon bring out the facts, and if they proved the existence of any such situation as feared by our contemporary, it would then be time enough to call a mass meeting to give point to the findingsof such a commission of enquiry.
('5', 142, 1, 14, 327473) Indian Opinion, 31 3 1906
('5', 142, 2, 15, 327499) 132. THE BULWARK OF JUSTICE
('5', 142, 3, 16, 327527) A very important case has just been heard before the Circuit Court in Potchefstroom.
('5', 142, 3, 17, 327612) An attempt was made by two Europeans to levy blackmail on an Indian merchant in Potchefstroom.
('5', 142, 3, 18, 327707) The method adopted was to take him to the wife of one of them, and there to charge him with an attempted rape.
('5', 142, 3, 19, 327818) The conspiracy was all but successful.
('5', 142, 3, 20, 327857) The blackmailers received £300 by cheque from the terrified Indian, but fortunately for the latter, he immediately sought legal help.
('5', 142, 3, 21, 327991) His lawyer advised him to stop payment of the cheque and lodge information with the police.
('5', 142, 3, 22, 328083) This was promptly done.
('5', 142, 3, 23, 328107) The men were arrested and so was the woman.
('5', 142, 3, 24, 328151) The result was a sensational case before Justice Wessels, and the Indian’s reputation was made good.
('5', 142, 3, 25, 328252) The charge of blackmail was proved, and the two male prisoners were sentenced to three years, imprisonment with hard labour.
('5', 142, 3, 26, 328377) There was no supporting evidence for the Indian’s story with reference to the
('5', 143, 0, 1, 328455) 144 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 143, 1, 2, 328497) blackmail; as against him, there were the two Dutch prisoners, who emphaticlly said that he was attempting to rape the female prisoner.
('5', 143, 1, 3, 328633) The Indian stoutly denied it and said that he was inveigled into the house and then falsely charged.
('5', 143, 1, 4, 328734) That, under such difficult circumstances an Indian has been able to get justice is a matter for universal congratulation, as it is of very great satisfaction to British Indians.
('5', 143, 1, 5, 328912) Once more it has been proved, in a most striking manner, that the fount of British justice, when it is a matter of the High Court, is the purest possible.
('5', 143, 1, 6, 329067) A long line of fearless and impartial judges has handed down traditions which have become an inherent part of the British Constitution, and we have no hesitation in saying that one of the greatest secrets of the success of the Empire is its ability to deal out even handed justice.
('5', 143, 1, 7, 329349) A case such as the one we have referred to makes up for many a defect in the legal administration in the various British possessions.
('5', 143, 1, 8, 329483) It serves as a beacon light to tell Indians, and all those who may suffer from temporary disabilities and consequent irritation, that they need not be without hope, so long as the fierce sun of pure justice beats on the chill surface of broken promises.
('5', 143, 1, 9, 329737) Justice Wessels in his summing up not only dealt with the case itself but felt called upon to deal generally with the right of the meanest British Subject to have a full and fair hearing.
('5', 143, 1, 10, 329925) “It was a painful thing,” said His Lordship, (we quote the report in the Potchefstroom Budget,)
('5', 143, 2, 11, 330021) to hear in this country—he had heard it in that Court that when they had a conflict of evidence between a white man and a black man, they ought to accept the testimony of the white man.
('5', 143, 2, 12, 330207) That was a fallacy, an untruth.
('5', 143, 2, 13, 330239) He thought the jury would act very wrongly if they accepted the testimony of the white man against the black that day.
('5', 143, 2, 14, 330358) The liberties and property of the black man should be respected to the utmost of their power.
('5', 143, 2, 15, 330452) There would be nothing more fatal than that they should, when they had the interests of the white and black man to deal with, for one moment swerve from their sense of justice.
('5', 143, 2, 16, 330629) The black man in this country must have as true justice meted out to him as the white man among the highest in the land.
('5', 143, 2, 17, 330750) That was a maxim they must keep before them, and not, because the prosecutor was a black man, let the prisoners off.
('5', 143, 2, 18, 330867) Every true lover of the Empire must feel deeply grateful to Justice Wessels for having so nobly vindicated British justice.
('5', 143, 2, 19, 330991) Indian Opinion, 31 3 1906
('5', 144, 0, 1, 331017) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 145
('5', 144, 1, 2, 331064) 133. INDIAN VOLUNTEERING
('5', 144, 2, 3, 331089) Mr. Watt, the Minister of Defence, has been “letting himself go” at a recent meeting which was held in connection with the militia.
('5', 144, 2, 4, 331221) In reply to a question:
('5', 144, 3, 5, 331245) Do the Government propose to make Arabs, in possession of stores in various parts of the Colony, join the militia reserves, and if so, will they provide them with rifles ?
('5', 144, 3, 6, 331417) the answer, we are told, which Mr. Watt gave, drew forth a round of applause.
('5', 144, 3, 7, 331495) “I am pleased,” he is reported to have said,
('5', 144, 4, 8, 331540) to say that the militia is composed entirely of Europeans.
('5', 144, 4, 9, 331599) I should be sorry indeed if I should have to depend for the defence of myself and family on Arabs, but the Government, I am glad to say, has power in time of war to turn out all the Coloured population—Indians, Natives and Arabs—for any service which may be necessary.
('5', 144, 4, 10, 331868) The following further question was then put:
('5', 144, 5, 11, 331913) Does the Government recognise that when the Europeans are called out, the Arabs will obtain the trade’ in all districts?
('5', 144, 5, 12, 332034) What do they propose doing in regard to this?
('5', 144, 5, 13, 332080) Mr. Watt’s reply was in keeping with the first:
('5', 144, 6, 14, 332128) That is a matter in which I think the leaders should have a voice.
('5', 144, 6, 15, 332195) If I were a leader, I should advise the Government to regulate the opening and closing times of shops.
('5', 144, 6, 16, 332298) I should see that Europeans were not treated worse than Arabs, and I should see that the Arabs had their share of the work, if not in carrying rifles, in digging trenches.
('5', 144, 6, 17, 332470) We have no doubt that, as Defence Minister, Mr. Watt knows that digging of trenches is just as necessary in warfare as the shouldering of a rifle.
('5', 144, 6, 18, 332617) If, then, he would not depend for his own and his family’s defence on Arabs, why will he have the latter to dig trenches?
('5', 144, 6, 19, 332739) Either work, we have it from the late Mr. Harry Escombe, who, too, was a Minister of Defence, is equally honourable.
('5', 144, 6, 20, 332856) Whether Mr. Watt, on reconsideration, would have himself or the Colony defended by Arabs and Indians or not, by the work of digging trenches or other work, how does he expect them to do any work in connection with warfare unless previous trainingis given?
('5', 144, 6, 21, 333112) Even the camp followers in an army require proper discipline, otherwise they are, instead of being a help, a positive nuisance.But we despair of having either common sense or justice at the hands of a Minister who so far forgets himself as to offer an unwarranted insult to a whole class of inoffensive people.
('5', 144, 6, 22, 333423) In contradistinction to the attitude shown on various occasions by the Minister of Defence—whose business it is as a Minister, we
('5', 145, 0, 1, 333553) 146 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 145, 1, 2, 333595) might remark, to put his personal prejudices in his pocket — we welcome an editorial in The Natal Advertiser of the other day, which we reprint elsewhere.
('5', 145, 1, 3, 333750) Our contemporary rightly gives Indians and Coloured people the credit due to them.
('5', 145, 1, 4, 333833) It also points out that Section 83 of the Militia Act states that no ordinary member of a Coloured contingent shall be armed with weapons of precision, unless such contingents are called out to operate against [persons] other than Europeans.
('5', 145, 1, 5, 334075) Now it is evident that, in the unfortunate event of such a state of affairs arising as to necessitate the arming of an Indian contingent, the arms would be useless in the hands of inexperienced men.
('5', 145, 1, 6, 334274) Why will not the authorities adopt the suggestion we made some time ago, 1 and raise a volunteer corps from amongst Indians ?
('5', 145, 1, 7, 334400) We feel sure the Colonial born Indians especially —Natal’s own children equally with the whites—would give a good account of themselves.
('5', 145, 1, 8, 334537) Why do not the Colonists insist on these, at all events, being given a chance to prove their mettle?

('5', 145, 2, 10, 334664) 134. THE TRANSVAAL CONSTITUTION The Home Government have lost no time in appointing the much talked of Committee of Inquiry on Transvaal affairs.
('5', 145, 2, 11, 334810) Two of the members, Sir West Ridgeway 2 and Lord Sandhurst 3, are men with Indian experience.
('5', 145, 2, 12, 334904) The scope of the inquiry is to be limited to finding out a basis for the new Constitution.
('5', 145, 2, 13, 334995) The Government do not 4 “find it possible to form a Constitution without information, and this it hopes to obtain from you”.
('5', 145, 2, 14, 335120) The Commissioners are to take into their consideration, amongst other things, “community or diversity of interests”, and political and social conditions; and though it is difficult to state whether the scope of the inquiry includes an examination of the question of Coloured franchise, it is to be hoped that the Commissioners will have full power to advise upon that difficult and delicate subject.
('5', 145, 2, 15, 335520) Events that are happening in the Transvaal and elsewhere show the force of the remarks made in these columns, that, in the absence of any other remedy for the protection of Indian rights, Indian representation seems to be necessary.

('5', 146, 1, 2, 335968) 135. INDIAN LABOUR FOR THE TRANSVAAL MINES
('5', 146, 2, 3, 336011) The Transvaal papers are full of cablegrams regarding the proposed negotiations with the Government of India for the supply of Indian labour.
('5', 146, 2, 4, 336153) We are glad that the Anglo Indians in England are hostile to the movement for two reasons; first, that there will be very great mortality amongst the Indian miners, and secondly, because Indian mine labourers are all required for mining enterprise in India itself.
('5', 146, 2, 5, 336418) It will be remembered that, when Lord Miner asked Lord Curzon to let him have ten thousand Indians for the railway works, Lord Curzon declined to give the assistance unless the grievances of British Indians resident in the Transvaal were redressed.
('5', 146, 2, 6, 336667) 1 This was two years ago.
('5', 146, 2, 7, 336693) The position of British Indians in the Transvaal is no better today than it was at the time Lord Curzon declained to come to the rescue.
('5', 146, 2, 8, 336830) There are, therefore, three good reasons why Indian labour should not be made available for the mines in the Transvaal.
('5', 146, 2, 9, 336950) We think that, in any case, the bartering of the liberty of Indian labourers for the removal of the disabilities of British Indian settlers in the Transvaal would not be a creditable act and would create a very bad precedent.
('5', 146, 2, 10, 337176) Each in our opinion, ought to be treated on its own merits.
('5', 146, 2, 11, 337236) We have no doubt that British Indians in the Transvaal would decline to receive greater freedom if it involved unjust and unnatural restrictions on the liberty of their poorer countrymen.
('5', 146, 2, 12, 337424) We also feel that an introduction of thousands of Indian mine labourers into the Transvaal would render more complicated a situation which is already fraught with many difficulties.
('5', 146, 2, 13, 337606) We, therefore, trust that.
('5', 146, 2, 14, 337633) both Mr. Morley and Lord Minto will firmly oppose any proposal to assist the Transvaal at the expense of the interests of their wards.
('5', 146, 2, 15, 337768) Indian Opinion, 31 3 1906
('5', 146, 3, 16, 337794) 136. INDIANS AT THE CAPE The Cape Government Gazette of the 16th March contains a Bill to amend the Cape Immigration Restriction Act of 1902. The Bill is decidedly a retrograde step, so far as British Indians are con cerned.
('5', 146, 3, 17, 338019) The Act of 1902 was conceived in secrecy and sprung upon the public in indecent haste, so much so that many members of the Cape Aseembly protested against its being rushed through the House.
('5', 146, 3, 18, 338210) However, the Act was passed.
('5', 146, 3, 19, 338239) Now, by the Bill in question, it is proposed to amend it.
('5', 146, 3, 20, 338297) British Indians who approached the Govern
('5', 146, 4, 21, 338339) 1 Vide “Indentured Labour Draft Ordinance in the Transvaal”, 14 1 1904
('5', 147, 0, 1, 338410) 148 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 147, 1, 2, 338452) ment were almost assured that the latter would take an early oppor tunity of altering the Act in the direction suggested by them, and that they would probably ask the House to recognise the great Indian languages for the educational test, and make suitable provision for the entry of domestic servants and others for the benefit of those that were already settled in that Colony.
('5', 147, 1, 3, 338832) Instead, however, of any such improvement being made in the Act, the Bill is calculated to place still further restrictions on the liberty of British Indians.
('5', 147, 1, 4, 338991) That it is of general application does not take away from its deadly effect on the Indians at whom it is mainly aimed.
('5', 147, 1, 5, 339110) There is no definition of an immigrant in the present Act.
('5', 147, 1, 6, 339169) The common law definition, therefore, that an immigrant is one who enters to settle in the country, is applicable under it, and therefore, by inference, the Act leaves it free for the Minister to grant visitors’ passes, and to allow Indians and others, who may enter the Colony for a temporary visit, to do so unmolested.
('5', 147, 1, 7, 339491) The Bill in question changes all this, and defines an immigrant to “mean and include any person who, arriving [from] without this Colony, enters or claims to enter from land or sea”.
('5', 147, 1, 8, 339674) We imagine that, in such a definition, which is quite artificial, there will be no room left for provision being made to enable mere visitors to pass through or sojourn in the Colony.
('5', 147, 1, 9, 339858) Another important difference the Bill makes is that, whereas the Act of 1902 excepts from its operation persons domiciled in South Africa, the Bill excepts only those who “prove to the satisfaction of the Minister that they are domiciled in the Colony, and that they do not come under sub sections c, e, and f of the preceding section”.
('5', 147, 1, 10, 340195) The restriction, therefore, is much more severe, and will put endless obstacles in the way of British Indians entering the Colony.
('5', 147, 1, 11, 340326) The question of domicile is now to be left in the hands of the Minister, instead of being left to the interpretation of the Supreme Court.
('5', 147, 1, 12, 340465) Only a few days ago, we commented upon a case that happened at the Cape where an Indian was able, because he could approach the Supreme Court, to make good his claim to a domicile in South Africa.
('5', 147, 1, 13, 340662) Had the poor man been left to the mercy of the Minister, he would have received short shrift.
('5', 147, 1, 14, 340756) Then, again, domicile under the Bill is to be restricted only to the Cape Colony.
('5', 147, 1, 15, 340838) Those, therefore, who are still in the Transvaal or Natal will be unable to enter that Colony.
('5', 147, 1, 16, 340933) We trust the British Indian League of Cape Town will take the matter up, and see that proper relief is granted.
('5', 147, 1, 17, 341045) Indian Opinion, 31 3 1906

('5', 148, 4, 12, 342058) This is no small injustice.

('5', 148, 4, 14, 342212) Mr. Suliman Manga, being a British subject, had a greater right than Mr. Nomura.
('5', 148, 4, 15, 342293) His education also gives him a better claim.
('5', 148, 4, 16, 342338) Yet he was not permitted to pass through the Transvaal.
('5', 148, 4, 17, 342394) This is only an instance of the present hardships.
('5', 148, 4, 18, 342445) But if all the reports we hear are correct, the promise made by Lord Selborne is being honoured only in the breach.

('5', 150, 3, 10, 345501) 143. JOHANNESBURG LETTER
('5', 150, 4, 11, 345526) ABDURAHMAN’S ADDRESS A large meeting of the Coloured people was held in the Milner Hall on March 21. Dr. Abdurahman, who is the President of the African Political Organization as well as a member of the Cape Town Municipality, had especially come here to attend it.
('5', 150, 4, 12, 345792) The meeting was presided over by Mr. Daniel, and the hall was packed, about 500 men attending.
('5', 150, 4, 13, 345887) Some Indians too were present, including Mr. Abdul Gani, Mr. Omar Haji Amod Zaveri, Mr. Haji Ojer Ally, Mr. Gandhi and others.
('5', 150, 4, 14, 346014) The following were the main points of Dr. Abdurahman’s speech.
('5', 150, 4, 15, 346077) PURPOSE OF MEETING “We have foregathered here today with a view to petitioning His Majesty about our rights.
('5', 150, 4, 16, 346186) The petition has already been drawn up and signatures of all the Coloured people are being obtained.
('5', 150, 4, 17, 346287) When we in the Cape learnt of the hardships suffered by you in the Transvaal and the Orange River Colony, we thought that we should do the best we could for you.
('5', 150, 4, 18, 346449) That would be in our interest as well.
('5', 150, 4, 19, 346488) For, if your rights are whittled down, the same may well happen to us in the Cape to.
('5', 150, 5, 20, 346574) OUR GRIEVANCES “The Coloured people in the Transvaal and the Orange River
('5', 151, 0, 1, 346648) 152 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 151, 1, 2, 346690) Colony have to suffer many deprivations.
('5', 151, 1, 3, 346731) But the most important among them is that they do not have franchise and have been divested of many civil rights.
('5', 151, 1, 4, 346845) If we continue in a state of slavery, our condition is bound to deteriorate from day to day.
('5', 151, 1, 5, 346938) There is no difference between taxing people without their consent and stealing their money.
('5', 151, 1, 6, 347031) If therefore the Coloured people do not possess the right to franchise, no taxes should be levied on them.
('5', 151, 1, 7, 347138) THE REMEDY “The best way to end these hardships is now to petition the King Emperor.
('5', 151, 1, 8, 347223) We have done all we could here in South Africa.
('5', 151, 1, 9, 347271) A new ministry has come into power in England, and hopes of these grievances being remedied have been aroused.
('5', 151, 1, 10, 347382) If we start putting forth our best efforts, we shall doubtless obtain our rights gradually.
('5', 151, 1, 11, 347474) “We are worthy of these rights.
('5', 151, 1, 12, 347506) The greatest hero of the South African War was Esau who sacrificed his life out of loyalty to the British.
('5', 151, 1, 13, 347613) When the majority of the Boers opposed the British Government, the Coloured people remained single mindedly loyal.
('5', 151, 1, 14, 347728) In the Cape, the Coloured people have the right of franchise just as thewhites have and they have never misused it.
('5', 151, 1, 15, 347844) If it is true that the war, as British officials have claimed, was fought for our sake, then there should be no oppression practised against us.
('5', 151, 2, 16, 347989) A DIFFICULTY “Our position is strong, and we should, therefore, by and large, acquire these rights.
('5', 151, 2, 17, 348089) But there appears to be an obstacle in the way.
('5', 151, 2, 18, 348137) When the peace treaty with the Dutch was signed, it was agreed that the Natives should not be granted the right to vote before responsible government had been established.
('5', 151, 2, 19, 348309) Everything hinges on the interpretation of the word ‘Native’.
('5', 151, 2, 20, 348371) If all those who are born in South Africa are to be regarded as Natives, the whites born there should also come under that category.
('5', 151, 2, 21, 348504) But no one would interpret the term thus.
('5', 151, 2, 22, 348546) The word ‘Native’ has but one meaning everywhere, viz., one whose mother and father are both Kaffirs.
('5', 151, 2, 23, 348648) If this interpretation is correct, we are not covered at all by the treaty with the Dutch.
('5', 151, 2, 24, 348739) This small lacuna in the treaty we owe to Lord Milner.
('5', 151, 2, 25, 348794) However, in the meeting at Bloemfontein, Lord Milner posed the question, ‘Even if everybody’s claims are met, what about the Coloured people?’ We too wish to ask the same question.”
('5', 151, 3, 26, 348976) RESOLUTIONS AT THE MEETING After this speech, two resolutions were passed: one adopting the draft of the Coloured People’s Petition, and the other deputing Dr. Abdurahman to act as our spokesman before Lord Selborne.
('5', 152, 0, 1, 349193) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 153
('5', 152, 1, 2, 349240) After the two resolutions were passed, God Save the King was sung, and the meeting dispersed.

('5', 154, 6, 12, 353765) DURBAN , [Before April 7, 1906]
('5', 154, 7, 13, 353797) TO THE HON.
('5', 154, 7, 14, 353809) THE COLONIAL SECRETARY PIETERMARITZBURG SIR, We have the honour to acknowledge your letter of the 24th ult., dealing with the subject matter of our letter of the 10th ult., 1 in an exhaustive manner for which the Committee of our Congress is obliged to you.
('5', 154, 7, 15, 354067) Our Committee freely admits that the passes and certificates referred to in our letter are intended for facilitating the movements of those who hold such passes.
('5', 154, 7, 16, 354229) The submission of our Committee is that such passes are issued for the satisfaction of those who desire the enforcement of the Act.
('5', 154, 7, 17, 354361) Our Committee contends that, although the immigration of certain persons affected by the Act is prohibited, their passage or their temporary sojourn in the Colony is not.
('5', 154, 7, 18, 354532) Although there is no obligation on the part of those who are entitled to remain in the Colony to take out domicile certificates, etc., the stringency with which the Act is being enforced renders it absolutely necessary that British Indians should hold them.
('5', 154, 8, 19, 354790) 1 Vide “Letter to Colonial Secretary”, Before 10 3 1906
('5', 155, 0, 1, 354846) 156 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 155, 1, 2, 354888) Our Committee is aware that most of the visiting passes are taken out by Indians in the Transvaal.
('5', 155, 1, 3, 354987) This is natural, as there is so much inter trade between the two Colonies.
('5', 155, 1, 4, 355062) Our Committee is of the humble opinion that every facility should be given to Transvaal Indians by issuing visiting passes.
('5', 155, 1, 5, 355186) Both visiting and embarkation passes, as to which a prohibitive fee has been imposed, are a source of considerable revenue to the railways.
('5', 155, 1, 6, 355326) The whole of this question was raised during the late Mr. Escombe’s administration when similar fees were imposed and, subsequently, on representations by our Committee, withdrawn.
('5', 155, 1, 7, 355507) Our Committee feels that the charge for wives’ passes, as also the embarkation and visitors’ passes, is a very serious thing and, therefore, requests reconsideration.

('5', 155, 6, 11, 355834) 147. LETTER TO THE ‘‘LEADER” 1
('5', 155, 7, 12, 355865) WHEN IS AN INDIAN NOT AN INDIAN ?
('5', 155, 8, 13, 355899) [JOHANNESBURG] Before April 7, 1906]
('5', 155, 9, 14, 355936) [TO THE EDITOR The Leader JOHANNESBURG
('5', 155, 10, 15, 355975) SIR,] Some time ago, you were pleased to offer to Mr. Nomura, a Japanese subject, a public apology, because the Chief Secretary for Permits had refused to grant to the gentleman a temporary permit.
('5', 155, 10, 16, 356173) May I enlist your sympathy on behalf of a British subject?
('5', 155, 11, 17, 356232) 1 This undated letter was published in the Leader of April 7 under the heading “Distinction without Difference”.
('5', 156, 0, 1, 356345) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 157
('5', 156, 1, 2, 356392) Mr. Suliman Manga 1, I understood, was a British Indian.
('5', 156, 1, 3, 356449) He is studying for the bar.
('5', 156, 1, 4, 356477) He has returned from England to pay a visit to his relatives in Delagoa Bay.

('5', 157, 5, 28, 360471) 149. THE HAVEN OF REFUGE
('5', 157, 6, 29, 360496) Amid all the turmoil that South Africa is passing through, the Court of the different Colonies have been standing out as places of safety.
('5', 157, 6, 30, 360635) We had the pleasure of reproducing Mr. Justice Wessels’
('5', 158, 0, 1, 360691) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 159
('5', 158, 1, 2, 360738) summing up in an Indian case 1; in this issue we give, from the Transvaal Leader, Mr. Justice Mason’s judgment in a Chinese case.
('5', 158, 1, 3, 360868) As it is the Transvaal which is at present suffering from the most arbitrary laws, it is there that the judges are called upon to exercise their traditional independence to protect the liberty of the subject.
('5', 158, 1, 4, 361077) A Chinese policeman in the employ of the Foreign Labour Department, having proved troublesome, was, it appears, without any warrant, arrested, handcuffed, and lodged in a cell at the instance of the Superintendent of the Foreign Labour Department, and under a section of the Chinese Labour Ordinance, ordered to be repatriated.
('5', 158, 1, 5, 361405) Before the unfortunate policeman was sent away to Durban, he was prevented from receiving legal assistance or from seeing his friends, and had it not been for the fact that he was able, surreptitiously and behind the back of the Superintendent, to sign a power of attorney appointing solicitors, he would probably have gone away to China without relief and without being heard.
('5', 158, 1, 6, 361783) Whether the policeman was a dangerous character or not is quite beside the point.
('5', 158, 1, 7, 361865) We do not enter into the merits of the case.
('5', 158, 1, 8, 361910) The Acts we have stated above are admitted.
('5', 158, 1, 9, 361954) The Superintendent of the Foreign Labour Department was informed that the solicitors who were retained by the man were going to apply to the Supreme Court for a writ of habeas corpus, and yet, before the writ was issued, the man was safely sent away to Durban.
('5', 158, 1, 10, 362215) The Superintendent was, however, called upon to appear before the Supreme Court and to produce the policeman.
('5', 158, 1, 11, 362325) At the hearing, which took place on the 30th day of March before Mr. Justice Mason in Pretoria, an attempt was again made to frustrate the application by the Superintendent stating that it was physically impossible for him toproduce the policeman,owing to the Chinese Labour Ordinance preventing any Chinaman from entering the country without a licence, and owing to such licences having been stopped.
('5', 158, 1, 12, 362727) The matter was argued by Mr. Smuts, on behalf of the Chinaman, and Mr. Justice Mason, in delivering judgment, strongly deprecated the action of the Superintendent.
('5', 158, 2, 13, 362891) One of the most serious features of the case was that, in substance and in fact, the Superintendent of Foreign Labour had brought to bear a tyrannical exercise of power in preventing any one from having access to the Chinese Sergeant.
('5', 158, 2, 14, 363126) He regarded that as a very serious thing indeed.
('5', 158, 2, 15, 363175) He thought the only way of preventing a person being illegally done away with and illegally treated was to uphold to the fullest extent the right of every person to have any of his friends to see him who chose to go.
('5', 158, 2, 16, 363392) His action had the effect of defeating
('5', 158, 3, 17, 363431) 1 Vide “The Bulwark of Justice”, 31 3 1906
('5', 159, 0, 1, 363474) 160 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 159, 1, 2, 363516) any such action, and he did wrong in sending the coolie out of the Colony with a notice, like that served by the solicitors, hanging over his head.
('5', 159, 1, 3, 363664) The learned Judge has made an order for the production of the man, and has ordered the Superintendent to show cause why he should not be punished for contempt of court by deporting the Chinaman from the Colony when he knew that an application was to be made for his protection before the Court.
('5', 159, 1, 4, 363959) He also ordered that Mr. Jamieson 1 should pay all the costs, as between attorney and client, of the application, and added that “he made that order chiefly because of, what he has called before, ‘the tyrannical exercise of power in preventing any person from having access to the applicant’ ”.
('5', 159, 1, 5, 364254) Here is an official, on the one hand, enjoying a very influential position, and, on the other hand, a humble policeman, and yet the policeman has been able to make good his right of being heard before the highest tribunal of justice in the Transvaal.
('5', 159, 1, 6, 364505) The Superintendent himself must feel proud of an institution which thus protects the liberty of the meanest subject under the Crown; for what has happened to the Chinaman at his hands, it is quite conceivable, may happen to the Superintendent at the hands of those who may be superior to him.
('5', 159, 1, 7, 364798) It may be a mere error of judgment on Mr. Jamieson’s part, but it is better that he should suffer rather than that the liberty of the subject should remain without vindication.
('5', 159, 1, 8, 364975) Indian Opinion, 7 4 1906
('5', 159, 2, 9, 365000) 150. THE INDENTURE TAX
('5', 159, 3, 10, 365023) We took from The Times of Natal, last week, a report of a prosecution, under the Immigration Law of the Colony, for recovering the annual tax of £3. On looking through The Natal Witness, we find that the prosecution was not only against himself, but also against his wife.
('5', 159, 3, 11, 365296) The only manner provided by law of recovering the tax is “by summary process by any clerk of the peace or other officer appointed to get in such licence money”.
('5', 159, 3, 12, 365457) In the process, it appears the personal jewellery of the Indian woman has been taken, under order of Court, by the prosecuting sergeant as security.
('5', 159, 3, 13, 365606) She has been given three months within which to pay the tax, under pain of her jewellery being sold if the tax is not paid within the period.
('5', 159, 3, 14, 365748) Both the magistrate and the prosecuting sergeant have been considerate, and yet the grievous hardship that indentured Indians, who become free, have to suffer, by reason of the imposition, has been clearly brought out by the prosecution.

('5', 160, 2, 5, 366406) 151. POLITICAL TURMOIL IN NATAL
('5', 160, 3, 6, 366438) Important events, the effects of which will not be forgotten for many years, took place in Natal last week.
('5', 160, 3, 7, 366546) As a result of these, Natal has gained in stature.
('5', 160, 3, 8, 366597) The cause of self government has triumphed; but the British Empire has received a set back.
('5', 160, 3, 9, 366689) The Kaffirs in Natal rose in revolt against the poll tax.
('5', 160, 3, 10, 366747) Sergeants Hunt and Armstrong 1 were killed in the revolt; martial law was declared in Natal and the Kaffirs were severely dealt with.
('5', 160, 3, 11, 366881) Some Kaffirs were prosecuted under the martial law, and twelve of them were condemned to death and blown up at the mouth of a cannon.
('5', 160, 3, 12, 367015) The Kaffirs from neighbouring areas and their Chief were invited to witness the execution, which was to take place on March 29. Meanwhile, Lord Elgin sent a cablegram from England to the Governor of Natal, asking him to suspend the execution of the sentence.
('5', 160, 3, 13, 367274) The executive councillors of the Natal Government resented this and tendered their resignations to the Governor.
('5', 160, 3, 14, 367387) The Governor asked them to wait until a further communication was received from Lord Elgin, and to this they agreed.
('5', 160, 3, 15, 367504) As soon as the full story became known, a wave of excitement swept over the whole of South Africa.
('5', 160, 3, 16, 367603) The Press protested vehemently, arguing that the constitution of self governing Natal was violated by Lord Elgin’s intervention.
('5', 160, 3, 17, 367732) They said that, as Natal was a self governing Colony, the Imperial Government could not interfere in its administration.
('5', 160, 3, 18, 367853) Congratulations were showered from every side on the executive councillors for having resigned.
('5', 160, 3, 19, 367949) Meetings were held at many places, and speeches made against the Imperial Government.
('5', 160, 3, 20, 368035) The Imperial Government believed that, since they had helped Natal to put down the rebellion, it was their duty to see that justice wasdone to the Kaffirs; and hence they saw nothing improper in asking the Natal Government to put off execution of the sentence.
('5', 160, 3, 21, 368296) But South Africa became excited, the arguments of the Imperial Government proved unavailing, and Lord Elgin had to bow down before Natal opinion.
('5', 160, 4, 22, 368442) 1 Sub Inspector Hunt and Trooper Armstrong of the Natal Police
('5', 161, 0, 1, 368505) 162 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 161, 1, 2, 368547) Lord Elgin has written to the Governor that, on inquiry, it was found that justice had been done in the case of the Kaffirs, that the Imperial Government did not now wish to interfere in the administration by the executive councillors of Natal, and that they could do what they deemed proper.
('5', 161, 1, 3, 368840) Lord Elgin has, however, put the entire blame on the Governor.
('5', 161, 1, 4, 368903) He further says that no intervention bythe Imperial Government would have taken place if the Governor had supplied all the facts of the case at the outset.
('5', 161, 1, 5, 369059) Twelve lives have been taken for two.
('5', 161, 1, 6, 369097) The twelve Kaffirs were blown to death at the mouth of a cannon on Monday.
('5', 161, 1, 7, 369172) During all this excitement, only one man kept a cool head, and that was Mr. Morcum.
('5', 161, 1, 8, 369256) At a meeting in Maritzburg, he declared that Lord Elgin’s move was quite proper.
('5', 161, 1, 9, 369337) It was a matter of saving human life, and there was no need for the executive to resign.
('5', 161, 1, 10, 369426) Hunt and Armstrong were killed before martial law was declared; and hence the Kaffirs ought to have been tried by the Supreme Court.
('5', 161, 1, 11, 369559) The whole meeting was against him, and though they hissed and hooted at him, the brave Mr. Morcum had his way.
('5', 161, 1, 12, 369670) What is the outcome of all this?
('5', 161, 1, 13, 369703) That some Kaffirs were killed will soon be forgotten.
('5', 161, 1, 14, 369757) We cannot say for certain whether or not theyhave received justice.But wherever self government has been granted, a people become overweening.
('5', 161, 1, 15, 369900) They will take undue liberties, and the Imperial Government will hesitate to intervene.
('5', 161, 1, 16, 369988) It will seldom do so, for, as the saying goes, a man once bitten by a serpent dreads even a length of rope.
('5', 161, 1, 17, 370096) It is only the Coloured people who stand to lose by this.
('5', 161, 1, 18, 370154) They have no vote.
('5', 161, 1, 19, 370173) Where they have it they cannot use it effectively, so that the Colonial authority will place greater restrictions on them, and they alone will get justice who ingratiate themselves with it.
('5', 161, 1, 20, 370363) Great changes are likely to take place in South Africa during the coming years.
('5', 161, 1, 21, 370443) The Indians and other Coloured people have much to ponder and they must act with circumspection.

('5', 161, 2, 23, 370581) 152. THE LAND ACT IN THE TRANSVAAL
('5', 161, 3, 24, 370616) AN IMPORTANT LAW SUIT In the Transvaal, there was only one plot of land outside the Location registered in the name of an Indian, the well known Sheth Abubaker Amod, who is no more.
('5', 161, 3, 25, 370798) The land was in Church Street in Pretoria.
('5', 161, 3, 26, 370841) The late Mr. Abubaker bought it in June 1885, and the sale deed was presented at the Registrar’s office on June 12, 1885.
('5', 162, 0, 1, 370963) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 163
('5', 162, 1, 2, 371010) The anti Indian Act came into force on June 17. There were some difficulties in getting the deed registered.
('5', 162, 1, 3, 371119) The British Agent intervened, and it was only after a special letter was written by the State Attorney that the Registrar registered the documents on June 26. Mr. Abubaker died in 1888. Until now, the possession and enjoyment of the land has vested in the heirs or trustees of the late Mr. Abubaker.
('5', 162, 1, 4, 371419) According to law, the disposal of a man’s estate on his death should be through the Government.
('5', 162, 1, 5, 371515) This estate has not, however, been dealt with in this manner, and the land has remained untransferred to the heirs.
('5', 162, 1, 6, 371631) When the land fell vacant in 1905, it was decided to let it out on a long lease for building a house on it.
('5', 162, 1, 7, 371739) Now, according to the Transvaal laws, every long lease has to be registered at the Registrar’s office.
('5', 162, 1, 8, 371842) Hence steps had to be taken to have the land transferred to the names of the heirs, for, under the law, land could not remain in the name of a deceased person.
('5', 162, 1, 9, 372002) The heirs being Indians, the Registrar refused to transfer the land to them.
('5', 162, 1, 10, 372079) Thereupon an appeal was filed against the Registrar before a civil judge.
('5', 162, 1, 11, 372153) The Registrar put forward two reasons for not transferring the land to the heirs.
('5', 162, 1, 12, 372235) First, the land was registered after Act 3 of 1885 had been passed; and since that Law prohibited Indians from holding land in their names, the sale deed executed in favour of the late Mr. Abubaker was void and should therefore be cancelled.
('5', 162, 1, 13, 372477) Secondly, even if it was conceded that the sale deed in favour of Mr. Abubaker was legally valid, his heirs, being Indians, could not hold the land in their own names under the Act of 1885. Justice Fox who heard the appeal accepted the Registrar’s second plea, and dismissed the case.
('5', 162, 1, 14, 372762) An appeal against this decision was preferred to the Supreme Court on behalf of the heirs.
('5', 162, 1, 15, 372853) Barristers Leonard and Gregorowski were engaged by the heirs, on whose behalf they represented that, if the Supreme Court did not order the land to be transferred to the names of the heirs, they should at least pass orders for the registration of the 21 year lease and allow meanwhile the original deed to remain in the name of the late Mr. Abubaker.
('5', 162, 1, 16, 373204) Mr. Leonard advanced strong arguments and the judges expressed much sympathy, but regretted that they were helpless to do justice by the heirs.
('5', 162, 1, 17, 373348) The judges admitted that the Act of 1885 itself was very bad, and if they wanted justice in spite of that law, they could get it only from Parliament.
('5', 162, 1, 18, 373499) In view of this judgment, the only remedy left to the heirs to save the land for the time being was to get it transferred to some white person andthemselves retain physical possession.
('5', 162, 1, 19, 373684) This step they have taken and their enjoyment of the property will not therefore be hampered in any way.
('5', 162, 1, 20, 373789) However, the fact that, according to the judgment of the Supreme Court, the land cannot be transferred to the heirs’ names is bound to make them feel
('5', 163, 0, 1, 373939) 164 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 163, 1, 2, 373981) oppressed.
('5', 163, 1, 3, 373992) The only thing that remains to be done is to carry on a political struggle through Parliament.
('5', 163, 1, 4, 374087) We know that they will do so.
('5', 163, 1, 5, 374117) Thejudgment in this case makes it quite clear that even the judges admit that the Act of 1885 is oppressive.
('5', 163, 1, 6, 374226) Sir Henry Cotton has asked a question about this in the Imperial Parliament.
('5', 163, 1, 7, 374303) We shall await the outcome.

('5', 167, 7, 12, 382345) 25 & 26 COURT CHAMBERS, RISSIK STREET, JOHANNESBURG, April 12, 1906 SIR WILLIAM WEDDERBURN PALACE CHAMBERS LONDON
('5', 167, 8, 13, 382459) SIR, The position in the Transvaal of British Indians is getting day by day more insecure and harassing.
('5', 167, 8, 14, 382564) I need only recapitulate what is happening and appeal for active work.
('5', 167, 8, 15, 382635) Whilst it is true that the Home Government will be slow to interfere with the Crown Colony of the Transvaal, I take it there must be a limit to this policy of non intervention.
('5', 167, 8, 16, 382812) There is a Peace Preservation Ordinance in the Transvaal under which the immigration of British Indians is restricted in a most high handed manner.
('5', 167, 8, 17, 382960) (a) The Ordinance was intended to preserve the peace [and], therefore, to keep out rebels and others who were ill disposed towards
('5', 167, 9, 18, 383091) 1 This seems to be a circular letter.
('5', 167, 9, 19, 383129) A copy of it was sent to Dadabhai Naoroji who, omitting the last paragraph, forwarded it in the form of a statement to the Secretary of State for the Colonies on May 8, 1906.
('5', 168, 0, 1, 383304) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 169
('5', 168, 1, 2, 383351) the British Government, but it is today being, in fact, solely used to restrict British Indian immigration.
('5', 168, 1, 3, 383459) (b) The British Indian Association has accepted the position that non refugee British Indians who do not possess educational attainments may be kept out.
('5', 168, 1, 4, 383613) (c) As a matter of fact, even refugees who were in the Colony before the war and who had paid £3 as a price for permission to reside in the Colony are now being prevented from entering, except under most difficult circumstances.
('5', 168, 1, 5, 383842) (d) Such men have to wait in the coast towns for months before the permit officer would issue them a permit.
('5', 168, 1, 6, 383951) (e) A most vexing examination is carried on and then they are called upon to put their thumb impressions and to undergo other unnecessary severities before they get a permit to enter the country.
('5', 168, 1, 7, 384147) (f) Their wives, too, are often required to produce documents before they are allowed to enter the Transvaal.
('5', 168, 1, 8, 384257) (g) Their children over eleven years are totally prevented from accompanying them.
('5', 168, 1, 9, 384340) (h) Children under twelve of such refugees are made to take out permits before they can come.
('5', 168, 1, 10, 384434) Just recently, a boy under six years was torn away from his father and detained at Volksrust because he did not hold a separate permit, in spite of the fact that the registration certificate of the father mentioned that he had two boys.
('5', 168, 1, 11, 384671) (i) Only three months ago, boys under sixteen, if they had their parents, or if their parents were dead and they were with their guardians in the Transvaal domiciled, were free to enter the Transvaal.
('5', 168, 1, 12, 384872) Now, as mentioned above, all of a sudden a new regulation has been sprung upon the Indian community and boys who are under twelve only are allowed to enter.
('5', 168, 1, 13, 385029) The result is that many boys under sixteen who have arrived in South Africa after considerable expense have, instead of joining their parents who are domiciled in the Transvaal, to return to India.
('5', 168, 1, 14, 385227) (j) About three months ago, temporary permits for Indians, who wished to pass through the Transvaal on their way to other parts of South Africa or intended to do some business, were granted fairly freely; now such permits are issued after the greatest scrutiny.
('5', 168, 1, 15, 385489) Mr. Suliman Manga, 1 the son of a well known Indian merchant of Delagoa Bay, who is studying at present in England for the Bar, recently returned from England to pay a visit to his relatives in Delagoa Bay.
('5', 168, 1, 16, 385696) He landed at Durban, applied for a permit to enable him to pass

('5', 169, 0, 1, 385816) 170 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 169, 1, 2, 385858) through the Transvaal on his way to Delagoa Bay and the permit was refused.
('5', 169, 1, 3, 385934) His case was considered as if he was a British Indian.
('5', 169, 1, 4, 385989) He went to Delagoa Bay, therefore, by sea.
('5', 169, 1, 5, 386032) There he attempted again through the Transvaal Government to receive a temporary permit as he intended to see Pretoria and Johannesburg but his application was refused.
('5', 169, 1, 6, 386201) He, therefore, thought that he, having been born in Portuguese India, should approach the Portuguese Government.
('5', 169, 1, 7, 386314) He did so and a permit was immediately issued to him.
('5', 169, 1, 8, 386368) It comes, therefore, to this that a British Indian, no matter what his status may be, cannot even pass through the Transvaal and have safe conduct, but if an Indian belongs to a foreign power, he gets a permit for the asking.
('5', 169, 1, 9, 386594) (k) From the above, it follows that Indians of attainments are unable to get a permit to settle in the Transvaal, that is to say, the Peace Preservation Ordinance is so administered that, whereas before war any Indian was free to enter the Transvaal, now an Indian who can enter by reason of his being able to pass the educational test of the self governing Colony of the Cape or Natal is debarred from entering the Crown Colony of the Transvaal.
('5', 169, 1, 10, 387041) Here, there is no question of the British Government having inherited pre war legislation, but it is a question of deliberate[ly] pressing into service an ordinance passed just after martial law and which ordinance had no connection with British Indians.
('5', 169, 1, 11, 387296) Under Law 3 of 1885, the British Indian heirs of the late Mr. Aboobaker Amod, one of the Indian pioneer settlers of South Africa, have been prevented from having the property left to them registered in their names.
('5', 169, 1, 12, 387511) 1 Such is the working of the law regarding ownership of and by Indians.
('5', 169, 1, 13, 387583) It should be noticed that Natives of the Transvaal, as is quite proper, are free to own landed property anywhere they choose.
('5', 169, 1, 14, 387709) The Cape Coloured people are also free to hold immovable property in the Transvaal.
('5', 169, 1, 15, 387793) The ban is placed only upon Asiatics.
('5', 169, 1, 16, 387831) Before war, Indians were not debarred from making use of any train service in the Transvaal.
('5', 169, 1, 17, 387924) Now the Railway Board has issued notices to the station masters not to issue tickets to British Indians and Coloured people for an express train service between Pretoria and Johannesburg, 2 thus causing serious inconvenience to Indian businessmen.
('5', 169, 1, 18, 388172) It is highly probable that relief will be ultimately granted, but this notice shows which way the tendency of the Government lies.
('5', 169, 1, 19, 388303) In Johannesburg, as in Pretoria, British Indians and Coloured

('5', 170, 2, 3, 388566) In Natal, the position is briefly as follows: The Dealers’ Licenses Act causes the greatest amount of mischief.
('5', 170, 2, 4, 388678) Mr. Dada Osman, a British Indian merchant of very long standing, had his store in Vryheid before war when it was part of the Transvaal, [and] he traded there unfettered.
('5', 170, 2, 5, 388848) When Vryheid was incorporated with Natal, the anti Asiatic laws were also taken over, so that in Vryheid there is Law 3 of 1885 in force as also the Natal Dealers’ Licenses Act.
('5', 170, 2, 6, 389026) Acting thereunder, Mr. Dada Osman’s licence has been taken away from him and his Vryheid business has been totally ruined.

('5', 170, 2, 14, 389716) This, however, is not true.
('5', 170, 2, 15, 389744) The white man in question was known to have allowed his sub tenants to traffic in liquor sold to Natives and was convicted of selling opium on his premises.

('5', 170, 2, 21, 390571) It is not possible to give cases of greater hardship than those quoted above.
('5', 170, 2, 22, 390649) All that is claimed by British Indians is that the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court over the decisions of the Licensing Officers and the Licensing Boards, which consist mainly of traders, should be restored.
('5', 170, 2, 23, 390858) Under the Immigration Restriction Act, rules have been now framed whereby a fee of £1 is imposed for the issue of a domicile

('5', 171, 3, 9, 391885) 158. JOHANNESBURG LETTER
('5', 171, 4, 10, 391910) JOHANNESBURG, April 13, 1906
('5', 171, 5, 11, 391939) CAUTION TO INDIAN LAND OWNERS IN TRANSVAAL I have come across a very important case which concerns the vast majority of Indians who own land in the Transvaal.
('5', 171, 5, 12, 392098) A certain Indian holds land in the name of a White.
('5', 171, 5, 13, 392150) He has secured no bond from the latter, who is practically on the verge of insolvency.
('5', 171, 5, 14, 392237) It has now become extremely difficult to save this land.
('5', 171, 5, 15, 392294) The White himself is eager enough to help.
('5', 171, 5, 16, 392337) He has no right over the land but, since there is no bond against it, there is every danger of his creditors swallowing it up.
('5', 171, 5, 17, 392464) If a bond had been secured from the White in time, no such contingency would have arisen.
('5', 171, 5, 18, 392554) After this case, it is imperative that every Indian who holds land in the name of a White should secure a bond against it, however trustworthy the White may be; otherwise he will run the risk of being put to a severe loss.

('5', 173, 1, 2, 394946) 160. A HARD CASE
('5', 173, 2, 3, 394963) We gave last week a resume of a licensing appeal case heard in Ladysmith on the 30th March last.
('5', 173, 2, 4, 395060) An Indian trader has been trading within Klip River Division on a farm called Wittekleifontein for the last three years.
('5', 173, 2, 5, 395181) Latterly, a European firm, by name Burdett & Co.
('5', 173, 2, 6, 395230) has opened a store near his.
('5', 173, 2, 7, 395259) The firm has amongst its partners, so it would appear from a report in The Natal Witness, Sergeant Batterberg, who is the Prosecutor for the Division.
('5', 173, 2, 8, 395410) During his absence, the Indian trader’s store assistant was trapped by the police and convicted of Sunday trading.
('5', 173, 2, 9, 395525) He sold a bit of soap and some sugar.
('5', 173, 2, 10, 395563) The store keeper, on his return, finding that his assistant had been guilty of trading on Sunday, dismissed him.
('5', 173, 2, 11, 395676) When the time came for renewal, Messrs Burdett & Co.
('5', 173, 2, 12, 395729) lodged their objection with the Licensing Officer against the Indian store keeper’s getting a renewal of his licence, on the ground that he had committed a breach of the Sunday law.
('5', 173, 2, 13, 395911) The Licensing Officer upheld this objection, and the licence was refused.
('5', 173, 2, 14, 395985) Against this decision, the poor Indian store keeper appealed to the Licensing Board, but in spite of the eloquent defence of his counsel, the appeal was dismissed, and the Board, in giving judgment, said that they did so because of a breach by the store keeper’s assistant of the Sunday regulations, and they supported their decision by quoting a similar case where they [had] refused the application for a licence made by a European.
('5', 173, 2, 15, 396420) 1 We think, however, that the European case quoted by the Board could have no bearing on the present case, as some of the ingredients were wanting.
('5', 173, 2, 16, 396568) Here, the Indian store keeper himself has not committed the crime.
('5', 173, 2, 17, 396635) He repaired the mischief in the only manner that was possible for him, and, after all, it is patent to any layman that the whole of the objection has been raised by a rival firm of store keepers who are interested in removing the Indian store keeper.
('5', 173, 2, 18, 396886) The fact, too, that the firm contains, as its partner, the Public Prosecutor in Ladysmith, who conducted the prosecution against the Indian’s store man, is not without serious significance.
('5', 173, 2, 19, 397076) It is indeed a pity that the Board did not allow the objection raised by the appellant’s counsel that Burdett & Co.
('5', 173, 2, 20, 397192) had no locus standi before the Board, and we cannot help thinking that the Board have, by their decision, encouraged opposition of the kind raised in the case in question.
('5', 173, 2, 21, 397364) The deprivation of a licence is altogether a disproportionate penalty imposed on a man for a breach of a statutory provision by his servant, who had already been punished for the same offence.
('5', 173, 2, 22, 397557) But this
('5', 173, 3, 23, 397566) 1 Vide “The Ladysmith Licensing Board”, 21 4 1906
('5', 174, 0, 1, 397616) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 175
('5', 174, 1, 2, 397663) case merely illustrates how unjust and oppressive the Dealers’ Licenses Act of Natal is.
('5', 174, 1, 3, 397752) The Ladysmith case supports the argument advanced in Dada Osman’s petition 1. Unless the right of appeal to the Supreme Court is restored, there is no possibility of any justice being done under the Dealers’ Licenses Act.
('5', 174, 1, 4, 397974) Indian Opinion, 14 4 1906
('5', 174, 2, 5, 398000) 161. THE TRANSVAAL PERMIT ORDINANCE The Peace Preservation Ordinance, passed at a time when, as its name implies, peace within the Transvaal borders was in danger, has hung over the heads of British Indians like Damocles’ sword, ready to descend upon them at any moment.
('5', 174, 2, 6, 398271) The latest instance is brought to our readers’ notice by our Transvaal correspondent.
('5', 174, 2, 7, 398357) 2 It appears that Mr. Suliman Manga, the son of a very well known Indian in Delagoa Bay, has been studying for the Bar for some years in England, and has been admitted as a member of the Middle Temple.
('5', 174, 2, 8, 398559) He has just arrived from England to pay a visit to his relatives in Delagoa Bay.
('5', 174, 2, 9, 398640) On his landing at Durban, he intended to pass through the Transvaal on his way to Delagoa Bay.
('5', 174, 2, 10, 398735) He instructed a solicitor in Johannesburg to apply for his permit.
('5', 174, 2, 11, 398802) The solicitor, Mr. Gandhi, seems to have assumed that he was a British Indian, and proceeded with the application.
('5', 174, 2, 12, 398917) After a few days’ delay, he received a reply saying that his client could not be granted a temporary permit.
('5', 174, 2, 13, 399026) He then applied to the Colonial Secretary and received the same answer.
('5', 174, 2, 14, 399098) No reasons were given for the refusal.
('5', 174, 2, 15, 399137) Mr. Manga then took a steamer to Delagoa Bay.
('5', 174, 2, 16, 399183) Young, enthusiastic, and freshly returned from England, he could not brook rejection of his application.
('5', 174, 2, 17, 399288) During his brief stay, he wanted to see the capital of the Transvaal, and the centre of the gold mining activity.
('5', 174, 2, 18, 399402) He, therefore, again applied to the port Protector of Asiatics, who could only confirm the reply given to his solicitor.
('5', 174, 2, 19, 399523) Mr. Manga, being in fact a Portuguese subject, then appealed to his own Government, who soon procured relief for their subject, and Mr. Manga entered the Transvaal on a temporary permit granted to him by His Majesty’s British Consul General.
('5', 174, 2, 20, 399765) This is an instance of a most glaring abuse of arbitrary powers vested in the hands of the Government.
('5', 174, 2, 21, 399868) We may here recall the parallel case of Mr. Nomura, a Japanese subject.
('5', 174, 2, 22, 399940) This gentleman, in order to dispose ofhis wares in the Transvaal, applied for a temporarypermit, which the Chief Secretary for Permits declined to
('5', 174, 3, 23, 400087) 1 Vide “Petition to Lord Elgin”, 30 3 1906.
('5', 174, 4, 24, 400131) 2 Vide “Letter to the Leader”, Before 7 4 1906
('5', 175, 0, 1, 400178) 176 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 175, 1, 2, 400220) He evidently reasoned to himself that, if a British subject could not get similar facilities, he could not grant it to Mr. Nomura.
('5', 175, 1, 3, 400351) 1 The case was publicly discussed, and the Transvaal Leader offered a public apology to Mr. Nomura.
('5', 175, 1, 4, 400451) The High Commissioner immediately ordered the Chief Secretary for Permits to issue a permit to Mr. Nomura, and it was delivered to him personally at his residence in Durban.
('5', 175, 1, 5, 400625) Mr. Manga’s case is much stronger than Mr. Nomura’s.
('5', 175, 1, 6, 400678) As it was first put before the Colonial Secretary, it was a case of a British subject and a student asking for permission merely to pass through the Transvaal.
('5', 175, 1, 7, 400838) He had no business to transact in the Colony, and, therefore, he could not come into competition with anybody.
('5', 175, 1, 8, 400949) We question whether the most rabid member of the anti Asiatic Convention could ever have contemplated rejection of an application like Mr. Manga’s, and yet so long as Mr. Manga was considered as a British subject, and so long as there was no intervention on the part of any foreign government, his case was not considered worthy of attention by the Transvaal Government.
('5', 175, 1, 9, 401320) So soon, however, as it is known that Mr. Manga happens to be a Portuguese subject, he gets a permit.
('5', 175, 1, 10, 401422) The net result of this case is that, at the hands of the present Government in the Transvaal, there is to be no justice for British Indians.
('5', 175, 1, 11, 401563) The latter may be insulted, they may be put to all kinds of inconvenience, their applications may be summarily rejected, they may not be given reasons for arbitrary decisions of the Government, even though bona fide refugees, it may take months before their claims can be considered for re entry into the Transvaal, their very means of livelihood may be allowed to depend on the absolute discretion of the Government.
('5', 175, 1, 12, 401981) Yet we have Lord Selborne’s assurance that it is not his desire that Indians should be treated in a harsh manner, or that regulations under the Peace Preservation Ordinance should in any way be unreasonable.
('5', 175, 1, 13, 402189) 2 The community has every right, therefore, to appeal to Lord Selborne for some measure of justice being meted out to it.
('5', 175, 1, 14, 402311) Indian Opinion, 14 4 1906

('5', 176, 1, 2, 402465) 162. A LICENSING PETITION
('5', 176, 2, 3, 402491) Our readers will recall the facts in connection with the licence of a British Indian in Vryheid.
('5', 176, 2, 4, 402588) Mr. Dada Osman, the Indian merchant concerned, having failed to obtain the justice to which he was entitled, owing to the state of the Dealers’ Licenses Act, has now approached His Majesty’s Principal Secretary of State for the Colonies, 1 and has forwarded to us a copy ofthe petition for review.
('5', 176, 2, 5, 402886) The petition is a colourless statement of facts, but it shows most clearly that underlying it is the general question as to the operation of the Dealers’ Licenses Act.
('5', 176, 2, 6, 403054) Unless it is erased from the Statute book of the Colony, there will be no rest for British Indian traders.
('5', 176, 2, 7, 403161) It is not fair to them, and it is less fair to the licensing officers, that arbitrary powers should be placed in the latter’s hands.
('5', 176, 2, 8, 403294) We do not ask for indiscriminate trading rights, but we do contend that every trading application should be treated on its merits, and where no reasons, save those of prejudice, can be adduced against such application, it should be granted.
('5', 176, 2, 9, 403535) The case before us is aggravated, because the petitioner labours under a double barrelled disability, for, in Vryheid, he, being a British Indian, labours under all the disabilities of the Natal laws, without getting any of the advantages, as Law 3 of 1885 of the Transvaal has also been retained, in spite of the incorporation of Vryheid with Natal.
('5', 176, 2, 10, 403886) The condition is as anomalous as it possibly could be, and it is to be hoped that Lord Elgin will secure substantial justice for his petitioner.
('5', 176, 2, 11, 404031) The question of interference with the domestic affairs of the Colony will naturally be raised.
('5', 176, 2, 12, 404126) The principle of non interference can hardly stand, in the case of those who are totally unrepresented in a Colony governed under representative institutions.
('5', 176, 2, 13, 404285) Natal enjoys self government, on the tacit assumption that it is capable of governing itself.
('5', 176, 2, 14, 404379) There is little self government exercised, when one class of subjects living in the Colony are meted out scant justice.
('5', 176, 2, 15, 404499) Self government means self control; if privileges are granted, responsibilities must be assumed also, and if these privileges are enjoyed to the fullest extent, without discharge of the responsibilities, the power that gave them surely has the right to see to it that those responsibilities are properly discharged.

('5', 176, 3, 17, 404841) 1 Vide “Petition to Lord Elgin”, 30 3 1906

('5', 177, 1, 2, 404926) 163. A LICENSING CIRCULAR
('5', 177, 2, 3, 404952) A Gujarati correspondent draws our attention to some rules said to have been framed by the Government for the guidance of traders’ licenses officers.

('5', 177, 2, 5, 405286) This, we understand, has been done in order to establish identity.

('5', 177, 2, 7, 405500) Where is the occasion for establishing identity?

('5', 177, 2, 9, 405692) Do they, in other words, mean to convey to the Licensing Officers that Indian businesses are to become extinct with their owners?
('5', 177, 2, 10, 405822) If so, it means that, sooner or later, every Indian must be compelled to sell off, instead ofdisposing of his business as a going concern.
('5', 177, 2, 11, 405961) And why should the Government interfere with the administration of the law in such a one sided manner?

('5', 177, 2, 13, 406296) The position under the Licensing Law is becoming more and more unbearable, and unless some relief can be granted by the Home Government, it is merely a question of time as to when British Indian traders in Natal will have to close their businesses entirely.

('5', 179, 4, 12, 410877) 166. THE LADYSMITH LICENSING BOARD
('5', 179, 5, 13, 410912) We have already dealt with what has appeared to us to be a case of very great injustice done to an inoffensive Indian trader.
('5', 179, 5, 14, 411038) 1 We have since been placed in possession of fuller information regarding the case of Mackillican referred to by the appellate court in support of its decision.
('5', 179, 5, 15, 411199) We have a true copy of the original record of that case placed before us.
('5', 179, 5, 16, 411273) From it we find that the reasons for refusing to renew the licence of Mackillican were overwhelmingly strong.
('5', 179, 5, 17, 411383) They are:
('5', 179, 6, 18, 411393) I. Because a native man and woman were convicted on the 19th October, 1903, for selling liquor without a licence in a shed—a building on applicant’s premises which were only licensed as a retail store.
('5', 179, 6, 19, 411595) No less than three large casks of beer were found in the shed.
('5', 179, 6, 20, 411658) The applicant must have been cognisant of the carrying on of this illicit traffic.
('5', 179, 7, 21, 411741) 2. Because the applicant was convicted on the 15th day of January, 1904 of selling opium at the same premises on the 7th day of November, 1903; this trade had been carried on for some time causing severe mental
('5', 179, 8, 22, 411952) 1 Vide “A Hard Case”, 14 4 1906
('5', 180, 0, 1, 411984) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 181
('5', 180, 1, 2, 412031) depression and other injuries to the Indians at the Elandslaagte mine, besides being a constant cause of worry to the Manager, till he found out the source of the evil that was being wrought on his servants.
('5', 180, 1, 3, 412239) Thus, the applicant was indirectly guilty of poisoning Natives with liquor sold illicitly and of stupefying Indian miners by selling them opium in contravention of the law.
('5', 180, 1, 4, 412412) In each case, the fault was the applicant’s own.
('5', 180, 1, 5, 412461) It is a prostitution of terms to compare this case with the Indian case and use it as a precedent for depriving the latter of his licence.
('5', 180, 1, 6, 412600) It would have been more dignified and more honest on the part of the Board to have taken its stand on the true ground for refusal—that is, of colour.
('5', 180, 1, 7, 412750) We have been placed in possession, too, of some of the certificates produced by the applicant in support of his application.
('5', 180, 1, 8, 412875) One of the principal merchants of Durban, writing to the Licensing Officer, states: “We consider him to be a very respectable, reliable, and straightforward Indian, and quite fitted to hold a licence in your district.” Thus, while the personal character of Mackillican undoubtedly unfitted him to hold a trading licence, that of the Indian is irreproachable.
('5', 180, 1, 9, 413234) What has happened to the poor Indian in Ladysmith is probably not an uncommon experience for Indians in Natal.
('5', 180, 1, 10, 413345) We trust, therefore, that the Natal Indian Congress, which is ever watchful of the interests of the Indian community, will not fail to bring the matter to the notice of the Government and secure justice.

('5', 181, 4, 19, 416549) From half concealed suggestions to Licensing Officers, they have now proceeded to open instructions to them.

('5', 181, 4, 21, 416860) They will thus reduce the Licenses Act to a mere farce.

('5', 184, 1, 2, 421846) 172. INSTRUCTIONS TO INDIANS COMING TO NATAL BY STEAMER
('5', 184, 2, 3, 421902) We often find that Indian passengers entitled to land at Durban are greatly discommoded while doing so.
('5', 184, 2, 4, 422006) In order that some at any rate of these difficulties may be avoided, we make the following suggestions.
('5', 184, 2, 5, 422110) There should be no difficulty at all about the entry of the wife whose husband is according to law a resident of Natal; but the Immigration Officer allows a woman to land only after she has produced legal proof of her marriage to a resident.
('5', 184, 2, 6, 422352) Hence the man should make an affidavit and get it endorsed by the Immigration Officer in advance.
('5', 184, 2, 7, 422450) This will enable his wife to disembark soon after the steamer arrives.
('5', 184, 2, 8, 422521) The same procedure should be followed in the case of children.
('5', 184, 2, 9, 422584) The father making the affidavit should remember that the son or the daughter must be under sixteen years of age.
('5', 184, 2, 10, 422697) It is not enough that the parent swears an affidavit that the age of his son or daughter is below sixteen.
('5', 184, 2, 11, 422804) For it is up to the Immigration Officer to accept or reject the statement about age.
('5', 184, 2, 12, 422889) A difficulty may therefore arise if the son or daughter appears to be over sixteen, the affidavit notwithstanding.
('5', 184, 2, 13, 423004) Moreover, if the person is married, he or she, though under sixteen, is not entitled to land by virtue of the title of his or her parents.
('5', 184, 2, 14, 423143) If a resident of Natal himself wants to disembark but does not hold a domicile pass, he too has to put up with inconvenience.
('5', 184, 2, 15, 423269) Strong evidence has to be produced before the officer well in advance.
('5', 184, 2, 16, 423340) Nevertheless, there is one way by which such a person can land immediately: he should deposit £100 as security and after landing; produce the requisite evidence, or he should take out a £10 visiting pass and then do likewise.
('5', 184, 2, 17, 423566) If £100 are deposited, one is not required to pay the fee of £1 to the Government.
('5', 184, 2, 18, 423649) But, according to the new regulation, one has to pay that fee to take out a £10 visiting pass.

('5', 185, 1, 2, 423828) 173. JOHANNESBURG LETTER
('5', 185, 2, 3, 423853) JOHANNESBURG, April 21, 1906
('5', 185, 3, 4, 423882) DEPUTATION REGARDING MALAY LOCATION As I promised last week, I give here an account of the deputa tion that waited upon Sir Richard Solomon 1 concerning the Malay Location.
('5', 185, 3, 5, 424055) Mr. Haji Ojer Ali saw Sir Richard and presented the following facts before him.
('5', 185, 3, 6, 424135) When land was allotted by the Boer Government to the Malay people, they developed it.
('5', 185, 3, 7, 424221) On their applying for permission to construct buildings on it, the Government allowed them to do so unconditionally.
('5', 185, 3, 8, 424338) Consequently many well built houses of burnt brick have sprung up in the Malay Location.
('5', 185, 3, 9, 424427) Moreover, the residents have effected lasting improvements in the land, and the population has increased.
('5', 185, 3, 10, 424533) When the site for the Malay Location was fixed, the white population in the surrounding area was also increasing, but they did not raise any objection at the time.
('5', 185, 3, 11, 424697) And though the improvement of the land by the residents of the Location has been going on for years, nothing has been done to give them security of tenure.
('5', 185, 3, 12, 424853) An Ordinance was promulgated last September vesting the ownership of the Location in the Johannesburg Municipality.
('5', 185, 3, 13, 424969) On the other hand, the Government intends to confer definite rights on the Dutch residents of Vrededorp.
('5', 185, 3, 14, 425074) Handing over the Malay Location to the Municipality is likely therefore to prejudice the interests of the residents in the Location.
('5', 185, 3, 15, 425207) If rights are granted to the Dutch, they should be granted equally to the Stand holders of the Malay Location, who have always been loyal subjects.
('5', 185, 3, 16, 425355) If a permanent lease is granted to the people of the Malay Location, it can be safely assumed that they will improve the land further and construct even more elegant buildings.
('5', 185, 3, 17, 425532) In reply to this representation, Sir Richard has promised to go into the whole matter fully and write later in detail.
('5', 185, 3, 18, 425651) He has shown much sympathy, but it appears that the Government is nowadays plentiful in that commodity.
('5', 185, 3, 19, 425755) Even Mr. Winston Churchill has expressed much sympathy.
('5', 185, 3, 20, 425811) What the worthy knight will actually do, he alone knows.
