('5', 186, 2, 6, 426281) 174. “INDIAN OPINION”
('5', 186, 3, 7, 426303) A meeting of Durban Indian was held at Mr. Omar Haji Amod Zaveri’s residence on Monday, to consider the future of Indian Opinion.
('5', 186, 3, 8, 426433) Mr. Abdulla Haji Amod Zaveri was in the chair.
('5', 186, 3, 9, 426480) On being requested to place the position of the journal before the meeting, Gandhiji spoke as follows.
('5', 186, 3, 10, 426583) DURBAN, April 23, 1906 Indian Opinion has been published for some years now.
('5', 186, 3, 11, 426660) It was founded by Mr. Madanjit, who struggled hard to make it a success and put his all into it.
('5', 186, 3, 12, 426757) When the paper was started, the extent of the financial liability was not fully realised.
('5', 186, 3, 13, 426847) Later on, it was found that much more money was needed to run the paper.
('5', 186, 3, 14, 426920) The total deficit could not be covered even after the £1,600 received by me as fees in the cases against the Johannesburg Corporation was handed over.
('5', 186, 3, 15, 427071) 1 Every month there was a deficit of £75. which was beyond my means to meet.
('5', 186, 3, 16, 427148) We had therefore to think of running the paper on different lines.
('5', 186, 3, 17, 427215) It was decided to shift the Press to some place outside the city where the workers would lead a very simple life.
('5', 186, 3, 18, 427329) 2 For this step no responsibility attaches to Mr. Madanjit.
('5', 186, 3, 19, 427389) He was afraid that the paper would not come out under the proposed arrangement and therefore dissociated himself from it, leaving the responsibility solely to me.
('5', 186, 3, 20, 427552) However, since Mr. Madanjit had started the paper for selfless reasons and since after his return to India he is still serving the country like a true patriot, his name has been retained as printer and publisher.
('5', 186, 3, 21, 427765) The paper has been published for some time past according to this arrangement; but I find that we have reached a stage when, if we do not make special efforts, we shall incur deficits and not have enough to pay even the bare monthly allowance to the workers who take only £3 a month.
('5', 186, 3, 22, 428049) When I took charge of the paper, the number of subscribers was 887 and the advertisements had greatly decreased.
('5', 186, 4, 23, 428162) 1 Vide Autobiography, PartIV, Chap.
('5', 186, 5, 24, 428198) 2 The Press was shifted to Phoenix in December, 1904.
('5', 187, 0, 1, 428252) 188 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 187, 1, 2, 428294) am confident that I shall somehow continue to bring out the English section, at any rate as long as some of the Press workers hold on.
('5', 187, 1, 3, 428429) But I have never believed that the Indian community will not accord the venture any support I, therefore, still hope that the paper will get all the help it needs.
('5', 187, 1, 4, 428593) The objects of the journal are threefold: first, to make our grievances known to the Government, to the whites here in South Africa and in England and to people in India; secondly, to tell our people of their ownshortcomings and to exhort them to over come these and, thirdly—and this is perhaps the principal object—to eliminate the distinctions as between Hindus and Mahomedans and also those among Gujaratis, Tamilians and Calcuttawallas prevalent here.
('5', 187, 1, 5, 429050) The British rulers in India, it would appear, follow a different policy.
('5', 187, 1, 6, 429123) They do not desire that we should come together and become united.
('5', 187, 1, 7, 429190) Here in South Africa, these groups are small in numbers.
('5', 187, 1, 8, 429247) We are all confronted with the same disabilities.
('5', 187, 1, 9, 429297) We are moreover free from certain restrictions from which our people suffer in India.
('5', 187, 1, 10, 429383) We can therefore easily essay an experiment in achieving unity.
('5', 187, 1, 11, 429447) It is the aim of this journal to inculcate these ideals in the minds of our people and strengthen the community.
('5', 187, 1, 12, 429560) It is necessary to secure the assistance of all thoughtful Indians to this end.
('5', 187, 1, 13, 429640) I believe that many things can be achieved if this journal receives adequate support.
('5', 187, 1, 14, 429726) I think that those among us who are educated and can afford to pay should subscribe to it.
('5', 187, 1, 15, 429817) There are at least 20,000 Gujaratis living in South Africa.
('5', 187, 1, 16, 429877) It would not be too much to expect 25 per cent.
('5', 187, 1, 17, 429925) of this number to become subscribers.
('5', 187, 1, 18, 429963) As for educated Indians, it is not enough that they become subscribers themselves.
('5', 187, 1, 19, 430046) They should try their utmost to help in the fulfilment of the aims of the journal.
('5', 187, 1, 20, 430129) They can persuade others to do so.
('5', 187, 1, 21, 430164) The journal is a great instrument of education.
('5', 187, 1, 22, 430212) It is necessary for every Indian to look upon the journal as belonging to him, not as something mine.

('5', 188, 2, 7, 431234) 176. SPEECH AT CONGRESS MEETING
('5', 188, 3, 8, 431266) A meeting of the Natal Indian Congress was held in the Congress Hall, Durban to consider the advisability of raising an Indian ambulance corps to help the Government during the Zulu rebellion.
('5', 188, 3, 9, 431459) Dawad Mahomed, Chairman of the Congress, presided.
('5', 188, 3, 10, 431510) This speech by Gandhiji is extracted from a press report of the meeting at which others also spoke.
('5', 188, 3, 11, 431610) DURBAN, April 24, 1906 Mr. Gandhi referred to the part that the Indians had taken during the Boer war.
('5', 188, 3, 12, 431713) He said that the meeting was not concerned with the general question of Indian volunteering.
('5', 188, 3, 13, 431806) He thought that the Government were neglecting a plain duty to the Colony in not utilizing the defensive force they had at their disposal in the Indian community.
('5', 188, 3, 14, 431969) Mr. Watt had stated that he would not be defended by an Indian and at the same time said that he would use the Indian for digging trenches.
('5', 188, 3, 15, 432109) We had the late Mr. Escombe’s word for it that the digging of trenches and the nursing of the wounded were just as honourable and necessary as the shouldering of a rifle.
('5', 188, 3, 16, 432280) But they had nothing to do that evening with Mr. Watt’s views.
('5', 188, 3, 17, 432343) They had to consider whether they should, during the present crisis, offer to the Government their assistance, however humble it might be.
('5', 188, 3, 18, 432482) It was true they were labouring under disabilities and they were irritated.
('5', 188, 3, 19, 432558) Opinions, too, may differ as to the cause of the Native revolt.
('5', 188, 3, 20, 432622) But it was their duty not to be prejudiced by any such thoughts.
('5', 188, 3, 21, 432687) If they claimed rights of citizenship, they were bound to take their natural share in the responsibilities that such rights carried with them.
('5', 188, 3, 22, 432830) It was, therefore, their duty to assist in averting the danger that threatened the
('5', 189, 0, 1, 432913) 190 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 189, 1, 2, 432955) Colony.
('5', 189, 1, 3, 432963) The Indians had done good work during the Boer war.
('5', 189, 1, 4, 433015) It was recognised by General Buller, and the speaker advised that a similar offer should be made to the Government this time also.
('5', 189, 1, 5, 433146) Mr. Advocate Gabriel then moved the following resolution:
('5', 189, 2, 6, 433204) This Meeting of British Indians, assembled under the auspices of the
('5', 189, 3, 7, 433273) Natal Indian Congress, hereby authorises the Chairman to send an
('5', 189, 4, 8, 433338) offer to the Government, in connection with the Native rising, of the
('5', 189, 5, 9, 433408) same nature as during the Boer war.
('5', 189, 5, 10, 433444) Mr. Lazarus Gabriel asked whether those who might vote for the resolution bound themselves to offer their services.
('5', 189, 5, 11, 433560) Mr. Gandhi said such was not the meaning of the resolution.
('5', 189, 5, 12, 433620) But every member who voted for it would be bound to assist in making the movement a success.
('5', 189, 5, 13, 433713) It was for the members present to form a corps, should the Government be pleased to accept the offer.

('5', 191, 3, 12, 438322) 180. THE NATAL SHOPS ACT
('5', 191, 4, 13, 438347) Our contemporary, The Natal Advertiser, has given prominence to a lengthy contribution from the Secretaries of the Natal Stores Employees’ Association on the Shops Act.
('5', 191, 4, 14, 438516) In it the Secretaries have endeavoured to justify the Act by attempting to show that it has injured Asiatic trade.
('5', 191, 4, 15, 438631) Whether it has injured that trade or not, we do not propose to discuss.
('5', 191, 4, 16, 438703) We have accepted the principle underlying the Act.
('5', 191, 4, 17, 438754) We believe it is right that the opening and the closing hours of shops should be State regulated.
('5', 191, 4, 18, 438852) But we cannot help thinking that the actual hours fixed by the statute are inconvenient in every respect.
('5', 191, 4, 19, 438958) In fixing them, no account has been taken of the public who support the traders.
('5', 191, 4, 20, 439039) To close the shops on Saturday afternoons is the height of absurdity.
('5', 191, 4, 21, 439109) But all this is by the way.
('5', 191, 4, 22, 439137) We believe that the Act will require early amending before it becomes workable.
('5', 191, 4, 23, 439217) It is, however, the irresponsible manner in which the responsible
('5', 191, 5, 24, 439283) 1 Vide “Indian Volunteering”,31 3 1906
('5', 192, 0, 1, 439322) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 193
('5', 192, 1, 2, 439369) officers of the Association have dealt with the Indian traders that appears to us to call for some remarks.
('5', 192, 1, 3, 439477) The Secretaries state that, before the Act, the Indian traders kept their shops open for 103 hours per week, as against 53 hours after the passing of the Act.
('5', 192, 1, 4, 439636) There is no authority produced for the sweeping statement.
('5', 192, 1, 5, 439695) It is inherently incorrect.
('5', 192, 1, 6, 439723) The 103 hours per week mean 17 hours and ten minutes per day.
('5', 192, 1, 7, 439785) Now, if we assume that the Indian store keeper (not requiring, of course, any food and not attending to the toilet) opened his store at 6 a.m., he would not close, in order to have over 17 hours, until after 11.10 p.m.
('5', 192, 1, 8, 440004) We should be glad to be furnished with the names of Indian traders who kept open during the pre Act days between 6 a.m.
('5', 192, 1, 9, 440124) and 11.10 p.m.
('5', 192, 1, 10, 440139) We have heard of Irish members of the House of Commons tirelessly sitting out whole nights in the House, satisfying their hunger on a bit of kola nut.
('5', 192, 1, 11, 440290) But we have not heard of any Indian traders, with their employees, springing out of their beds (if they may be credited with having any) and hastening to their shops at 6 a.m., and standing behind the counter up to 11.10 p.m.
('5', 192, 1, 12, 440516) We have heard many exaggerated accounts about Indians, but this one from the Natal Stores Employees’ Association must certainly take the palm.
('5', 192, 1, 13, 440659) We are prepared, however, to admit that some Indian store keepers did keep open longer than they do now, but we are also prepared to show, if proof were needed, that European traders of the same type sinned equally, if not much worse.
('5', 192, 1, 14, 440894) Almost on a par with the above exaggeration are the other statements made by the Secretaries.
('5', 192, 1, 15, 440988) We ask them to study their facts before they rush into print and they will, we assure them, find that the Indian trader is not as vile, after all, as they make him appear.
('5', 192, 1, 16, 441160) Indian Opinion, 28 4 1906

('5', 193, 2, 7, 442509) 182. APPEAL TO YOUNG INDIANS IN SOUTH AFRICA
('5', 193, 3, 8, 442554) Various associations of Indian youth are nowadays being formed in South Africa.
('5', 193, 3, 9, 442634) They indicate an improvement in our condition.
('5', 193, 3, 10, 442681) While a Young Men’s Mahomedan Society has come into being in Durban, Sanatan Dharma Sabhas have been founded in Johannesburg and other towns.
('5', 193, 3, 11, 442823) This is a matter for satisfaction.
('5', 193, 3, 12, 442858) But we feel it necessary to sound a note of warning to both kinds of bodies.
('5', 193, 3, 13, 442935) It is a confirmed law of nature that an association of persons can grow and endure only if their minds are free from prejudice and all of them seek their good in the good of the association.
('5', 193, 3, 14, 443126) Every country depends a great deal on its young men and women.
('5', 193, 3, 15, 443189) Old men with their set habits of thought cannot readjust their opinions as necessary.
('5', 193, 3, 16, 443275) They cling to old ideas.
('5', 193, 3, 17, 443300) Every community, however, has undoubtedly need of such men, for they help to contain the restless enthusiasm of youth within limits.
('5', 193, 3, 18, 443433) While they have their uses, they have their disadvantages also, since they often hesitate to do things which needs mustbe done.
('5', 193, 3, 19, 443561) This may be thought becoming in them; but it is helpful to have good young men coming forward, for it is they alone who can venture to experiment.
('5', 193, 3, 20, 443708) It is therefore as necessary for us to encourage these associations as to caution them against over enthusiasm.
('5', 193, 3, 21, 443820) The members of these youth organizations will be able to achieve many great things, if they work with sincerity and with the sole intention of doing the right thing by their country.
('5', 193, 3, 22, 444003) For instance, there is much insanitation among us.
('5', 193, 3, 23, 444054) Mr. Peeran Mahomed has already commented on this subject at a Congress meeting.
('5', 193, 3, 24, 444134) Our young men can do much to remedy this laxity by making house to house visits and politely persuading people.
('5', 193, 3, 25, 444246) Some poor Indians are given to drinking, and their wives have also fallen victims to the habit.
('5', 193, 3, 26, 444342) Our young men can do much, if they take up the very important work of redeeming them.
('5', 193, 3, 27, 444428) We should like here to ask our Gujarati readers not
('5', 194, 0, 1, 444480) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 195
('5', 194, 1, 2, 444527) to assume that they may not do this kind of work among the Madrasis given to drinking.
('5', 194, 1, 3, 444614) We may add that the drinking habit is spreading among some Gujarati Hindus also.
('5', 194, 1, 4, 444695) Whether Hindus or Muslims, all of us can help in reclaiming them.
('5', 194, 1, 5, 444761) Moreover, it is necessary for such youth organizations to be more mindful of the needs of education.
('5', 194, 1, 6, 444862) There is a dearth of education even among our youth.
('5', 194, 1, 7, 444915) We do not consider mere literacy to be education.
('5', 194, 1, 8, 444965) We ought to have some knowledge of world history, the constitutions of various countries and other related subjects.
('5', 194, 1, 9, 445082) We can learn from history how other nations have progressed.
('5', 194, 1, 10, 445143) We can emulate them in the matter of their burning patriotism.

('5', 196, 2, 3, 449017) An article by the renowned Dr. Cortez of Paris has appeared in the latest number of The Indian Review, wherein he mentions many evils of tobacco.
('5', 196, 2, 4, 449163) The more important among them are that digestion is impaired and eyesight badly affected.
('5', 196, 2, 5, 449253) It leads to loss of memory and disables one from developing high moral virtues.
('5', 196, 2, 6, 449333) Moreover, it has now been found that even hearing is affected.
('5', 196, 2, 7, 449396) The doctor has conclusively shown that irregular action of the nerves governing the sense of hearing is to be ascribed to tobacco.

('5', 198, 7, 27, 454995) 190. NATAL LAND BILL
('5', 198, 8, 28, 455016) The Parliament of Natal will have before it a measure of far reaching importance for consideration in the shape of the Land
('5', 199, 0, 1, 455140) 200 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 199, 1, 2, 455182) Clauses Bill.
('5', 199, 1, 3, 455196) It is the second attempt of the Natal Government to pass the measure through Parliament.
('5', 199, 1, 4, 455285) The clause of the greatest importance to the Indian community is that which restricts the meaning of beneficial occupation, so far as tenant’s occupation is concerned, to European occupation only.
('5', 199, 1, 5, 455482) Thus, land that may be occupied by Indian tenants would be considered to be non beneficial occupation, and will be subject, on that account, to heavy taxation.
('5', 199, 1, 6, 455642) It has been universally admitted that, whatever may be the faults of the Indian, he is not lazy; he is a born tiller of the soil.
('5', 199, 1, 7, 455772) He is, by common consent, considered to have reclaimed some of the worst soil in the Colony.
('5', 199, 1, 8, 455865) He has turned dense bush into gardens, and has made it possible, by his productive capacity, to bring garden produce within easy reach of the poor householder in Natal.
('5', 199, 1, 9, 456034) Is his very virtue to be singled out for taxation?
('5', 199, 1, 10, 456085) Will the Government thereby promote European occupation?
('5', 199, 1, 11, 456142) We doubt it.
('5', 199, 1, 12, 456155) And if our doubt be reasonable, we are safe in saying that the Government will be pursuing a dog in the manger policy, by persisting in retaining the definition, above alluded to, of the expression “beneficial occupation”.
('5', 199, 1, 13, 456378) It is not by Acts such as thin that the Government will be able to solve the Indian question in Natal.
('5', 199, 1, 14, 456481) It behoves the ministers and the leaders of public opinion to reflect seriously and calmly on the whole question and deal with it in a statesmanlike manner, instead of by the recent spasmodic anti Indian legislation.

('5', 202, 2, 12, 462580) 195. WORKMEN’S LIVING HABITS
('5', 202, 3, 13, 462609) Nowadays, there is an increasing appreciation among enlight ened men of the need for open air.
('5', 202, 3, 14, 462704) Where large cities have come into being, labourers have to work cooped up in factories the whole day.
('5', 202, 3, 15, 462806) As the price of urban land is high, factory buildings are not spacious enough, and the tenements of labourers are also very small.
('5', 202, 3, 16, 462937) This invariably results in a steady deterioration of their health.
('5', 202, 3, 17, 463004) Dr. Newman of Hinsborough in London has shown that the death rate per thousand is 38 in areas where too many people live huddled together in one room, but where the same number live in two rooms, the death rate is 22; where the same number of people share three rooms, it is 11 and where they have the use of four rooms, the death rate is only 5. There is nothing surprising in this.
('5', 202, 3, 18, 463388) A man can do without food for several days and live a day altogether without waters but it is impossible to carry on without air even for a minute.
('5', 202, 3, 19, 463536) If a thing that is so very vital to life is not pure, the result cannot but be deleterious.
('5', 202, 3, 20, 463628) It was for these considerations that large manufacturers like Cadbury Brothers and Lever Brothers, who have always been very mindful of the welfare of their workers have shifted their factories to open places outside cities.
('5', 202, 3, 21, 463853) They have built very good quarters for their workers with all the attendant amenities, such as gardens and libraries; although they have spent all this money, they have flourished in their business.
('5', 202, 3, 22, 464052) A similar movement has spread all over England in the wake of this example.
('5', 202, 4, 23, 464128) 1 Vide “The Meeting at Mombasa”, 28 4 1906
('5', 203, 0, 1, 464171) 204 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 203, 1, 2, 464213) This matter deserves consideration by Indian leaders.
('5', 203, 1, 3, 464267) We suffer much because we do not realise the value of pure air, and this again is a strong reason why diseases like plague spread among us.

('5', 203, 3, 9, 464726) Had Indians taken part in the activities of British chambers from the beginning, the condition of the Indian trader would be different today.
('5', 203, 3, 10, 464868) Numerous reforms could have been effected through them.

('5', 203, 3, 13, 465116) Mr. Omar Zaveri now puts forward the idea that, if we cannot secure admission to the British Chamber, we can start one of our own.
('5', 203, 3, 14, 465247) If it is started and our traders work for it diligently and introduce such reforms as are necessary, and if all of them act according to its advice, it will be able to achieve a good many things.
('5', 203, 3, 15, 465443) The British chambers command great influence because their authority is accepted by all traders.
('5', 203, 3, 16, 465540) If we cannot bring about such a state of affairs, it will make no difference whether or not we set up a Chamber.

('5', 204, 2, 6, 466745) HARDSHIPS ON THE RAILWAY
('5', 204, 3, 7, 466770) The Chairman and the Secretary of the British Indian Association saw Mr. Price, the General Manager, regarding the prohibition of Indian and other Coloured passengers from travelling by the 8 30 [a.m.] and 4 40 p.m.
('5', 204, 3, 8, 466986) trains from Johannesburg to Pretoria and the morning train leaving Pretoria at 8 30 for Johannesburg.
('5', 204, 3, 9, 467088) The interview lasted about an hour.
('5', 204, 3, 10, 467124) Mr. Price argued that the feeling among the whites ran rather high then and it would not be desirable for the Indians to press the point further.
('5', 204, 3, 11, 467270) Finally, he gave the assurance that, if an Indian had to travel by any of these trains for any urgent piece of work, the station master would, on request, arrange for him to travel with the guard.
('5', 204, 3, 12, 467467) Mr. Price, however, suggested that, for the present, as few Indians as possible should travelby these three trains.
('5', 204, 3, 13, 467583) He said that such restriction would not continue for long.
('5', 204, 3, 14, 467642) A recent case that has a bearing on this subject deserves notice.
('5', 204, 3, 15, 467708) A Coloured man was travelling in a second class carriage with a white woman sitting beside him.
('5', 204, 3, 16, 467804) Mr. Bowcker, a white, noticed this, and his blood boiled at the sight.
('5', 204, 3, 17, 467875) He asked the Coloured man to vacate his seat, but the latter merely produced his ticket.
('5', 204, 3, 18, 467964) But Mr. Bowcker was not satisfied and spoke to the guard who refused to intervene.
('5', 204, 3, 19, 468047) Mr. Bowcker thereupon brought other white passengers to the carriage and threatened to evict the Coloured man.
('5', 204, 3, 20, 468158) The helpless guard was forced to throw him out.
('5', 204, 3, 21, 468206) It is not here possible to apportion blame to any official.
('5', 204, 3, 22, 468266) Such difficulties are bound to occur as long as the whites continue to behave excitedly over this question.
('5', 204, 3, 23, 468374) The following is a translation of what another white writes in The Transvaal Leader under the title “Coolie Traveller”.
('5', 204, 4, 24, 468494) Mr. Bowcker deserves the gratitude of the whites for what he has written about the Coloured man.

('5', 204, 4, 27, 468695) It is true that they were in another compartment; but that does not lessen the evil.
('5', 204, 4, 28, 468780) For a white will have to sit in that compartment after they leave.

('5', 207, 6, 26, 475406) [JOHANNESBURG, Before May 12, 1906]
('5', 207, 7, 27, 475442) SIR, I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of your letter dated the 30th ultimo, No.
('5', 207, 7, 28, 475534) 15/4/1906. My Association ventures to think that the complaint forwarded to His Excellency 2 has not received that investigation which the circumstances required.
('5', 207, 7, 29, 475697) As to the dilatoriness, my Association will watch the working of the new
('5', 207, 8, 30, 475770) 1 This was published in Indian Opinion under the caption “British Indian Association’s Reply”.

('5', 208, 1, 2, 475960) department.
('5', 208, 1, 3, 475972) In the meanwhile, attention is respectfully drawn to the fact that applications have been pending for months, and it is difficult for my Association to reconcile such a lapse of time with any regard for the convenience of the applicants.
('5', 208, 1, 4, 476210) With reference to the case of Mr. Suliman Manga, my Association has ascertained the full facts, and my Association thinks that the information given to His Excellency is by no means complete.
('5', 208, 1, 5, 476402) There was absolutely no mis statement of material facts in connection with the application.
('5', 208, 1, 6, 476494) The application was made through Mr. Gandhi, who, my Association understands, was instructed by a friend of the Mangas’.
('5', 208, 1, 7, 476615) The ground for the application was not that Mr. Manga wanted to visit his uncle, but that he wanted to pass through the Transvaal on his way to Delagoa Bay.
('5', 208, 1, 8, 476772) A reply was received on the 14th March rejecting the application for a temporary permit.
('5', 208, 1, 9, 476861) The variation as to the description of the relative only took place after rejection of the application.
('5', 208, 1, 10, 476965) In reply to the letter in question, Mr. Gandhi wrote to the Permit Officer expressing his surprise and there described the uncle as father, which, as he explains, was written without his having referred to the previous letter.
('5', 208, 1, 11, 477192) In any case, there was no question of misleading, as the variation in the description of relationship was so palpable that it could only be accounted as a mistake.
('5', 208, 1, 12, 477356) As a matter of fact, as it now transpires, Mr. Manga had neither a father nor an uncle in Delagoa Bay, but he had a cousin, and for that matter there was a further discrepancy that Mr. Manga was described as a British Indian, whereas he happened to be a Portuguese Indian.
('5', 208, 1, 13, 477629) All this arose as instructions were given by a friend of the Mangas’ who did not know them intimately.
('5', 208, 1, 14, 477732) But none of these facts had any direct bearing on the application.
('5', 208, 1, 15, 477799) In the second letter, information was given to the effect that Mr. Manga was a student from England.
('5', 208, 1, 16, 477900) A later development of the case showed the painful fact that Mr. Manga, considered as a British Indian, was unable to securewhat he got for the asking when it became known that he was a Portuguese subject.
('5', 208, 1, 17, 478106) The case of Mr. Suliman Manga is, in the humble opinion of my Association, very important as showing the difficult position in which the British Indian community is placed in the Transvaal.
('5', 208, 1, 18, 478296) The reason, too, given for the refusal was denied to my Association.
('5', 208, 1, 19, 478365) My Association became aware of it for the first time through your letter.
('5', 208, 1, 20, 478439) The foregoing statement of facts shows that the reason for refusal could not have been the variation in the description of the relative in Delagoa Bay, because when the decision was announced, the slip as to the uncle being described as father had not occurred.
('5', 208, 1, 21, 478701) My Association ventures to submit that there should be sufficient latitude granted in connection with temporary permits, or what may be termed visitors’
('5', 209, 0, 1, 478854) 210 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 209, 1, 2, 478896) passes, and that in any case applicants should have reasons given to them as to why their applications have been rejected.
('5', 209, 1, 3, 479019) My Association has obtained copies of the correspondence in the matter which I take the liberty to enclose herewith.
('5', 209, 1, 4, 479136) 1 Regarding the age limit for the introduction of male Asiatic minors, my Association respectfully submits that the reduction of the age limit would hardly cure the abuses referred to in the letter under reply.
('5', 209, 1, 5, 479347) Those who intend to practise deception will continue to do so whether the age limit is sixteen or twelve.
('5', 209, 1, 6, 479453) Abuses under legislation restrictive of human liberty are inevitable, but my Association respectfully submits that the abuses have by no means been extensive, and they have always been avoidable.
('5', 209, 1, 7, 479649) May I further venture to state that the reduction of age limit is a punishment awarded to the innocent for the crimes of the guilty persons.
('5', 209, 1, 8, 479790) With reference to all persons irrespective of age or sex being required to obtain permits, my Association takes it that it only refers to British Indians or Asiatics, for it is within the knowledge of my Association that many European children and ladies have entered the country without any permits at all.

('5', 209, 2, 12, 480562) 201. INDIAN VOLUNTEERING
('5', 209, 3, 13, 480587) Correspondence has appeared in The Natal Advertiser on the offer of the Indian community, in connection with the Native rebellion, which ordinarily we should not feel justified in noticing.
('5', 209, 3, 14, 480777) As, however, the subject discussed by the correspondents of our contemporary is of such vital importance both to the Indian community and to the Colony, we make no apology for dealing with the points raised by them.
('5', 209, 3, 15, 480993) We have no concern with the reckless abuse
('5', 209, 4, 16, 481036) 1 Not reproduced here
('5', 210, 0, 1, 481058) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 211
('5', 210, 1, 2, 481105) indulged in by some of the correspondents.
('5', 210, 1, 3, 481148) One of them has satirically suggested that Indians, so that they may not run away, should be placed in the front line, and that then the fight between them and the Natives will be a sight for the gods.
('5', 210, 1, 4, 481350) We propose to take the correspondent seriously, and venture to suggest that, if such a course were adopted, it would be undoubtedly the very best that could happen to the Indians.
('5', 210, 1, 5, 481530) If they be cowardly, they will deserve the fate that will overtake them; if they be brave, nothing can be better than for brave men to be in the front line.
('5', 210, 1, 6, 481687) But the pity of it is that the Government, and the European Colonists who have dictated the policy to the Government, have not taken the elementary precaution of giving the necessary discipline and instruction to the Indians.
('5', 210, 1, 7, 481913) It is, therefore, a matter of physical impossibility to expect Indians to do any work with the rifle; or, for that matter, to do any work in connection with war with much efficiency.
('5', 210, 1, 8, 482096) The Indian Ambulance Corps, at the time of the late war, did excellent work, without the necessary instruction and discipline, only because the Indian leaders who joined the Corps had previously been instructed and prepared under Dr. Booth.
('5', 210, 1, 9, 482337) Another correspondent has suggested that Indians should not be armed, because if they were, they would sell their arms to the Natives.
('5', 210, 1, 10, 482472) This is a suggestion which is made wickedly, and without any foundation in fact.
('5', 210, 1, 11, 482553) Indians have never been armed; it is, therefore, sheer folly to say that, if they were, they would act in a particular direction.
('5', 210, 1, 12, 482683) It has also been suggested that the offer has been made to gain cheap applause, and also to gain something not made apparent in the proceedings of the Congress meeting.
('5', 210, 1, 13, 482852) The first statement is slanderous, and the best way to disprove the stricture is for these correspondents to make the Government accept the offer, and to see whether the response is adequate or not.
('5', 210, 1, 14, 483051) The second statement is difficult to understand.
('5', 210, 1, 15, 483100) If it is intended to convey the impression that Indians, by serving during war time, hope to obtain a redress of their wrongs, the statement is true, and no Indian should be ashamed of such a motive.
('5', 210, 1, 16, 483300) What can be better and more praise worthy than that Indians, by standing shoulder to shoulder with their fellow Colonists in the present trouble, should show that they are not unworthy of the ordinary rights of citizenship which they have been claiming all these years?
('5', 210, 1, 17, 483570) But it is equally true also that the offer has been made unconditionally, as a matter of simple duty, and irrespective of whether there is any redress of the grievances granted or not.
('5', 210, 1, 18, 483755) We, therefore, consider it to be the special aim of every Colonist to support the Indian community in the offer it has made, and thereby to show prudence and foresight, for it cannot be seriously
('5', 211, 0, 1, 483951) 212 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 211, 1, 2, 483993) argued that there is any wisdom or statesmanship in blindly refusing to make use of, for purposes of war, one hundred thousand Indians who are perfectly loyal, and who are capable of good training.
('5', 211, 2, 3, 484191) Indian Opinion, 12 5 1906
('5', 211, 3, 4, 484217) 202. INDIAN PERMITS
('5', 211, 4, 5, 484237) Lord Selborne has now replied to the representations of the British Indian Association on the working of the Permit Ordinance.
('5', 211, 4, 6, 484364) The Association has sent in a further representation, traversing some of the facts and arguments contained in His Excellency’s reply.
('5', 211, 4, 7, 484498) We cannot help saying that Lord Selborne’s reply is most disappointing.
('5', 211, 4, 8, 484570) The Manga case has been fully dealt with by the Association in its reply.
('5', 211, 4, 9, 484644) 1 We need not, therefore, comment any further upon the curious reason given for refusing Mr. Manga’s application for a permit.
('5', 211, 4, 10, 484771) It is evident, from Lord Selborne’s letter, that the age limit has been reduced arbitrarily from sixteen to twelve, for, as the Association has pointed out, evasion of the regulations by some people could be no ground for reduction of the age limit.
('5', 211, 4, 11, 485021) But where utter want of regard for the feelings of Indians has been shown is in connection with separate permits being required for wives accompanying their husbands.
('5', 211, 4, 12, 485188) This is an innovation which has absolutely no justification for it.
('5', 211, 4, 13, 485256) The anti Asiatic party has never said one word regarding the influx of Indian women.
('5', 211, 4, 14, 485341) There are, as is well known, very few Indian women in the Transvaal, and they do not in any way compete in trade.
('5', 211, 4, 15, 485455) Their work is confined solely to looking after their households.
('5', 211, 4, 16, 485520) We must, therefore, frankly confess that we were not prepared for the reply that Lord Selborne has given regarding separate permits for wives.
('5', 211, 4, 17, 485663) Is it a new discovery that “all persons in the Transvaal, irrespective of age or sex, are required under the Peace Preservation Ordinance to obtain permits”?
('5', 211, 4, 18, 485821) If it is not, why have Indian women not been called upon hitherto to produce any permits?
('5', 211, 4, 19, 485911) Why have Indian children been exempted until recently from having to carry any permits?
('5', 211, 4, 20, 485999) And,as the Association points out, the Peace Preservation Ordin ance is not by any means universally applied, in that European ladies and children under sixteen years are free from having to obtain orcarry permits when travelling with their husbands or parents; nor has His Excellency taken any note of peculiar Indian susceptibilities regarding Indian womanhood.
('5', 211, 4, 21, 486363) We have no hesitation in saying that
('5', 211, 5, 22, 486400) 1 Vide “Letter to Lord Selborne”, Before 21 5 1906
('5', 212, 0, 1, 486451) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 213
('5', 212, 1, 2, 486498) the regulation is unreasonable, insulting, and totally uncalled for.
('5', 212, 1, 3, 486567) If it is enforced, it will create irritation which will be difficult to allay.
('5', 212, 1, 4, 486646) It is strange, indeed, that, with the innovations introduced, His Excellency can conclude his letter by saying that the permit work is being done with “as much consideration for the convenience of the applicants as is possible under all circumstances”.
('5', 212, 1, 5, 486899) Not until the age limit has been restored, not until Indian women are rendered free from unwarranted insult, not until Indian refugees can have their applications considered immediately on their receipt, can, in our humble opinion, His Excellency say, with any show of justice, that the Permit regulations are enforced with any degree of reasonableness.
('5', 212, 1, 6, 487253) We can quite understand the difficulties in the way of the officers who have to administer the law, but if they are short handed, it is the duty of the Government to supplement the staff, so as not to delay consideration of the applications.
('5', 212, 1, 7, 487495) Such an increase in the staff can only be temporary, for there must, some time or other, be an end to the applications from refugees.
('5', 212, 1, 8, 487629) It is the congestion of work in the Office which has to be dealt with.
('5', 212, 1, 9, 487700) Why cannot that congestion be removed by employing extra men?
('5', 212, 1, 10, 487762) Indian Opinion, 12 5 1906
('5', 212, 2, 11, 487788) 203. THE COLOURED PEOPLE’S PETITION
('5', 212, 3, 12, 487824) The Coloured People’s Vigilance Committee has prepared a petition, for submission to the House of Commons, in connection with the new Constitution to be granted to the Transvaal and the Orange River Colony.
('5', 212, 3, 13, 488031) The public are not informed whether the petition is in continuation of that addressed to King Edward VII by the African Political Organization 1, or whether it is a distinct and separate movement.
('5', 212, 3, 14, 488228) In any case, both the petitions represent practically the same interests.
('5', 212, 3, 15, 488302) The only difference is that, whereas the petition to the King deals with Coloured people as distingui shed from the Natives, the present petition seems to include the Natives.
('5', 212, 3, 16, 488478) There is no doubt that, ultimately, the policy enunciated by the late Mr. Rhodes 2 will have to be accepted by South Africa, if there is to be federation, and if it is to continue to remain under the British flag.

('5', 213, 3, 4, 489420) 204. HOME RULE FOR INDIA
('5', 213, 4, 5, 489445) Mr. Parekh, the Vice President of the Indian Home Rule Society, delivered a speech at Newcastle in England to the effect that home rule should be granted to India.
('5', 213, 4, 6, 489609) He said that India should be given complete independence and that Englishmen should leave the country.
('5', 213, 4, 7, 489712) The present policy was good for neither the rulers nor the ruled.
('5', 213, 4, 8, 489778) That policy sometimes vitiated the character of the persons going out to serve in India.
('5', 213, 4, 9, 489867) It is said that the administration of India is carried on under the direction and control of Parliament; but in reality the authority of Parliament was so limited as to be almost negligible.
('5', 213, 4, 10, 490058) Since Parliament had no time to listen to the grievances of India’s millions, the bureaucracy there exercised its powers arbitrarily.
('5', 213, 4, 11, 490192) If home rule was granted, the condition of the people would certainly improve.
('5', 213, 4, 12, 490271) The reason why famines continually recur in India is not that there is not enough grain in the country.
('5', 213, 4, 13, 490375) Where there is scarcity of grain, it is often confined only to particular parts of the country.
('5', 213, 4, 14, 490471) The reason for countrywide famines, however, is quite different.
('5', 213, 4, 15, 490536) Grain there is, but the people have not the means of buying it.
('5', 213, 4, 16, 490600) India suffers from starvation because there is dearth not of grain, but of purchasing power.
('5', 213, 4, 17, 490693) The Government there does not do its duty by its subjects; and the claim that British rule promotes the common weal has become a sheer pretence and mockery.
('5', 213, 4, 18, 490850) In the name of justice and for the good of humanity, India must be given home rule.
('5', 213, 4, 19, 490934) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 12 5 1906

('5', 217, 5, 6, 497733) 209. AN ASIATIC POLICY
('5', 217, 6, 7, 497756) The well known writer L. E. N. has now finished his able articles contributed to The Rand Daily Mail on Asiatics in the Colonies.
('5', 217, 6, 8, 497886) He has suggested the following measures for dealing with the question: (1) Keep out masses of Asiatics as permanent residents, as far as possible, at all costs.
('5', 217, 6, 9, 498047) (2) If indentured labour is needed, insist on repatriation on expiration of contract.
('5', 217, 6, 10, 498133) (3) Fair, even generous, treatment to those Asiatics who have, under the conditions of the old days, become part of the population of the country.
('5', 217, 6, 11, 498280) (4) No irritating restrictions on the movements of the temporary visitor or traveller.
('5', 217, 6, 12, 498367) L. E. N. winds up by saying:
('5', 217, 7, 13, 498396) With such a policy there must be no vexatious restrictions to insult the educated man—things more irritating and harmful than the regulation which quietly keeps out thousands of the poorer class.
('5', 217, 7, 14, 498592) The cultured traveller of the Eastern world ought not to have to submit to treatment which is not even meted out to a pauper immigrant on a New York quay; he should not have to consent to having his thumb impressions taken like a criminal or to be threatened, as the extremists of the Transvaal threatened him, with instant removal to a location.
('5', 217, 7, 15, 498939) With a presentment such as this we can heartily agree except in one particular.
('5', 217, 7, 16, 499019) In fact the policy sketched out by L. E. N. is one thathas been accepted by the Indian community.
('5', 217, 7, 17, 499117) The exception, however, that we have in mind is a very serious one.
('5', 217, 7, 18, 499185) If indentured labour be introduced from India, whether for the Rand mines or for the plantations of Natal, it should not be subject to the repatriation clause.
('5', 217, 7, 19, 499345) Had such labour not been introduced, probably the Indian question would never have arisen in South Africa, but if it be considered absolutely essential to the prosperity of any portion of South Africa that indentured Indian labour should be introduced, it is only fair that, after the men have been so introduced, and, in the words of the late Mr. Escombe, have given the best five years of their lives,
('5', 218, 0, 1, 499749) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 219
('5', 218, 1, 2, 499796) they should be free to settle in the country and reap the reward of their services by following any honest occupation they may choose.
('5', 218, 1, 3, 499931) Even the late Sir William Wilson Hunter, who was known for his extreme moderation, and who was always credited with being able to take a sane view of things, did not hesitate to consider the state of indentured labour as “one perilously near slavery”.
('5', 218, 1, 4, 500183) The least, therefore, that such men are entitled to is freedom of residence in the country which they have served so well.
('5', 218, 1, 5, 500306) We think, therefore, that L. E. N. would have added greater weight to his contributions had he treated the question of free Indian immigration on its own merits, because such immigration is a matter of Imperial policy, whereas the question of indentured labour is a matter of contract and bargain.
('5', 218, 1, 6, 500604) Considerations that guide the examination of the one question do not necessarily apply to that of the other; in South Africa, where both the Transvaal and Natal are largely dependent upon indentured labour, either from India or other parts of Asia, it is extremely necessary to bear this distinction in mind.
('5', 218, 1, 7, 500913) Indian Opinion, 19 5 1906
('5', 218, 2, 8, 500939) 210. MOVE FOR SHOP CLOSING HOURS IN SOUTH AFRICA Everyone knows that a law requiring shops to be closed at a given hour has already been enacted in Natal.

('5', 218, 2, 15, 501653) The store managers of Natal are trying to show that, in closing shops after being compelled by law to do so, we are doing nothing extraordinary.
('5', 218, 2, 16, 501798) This is true to some extent.
('5', 218, 2, 17, 501827) When Indian merchants in Potchefstroom decided to close shops at regular hours, we congratulated them.
('5', 218, 2, 18, 501930) Our agent, however, informs us that they have reverted to their earlier practice.

('5', 218, 2, 20, 502042) We would strongly urge upon the Indian merchants in Potchefstroom as also those in other places that they reach an understanding with white merchants in the matter of closing shops before a law is enacted.

('5', 219, 1, 2, 502332) 211. POTCHEFSTROOM AND KLERKSDORP 1
('5', 219, 2, 3, 502368) There is at present a trade depression in Potchefstroom.
('5', 219, 2, 4, 502425) The discrimination that Indians there have to suffer relates in particular to using cabs and visiting public gardens.
('5', 219, 2, 5, 502543) It is difficult for an Indian to hire a cab readily.
('5', 219, 2, 6, 502596) There is little chance of securing legal redress in the matter.
('5', 219, 2, 7, 502660) For when an incident of this nature occurred earlier, the Potchefstroom Municipality framed a bye law, which is now in force.
('5', 219, 2, 8, 502786) The remedy about the use of gardens lies in the hands of the Indians themselves.
('5', 219, 2, 9, 502867) We cannot be legally debarred from visiting the public gardens; and we can institute a case even in a Magistrate’s court and seek redress.
('5', 219, 2, 10, 503006) The agreement arrived at by the Indians in Potchefstroom after negotiations with the British traders, regarding the closing of shops at the same time as whites, appears to have been broken.
('5', 219, 2, 11, 503196) This is not at all proper.
('5', 219, 2, 12, 503223) The agreement should have been implemented in the same way in which it was negotiated.
('5', 219, 2, 13, 503310) It should not happen that, because the whites are not fair in their dealings with us, we should also fail to do the right thing.
('5', 219, 2, 14, 503439) As between Klerksdorp and Potchefstroom, the Indian stores in the former town excel those in the latter.
('5', 219, 2, 15, 503544) The Klerksdorp stores are built better and their facades, too, are more pleasing.

('5', 219, 2, 17, 503691) Both at Klerksdorp and Potchefstroom, the Indian stores were mostly found to be quite comparable to those of the Europeans in elegance and in other respects; but the backyards and living conditions need improvement.
('5', 219, 2, 18, 503907) The tenements in the yard should, however, be cleaner and more spacious; and the bathrooms, etc., should also be kept clean.

('5', 220, 1, 23, 506860) The richest persons in the world are to be found among the Jews.
('5', 220, 1, 24, 506925) It is characteristic of human nature to discover in others the faults which are in oneself, and thus to feel complacent in the beliefthat others share one’s defects.
('5', 220, 1, 25, 507091) Men of discernment who are patriotic, and who are moved by the valour of others, should entertain good thoughts, should consider the merits and not the demerits of
('5', 221, 0, 1, 507255) 222 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('5', 222, 4, 11, 510222) 216. JOHANNESBURG LETTER
('5', 222, 5, 12, 510247) [After May 18, 1906] 2
('5', 222, 6, 13, 510270) TRAM TEST CASE The case filed by Mr. Ebrahim Saleji Coovadia against the Johannesburg municipality was heard last Friday the 18th by Mr. Cross, the Magistrate.
('5', 222, 6, 14, 510430) In his deposition, Mr. Coovadia stated that he was the Treasurer of the British Indian Association and that, when, on April 7, he attempted to board an electric tram, the conductor refused to admit him.
('5', 222, 6, 15, 510633) The conductor deposed on behalf of the municipality, and with his testimony, the presentation of the municipal case was over.
('5', 222, 6, 16, 510759) On this occasion, the municipality was represented by Barrister Feetham.

('5', 223, 1, 7, 511974) During the case, it transpired that the Town Council, with a view to thwarting the Indian case, had stated, while taking out a licence, that the trams were for the exclusive use of the whites; and Mr. Feetham was all flushed with triumph when he produced the licence before the court.
('5', 223, 1, 8, 512259) But, as the Gujarati proverb goes, he who digs a pit for others falls into it himself; the Town Council committed a blunder in producing the licence.

('5', 223, 1, 14, 513117) There is nothing apparently objectionable in such a regulation; but its legal implications are as follows.
('5', 223, 1, 15, 513224) Our plea was that, as the tram regulations of the Johannesburg municipality came after the smallpox regulations, the latter, which were not in consonance with the said municipal regulations, stood abrogated.
('5', 223, 1, 16, 513432) But the argument of the municipality appears to be that, since the new regulations have now been repealed, the old ones about smallpox come into force again.
('5', 223, 1, 17, 513590) This is a clear case of betrayal.
('5', 223, 1, 18, 513624) This means that we shall have to put up a fresh struggle beginning all over again—which will be both very troublesome and costly.
('5', 223, 1, 19, 513754) But it has to be undertaken if the Indian community does not want to submit to this defeat.

('5', 225, 2, 11, 517463) 217. LETTER TO “TRANSVAAL LEADER” 1
('5', 225, 3, 12, 517499) JOHANNESBURG, May 21, 1906
('5', 225, 4, 13, 517526) TO THE EDITOR Transvaal Leader [JOHANNESBURG]
('5', 225, 5, 14, 517572) SIR, May I say with reference to your leader on the tram car case, brought at the instance of the British Indian Association, that the magistrate’s decision does not “throw open the trams to Coloured persons of every grade”.
('5', 225, 5, 15, 517797) For instance, it does not throw open the cars to the Natives, and it leaves untouched the regulation which enables conductors to reject passengers who are drunken, ill dressed or otherwise objectionable.
('5', 225, 5, 16, 518001) So that when you say that your “remarks are directed to the matter in its broadest aspects”, you give away the case for the Council.
('5', 225, 5, 17, 518134) For nobody has ever contended that the cars should be usable by all without distinction.
('5', 225, 6, 18, 518223) 1 This was published under the caption “Tram Case”.
('5', 226, 0, 1, 518275) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 227
('5', 226, 1, 2, 518322) But, Sir, the Town Council, by a method which is the reverse of honourable, has deprived the Indians of the fruits of their victory.
('5', 226, 1, 3, 518455) For, in the current number of the Government Gazette, there appears a by law which repeals the Traffic By laws regarding tram cars.
('5', 226, 1, 4, 518587) This means that the tram cars are now to run without any regulations to control the traffic on them.
('5', 226, 1, 5, 518688) But it means too that now it will not be possible for a British Indian to claim to ride in the municipal cars under the general by laws.
('5', 226, 1, 6, 518825) And, I expect, the municipality will contend that the repeal revives the smallpox regulations of the old Government which the magistrate held to be not applicable in the face of the by laws now repealed.
('5', 226, 1, 7, 519029) Britishers are rightly proud of the fact that they never hit below the belt.
('5', 226, 1, 8, 519106) With great deference, it appears to me, as it would, I hope, to every other ratepayer, that the Town Council, in adopting the above procedure, has departed from that proud tradition.
('5', 226, 1, 9, 519289) Consequent upon the Town Council’s action then, for the timebeing, your fear as to the tram cars being used by “Coloured persons of every grade” are groundless, apart from the facts submitted by me.
('5', 226, 1, 10, 519488) I, however, ask you whether you approve of the means adopted by the Town Council to achieve its purpose.
('5', 226, 1, 11, 519593) I am, etc., M. K. GANDHI Transvaal Leader, 25 5 1906
('5', 226, 2, 12, 519646) 218. EMPIRE DAY On Thursday last, throughout the Empire, the birthday of the late Queen Empress was celebrated.
('5', 226, 2, 13, 519758) As the years roll on, the memory of that noble lady remains as fresh as ever.
('5', 226, 2, 14, 519836) Her interest in India and its people was intense, and in return, she received the whole hearted affection of India’s millions.
('5', 226, 2, 15, 519963) Her late Majesty showed her interest in and toleration for the religions of India, when she had the whole of the Proclamation of 1858 re written, because of an unwarranted reference to the power the Government possessed of undermining native religions and customs.
('5', 226, 2, 16, 520228) In her letter to Lord Derby 1, the Queen wrote: Such a document should breathe feelings of generosity, benevolence, and religious toleration, and point out the privileges which the Indians will receive in being placed on an equality with the subjects of the British Crown, and the prosperity following in the train of civilization.
('5', 226, 3, 17, 520560) 1 Edward Stanley Derby, (1799 1869), Prime Minister of England, 1852, 1856 and 1866
('5', 227, 0, 1, 520644) 228 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 227, 1, 2, 520686) These were the principles on which the Empire’s foundation was laid.
('5', 227, 1, 3, 520755) Expansion of trade and the acquisition of territory are not the only things true Imperialists aim at.
('5', 227, 1, 4, 520857) There is a greater and a nobler ideal to work for: that of producing, as John Ruskin puts it, “as many as possible full breathed, bright eyed, and happy hearted human creatures”.
('5', 227, 1, 5, 521036) We would place this ideal before our South African public men, and ask them to put away the feelings of race hatred and colour distinction.
('5', 227, 1, 6, 521176) The great British Empire has not risen to its present proud position by methods of oppression, nor is it possible to hold that position by unfair treatment of its loyal subjects.
('5', 227, 1, 7, 521355) British Indians have always been most devoted to their Sovereign, and the Empire has lost nothing by including them among its subjects.
('5', 227, 1, 8, 521491) India is a vast storehouse of wealth to Great Britain, whilst thousands of its inhabitants are dying of starvation with scarcely a murmur.
('5', 227, 1, 9, 521630) We venture to suggest that, if there were more of Queen Victoria’s spirit of enlightenment put into the affairs of the Empire, we should be worthier followers of so great an Empire builder.

('5', 229, 2, 4, 525257) 223. WEALTHY AMERICANS
('5', 229, 3, 5, 525280) It is well known that America has a large number of wealthy persons.
('5', 229, 3, 6, 525349) Generally speaking, the people of Europe are found to be foremost in amassing fortunes.
('5', 229, 3, 7, 525437) With the help of new inventions and technology, the people of Europe see to it that the world market does not go out of their hands.
('5', 229, 3, 8, 525570) Despite this, it would not be wrong to say that Europe lags far behind America in the race for wealth.
('5', 229, 3, 9, 525673) There are, of course, some reasons for this.
('5', 229, 3, 10, 525718) The people there are caught in the spell of money more than the Europeans, and it has been found that, once large quantities of wealth accumulate, they tend to go on increasing.
('5', 229, 3, 11, 525896) This becomes understandable if a long range view is taken.
('5', 229, 3, 12, 525955) Now, some of these Americans have grown so inordinately rich—so we learn from a speech by President Roosevelt, the Head of the United States—that it will not be improper to enact a law enabling the State to limit this acquisition of wealth.
('5', 229, 3, 13, 526196) He said that one might not think it wrong for a man to own one or two million pounds; but that hoarded fortunes have so exceeded this volume and so spread in extent that there is a large number of Americans who have a hundredtimes this sum.These multi millionaires, President Roosevelt has found, might some day influence State authority.
('5', 229, 3, 14, 526535) With the power of their money they can influence, as they deem fit, such institutions of the State as courts of justice, and elections to a municipality or the Senate.
('5', 229, 3, 15, 526703) Such a development, it is felt, will be dangerous, and limiting by law the accumulation of wealth is contemplated.
('5', 229, 3, 16, 526818) An individual may not hold more than £10,00,000 and whatever he may have in excess, he must distribute as he likes among his relatives and others.
('5', 229, 3, 17, 526965) These thoughts of President Roosevelt have greatly perturbed American multi millionaires.

('5', 229, 4, 19, 527097) 224. CHANGES IN THE CONDITION OF CHINA It cannot be gainsaid that civilization is spreading day by day.
('5', 229, 4, 20, 527201) Few can be ignorant of the effect produced on India by European civilization.
('5', 229, 4, 21, 527279) This march of civilization has received a new impetus
('5', 230, 0, 1, 527333) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 231
('5', 230, 1, 2, 527380) from the progress made by Japan, which has attracted the attention of the whole world.
('5', 230, 1, 3, 527467) Wherever we go, we hear Japan being discussed.
('5', 230, 1, 4, 527514) It is clear that in the circumstances, European civilization should influence China, a neighbour of Japan.
('5', 230, 1, 5, 527621) This civilization is burgeoning everywhere in China.
('5', 230, 1, 6, 527674) On the one hand, thanks to the Japanese living in China, the attention of the people is drawn to education; on the other, hundreds of young Chinese go to foreign countries to learn the various arts and sciences.
('5', 230, 1, 7, 527886) Some Chinese students have gone to Japan for all kinds of study, and others have gone as far as America for the same purpose.
('5', 230, 1, 8, 528012) These students not only acquire proficiency in the arts and sciences, but the noteworthy thing is that they also bring home with them new ideas from America, Japan and Europe.
('5', 230, 1, 9, 528188) The spirit of freedom blowing through those lands has thoroughly permeated their youthful blood.
('5', 230, 1, 10, 528285) These students return home and lend their energies to promoting the progress of China.
('5', 230, 1, 11, 528372) By holding meetings and making speeches at various places, they have begun to impress their ideas upon people’s minds.
('5', 230, 1, 12, 528491) They start new journals and send out men in all directions to propagate their ideas.
('5', 230, 1, 13, 528576) Thus, they educate the people in a number of ways and sow the seeds of freedom and ideas of reform in their minds.
('5', 230, 1, 14, 528691) Neither do they appear to have left political reform out of their list.
('5', 230, 1, 15, 528763) They are carrying on an agitation to keep foreigners out of their country, and this has set the white nations a thinking.
('5', 230, 1, 16, 528885) That the boycott of American goods is spreading with more or less success in some parts of the country is also due to these new ideas.
('5', 230, 1, 17, 529020) In this agitation, some Japanese, too, are taking a leading part.
('5', 230, 1, 18, 529086) It is natural that everyone who desires the growth of civilization should welcome these signs of progress.
('5', 230, 1, 19, 529193) Yet, there are some Europ eans who say that this enthusiasm has exceeded the limits of propriety and is likely to lead the people astray, and that it should therefore be kept under restraint.With this end in view, a writer has suggested that the Chinese Government should be persuaded to bring under control, and if possible eliminate, those journals which spread undesirable ideas and incite people to harmful acts.

('5', 233, 5, 13, 534558) To the communication that the British Indian Association had again addressed him, Lord Selborne has replied saying that for the present he has nothing more to add to his previous answer.
('5', 233, 5, 14, 534745) This means that women will have to take out permits and that only children under twelve will be able to enter.
('5', 233, 6, 15, 534856) THE REMEDY
('5', 233, 7, 16, 534867) This reply will cause much disappointment.
('5', 233, 7, 17, 534910) However, women need not take out separate permits but the struggle about children should continue.
('5', 233, 8, 18, 535009) THE REQUEST OF THE BRITISH INDIAN ASSOCIATION
('5', 233, 9, 19, 535055) The Association has addressed a letter to Mr. Chamney, the Registrar, demanding that permission should at least be granted to the boys who are twelve years old and are waiting at various ports to enter the Transvaal.
('5', 233, 9, 20, 535272) The Association says that the number of such boys is not likely to exceed a hundred.
('5', 233, 10, 21, 535357) AN IMPORTANT PERMIT CASE
('5', 233, 11, 22, 535382) While official pressure is thus being exerted against us, the law is in our favour.
('5', 233, 11, 23, 535466) There is a boy under 12, named Adam Ebrahim, whose
('5', 234, 0, 1, 535517) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 235
('5', 234, 1, 2, 535564) father is at Johannesburg.
('5', 234, 1, 3, 535591) He has come with a “Letter of Notification”.
('5', 234, 1, 4, 535636) He has not yet got a permit.
('5', 234, 1, 5, 535665) He has not been to Pretoria.
('5', 234, 1, 6, 535694) Meanwhile, he was charged with failure to take out a £3 register and the case was heard by Mr. Cross yesterday.
('5', 234, 1, 7, 535806) Mr. Gandhi, who appeared on behalf of the boy, pleaded that it was not necessary for children to take out such a register in any case not for a person who did not himself carry on a trade.
('5', 234, 1, 8, 535995) The Magistrate admitted the plea and dismissed the case.
('5', 234, 2, 9, 536052) THE CONSEQUENCE OF THE CASE
('5', 234, 3, 10, 536080) If no appeal is preferred against the Magistrate’s decision, it will mean that, for boys who are already in the Transvaal, there will be no difficulty in remaining there even without a permit or a register.
('5', 234, 3, 11, 536287) Really speaking, the decision in the case does not give a ruling about permits; but it can be so construed by implication.
('5', 234, 3, 12, 536410) It may perhaps be necessary to have a test case about permits for children.
('5', 234, 4, 13, 536486) THE TRAM CASE
('5', 234, 5, 14, 536500) The discussion on the matter is still going on.
('5', 234, 5, 15, 536548) The Town Council has not yet answered the question put to it by Mr. Lane.

('5', 234, 6, 17, 536710) You say that the Magistrate’s decision is unsatisfactory, because it would enable a person, however unclean, to travel by a tram and that even the Kaffirs would be able to do so.
('5', 234, 6, 18, 536889) But the Magistrate’s decision is quite different.
('5', 234, 6, 19, 536939) The Court has declared that the Kaffirs have no legal right to travel by the trams.
('5', 234, 6, 20, 537023) And, according to tram regulations, those in an unclean dress or in a drunken state are prohibited from boarding a tram.
('5', 234, 6, 21, 537144) Thanks to the Court’s decision, only clean Indians or Coloured people other than Kaffirs can now travel by the trams.
('5', 234, 6, 22, 537262) But even this victory that we have achieved has been snatched away from us by the Council in an indecent manner.
('5', 234, 6, 23, 537375) For, while the Magistrate gave his decision on Friday, on Saturday appeared the news in the Government Gazette that the Town Council had withdrawn the tram regulations.
('5', 234, 6, 24, 537544) This means that an Indian will no more be able to file a suit under the bye laws; and the Council may perhaps be under the impression that the Smallpox Act of 1897 will now apply to Indians.
('5', 234, 6, 25, 537735) It has been a common belief that the British people never stab any one in the back.
('5', 234, 6, 26, 537819) But I feel—and other tax payers must also feel the same— that the Town Council has stabbed the Indian community

('5', 236, 2, 4, 540277) 231. LETTER TO LAKSHMIDAS GANDHI 1
('5', 236, 3, 5, 540312) JOHANNESBURG, May 27, 1906
('5', 236, 4, 6, 540339) RESPECTED BROTHER, I have your letter of the 17th April.
('5', 236, 4, 7, 540396) I do not know what to say.
('5', 236, 4, 8, 540423) You are prejudiced against me.
('5', 236, 4, 9, 540454) There is no remedy against prejudice.
('5', 236, 4, 10, 540492) I am helpless.
('5', 236, 4, 11, 540507) I can only reply to your letter in full.
('5', 236, 4, 12, 540548) 1. I have no idea of separating from you.
('5', 236, 4, 13, 540590) 2. I claim nothing there.
('5', 236, 4, 14, 540616) 3. I do not claim anything as mine.
('5', 236, 4, 15, 540652) 4. All that I have is being utilized for public purposes.
('5', 236, 4, 16, 540710) 5. It is available to relations who devote themselves to public work.
('5', 236, 4, 17, 540780) 6. I could have satisfied your desire for money if I had not dedicated my all for public use.
('5', 236, 4, 18, 540874) I have never said that I have done much for brothers or other relations.
('5', 236, 4, 19, 540947) I gave them all that I could save; and this I have mentioned not out of pride, and only to friends.
('5', 236, 4, 20, 541047) Rest assured that I will cheerfully assume the burden of supporting the family in case you pass on before me.
('5', 236, 4, 21, 541157) You need have no fear on that score.
('5', 236, 4, 22, 541194) I am not now in a position to send you money as you desire.
('5', 236, 4, 23, 541254) It is well if Harilal is married; it is also well if he is not.
('5', 236, 4, 24, 541318) For the present at any rate I have ceased to think of him as a son.
('5', 236, 4, 25, 541386) I am willing to go to India to attend Mani’s wedding if at all possible.
('5', 236, 4, 26, 541459) But I cannot give you any idea of my present condition.
('5', 236, 4, 27, 541515) I am so hard pressed for time that I scarcely know what to do.
('5', 236, 4, 28, 541578) Please cable the date of marriage, so that if possible I might hold myself in readiness to go.
('5', 236, 4, 29, 541673) I might perhaps inform you that I am in debt to Revashankarbhai.
('5', 236, 5, 30, 541738) 1 The letter was translated from Gujarati by V. G. Desai who tells us that it was revised by Gandhiji himself.
('5', 237, 0, 1, 541849) 238 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 237, 1, 2, 541891) You may repudiate me, but still I will be to you what I have always been.
('5', 237, 1, 3, 541965) I do not remember that I expressed a desire to separate from you when I was there.
('5', 237, 1, 4, 542048) But even if I did, my mind is now quite clear, my aspirations are higher and I have no desire for worldly enjoyments of any type whatever.
('5', 237, 1, 5, 542187) I am engaged in my present activities as I look upon them as essential to life.
('5', 237, 1, 6, 542267) If I have to face death while thus engaged, I shall face it with equanimity.
('5', 237, 1, 7, 542344) I am now a stranger to fear.
('5', 237, 1, 8, 542373) I like those who are pure in heart.
('5', 237, 1, 9, 542409) Young Kalyandas, Jagmohandas’s son, is like Prahlad in spirit.
('5', 237, 1, 10, 542472) He is therefore dearer to me than one who is a son because so born.

('5', 237, 3, 12, 542604) 232. STATEMENT PRESENTED TO CONSTITUTION COMMITTEE 1
('5', 237, 4, 13, 542657) [JOHANNESBURG, May 29, 1906]
('5', 237, 5, 14, 542686) WHITE PREDOMINANCE
('5', 237, 6, 15, 542705) (1) The British Indian Association has always admitted the principle of white predominance and has, therefore, no desire to press, on behalf of the community it represents, for any political rights for the sake of them.
('5', 237, 6, 16, 542925) But past experience shows that in a Colony enjoying self government, communities that have no voice in the choice of representatives have been very largely neglected.
('5', 237, 7, 17, 543092) HISTORY OF BOER ANTI INDIAN LEGISLATION
('5', 237, 8, 18, 543132) (2) There is in the Transvaal, at the present moment, an estimated population of over 12,000 British Indians.
('5', 237, 8, 19, 543242) Before war, the adult Indian population was 15,000. (3) The first Indian settlers found their way into the Transvaal in the early eighties.
('5', 237, 8, 20, 543382) (4) They were then free from restrictions of any kind whatsoever.
('5', 237, 8, 21, 543448) (5) But by their successful enterprise, they aroused the jealousy of white traders and soon there sprang up an anti Indian agitation
('5', 237, 9, 22, 543581) 1 This along with the addenda was presented to the Constitution Committee.
('5', 237, 9, 23, 543656) Vide “Johannesburg Letter”, After 18 5 1906
('5', 238, 0, 1, 543700) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 239
('5', 238, 1, 2, 543747) initiated by chambers of commerce wherein the British element was predominant.
('5', 238, 1, 3, 543826) (6) As a result, the Government of the late President Kruger approached Her late Majesty’s Government for permission to pass legislation restrictive of the liberty of British Indians.
('5', 238, 1, 4, 544010) They proposed to interpret the term, “Natives”, occurring in the London Convention, to include Asiatics.
('5', 238, 1, 5, 544115) (7) This contention Her Majesty’s advisers rejected but they were not unwilling, for “sanitary reasons”, to sanction legislation restricting Asiatics as to their residence to Bazaars or Locations with the proviso that British Indians of the trader class should be left entirely free.
('5', 238, 1, 6, 544399) (8) As a result of these negotiations, Law 3 of 1885 as amended in 1886 was passed.
('5', 238, 1, 7, 544483) (9) Immediately it became known, a strong protest went up from British Indians.
('5', 238, 1, 8, 544563) (10) It was then realized that the Law was, contrary to the expectations of Her late Majesty’s Government, sought to be enforced against all British Indians.
('5', 238, 1, 9, 544721) (11) Then followed a series of strong representations by Her late Majesty’s Government, addressed to the late Boer Government, culminating in the matter being submitted to the arbitration of the then Chief Justice of the Orange River Colony.
('5', 238, 2, 10, 544963) (12) Between 1885 and 1895, therefore, the Law 3 of 1885 practically remained a dead letter, although the Boer Government always threatened to enforce it.
('5', 238, 2, 11, 545118) (13) The award of the arbitrator did not define the legal position.
('5', 238, 2, 12, 545186) But it left the question of interpretation of Law 3 of 1885 to the Courts of the late Republic.
('5', 238, 3, 13, 545282) (14) British Indians again appealed to the British Government for protection.
('5', 238, 3, 14, 545360) (15) Mr. Chamberlain, whilst he declined to disturb the award, did not abandon the case for the Indian subjects of Her late Majesty.
('5', 238, 3, 15, 545493) In his dispatch dated the 4th September 1895, he stated:
('5', 238, 4, 16, 545550) In conclusion, I would say, that whilst desirous loyally to abide by the award, and to allow it to close the legal and international question in dispute between the two Governments, I reserve to myself the liberty later on to make friendly representations to the South African Republic as to the
('5', 238, 5, 17, 545846) 1 1888.
('5', 239, 0, 1, 545854) 240 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 239, 1, 2, 545896) traders, and possibly to invite the Government to consider whether, when once its legal position has been made good, it would not be wise to review the situation from a new point of view, and decide whether it would not be better in the interests of its own burghers to treat the Indians more generously, and to free itself from even the appearance of countenancing a trade jealousy which, I have some reason to believe, does not emanate from the governing class in the Republic.
('5', 239, 1, 3, 546376) This was in 1895. (16) Owing, then, to such representations, which continued up to the time of the war, the Law in question was never effectively enforced, and Indians traded and lived where they liked, in spite of the prohibition contemplated by it.
('5', 239, 1, 4, 546627) (17) But an enforcement of the Law being imminent in 1899, it was, among other things, a subject for discussion at the Bloemfontein Conference, which preceded the war.
('5', 239, 1, 5, 546795) The subject was considered so important by Lord Milner that, when the question of franchise to the Uitlanders seemed to admit of a settlement, Lord Milner cabled that the question of the status of coloured British subjects was still outstanding.
('5', 239, 1, 6, 547041) (18) Lord Lansdowne declared that it was a contributory cause of war.
('5', 239, 1, 7, 547111) (19) At the close of the war, and at the time of the Vereeniging compact, His Majesty’s Government informed the Boer representa tives that the status of Coloured persons should be the same in the two Colonies as at the Cape.
('5', 239, 2, 8, 547336) THE POSITION TODAY
('5', 239, 3, 9, 547355) (20) But today the position is worse than before war.
('5', 239, 3, 10, 547409) (21) The Progressive party, from which at least Indians as fellow loyalists and fellow sufferers before war may claim a fair measure of justice, has stated it as an item of its programme that the liberty of British Indians should be specifically restricted.
('5', 239, 3, 11, 547667) If its desires were carried out, the position, bad as it is today, would be much worse then.
('5', 239, 3, 12, 547760) (22) From the Dutch party, it is now impossible to expect any measure of reasonableness.
('5', 239, 3, 13, 547849) (23) Under Responsible Government, then, British Indians and others similarly situated, unless they are specially protected, stand practically little chance of justice being done to them.
('5', 239, 5, 14, 548037) (24) It would, therefore, seem that the granting of the franchise
('5', 240, 0, 1, 548103) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 241
('5', 240, 1, 2, 548150) to British Indians would be the most natural means of protecting their interests.
('5', 240, 1, 3, 548232) (25) It has been urged that the treaty of Vereeniging precludes the possibility of any such provision being made.
('5', 240, 1, 4, 548346) (26) But it is respectfully submitted that the term “Natives”, whatever else it may mean, can never include British Indians.
('5', 240, 1, 5, 548471) (27) The Statute book of the Colony is replete with laws which deal with the “Natives”, but which admittedly do not apply to Asiatics or British Indians.
('5', 240, 1, 6, 548625) (28) The fact that Law 3 of 1885 deals specially with Asiatics and does not apply to the “Natives” shows, too, that the Transvaal laws have almost invariably distinguished between “Natives” and “Asiatics”.
('5', 240, 1, 7, 548831) (29) Indeed, whereas Natives can, owing to the meaning that the term has borne, hold landed property in the Transvaal, Asiatics cannot.
('5', 240, 1, 8, 548967) (30) Thus, therefore, so far as the Vereeniging compact is concerned, there appears to be no justification whatever for depriving the Indians of the franchise.
('5', 240, 1, 9, 549127) (31) But the Committee of the British Indian Association is well aware of the almost unanimous hostility of white races against provision being made in the Constitution for a grant of the franchise to British Indians.
('5', 240, 1, 10, 549345) (32) If, therefore, such a grant be considered impossible, it is absolutely essential that, apart from the orthodox reservatory clause as to the power of veto over all class legislation, there should be a special clause which shall be a living reality, and which, instead of being exercised only on the rarest occasions, should ensure the fullest protection to the British Indian settlers as to their right to own landed property, freedom of movement, and freedom of trade, subject to such safeguards of a general nature as may be considered necessary, and are made applicable to all, irrespective of race or colour.
('5', 240, 1, 11, 549962) (33) Then, and only then, will it be possible, apart from the inherent right that every British subject should have to ordinary civil rights in British dominions, for His Majesty’s advisers to redeem the promises specifically made to British Indians as to their status in the Transvaal.
('5', 240, 1, 12, 550249) (34) Much of what has been stated above applies to the position of British Indians in the Orange River Colony.
('5', 240, 1, 13, 550360) (35) There the Indian has no rights, save as a domestic servant.
('5', 240, 1, 14, 550425) An elaborate anti Asiatic law deprives him of practically all civil
('5', 241, 0, 1, 550493) 242 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 241, 1, 2, 550535) liberty.
