('5', 241, 6, 13, 551265) APPENDIX B
('5', 241, 7, 14, 551276) The following is a comparison of the position of British Indians in the Transvaal under Boer and under British rule.
('5', 241, 7, 15, 551393) Before the War Under British Rule
('5', 241, 8, 16, 551427) (1) Indians were free to enter the country without restriction.
('5', 241, 8, 17, 551491) (1) No immigration permitted other than of bona fide refugees who left on the eve of the war, and they are only admitted gradually and after long delay for the consideration of their applications.
('5', 241, 8, 18, 551688) Permits are required even for little children, and every Indian has to attach his thumb impression on these documents.
('5', 241, 9, 19, 551807) (2) Payment of registration fee not enforced.
('5', 241, 9, 20, 551853) (2) Registration fee of £3, on pain of fine not exceeding £100, or imprisonment for not more than 6 months, strictly enforced.
('5', 241, 9, 21, 551980) Attempt is being made now to exact
('5', 242, 0, 1, 552015) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 243
('5', 242, 1, 2, 552062) registration fees from Indian women and require them to take out permits.
('5', 242, 2, 3, 552136) (3) Landed property could be held in the names of Europeans.
('5', 242, 2, 4, 552197) (3) The law against Asiatics holding real property strictly enforced, even in cases where land is required for religious purposes.
('5', 242, 3, 5, 552328) (4) Indians held 99 years’ lease for landed property in Location or bazaar in Johannesburg.
('5', 242, 4, 6, 552420) (4) These leases have been expropriated under the Insanitary Area Commissioner’s Report, without the owners receiving equal title elsewhere in Johannesburg in a suitable position.
('5', 242, 5, 7, 552600) (5) No separate inquisitorial Asiatic Department.
('5', 242, 5, 8, 552650) (5) Office of Registrar of Asiatics established; is arbitrary in procedure and delays the settlement of individual applications, permits, etc.
('5', 242, 6, 9, 552793) (6) Many harsh legislative restrictions allowed to remain inoperative owing largely to British intervention.
('5', 242, 7, 10, 552902) (6) Inoperative Boer enactments brought into force, and rendered more stringent by Ordinances or Executive Orders, and British Indians offensively classed in legislation with Kaffirs, savages, and semi civilised races.
('5', 242, 8, 11, 553121) The following addendum was prepared at the instance of the Constitution Committee.
('5', 242, 9, 12, 553204) CIVIL DISABILITIES
('5', 242, 10, 13, 553223) I. The Commissioners seem to be under the impression that British Indians have full rights in the Transvaal.
('5', 242, 10, 14, 553332) Unfortunately, as will appear from the schedule attached to the statement, British Indians have very few civil rights; we venture to recapitulate the civil disabilities:
('5', 242, 11, 15, 553502) NO OWNERSHIP OF LAND
('5', 242, 12, 16, 553523) (1) British Indians cannot own landed property, including even long leases, except in Locations or streets set apart for them.
('5', 242, 12, 17, 553650) (2) There are no streets set apart, but there are Locations far away from town, like the Continental Ghettos.
('5', 242, 12, 18, 553760) And in these, too, except in one or two places, Indians are only monthly squatters.
('5', 242, 12, 19, 553844) In Pretoria and Potchefstroom alone do they receive twenty one years’ leases.
('5', 242, 12, 20, 553922) In Germiston, they have even received notices not to receive any tenants on their Stands.
('5', 242, 12, 21, 554012) The notice reads as follows:
('5', 242, 13, 22, 554041) You are hereby notified that you are not permitted to sublet rooms to natives or others.
('5', 242, 13, 23, 554130) Such subletting to any person is a breach of the contract
('5', 243, 0, 1, 554188) 244 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 243, 1, 2, 554230) under which you are allowed to hold a stand, and renders you liable to have your stand permit cancelled, and yourself expelled from this location.
('5', 243, 1, 3, 554377) (3) So much is this prohibition carried out in practice that Indians are unable to have their mosques transferred in the names of Indian trustees.
('5', 243, 2, 4, 554524) REGISTRATION FEE
('5', 243, 3, 5, 554541) (4) Indians have to pay a registration fee of £3 on arrival in this country.
('5', 243, 3, 6, 554618) The Government has now threatened even to require women and children to take out registration certificates.
('5', 243, 4, 7, 554726) FOOT PATHS AND TRAMWAYS
('5', 243, 5, 8, 554750) (5) Indians in Pretoria and Johannesburg are prohibited by law from walking on the foot paths.
('5', 243, 5, 9, 554845) They, however, do make use of them on sufferance.
('5', 243, 5, 10, 554895) An attempt was only recently made to prevent them from using the foot paths.
('5', 243, 5, 11, 554972) (6) Indians are not allowed to make use of the tram cars in Pretoria.
('5', 243, 5, 12, 555042) (7) They are prevented in Johannesburg from riding in the ordinary cars but special trailer cars are occasionally run for Coloured people.
('5', 243, 5, 13, 555181) (8) It was contended on behalf of the Indians that, under the ordinary by laws, they could insist on riding in the tram cars.
('5', 243, 5, 14, 555307) The Town Council opposed the contention on the ground that certain smallpox regulations that were promulgated by the late Dutch Government in 1897 were still in force.
('5', 243, 5, 15, 555475) The matter was twice tested before the Magistrate at Johannesburg and, each time, the Town Council lost.
('5', 243, 5, 16, 555580) It has, therefore now met the Indians by cancelling, the by laws regulating the traffic on the tram cars.
('5', 243, 5, 17, 555686) In order to gain its end, the Town Council is now running the Municipal cars without any by laws whatsoever.
('5', 243, 5, 18, 555795) Whether under the common law Indians will be able now to make good their right or not is an open question.
('5', 243, 5, 19, 555902) It is worthy of note that the above mentioned cancelling by law was surreptitiously published in the following manner:
('5', 243, 6, 20, 556021) Prior to the 9th May, 1906, in accordance with Section 22 of Proclamation 16 of 1901, a notice had been published in a newspaper circulating in the Municipality, setting forth the general purport of these proposed amendments and stating that they were open to inspection at the office of the Council.
('5', 243, 6, 21, 556322) On the 9th inst., a meeting of the Town Council was held.
('5', 243, 6, 22, 556380) The notice was apparently advertised in such a manner as to render it almost a matter of impossibility for parties concerned to challenge the
('5', 244, 0, 1, 556522) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 245
('5', 244, 1, 2, 556569) proposed amendments, owing chiefly to the fact that no report of them had appeared in the ordinary columns of the newspapers, and to the further fact that, as will be seen, the proposal came through the Works Committee, instead of the Tramways and Lighting Committee, which would ordinarily concern itself with Tramways Regulations as it has done in the past.
('5', 244, 1, 3, 556929) On the occasion of the aforesaid Council meeting, the Works Committee brought forward the proposed amendment on the following pretext:
('5', 244, 2, 4, 557064) Since the Tramway System was taken over by the Municipal Council, the Traffic Bye laws applicable to tram cars are no longer required as they were only intended for application to private tram cars.
('5', 244, 2, 5, 557263) It is proposed, therefore, that the Bye laws should be amended accordingly.
('5', 244, 2, 6, 557339) The proposals were submitted at the end of a long agenda, when even the most vigilant Councillor might have been lulled into a sense of security, especially in view of the seemingly innocuous nature of the preamble and passed without comment.
('5', 244, 2, 7, 557582) A notice appeared in the Government Gazette of the 18th inst., adopting the proposed cancelling bye law, and giving it the force of law.
('5', 244, 2, 8, 557719) The whole matter, therefore, was settled practically behind the backs of the British Indians within a period of nine days, for all practical purposes, without warning.
('5', 244, 2, 9, 557887) (9) Attempt is now being made to expropriate what is known as the Malay Location in Johannesburg, which has a large Indian population, and to send the Indians to a place thirteen miles away from Johannesburg.
('5', 244, 3, 10, 558096) PERMIT ORDINANCE
('5', 244, 4, 11, 558113) (10) Whereas formerly Indians were free to immigrate into the Transvaal, at present the Peace Preservation Ordinance, which is purely a political law, is being wrested from its legitimate purpose to prevent Indians from entering the Transvaal.
('5', 244, 4, 12, 558357) Not only are new Indians being prevented from entering the country, but the following exceptional hardships are imposed on all residents of the Transvaal: (a) There are no published regulations regarding the administration of the Ordinance.
('5', 244, 4, 13, 558598) (b) It changes according to the whims or prejudices of the officials administering it.
('5', 244, 4, 14, 558685) The following is, therefore, the practice in vogue today: (i) Indians, who were in the Transvaal before war and who paid £3 for registration, are prevented from returning, unless they can prove absolutely that they left on the outbreak of hostilities.
('5', 245, 0, 1, 558937) 246 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 245, 1, 2, 558979) (ii) Those who are allowed to enter the Transvaal have to put their thumb impressions upon their applications, as also upon their permits, and they are required to put them each time they enter the Transvaal.
('5', 245, 1, 3, 559188) This is applicable to all Indians without regard to their position and without regard to the fact whether they can sign their names in English or not.
('5', 245, 1, 4, 559339) An England returned Indian gentleman, who speaks English well, and who is a very well known merchant, was twice obliged to put his thumb impression .
('5', 245, 1, 5, 559489) (iii) Wives and children under twelve years of such Indians are now required to take out separate permits.
('5', 245, 1, 6, 559596) (iv) Children, twelve years old or over, of such Indians are not allowed to join or accompany their parents.
('5', 245, 1, 7, 559705) (v) Indian merchants are not allowed to import any trustworthy clerks or managers, unless the latter are themselves such as fall within the first clause hereinbefore referred to.
('5', 245, 1, 8, 559884) (vi) Even those who are allowed to enter have to wait for months before they are permitted to enter the country.
('5', 245, 1, 9, 559997) (vii) Even temporary permits are refused to Indians of respectability.
('5', 245, 1, 10, 560068) Mr. Suliman Manga, who is studying for the bar in London, wishing to pass through the Transvaal on his way to Delagoa Bay, was refused a permit when his case was considered as of a British subject.
('5', 245, 1, 11, 560266) When it became known that he was a Portuguese subject, for fear, evidently, of international complications, he was granted a temporary permit.
('5', 245, 1, 12, 560409) (viii) Such is the terrible position of British Indians who are resident in the Transvaal.
('5', 245, 1, 13, 560500) It is growing daily worse, and unless the Imperial Government is willing and ready to protect them, the ultimate result can only be slow extinction.
('5', 245, 2, 14, 560649) WHAT EUROPEANS WILL DO.
('5', 245, 3, 15, 560673) (11) The following facts will shew what the Europeans of the Transvaal will do, if they are left to themselves: (a) The National Convention, which specially met to consider the Asiatic question, passed the following resolutions:
('5', 245, 4, 16, 560902) (lst) That having regard to the preponderance of the native races in this country, the difficulties surrounding the settlement of native policy, the necessity for protecting the existing European population and encouraging further European immigration, this Convention affirms the principle that Asiatic immigration should be prohibited except under the provisions of the Labour Importation Ordinance.
('5', 245, 5, 17, 561304) (2nd) That this Convention, having regard to the importance of arriving
('5', 246, 0, 1, 561376) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 247
('5', 246, 1, 2, 561423) at a permanent and conclusive settlement of the whole question and preventing any further attempts to reopen the matter, recommends that the Government be invited to take into consideration the advisability of removing into bazaars all Asiatic traders, compensation being provided for such as may have vested interests which have been legally acquired prior to the war.
('5', 246, 2, 3, 561793) (3rd) That this Convention, recognising the grave danger resulting from the continued issue of trading licences to Asiatics permitting trade outside bazaars, requests the Government to take immediate steps to pass the necessary legal enactments to prevent any further issue of such licences and that with regard to the appointment of any proposed Commission to deal with the Asiatic question, this Convention urges upon the Government the necessity for including therein men, other than officials, with a thorough knowledge of existing conditions in South Africa.
('5', 246, 3, 4, 562357) (4th) That this Convention affirms its opinion that all Asiatics should be required to reside in bazaars.
('5', 246, 3, 5, 562463) (b) The following is the declared policy of the Progressive party: The restriction of immigration of Asiatics into the Transvaal, except in the case of indentured labourers who are subject to repatriation at the expiration of their contract, and the regulation of Asiatic trading licences.
('5', 246, 3, 6, 562753) (c) The people of Potchefstroom once met together, created a disturbance, and even broke the windows of Indian stores.
('5', 246, 3, 7, 562872) (d) The Europeans of Boksburg wish to remove Indians from their present Location, which they occupied before war, to a site far away from town where trade is utterly impossible, and they have more than once threatened to use physical force should an Indian attempt to open a store outside the Location.
('5', 246, 4, 8, 563175) PAST EXPERIENCE—A PARALLEL
('5', 246, 5, 9, 563202) (12) In the main statement, the Deputation have urged that past experience shows that the deprivation of the franchise and the orthodox power of veto have been totally inadequate to protect Indians.
('5', 246, 5, 10, 563401) (13) We will venture now to give instances: In Natal, after the grant of Responsible Government, Indians were virtually deprived of the franchise.
('5', 246, 5, 11, 563548) The late Sir John Robinson, in supporting the Bill, said that, by disfranchising Indians, every
('5', 247, 0, 1, 563644) 248 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 247, 1, 2, 563686) member of the Natal Parliament became a trustee for Indians.
('5', 247, 2, 3, 563747) Soon after the Bill became an Act of Parliament the trust was thus discharged: (a) An annual poll tax of £3 was imposed on all indentured Indians, who entered after its promulgation, to be payable on the termination of their indentures, unless they returned to India or re indentured themselves.
('5', 247, 2, 4, 564043) (b) An Immigration Restriction Act was passed prohibiting all who did not possess a knowledge of one of the European languages from entering Natal unless they were formerly domiciled in the Colony.
('5', 247, 2, 5, 564241) (c) A Dealers’ Licenses Act was passed with absolute powers to the Town Councils or Licensing Boards to control trade licences.
('5', 247, 2, 6, 564369) It ousts the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court.
('5', 247, 2, 7, 564417) Ostensibly applying to all traders, it is enforced only against Indians.
('5', 247, 2, 8, 564490) And under it, no Indian, however, well established, is ever secure as to his license from year’s end to year’s end.
('5', 247, 2, 9, 564606) Against all this legislation, the Imperial Government has felt powerless to protect British Indians.
('5', 247, 3, 10, 564707) THE UNIQUE POSITION IN THE TRANSVAAL AND THE ORANGE
('5', 247, 4, 11, 564759) RIVER COLONY
('5', 247, 5, 12, 564772) (14) Whether Indians are granted the franchise under the Constitution or not, a special clause protecting vested interests is absolutely necessary.
('5', 247, 5, 13, 564920) (15) No Colony on the eve of receiving self government has presented the features that the Transvaal and Orange River Colonies present.
('5', 247, 5, 14, 565056) (16) All the causes for which the war took place have not been removed.
('5', 247, 5, 15, 565128) Anti Indian legislation of the Transvaal was one of the causes.
('5', 247, 5, 16, 565192) (17) Promise made by the Home Government that Indians and other Coloured people in the two Colonies should be treated the same way as those at the Cape has not yet been redeemed.
('5', 247, 5, 17, 565371) (18) Negotiations were actually pending between the Home Government and the Local Governments as to the removal of the disabilities of British Indians when His Majesty’s new Ministers decided to grant Responsible Government to the two Colonies, and the negotiations have, therefore, been suspended or dropped altogether.
('5', 247, 6, 18, 565692) 1 Vide “The Plague”, 9 7 1903
('5', 248, 0, 1, 565722) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 249
('5', 248, 1, 2, 565769) (19) The position at the Cape is that Indians have equal rights with the Europeans, i.e., (a) They have the same franchise rights as the Europeans.
('5', 248, 1, 3, 565917) (b) They are under the same Immigration Restriction Act as the Europeans.
('5', 248, 1, 4, 565991) (c) They have equal rights with the latter to hold landed property and to trade.
('5', 248, 1, 5, 566072) (d) They have full freedom of locomotion from place to place.

('5', 248, 2, 7, 566208) 233. INDIAN PASSENGERS
('5', 248, 3, 8, 566231) Of late our Gujarati correspondence columns have been full of complaints from Indian deck passengers who so largely patronise the steamers of the German East Africa Company.
('5', 248, 3, 9, 566405) Our correspondents have complained of over crowding, insufficient sanitary arrangements, and general want of consideration for deck passengers.
('5', 248, 3, 10, 566549) Some of them state that the passengers are very much inconvenienced whenever the steamers touch any port.
('5', 248, 3, 11, 566655) They are then without any cover, and are called upon to shift their luggage.
('5', 248, 3, 12, 566732) We draw the attention of the local agents of the Company to these complaints.
('5', 248, 3, 13, 566810) In many respects, we are aware that a certain amount of inconvenience is inseparable from the mode of travelling that the poor Indian passengers are compelled to select.
('5', 248, 3, 14, 566980) It is impossible to expect much from accommodation on deck.
('5', 248, 3, 15, 567040) At the same time, it is a notorious fact that the deck passenger traffic is the most lucrative and least troublesome.
('5', 248, 3, 16, 567158) It, therefore, behoves the Company’s managers to ensure as much comfort as is possible in the circumstances for the deck passengers, if only for mercenary reasons.

('5', 248, 5, 18, 567347) 234. A PERMIT CASE
('5', 248, 6, 19, 567366) Our Johannesburg correspondent reports a case tried the other day before Mr. Cross at the Johannesburg Court.
('5', 248, 6, 20, 567476) One Adam Ebrahim, a lad under twelve years, was brought before the Magistrate for being in the Transvaal without a registration certificate.
('5', 248, 6, 21, 567617) The form of prosecution was somewhat novel, for hitherto all such cases were tried under the Peace Preservation Ordinance.
('5', 248, 6, 22, 567740) Whilst escape under it was less easy, there was no penalty in the nature of a fine or imprisonment, whereas a conviction under Law 3 of 1885
('5', 249, 0, 1, 567881) 250 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 249, 1, 2, 567923) renders the accused liable to a fine of not more than £100 or not more than six months’ imprisonment, with or without hard labour.
('5', 249, 1, 3, 568054) Happily, counsel for the accused had no difficulty in showing that the boy was not liable to pay the registration fee on entering the Transvaal.
('5', 249, 1, 4, 568199) Thus, the more galling the shackles imposed by the Government upon the Indian, the heavier, it would appear, is the liberating blow delivered by the judicial hammer.
('5', 249, 1, 5, 568365) The Judiciary protects what the Executive would gladly destroy.
('5', 249, 1, 6, 568429) Will Lord Selborne still say that the administration of the Law, which has now been demonstrated to be illegal, is reasonable and is being carried on with due consideration for those affected by it?

('5', 251, 0, 1, 572018) 252 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 251, 1, 2, 572060) 239. A NEW SAN FRANCISCO
('5', 251, 2, 3, 572085) It is certainly not for the first time that the reader is reminded of the proverb, “God can do what He wills within the instant.” History furnishes many examples of a pauper becoming wealthy and a wealthy man turning pauper in a moment.
('5', 251, 2, 4, 572322) But this rule is not confined to individuals.
('5', 251, 2, 5, 572368) The rule, “from the palace to the hovel”, and vice versa can apply equally to a whole city or country.
('5', 251, 2, 6, 572471) The recent San Francisco earthquake is a case in point.
('5', 251, 2, 7, 572527) Three hundred thousand persons—why, even more— were in a moment rendered homeless !
('5', 251, 2, 8, 572611) Thousands, who were used to living in comfort and the luxury of big palaces and did not have to tell day from night, were left without even a rickety hut.
('5', 251, 2, 9, 572766) Spacious and well furnished mansions and beautiful streets, razed to the ground in a movement and reduced to a heap of dust, have paid their obeisance to Time.
('5', 251, 2, 10, 572926) A barren desert has spread over the site once covered by gardens and villas.
('5', 251, 2, 11, 573003) Countless men have been deprived of shelter and food in the twinkling of an eye.
('5', 251, 2, 12, 573084) Who, having seen this, would not wonder at the mysterious ways of God?
('5', 251, 2, 13, 573155) By far the more astonishing fact is, however, quite a different one.
('5', 251, 2, 14, 573224) True bravery consists in standing erect and boldly in the face of the cruel blow dealt by such a fearful catastrophe.
('5', 251, 2, 15, 573342) This colossal task has been undertaken by the people of San Francisco.
('5', 251, 2, 16, 573413) Well known for its perseverance and industry, the American nation is out to prove its mettle.
('5', 251, 2, 17, 573507) The task of reconstructing a new and more splendid San Francisco without the aid of the outside world and in the face of divine wrath has begun.
('5', 251, 2, 18, 573652) Plans are being drawn up to add to the world’s beauty by recreating a more beautiful San Francisco.
('5', 251, 2, 19, 573752) Huge structures are being erected for bringing a new celestial city into being.
('5', 251, 2, 20, 573832) Thousands of workmen have been invited from distant lands.
('5', 251, 2, 21, 573891) The quantity of steel ordered for the purpose is so large that it might lead to a boom in the country’s iron market.
('5', 251, 2, 22, 574008) Plans are being drawn up to construct a new dock of the latest style, the like of which will be found only in a few parts of the world.
('5', 251, 2, 23, 574144) The streets are so planned that they will further add to the charm of the new city.
('5', 251, 2, 24, 574228) The people there are thus fully prepared to meet this natural calamity in a variety of ways.
('5', 251, 2, 25, 574321) With the help of electric power generated from waterfalls, human intelligence has been able to run railway trains and factories thousands of miles away.
('5', 251, 2, 26, 574474) It has been able to produce ships and balloons voyaging across the high seas and reaching the highest regions of the sky.
('5', 251, 2, 27, 574596) It is also conducting experiments to communicate with men on other planets of the Universe.
('5', 251, 2, 28, 574688) But the selfsame
('5', 252, 0, 1, 574705) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 253
('5', 252, 1, 2, 574752) intelligence cannot feel the tremors within the bowels of the earth and is unable to prevent the occurrence of earthquakes.
('5', 252, 1, 3, 574876) This, indeed, is a matter for sorrow, but it should certainly gladden our hearts to see how man faces such shocks with courage.
('5', 252, 1, 4, 575004) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 2 5 1906

('5', 253, 4, 5, 575967) SIR, The Natal Indian Congress has received from the Government a communication accepting the offer of an Indian Ambulance Corps.
('5', 253, 4, 6, 576097) As a preliminary trial, the Government state that the Corps should consist of 20 stretcher bearers.
('5', 253, 4, 7, 576197) Our Committee has the honour to inform you that 20 men will be at your disposal at the time and place that you may be pleased to advise.

('5', 253, 4, 11, 576657) Our Committee, therefore, trusts that the Government will be pleased to allow the Indian community to pay their men.
('5', 253, 4, 12, 576774) At the same time, we beg to submit that it is not possible to raise the Corps on a salary of less than one pound per week, which sum, we are instructed to say, the Indian community is willing to pay as long as the services of the Corps are required.
('5', 253, 4, 13, 577024) We beg further to add that most of the men, whilst in every respect willing to work, are untrained, for no fault of their own, for the purpose of an Ambulance Corps.

('5', 254, 1, 2, 577380) 242. JOHANNESBURG LETTER
('5', 254, 2, 3, 577405) June 6, 1906
('5', 254, 3, 4, 577418) THE STORY OF THE TRAM CASE
('5', 254, 4, 5, 577445) The tram case has taken a new turn.
('5', 254, 4, 6, 577481) A keen tussle is going on between the Town Council and the Indians.
('5', 254, 4, 7, 577549) Neither side would accept defeat.
('5', 254, 4, 8, 577583) While, on the one hand, the Town Council abolished the tramway regulations on the excuse that none were necessary, a committee of the Council has, on the other, framed new ones.
('5', 254, 4, 9, 577761) From information received from confidential sources, I learn that Mr. Duncan 1 attended the Committee meeting.
('5', 254, 4, 10, 577872) The Committee expressed the opinion that there should be a provision in the Regulations forbidding Indians from travelling in tram cars; that they might, if they so desired, use separate trams; and that only Indians with special permits could travel by all the trams.
('5', 254, 4, 11, 578140) Mr. Duncan, it is said, opposed this view of the Committee, saying that, just as the Indian community had remained patient in the matter of the railway, so they would remain patient in the matter of the tramway too, if some concessions were granted.
('5', 254, 4, 12, 578390) If further harassment were caused, they would be provoked and the result would be far from desirable.
('5', 254, 4, 13, 578492) The Committee’s work of framing Regulations is still going on.
('5', 254, 4, 14, 578555) In a few days, when these are published, we shall know more about them.
('5', 254, 4, 15, 578627) The Town Council has thus been active in the matter.
('5', 254, 4, 16, 578680) Meanwhile, the Indian community has taken a step forward.
('5', 254, 4, 17, 578738) Mr. Abdul Gani, the Chairman of the British Indian Association, and Mr. Polak, the present English Editor of this journal, got into a tram.
('5', 254, 4, 18, 578878) The conductor refused to allow Mr. Abdul Gani to sit, but he said that he would not get off the tram unless forced to do so.
('5', 254, 4, 19, 579003) The conductor called in the police, who also got the same reply.
('5', 254, 4, 20, 579068) At last, the Tram Inspector arrived and spoke politely to Mr. Gani.
('5', 254, 4, 21, 579136) As a result of the talk, it was decided that Mr. Abdul Gani would be prosecuted on a charge of having obstructed the tram car.
('5', 254, 4, 22, 579263) Mr. Abdul Gani and Mr. Polak agreed to this and got down.
('5', 254, 4, 23, 579321) When this was reported to the Town Council by the Inspector, the Town Clerk immediately wrote a note to Gani and Polak requesting them to see him.
('5', 254, 4, 24, 579468) He told them that the Indians had done enough, and that they should not further harass the Council; that the Regulations in the matter would be published in a few days; and that, if the Indians did not approve of them, they might
('5', 254, 5, 25, 579698) 1 Colonial Secretary

('5', 255, 1, 2, 579761) challenge them.

('5', 255, 2, 4, 579848) THE DEPUTATION TO ENGLAND
('5', 255, 3, 5, 579874) A second cablegram regarding a deputation to England has been received from Sir William Wedderburn.
('5', 255, 3, 6, 579974) Though the Committee working for us in England is not very hopeful of success, it suggests that Mr. Gandhi alone may be sent to England by the same steamer by which the Constitution Committee will sail.
('5', 255, 3, 7, 580177) The Committee is likely to leave for England towards the beginning of July.
('5', 255, 3, 8, 580253) The Committee of the Association met on the night of Wednesday last to consider the membership of the deputation.
('5', 255, 3, 9, 580367) It passed a resolution calling for a meeting of all the Indians in Johannesburg and appealing for funds.
('5', 255, 3, 10, 580472) It further decided that Mr. Haji Habib, the Secretary of the Pretoria Committee, and Mr. Haji Ojer Ali might be sent, besides Mr. Gandhi, if sufficient funds could be raised.
('5', 255, 3, 11, 580647) I have already written that this meeting will be held at 2 p.m.

('5', 255, 4, 13, 580733) MINERS’ DEMANDS
('5', 255, 5, 14, 580749) The Miners’ deputation, which waited on the Committee, demanded that Indians should in future be denied entry into the Colony, and that further issue of trade and other licences to them should be stopped.
('5', 255, 6, 15, 580954) PERMIT HARDSHIPS
('5', 255, 7, 16, 580971) Tired of the permit problems, the Association has now taken the last step.
('5', 255, 7, 17, 581046) It has written to the Government saying that, if the difficulties regarding permits were not now ended, the Association would file cases to test the four following principles: 1. Those who can prove having made a payment of £3 to the Boer Government should be allowed to enter without permits; 2. children under sixteen of parents who are themselves entitled to enter should be allowed in, and that without a permit; 3. wives of those who are entitled to enter should be allowed in without a permit; and, lastly, 4. instead of the current practice of arbitrarily issuing permits to whomsoever the Government wishes, there should be clear and definite regulations to determine those eligible for permits.
('5', 255, 7, 18, 581750) The Association has issued instructions that, if the Government does not give a satisfactory reply in this matter, test cases should be instituted on all the said points.

('5', 256, 1, 2, 582009) 243. LETTER TO DADABHAI NAOROJI
('5', 256, 2, 3, 582041) DURBAN, NATAL, June 8, 1906
('5', 256, 3, 4, 582069) TO THE HON’BLE DADABHAI NAOROJI KENNINGTON ROAD LONDON
('5', 256, 4, 5, 582124) DEAR SIR, I had your last cablegram suggesting that I should go to England alone by same steamer as the commissioners.
('5', 256, 4, 6, 582243) I was making preparations accordingly, when a communication was received from the Natal Government accepting the offer of the Indian community to form an “Indian Stretcher Bearer Corps”.
('5', 256, 4, 7, 582430) I am, therefore, expecting to leave for the front any day.
('5', 256, 4, 8, 582489) Under the circumstances, we have all decided that the formation of the Corps is far more important than a visit to England.
('5', 256, 4, 9, 582613) It is recognised that I should be with the Corps, at least in the initial stages.
('5', 256, 4, 10, 582695) It is evident that the Natal Government intend to test the capability of the Indians for ambulance work.
('5', 256, 4, 11, 582800) I fear, therefore, for the present, I should abandon any idea of going to England.
('5', 256, 4, 12, 582883) We here, therefore, hope that the Committee that is looking after Indian interests in South Africa will take the necessary steps to place the position before the Government.
('5', 256, 4, 13, 583057) You will have seen the statement placed before the Constitution Committee 1 on behalf of the British Indians in the Transvaal.
('5', 256, 4, 14, 583184) It represents all that could be said in the matter.
('5', 256, 4, 15, 583236) The statement appears in Indian Opinion for the 2nd instant.
('5', 256, 5, 16, 583297) I remain,
('5', 256, 6, 17, 583307) Yours faithfully, M. K. GANDHI

('5', 257, 1, 2, 583491) 244. INDIANS AND THE NATIVE UNREST
('5', 257, 2, 3, 583526) The Government have at last accepted the offer of the Indian community, and put it upon its mettle.
('5', 257, 2, 4, 583626) By way of experiment, they want a corps of twenty stretcher bearers.
('5', 257, 2, 5, 583695) The Natal Indian Congress has sent in a prompt reply.
('5', 257, 2, 6, 583749) 1 We think the Congress has done well in offering to defray the wages of the bearers, so long as the corps remains in the experimental stage.
('5', 257, 2, 7, 583891) The acceptance by the Government synchronizes with the amendment of the Fire Arms Act, providing for the supply of arms to Indians, and the statement made by Mr. Maydon to the effect that the Government intended to give Indians an opportunity of taking their share in the defence of the Colony.
('5', 257, 2, 8, 584186) Indians have now a splendid opportunity for showing that they are capable of appreciating the duties of citizenship.
('5', 257, 2, 9, 584303) At the same time, the fact of the corps being raised is nothing to be unduly proud of.
('5', 257, 2, 10, 584390) Twenty Indians, or even two hundred, going to the front is a flea bite.
('5', 257, 2, 11, 584462) The Indian sacrifice will rightly be considered infinitesimal.
('5', 257, 2, 12, 584525) But it is the principle involved which marks the importance of the event.
('5', 257, 2, 13, 584599) The Government have, by accepting the offer, shown their goodwill.
('5', 257, 2, 14, 584666) And if Indians come successfully through the ordeal, the possibilities for the future are very great.
('5', 257, 2, 15, 584768) Should they be assigned a permanent part in the Militia, there will remain no ground for the European complaint that Europeans alone have to bear the brunt of Colonial defence, and Indians will cease to feel that, in not being allowed to participate in it, they are slighted.
('5', 257, 2, 16, 585044) Indian Opinion, 9 6 1906

('5', 258, 2, 7, 586115) 246. INDIAN POSITION IN NATAL 1
('5', 258, 3, 8, 586147) [Before June 13, 1906] Two things cause the greatest trouble to the Indian community in Natal.
('5', 258, 3, 9, 586242) The first is the Dealers’ Licenses Act.
('5', 258, 3, 10, 586282) When this Act was passed, the late Sir Henry Binns strongly protested against it, saying that it was an un British measure, and that the ousting of the ordinary jurisdiction of the Supreme Court was a dangerous principle.
('5', 258, 3, 11, 586504) Experience has shown the justness of these prophetic words.
('5', 258, 3, 12, 586564) The administration of the Act was, in its initial stages, marked by an excess of zeal in restricting British Indian trade.
('5', 258, 3, 13, 586687) The Licensing Officer at Newcastle refused to renew all Indian licences, that is, nine in number.
('5', 258, 3, 14, 586785) It was after very great expense and trouble that six of them were renewed.
('5', 258, 3, 15, 586860) As a result, and owing to pressure from the Colonial Office, the Government issued a warning to the licensing authorities that, unless they administered the Act with prudence and moderation and respected existing licences, the Government might be obliged to amend the law, and restore the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court.
('5', 258, 3, 16, 587184) The circular letter served its purpose for a time.
('5', 258, 3, 17, 587235) It could do no more.
('5', 258, 3, 18, 587256) Three typical cases have since happened to show how harsh has been the administration.
('5', 258, 3, 19, 587343) 1. Mr. Hoondamal, who has been trading in the Colony for some time, wished to change premises, and to remove from Grey Street to West Street.
('5', 258, 3, 20, 587485) 2 The shop was absolutely free from objection from a sanitary standpoint.
('5', 258, 3, 21, 587559) It belonged to an Indian landlord, and it was in a block of buildings which have been devoted to Indian traders
('5', 258, 4, 22, 587671) 1 This was published in The Natal Mercury of 13 6 1906. That paper had suggested that Indians should “set down their grievances concisely in writing for the benefit of the public, who would then be in a better position to form an opinion”.
('5', 258, 4, 23, 587911) The statement was later reproduced in Indian Opinion
('5', 258, 5, 24, 587964) 2 Vide “Indian Licences: Need for Vigilance —I” 18 2 1905
('5', 259, 0, 1, 588022) 260 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 259, 1, 2, 588064) for several years.
('5', 259, 1, 3, 588083) Mr. Hoondamal had a fancyware business, and dealt in Oriental silks and other fancy goods.
('5', 259, 1, 4, 588174) He did not come into competition with any European.
('5', 259, 1, 5, 588226) His shop was kept in a scrupulously clean condition, but the transfer from one premises to another was rejected by the Town Council.
('5', 259, 1, 6, 588359) 2. Mr. Dada Osman had been in trade in Vryheid for several years before the war.
('5', 259, 1, 7, 588440) 1 The place he was trading in was considered a Location or a Bazaar during the Boer regime after Vryheid was annexed to Natal the Licensing Board refused to renew his licence, unless he would go to another Location far away from town, where it was impossible for him to do any business at all.
('5', 259, 1, 8, 588734) Mr. Dada Osman’s business in Vryheid has, therefore, proved a very serious loss to him.
('5', 259, 1, 9, 588822) In this case, as also in the previous case, many certificates from Europeans of good standing were produced to show the respectability of the applicants.
('5', 259, 1, 10, 588976) It should be remembered that Mr. Dada Osman’s was the only Indian store in Vryheid.
('5', 259, 1, 11, 589060) To add to the misery of the position, the anti Asiatic laws of the Transvaal have been taken over bodily for this district of Natal.
('5', 259, 1, 12, 589193) A British Indian, therefore, staying in Vryheid, not only has to undergo the disabilities that the Natal laws imposed on him, but has added to them the disabilities that the Transvaal laws have created for him.
('5', 259, 1, 13, 589404) 3. Mr. Cassim Mahomed has been trading for three years on a farm near Ladysmith.
('5', 259, 1, 14, 589485) For some time his was the only store.
('5', 259, 1, 15, 589523) Recently, a European firm, by name Burdett & Co., have opened a store near by.
('5', 259, 1, 16, 589602) Mr. Cassim Mahomed’s servant, in his absence, was trapped and charged with a breach of the law as to Sunday trading, the servant having sold to the traps a piece of soap and a little sugar.
('5', 259, 1, 17, 589792) Armed with this conviction, Messrs Burdett & Co.
('5', 259, 1, 18, 589841) opposed Mr. Cassim Mahomed’s application for a renewal of his licence.
('5', 259, 1, 19, 589912) The Licensing Officer listened to their objections, and refused to renew the licence.
('5', 259, 1, 20, 589998) There was an appeal to the Board, which confirmed the decision of the Licensing Officer.
('5', 259, 1, 21, 590087) The court said that it was not guided by any prejudice; it proposed to treat Mr. Cassim Mahomed as it had treated a certain European.
('5', 259, 1, 22, 590221) This was incorrect.
('5', 259, 1, 23, 590241) This European was himself convicted of having sold opium, in contravention of the law, to the Indians working at the mines in his neighbourhood, and other allegations were made against him.
('5', 259, 1, 24, 590431) There is an ocean of difference between the technical breach of the Sunday Law by the servant of Mr. Cassim Mahomed and the breach of the opium law of the Colony by the European personally.
('5', 259, 1, 25, 590621) Mr. Cassim Mahomed, too, produced
('5', 259, 2, 26, 590655) 1 Vide”Dada Osman’s Casee”, 14 9 1898
('5', 260, 0, 1, 590693) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 261
('5', 260, 1, 2, 590740) excellent references from European firms of good standing.
('5', 260, 1, 3, 590799) In all the above named three cases, there is not an iota of reason for depriving the applicants of their licences, and thereby, perhaps, their means of livelihood.
('5', 260, 1, 4, 590963) They were all vested interests, but the popular Boards, in our opinion, did not hesitate to trample under foot all sense of justice and right.
('5', 260, 1, 5, 591106) Had the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court been reserved, such gross injustice would never have been possible.
('5', 260, 1, 6, 591216) It is possible to understand objections to traders whose premises are insanitary or even ugly, to traders who cannot produce any intelligible record of their transactions or have been known to have deceived their creditors.
('5', 260, 1, 7, 591440) One could also understand a great deal of hesitation in granting new licences to Indian traders in view of popular feeling and prejudice, but it is hard to justify treatment meted out to cases like the foregoing.
('5', 260, 1, 8, 591653) A study of the Cape Bill, recently published, in connection with this matter would be very appropriate, and would throw a great deal of light on the question.
('5', 260, 1, 9, 591812) No reasonable exception could be taken to that measure, and yet itwould do all that the Natal Act was intended to do, without doing violence to British traditions, or even the elementary ideas of right and wrong.
('5', 260, 1, 10, 592025) A further difficulty has now been introduced by reason of a circular issued by the Government to the licensing authorities, to the effect that for Indian applications they are to take thumb impressions on the counterfoils of the licences issued, in order to establish identity.
('5', 260, 1, 11, 592303) Why such a distinction against Indians should be made it is difficult to understand, except on the supposition that the Government intend that, as soon as the present Indian holders have retired from business or died, the business should be sold, not as a going concern, but outright.
('5', 260, 1, 12, 592588) What this means to a trader can be better imagined than described.
('5', 260, 2, 13, 592655) IMMIGRATION RESTRICTION ACT Under this Act, latterly, the Government have framed rules imposing fees which are simply extortionate.
('5', 260, 2, 14, 592787) Any Indian who is domiciled in Natal, and wants to return to Natal, as a rule takes with him some documentary proof and the Government grant him a certificate of domicile on sufficient proof being given.
('5', 260, 2, 15, 592991) Hitherto, the nominal charge of 2s.
('5', 260, 2, 16, 593027) has been made, but it has now been raised to £1. Similarly, facilities are afforded to those who wish to enter the Colony for a temporary visit, or who, belonging to the inland States, wish to pass through Natal on their way to India.
('5', 260, 2, 17, 593262) These are called visitors’ or embarkation passes, and were naturally issued till recently without any fee, but on a deposit of £10, to be refunded on leaving the
('5', 261, 0, 1, 593424) 262 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 261, 1, 2, 593466) Colony.
('5', 261, 1, 3, 593474) A fee of £1 has now been imposed on these passes also.
('5', 261, 1, 4, 593529) The imposition is extraordinary.
('5', 261, 1, 5, 593562) British Indians not only contribute to the railway revenue by passing through Natal, but have now to pay for the privilege of doing so a fee of £1. The same argument applies to visitors.
('5', 261, 1, 6, 593749) One would consider that, seeing that the law restricts immigration, and not temporary sojourn, of people, the expenses of ensuring the return of those who wish to temporarily remain in the Colony should be borne by the general treasury.
('5', 261, 1, 7, 593986) The Government, however, have taken a different view.
('5', 261, 1, 8, 594040) They consider that a man who visits Natal temporarily may also be dealt with under the Immigration Restriction Act, and that, therefore, when he is allowed to visit the Colony, it is a privilege that is extended to him.
('5', 261, 1, 9, 594260) For such a contention there is no support in law.
('5', 261, 1, 10, 594310) Cases have occurred where British Indians in Johannesburg have taken out embarkation passes, for which they have paid £1. They have been obliged to change their minds, and to indefinitely postpone their visit to India, and yet they have been obliged to ferfeit the fee of £1 paid for their embarkation passes, although they have never used them, and when the time comes for them to go to India, they would have to take [out] other embarkation passes, and pay the fee again.
('5', 261, 1, 11, 594784) The above fees, therefore, could only be interpreted as an attempt to indirectly tax British Indians.
('5', 261, 1, 12, 594886) Indian Opinion, 16 6 1906

('5', 262, 1, 2, 595759) 248. LORD SELBORNE
('5', 262, 2, 3, 595778) Lord Selborne made a significant speech while laying the foundation stone of the new Town Hall at Germiston.
('5', 262, 2, 4, 595887) The speech consists of advice on morality and politics.
('5', 262, 2, 5, 595943) Addressed as it is to the whites, it is perhaps of less direct interest to us from a political standpoint.
('5', 262, 2, 6, 596050) But from the moral point of view, Lord Selborne’s words deserve to be pondered over.
('5', 262, 2, 7, 596135) Accordingly, we summarise the speech below: The Municipalities exercise a necessary influence on the lives of us whites, who are politically very active.
('5', 262, 2, 8, 596289) They are the schools which prepare men for the administration of the State.
('5', 262, 2, 9, 596365) It is there that the seeds of the freedom of a people are sown and nurtured.
('5', 262, 2, 10, 596442) The British prefer a harsh but self governing political system to a mild alien rule.
('5', 262, 2, 11, 596527) At all times and everywhere, the Municipalities have been the chief forum of public opinion.
('5', 262, 2, 12, 596620) The Municipality serves as a training ground not only for its members but also for the electorate and for others who discuss [public affairs].
('5', 262, 2, 13, 596763) The electors should never forget how to offer legitimate criticism.
('5', 262, 2, 14, 596831) This is a region in which engaging storms blow.
('5', 262, 2, 15, 596879) Storms are of two kinds: actual storms and the metaphorical ones in politics.
('5', 262, 2, 16, 596957) One who preserves one’s equanimity during an actual storm can be said to have a cool and collected temperament.
('5', 262, 2, 17, 597069) In the same way, one who remains unperturbed during a political storm is considered a man of firm convictions.
('5', 262, 2, 18, 597180) I should consider a person reliable who sticks to his own way of life in fair weather and foul.
('5', 262, 2, 19, 597276) A man should prove that he isabsolutely firm in his principles regardless of whether or not people interpret his words or actions aright.
('5', 262, 2, 20, 597414) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 16 6 1906

('5', 262, 4, 24, 597801) 1 Richard Seddon died on June 10, 1906 aboard the Oswestry Grange while on his way back to New Zealand after a tour of Australia.

('5', 265, 1, 2, 601111) 251. LETTER TO G. K. GOKHALE
('5', 265, 2, 3, 601140) STANGER LAAGER, June 22, 1906
('5', 265, 3, 4, 601170) DEAR PROF.
('5', 265, 3, 5, 601181) GOKHALE, I am writing this from the military laager at Stanger.
('5', 265, 3, 6, 601245) 1 The Indian Stretcher Bearer Corps received orders yesterday to march.
('5', 265, 3, 7, 601317) The work before the Corps this time is of a more difficult type.
('5', 265, 3, 8, 601382) In any case, it was absolutely necessary for me to accompany the Corps if it was to be formed at all.
('5', 265, 3, 9, 601484) The question of my coming to England must, therefore, remain in abeyance.
('5', 265, 3, 10, 601558) I am very thankful for your long letter and the suggestions made by you.
('5', 265, 3, 11, 601631) I suppose we shall know in time the result of your interviews 2 with Mr. Morley.
('5', 265, 3, 12, 601712) You will put a finishing touch to your brilliant work, if you could on your way pass through South Africa.
('5', 265, 3, 13, 601819) That I know is a selfish view, but I may be pardoned for taking such a view, seeing that all my work at present seems to be connected with South Africa alone.
('5', 265, 5, 14, 601978) Yours truly, M. K. GANDHI [PROF.
('5', 265, 5, 15, 602011) GOKHALE LONDON]
('5', 265, 6, 16, 602027) From the handwritten original: Courtesy: Servants of India Society
('5', 265, 7, 17, 602094) 252. AN IMPORTANT PERMIT CASE
('5', 265, 8, 18, 602124) Justice has again been vindicated, and the excesses of the Asiatic Permit Department in the Transvaal have received a salutary check at the hands of the presiding Magistrate at Volksrust.
('5', 265, 8, 19, 602312) From the summary furnished by our Johannesburg correspondent of the case in question, it would appear that Mr. E. M. Bhyat, brother of Mr. A. M. Bhyat, of Heidelberg, a well known Indian merchant, was refused a permit to
('5', 265, 9, 20, 602533) 1 A town 45 miles to the north east of Durban 2 Gokhale, who had presided over the Congress Session at Banaras in December 1905, was at this time in England and met Mr. Morley several times in connection with, the Partition of Bengal, proposals for reform and Indian problems generally.
('5', 266, 0, 1, 602820) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 267
('5', 266, 1, 2, 602867) re enter the Transvaal, although he proved that he was an old resident of that Colony and had paid three pounds to the Dutch Government as the price of settlement in the Transvaal.
('5', 266, 1, 3, 603048) Mr Bhyat’s application had received very influential European support.
('5', 266, 1, 4, 603119) He was to go to the Transvaal in order to replace his brother, who found it necessary togo to India for reasons of health.
('5', 266, 1, 5, 603242) In spite of such proof, Mr. Bhyat could not get a permit, the reason alleged being that he, having left the Transvaal some time before the outbreak of war, could not be termed a refugee.
('5', 266, 1, 6, 603429) The case went to Lord Selborne through the British Indian Association, but His Excellency declined to grant relief.
('5', 266, 1, 7, 603545) It is a matter of painful surprise to us that the High Commissioner should have denied justice in a case of such importance.
('5', 266, 1, 8, 603670) Indians have a right to complain that His Excellency did not show for the Indian community that reasonable regard to which he said some time ago it was rightly entitled.
('5', 266, 1, 9, 603840) Exasperated by the refusal, Mr. Bhyat appealed to the law court of the Colony, whose decision was entirely in Mr. Bhyat’s favour.
('5', 266, 1, 10, 603970) The Magisterial interpretation of the Peace Preservation Ordinance means that those Indians who have paid three pounds to the old Government are free to enter the Transvaal without permits, on proof of such payment.
('5', 266, 1, 11, 604186) The case shows once more how hard it is for an Indian to get justice from the Government in the Transvaal.
('5', 266, 1, 12, 604293) Ever since the establishment of British authority in that Colony, Indians have been obliged to struggle against it for their right to exist in that portion of the British Empire.
('5', 266, 1, 13, 604472) They have more than once been obliged to extort from an unwilling administration a measure of justice by the help of the law courts of the Colony.
('5', 266, 1, 14, 604619) Lord Selborne was inclined to resent the complaint of the British Indian Association that the Government opposed the Indian community in the licence test case.
('5', 266, 1, 15, 604779) Perhaps there was some ground for resentment, as there was a decided case of the Republican High Court to which the present Government felt bound to give effect.
('5', 266, 1, 16, 604941) In the present case, there was no such precedent.
('5', 266, 1, 17, 604991) The Peace Preservation Ordinance is a creation of the British Government.
('5', 266, 1, 18, 605065) It has been wrested from its proper sphere in order to restrict Indian immigration.
('5', 266, 1, 19, 605149) It was within the power of the Government to grant relief, of its own motion, without being troubled with any precedents.
('5', 266, 1, 20, 605271) And yet an Indian merchant has had to undergo much expense and worry, and has been compelled to resort to the law courts of the Colony before he could receive even the elements of equitable
('5', 267, 0, 1, 605461) 268 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 267, 1, 2, 605503) treatment.
('5', 267, 1, 3, 605514) We wonder how Lord Selborne will justify this latest action of the executive authority in the Transvaal.
('5', 267, 1, 4, 605619) Indian Opinion, 23 6 1906
('5', 267, 2, 5, 605645) 253. INDIAN VOLUNTEERS Much discussion has been carried on in this journal regarding whether or not the Indians should participate in the war.
('5', 267, 2, 6, 605788) The Government has agreed to accept a corps of twenty stretcher bearers, and the Congress has got that number together.
('5', 267, 2, 7, 605908) This has produced a very favourable impression on the minds of prominent whites.
('5', 267, 2, 8, 605989) Some leading members of the community have, because of this, formed the opinion that we must have innate ability for such work; and they advise us that we should accordingly ask for a permanent place in the Volunteer Corps.
('5', 267, 2, 9, 606213) Between this proposal and the Stretcher Bearer Corps that has already been raised, there is much difference.
('5', 267, 2, 10, 606322) The Stretcher Bearer Corps is to last only a few days.
('5', 267, 2, 11, 606377) Its work will be only to carry the wounded, and it will be disbanded when such work is no longer necessary.
('5', 267, 2, 12, 606485) These men are not allowed to bear arms.
('5', 267, 2, 13, 606525) The move for a Volunteer Corps is quite different and much more important.
('5', 267, 2, 14, 606600) That Corps will be a permanent body; its members will be issued weapons, and they will receive military training every year at stated times.
('5', 267, 2, 15, 606741) For the present they will not have any fighting to do.
('5', 267, 2, 16, 606796) Wars are not fought all the time.
('5', 267, 2, 17, 606830) A war breaks out, roughly speaking, once in twenty years.
('5', 267, 2, 18, 606888) It is now more than twenty years since the last Kaffir rebellion broke out.
('5', 267, 2, 19, 606964) There is, therefore, absolutely no risk in joining the Volunteer Corps.
('5', 267, 2, 20, 607036) It can be looked upon as a kind of annual picnic.
('5', 267, 2, 21, 607086) The person joining it gets enough exercise and thus keeps his body in good trim and improves his health.
('5', 267, 2, 22, 607191) One who enlists as a volunteer is much respected.
('5', 267, 2, 23, 607241) People love him and praise him, calling him a civilian soldier.
('5', 267, 2, 24, 607305) If the Indians are given such a status, we believe it would be a very good thing.
('5', 267, 2, 25, 607387) It is likely to bring in some political advantage.
('5', 267, 2, 26, 607438) Whether or not any advantage is to be derived, there is no doubt that it is our duty to enlist.
('5', 267, 2, 27, 607534) Hundreds of leading whites enlist themselves and take pride in doing so.
('5', 267, 2, 28, 607607) Under the prevailing law, it is open to the Government to enlist compulsorily.
('5', 267, 2, 29, 607686) We ought to obey the laws designed for the defence of the country we live in.
('5', 267, 2, 30, 607764) Therefore, considering the matter from any point, it is clear that, if we are able to join the Volunteer Corps, the reproach against us would be lived
('5', 268, 0, 1, 607915) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 269
('5', 268, 1, 2, 607962) down, once and for all.
('5', 268, 1, 3, 607986) For fifteen years now the whites have accused the Indians that, if it came to giving one’s life in defence of Natal, they would desert their posts of duty and flee home.
('5', 268, 1, 4, 608156) We cannot meet this charge with a written rejoinder.
('5', 268, 1, 5, 608209) There is but one way of disproving it—the way of action.
('5', 268, 1, 6, 608266) The time to act appears to have come now.
('5', 268, 1, 7, 608308) But how is it to be done?
('5', 268, 1, 8, 608334) Not by making volunteers out of the poor labourers freed from their indentures.
('5', 268, 1, 9, 608414) It is the duty of the trading community to take part in the movement themselves.
('5', 268, 1, 10, 608495) Many men can be trained up even if each shop offers only one man.
('5', 268, 1, 11, 608561) Trade will not suffer.
('5', 268, 1, 12, 608584) The condition of those who join will improve.
('5', 268, 1, 13, 608630) They will gain in strength and energy and will be deemed to have done their duty as citizens.
('5', 268, 1, 14, 608724) It is sheer superstition to believe, as some appear to do, that there is greater risk to life in going to the battle field or preparing for it.
('5', 268, 1, 15, 608868) Next week we intend to adduce examples in support of this.
('5', 268, 2, 16, 608927) Meanwhile, we are placing these thoughts before the leaders of the community and we hope that they will receive due consideration.

('5', 269, 3, 13, 611242) 257. AN IMPORTANT TENANCY CASE
('5', 269, 4, 14, 611273) The Supreme Court of Natal recently decided an important case on the notice to be given to a tenant on a monthly tenure.
('5', 269, 4, 15, 611394) The common understanding is that it is sufficient to give a tenant a month’s notice beginning from any date of the month, and that he in turn, can give a similar notice and vacate the premises.
('5', 269, 4, 16, 611588) This seems to be the interpretation accepted among some lawyers too.
('5', 269, 4, 17, 611657) But the Supreme Court has decided that the notice should be given on the same date on which the tenancy began.
('5', 269, 4, 18, 611768) For example, if the tenant took possession on the 6th of a certain month, he can give the necessary month’s notice on the 6th of any month or earlier, but the
('5', 269, 5, 19, 611927) 1 Vide Indian Opinion, 9 6 1906.
('5', 270, 0, 1, 611960) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 271
('5', 270, 1, 2, 612007) notice will only take effect from the 6th of the succeeding month.
('5', 270, 1, 3, 612074) The landlord also is, for his part, bound to give similar notice.

('5', 270, 2, 5, 612182) 258. JOHANNESBURG LETTER
('5', 270, 3, 6, 612207) MR. BHAYAT’S PERMIT CASE
('5', 270, 4, 7, 612232) Just as there was a permit case in respect of Mr. Suliman Manga, so a case has now been decided concerning Ebrahim Bhayat.
('5', 270, 4, 8, 612355) Mr. Manga, though fully and clearly entitled to a temporary permit, was not given one by the Permit Officer; he secured it at last from Delagoa Bay.
('5', 270, 4, 9, 612504) Mr. Ebrahim Bhayat was an old resident of the Transvaal and knew a number of prominent whites; and his application was supported by many of them.
('5', 270, 4, 10, 612650) Even so, he was refused a permit on the ground that it was not during the war that he had left the Transvaal but a year earlier.
('5', 270, 4, 11, 612779) This was the limit of oppression.
('5', 270, 4, 12, 612813) As it was absolutely essential for Mr. Bhayat to go to the Transvaal in connection with his brother’s business, he decided to go to court.
('5', 270, 4, 13, 612952) Mr. Benson’s opinion had been obtained, and Mr. Lichtenstein appeared in the case at Volksrust.
('5', 270, 4, 14, 613048) Mr. Bhayat’s defence was as follows: 1. Mr. Ebrahim Bhayat was an old resident of the Transvaal 2. He had paid £3 to the Dutch Government, and had by that payment purchased the right of permanent residence.
('5', 270, 4, 15, 613255) 3. By virtue of the London Convention such men were entitled to stay permanently.
('5', 270, 5, 16, 613337) 4. Furthermore, since Mr. Bhayat’s marriage had been solemnized in the Transvaal, he should be regarded a permanent resident of the Colony.
('5', 270, 5, 17, 613477) The Permit Act could not be enforced in the face of these arguments; and the Magistrate decided that such persons needed no permits to enter the Transvaal.
('5', 270, 5, 18, 613633) This is a very good decision, and the Permit Office has met with a crushing defeat.
('5', 270, 5, 19, 613717) We shall await the defence Lord Selborne can muster in reply.
('5', 270, 5, 20, 613779) As a result of this decision, those Indians who were formerly
('5', 270, 6, 21, 613841) 1 Under the terms of the London Convention, which provided for the free and unrestricted entry of all British subjects into the erstwhile Republic, a person was not subject to the Governor’s discretionary powers unless he was considered dangerous or seditious.
('5', 271, 0, 1, 614102) 272 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 271, 1, 2, 614144) residents of the Transvaal and hold a Dutch registration certificate will be able to enter without a permit.
('5', 271, 1, 3, 614253) This will obviate many inconveniences met with by those applying for permits.
('5', 271, 1, 4, 614331) I must, however, point out that there is a confusion in this case.
('5', 271, 1, 5, 614398) The good gentleman that the Volksrust Magistrate is, he has interpreted the law very sympathetically and in our favour.
('5', 271, 1, 6, 614518) There are many eminent barristers who are of the opinion that it is necessary even for those who possess registration certificates to take out permits; and, undoubtedly, there are many difficulties in doing so.
('5', 271, 1, 7, 614729) However, the Government cannot go in appeal against the Magistrate’s decision; and as long as the Indians make out their case carefully and strongly, they should have no trouble at all.
('5', 271, 1, 8, 614915) It will perhaps be easier for them to come through Volksrust than through Komatipoort, for there is no reason to suppose that all magistrates will give a similar decision.
('5', 271, 1, 9, 615087) The matter cannot be taken as finally settled as long as the Supreme Court has not given its decision.
('5', 271, 1, 10, 615190) It should also be remembered that this is not a case that can be taken to the Supreme Court.
('5', 271, 1, 11, 615283) New Act for JOHANNESBURG MUNICIPALITY The Johannesburg Municipality intends to get a new law passed concerning its own powers during the present session of the legislature.
('5', 271, 1, 12, 615456) It seeks further enabling powers to declare an area a Location or Bazaar, and to refuse a licence to those who are otherwise entitled to it on such grounds as the unsatisfactory condition of the building or the applicant being guilty of some offence.
('5', 271, 1, 13, 615707) Persons dissatisfied with the decision of the Municipality would be able to prefer an appeal before a Magistrate.
('5', 271, 1, 14, 615821) It does not seem possible to oppose either of these two points.
('5', 271, 1, 15, 615885) However, the power to fix a site for a Location or a Bazaar does not authorize the Municipality to force people to shift there.
('5', 271, 1, 16, 616013) LORD SELBORNE It appears from the local newspapers that a movement is afoot to recall Lord Selborne from South Africa.
('5', 271, 1, 17, 616132) Members of the Radical Party believe that Lord Selborne does not carry out the policy of the Liberal Party in full measure.

('5', 272, 0, 1, 616298) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 273
('5', 272, 1, 2, 616345) 259. SHOULD INDIANS VOLUNTEER OR NOT?
('5', 272, 1, 3, 616383) We commented on this subject in our last issue.
('5', 272, 1, 4, 616431) 1 Towards the end of that article, we had said that most of us held back only because of fear.
('5', 272, 1, 5, 616526) There is, however, no cause whatever for fear, as should be evident from the examples we propose to give for the benefit of those who believe that we should be ever ready to participate in war if we want to live happily and respectably in Natal, in South Africa or, for that matter, in any part of the British Empire.
('5', 272, 1, 6, 616844) The Crimean War caused heavy casualties; yet it has been estimated that fewer men died from bayonet or bullet wounds in that war than through sheer carelessness or perverse living.
('5', 272, 1, 7, 617025) It was calculated that, on an average, more men died of fever and other diseases during the attack on Ladysmith than by Boer bullets.
('5', 272, 1, 8, 617159) The experience in every war has been similar.
('5', 272, 1, 9, 617205) Moreover, those who can take care of themselves and lead regular lives while at the front can live in health and happiness.
('5', 272, 1, 10, 617329) The training such men receive cannot be had elsewhere, that is, if they do not go to the front only to prove their valour or quench their thirst for blood.
('5', 272, 1, 11, 617485) A man going to the battle front has to train himself to endure severe hardships.
('5', 272, 1, 12, 617566) He is obliged to cultivate the habit of living in comradeship with large numbers of men.
('5', 272, 1, 13, 617655) He easily learns to make do with simple food.
('5', 272, 1, 14, 617701) He is required to keep regular hours.
('5', 272, 1, 15, 617739) He forms the habit of obeying his superior’s orders promptly and without argument.
('5', 272, 1, 16, 617822) He also learns to discipline the movement of his limbs.
('5', 272, 1, 17, 617878) And he has also to learn how to live in limited space according to the maxims of health.
('5', 272, 1, 18, 617967) Instances are known of unruly and wayward men who went to the front and returned reformed and able fully to control both their mind and body.
('5', 272, 1, 19, 618109) For the Indian community, going to the battle field should be an easy matter; for, whether Muslims or Hindus, we are men with profound faith in God.
('5', 272, 1, 20, 618258) We have a greater sense of duty, and it should therefore be easier for us to volunteer.
('5', 272, 1, 21, 618346) We are not overcome by fear when hundred of thousands of men die of famine or plague in our country.
('5', 272, 1, 22, 618447) What is more, when we are told of our duty, we continue to be indifferent, keep our houses dirty, lie hugging our hoarded wealth.
('5', 272, 1, 23, 618577) Thus, we live a wretched life acquiescing in a long, tormented process ending in death.
('5', 272, 1, 24, 618665) Why, then, should we fear the death that may perhaps overtake us on the battle field?
('5', 272, 1, 25, 618751) We have to learn much from what the whites are doing in Natal.
('5', 272, 1, 26, 618814) There is hardly any family from which someone has not gone to fight the Kaffir rebels.
('5', 272, 1, 27, 618901) Following their
('5', 272, 2, 28, 618917) 1 Vide “Indian Volunteers”, 23 06 1906
('5', 273, 0, 1, 618956) 274 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 273, 1, 2, 618998) example, we should steel our hearts and take courage.
('5', 273, 1, 3, 619052) Now is the time when the leading whites want us to take this step; if we letgo this opportunity, we shall repent later.
('5', 273, 1, 4, 619172) We therefore urge all Indian leaders to do their duty to the best of their ability.
('5', 273, 1, 5, 619256) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 30 6 1906
('5', 273, 2, 6, 619298) 260. EXTRACT FROM LETTER TO DADABHAI NAOROJI 1
('5', 273, 3, 7, 619345) June 30, 1906 2
('5', 273, 4, 8, 619361) Under separate cover, I am sending you marked copy of Indian Opinion, wherein will be found copy of correspondence from Lord Elgin to the Governor of the Colony of Natal on the subject of the Municipal Corporations Consolidation Bill.
('5', 273, 4, 9, 619596) I would bring to your notice the resolution arrived at by the Municipalities Association at its recent meeting, held to consider Lord Elgin’s despatch, to the effect that no alteration should be made in the definition of “Coloured Persons”.
('5', 273, 4, 10, 619837) This decision leaves the Indian community in the same danger of insult and degradation as before, and it is to be hoped that the Secretary of State for India and the Indian Government will insist upon the carrying out of the suggestion proffered by the Secretary of State for the Colonies.
('5', 273, 4, 11, 620127) Moreover, I would point out that Lord Elgin omits all reference to the Clause of the Bill disfranchising all those who are not in possession of the parliamentary franchise.
('5', 273, 4, 12, 620300) It will doubtless be within your recollection that the Indian community of Natal acquiesced in the disfranchisement of all Indians who were not at that time on the Parliamentary Voters Roll at the urgent desire of the late Mr. Harry Escombe, on the distinct understanding that such disfranchisement was not to be carried to any greater lengths.
('5', 273, 4, 13, 620645) I need not do more than remind you that British Indians in Natal, if such Municipal disfranchisement takes place, will be in a worse position than they would be in India, where, of course, such representative institutions are enjoyed by them.
('5', 273, 4, 14, 620888) In view of the action of some of the Municipalities, as reported on various occasions in the columns of Indian Opinion, in making invidious, arbitrary distinctions between British Indians and Europeans, it is obvious that a grave injustice will be inflicted upon the British Indian community in Natal, unless steps

('5', 274, 3, 4, 621696) 261. INDIAN STRETCHER BEARER CORPS 1
('5', 274, 4, 5, 621733) [Before July 19, 1906]
('5', 274, 5, 6, 621756) COMPOSITION OF THE CORPS
('5', 274, 6, 7, 621781) This Corps, which has been formed at the instance of the Natal Government by way of experiment, in connection with the operations against the Natives, consists of twenty 2 Indians whose names are as fellows : M. K. Gandhi (Sgt. Major), U. M. Shelat (Sgt.), H. I. Joshi (Sgt.), S. B. Medh (Sgt.), Parbhu Hari (Corporal), Khan Mahomed, Jamaludin, Mahomed, Sheikh Madar, Sheik Dada Mia, Mahomed Essop, Puti Naiken, Appasamy, Kitama, Kupusamy, Bomaya, Kunji, Ajodhyasing.
('5', 274, 6, 8, 622249) According to religion, the Corps is composed of six Mahomedans and fourteen Hindus.
('5', 274, 6, 9, 622333) Geographically, there are five belonging to the Bombay Presidency, twelve to the Presidency of Madras, two to the Punjab, and one to the Presidency of Bengal.
('5', 274, 6, 10, 622492) It may be added that one of the twelve Madrasis is Colonial born.
('5', 274, 6, 11, 622558) According to status, thirteen men have been, at one time or [an]other, under indenture in Natal, and are now working as free men, in the capacity of gardeners, domestic servants, etc.
('5', 274, 6, 12, 622742) Two of them are engine drivers by profession, one [is] a goldsmith, three are agents and book keepers, having received higher education in India, and one is a barrister.
('5', 274, 6, 13, 622912) It is now well known that the Government has provided uniforms and rations, and the Natal Indian Congress pays the salaries.
('5', 274, 7, 14, 623037) AT THE FRONT
('5', 274, 8, 15, 623050) On the 22nd June, this Corps entrained for Stanger by the early train and joined the B. M. R. column under Colonel Arnott, who was in laager at Stanger.
('5', 274, 8, 16, 623203) After discussion with the regimental Sgt Major, Colonel Arnott gave orders that the Corps was to receive European rations, and rice and dholl, with curry powder, in lieu of meat.
('5', 274, 8, 17, 623382) For the information of readers of this journal, the scale per man per day is
('5', 274, 9, 18, 623459) 1 This was the first of the two despatches sent by Gandhiji and published in Indian Opinion as “From Our Special Correspondent at the Front”
('5', 274, 10, 19, 623600) 2 Actually only 18 are listed.
('5', 275, 0, 1, 623631) 276 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 275, 1, 2, 623673) appended: Bread or Biscuits 1 Ib., Sugar 5 oz., Tea _ oz., Coffee _ oz., Butter 1 oz., Salt _ oz., Jam 2 oz., Cheese 2 oz., Potatoes 4 oz., Onions 2 oz., Mealiemeal 4 oz., Pepper, Rice 1 Ib., Lentils _ Ib.
('5', 275, 1, 3, 623879) As there was no medical officer attached to Colonel Arnott’s column, the Colonel authorized the issue of a small quantity of medicine of immediate necessity, and a supply of bandages.
('5', 275, 1, 4, 624063) Seeing us with Red Cross bandages, application was made the same day by several troopers who had either suffered slight accidental injuries orwere suffering from malarial fever.
('5', 275, 1, 5, 624241) The medicine, therefore, came in very handy, and one portion of the Corps’ work commenced at the laager.
('5', 275, 1, 6, 624346) The night of the 22nd was passed in laager, and all of us had to sleep in the open.
('5', 275, 1, 7, 624430) One blanket supplied to each of us was not enough protection against cold, and the overcoats, furnished from the Comforts Fund opened by the Indian community, were very much appreciated.
('5', 275, 1, 8, 624617) After breakfast on the 23rd June, the whole column moved forward, the Durban Reserves, the Indian Corps, and an escort bringing up the rear.
('5', 275, 1, 9, 624758) We had to march with the whole of our kit on, and as the experience was new to most of us, and as the marching was mostly up hill, it was severely felt by some.
('5', 275, 1, 10, 624919) On the way, we passed by Sir James Hulett’s garden, and the troops were permitted to help themselves liberally to the luscious naartjes, with which the trees in the garden were weighted.
('5', 275, 1, 11, 625106) After three cheers for the donor for the timely gift, the column moved forward and laagered about a mile beyond the estate.
('5', 275, 1, 12, 625230) On the 24th, at 6 30 a.m., the march commenced.
('5', 275, 1, 13, 625278) We were allowed on this occasion to put our kit onto the waggons—a great relief.
('5', 275, 1, 14, 625359) The columns encamped at Otimati, a hill in a beautiful valley.
('5', 275, 1, 15, 625422) Just near us ran a sparkling stream.
('5', 275, 1, 16, 625459) The column was not intended to go as far as Mapumulo, but was to operate from the Otimati camp.
('5', 275, 1, 17, 625555) The Corps had, however, instructions to proceed with the first convoy to Mapumulo.
('5', 275, 1, 18, 625638) On the 25th June, therefore, we were in a state of uncertainty as to our fate, but hardly had our luncheon been half cooked, when orders were received that we should march to Mapumulo with some waggons that were leaving for that place.
('5', 275, 1, 19, 625874) we had therefore to leave our food, pack up kit, and march, which we did within a quarter of an hour of the receipt of the orders.
('5', 275, 1, 20, 626005) We reached Mapumulo at about 5 p.m.
('5', 275, 1, 21, 626041) and reported ourselves to Captain Howden, the P. M. O. at that place.
('5', 275, 1, 22, 626111) Captain Howden treated the Corps very nicely, and Corporal Little, who was to look after it, busied himself with providing us with tents,
('5', 276, 0, 1, 626249) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 277
('5', 276, 1, 2, 626296) etc., up to 10 p.m.
('5', 276, 1, 3, 626316) We were given one bell tent, and five patrol tents, which after three nights in the open were more or less a luxury, though, to most of us, a very necessary one.
('5', 276, 1, 4, 626478) Colonel Sparks, too, came and inquired about us.
('5', 276, 1, 5, 626527) Indian Opinion, 21 7 1906
