('5', 276, 4, 8, 626613) FATIGUE DUTIES
('5', 276, 5, 9, 626628) On the 26th our task was allotted to us.
('5', 276, 5, 10, 626669) Nine of us were to form a fatigue party to accompany the tank waggon, which brought water from an adjoining stream.
('5', 276, 5, 11, 626785) Some of us were detained to disinfect the whole camp, under the superintendence of Dr. Savage, the DistrictSurgeon for Mapumulo, and from three to four of us were to dress the wounds on the backs of several Native rebels, who had received lashes.
('5', 276, 5, 12, 627032) One of us assisted at entering up the daily roll of patients treated by Captain Howden.
('5', 276, 5, 13, 627120) The stretcher bearing work, however, had yet to come.
('5', 276, 5, 14, 627174) Some of the above work was partially interrupted or suspended as a helio message was received to forward a stretcher party to Otimati in connection with operations that were to be undertaken by the B. M. R. column at Thring’s Post.
('5', 276, 5, 15, 627406) Early on the morning of the 27th, therefore, one half of the Corps, with two stretchers under Sgt. Major Gandhi and Sgt.
('5', 276, 5, 16, 627527) Joshi proceeded to Otimati, where instructions were received to take a stretcher to carry one of the troopers who was dazed.
('5', 276, 5, 17, 627652) Fortunately, the trooper had recovered before the party reached Thring’s Post.
('5', 276, 5, 18, 627731) But by an unfortunate accident, another trooper, by name Forder, had received a bullet wound in the thigh from a co trooper.
('5', 276, 5, 19, 627856) He, however, pluckily rode to the camp.
('5', 276, 5, 20, 627896) The stretcher party had to assist Mr. Stokes, of the N. M. C., in treating the wounded trooper, and others, who had received slight injuries through accidents or otherwise, requiring medical help.
('5', 276, 5, 21, 628093) On the 28th, the stretcher party at Otimati were to take to Mapumulo Private Sutton of the Durban Reserves, whose toe was crushed under a waggon wheel, and Trooper Forder.
('5', 276, 5, 22, 628265) The latter had to be carried on a stretcher, as his wound was very delicate.
('5', 276, 5, 23, 628342) The work of carrying Trooper Forder proved to be much heavier than we had thought.
('5', 276, 5, 24, 628425) The energy of all the available men had to be taxed to the utmost in carrying the wounded men, especially as it meant going
('5', 276, 6, 25, 628549) 1 This was the second and final despatch sent by Gandhiji from the front.
('5', 277, 0, 1, 628623) 278 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 277, 1, 2, 628665) uphill all the way.
('5', 277, 1, 3, 628685) As we were nearing Mapumulo, the Captain of our escort sent word that, if it could be managed, Forder should be placed in the ambulance waggon, as the Natives about the hill might wrongly consider that the rebels had succeeded in wounding at least one of our men.
('5', 277, 1, 4, 628949) Trooper Forder, on hearing the message, gladly volunteered to go into the waggon.
('5', 277, 1, 5, 629031) And the fatigued bearers were equally glad to be relieved of the necessity of having to carry their charge up the very steep hill near Mapumulo.
('5', 277, 1, 6, 629176) With this brief interruption, then, the whole Corps resumed its former work, with which it had commenced, and continued to do so till the morning of the 3rd July, a day that will ever remain memorable to the members of the Corps.
('5', 277, 2, 7, 629406) HEAVY WORK
('5', 277, 3, 8, 629417) At 9 p.m.
('5', 277, 3, 9, 629427) on the 2nd July, the Corps was ordered to follow a combined column at 2 30 a.m.
('5', 277, 3, 10, 629507) the next morning which was to operate in the Umvoti Valley.
('5', 277, 3, 11, 629567) We had to take two days’ rations with us, our blankets, and five stretchers.
('5', 277, 3, 12, 629644) We did so, and the march commenced at 3 a.m.
('5', 277, 3, 13, 629689) on the 3rd.
('5', 277, 3, 14, 629701) There were no waggons with the column, and, with the exception of the infantry, which had gone forward before, all were mounted men whom we had to follow.
('5', 277, 3, 15, 629856) Men in the rear were to guard us.
('5', 277, 3, 16, 629890) We were all unarmed.
('5', 277, 3, 17, 629911) But as the troops galloped away in front of us and we followed them, we were quickly out distanced.
('5', 277, 3, 18, 630011) However, we marched on, trying, as far as possible, to overtake the column, but itwas a hopeless task.There was, therefore, as a rule, considerable distance between the rear guard and ourselves.
('5', 277, 3, 19, 630206) At daybreak, the movement of the troops became naturally more rapid, and the distance between them and us began to increase.
('5', 277, 3, 20, 630331) However, there was no prospect before us except that of running after the troops or of being assegaied by the rebels.
('5', 277, 3, 21, 630449) Probably we had a narrow escape.
('5', 277, 3, 22, 630482) At 7 o’clock troops were operating at some distance from us.
('5', 277, 3, 23, 630543) As we were struggling along, we met a Kaffir who did not wear the loyal badge.
('5', 277, 3, 24, 630622) He was armed with an assegai and was hiding himself.
('5', 277, 3, 25, 630675) However, we safely rejoined the troops on the further hill, whilst they were sweeping with their carbines the bushes below.
('5', 277, 3, 26, 630799) Thus, we had to perform what seemed to be a never ending march.
('5', 277, 3, 27, 630863) We had to cross and re cross the Umvoti River, an operation that was difficult enough, seeing that we were obliged to take off our heavy boots and putties.
('5', 277, 3, 28, 631019) One of the men narrowly escaped what might have been a very serious accident, and he only crossed the stream less his putties and with a bleeding toe.
('5', 277, 3, 29, 631170) However, he marched bravely on with the rest of us.
('5', 277, 3, 30, 631222) Towards evening, the column retired to a rise near the valley and pitched the camp.
('5', 278, 0, 1, 631306) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 279
('5', 278, 1, 2, 631353) “DEAD TIRED”
('5', 278, 2, 3, 631366) All of us were dead tired, and it was a stroke of good luck that there were no casualties or accidents on our side.
('5', 278, 2, 4, 631482) Had there been any, it is difficult to say how we would have discharged ourselves in carrying the wounded in such a fatigued condition, though the writer of these notes fully believes that, actuated as the Corps mainly was by a sense of duty, God would have given it sufficient strength to perform any such work.
('5', 278, 2, 5, 631795) Anyhow, such was the answer given to the laughing troopers, who, half in pity and half in ridicule, inquired, as we were struggling along, what we should do if we had actually to carry some wounded.
('5', 278, 2, 6, 631994) On the morning of the 4th, we were split up into two parties to accompany the two divisions of the column which were to operate in two different parts.
('5', 278, 2, 7, 632146) The march had still to be without real protection.
('5', 278, 2, 8, 632197) All this was inevitable in the nature of things.
('5', 278, 2, 9, 632246) One party, however, had an easier day.
('5', 278, 2, 10, 632285) Whilst it must have covered no less than 25 miles the previous day, on the 4th it could not have been more than 12 miles, but the other party, under Sgt.
('5', 278, 2, 11, 632439) Shelat, had an equally trying time on that day.
('5', 278, 2, 12, 632487) The result was that most of us were footsore, and it was about as much as we could do on the 5th to carry ourselves decently to Mapumulo, a distance of nearly 15 miles.
('5', 278, 2, 13, 632656) Of course, the whole column was in a state of practical starvation, as, in the expectation of having only one night on the veld, everyone had taken two days’ rations only.
('5', 278, 2, 14, 632828) And so we had all to return to Mapumulo.
('5', 278, 3, 15, 632869) WEARY AND FOOTSORE
('5', 278, 4, 16, 632888) Our surprise can be better imagined than described, when reaching Mapumulo, where we had expected a day’s rest, we were ordered to march to Thring’s Post the day following and shift our own camp there.
('5', 278, 4, 17, 633090) It was a physical impossibility for about nine or tenof us, and the Sgt. Major informed the P. M. O. that, unless transport was provided for such as were totally unfit to walk, it would be impossible to resume the march the following day.
('5', 278, 4, 18, 633329) The matter was placed before Colonel Sparks, who said that footsore bearers could go in an empty waggon that was going to Thring’s Post, and thus we were able to undertake the journey to Thring’s Post on the 6th July.
('5', 278, 4, 19, 633547) There, we were attached to Captain Pearson, who treated us with every consideration.
('5', 278, 4, 20, 633632) Transport that was provided for the footsore bearers put us on our feet again, and we were able to respond to the call of duty on the morning of the 8th.
('5', 278, 4, 21, 633786) Orders were received on Saturday evening that we should follow with our stretchers the guns that were to leave for the Tugela Valley at 3 a.m.
('5', 278, 4, 22, 633929) the following day.
('5', 278, 4, 23, 633948) Compared to the work done in the Umvoti Valley, our task was easy, and the march
('5', 279, 0, 1, 634029) 280 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 279, 1, 2, 634071) could not have covered more than 16 miles.
('5', 279, 1, 3, 634114) We returned to camp the same day.
('5', 279, 2, 4, 634148) DOING THE IMPOSSIBLE
('5', 279, 3, 5, 634169) At 2 30 a.m.
('5', 279, 3, 6, 634182) on the 10th, we had to proceed to the Otimati Valley with the infantry, and though the work was very difficult, we had by this time become more or less seasoned.
('5', 279, 3, 7, 634344) We had to take two days’ rations with us; the path lay through what would ordinarily be an inaccessible valley.
('5', 279, 3, 8, 634456) It was impossible for any ambulance to go down, and in parts we had to descend steep precipices.
('5', 279, 3, 9, 634553) Troopers had to lead their horses, and the route was so long that we never seemed to reach the bottom.
('5', 279, 3, 10, 634656) However, at about 12 o’clock we finished the day’s journey, with no Kaffirs to fight.
('5', 279, 3, 11, 634742) But an incident happened on the way down the valley which was calculated to test our ability to do stretcher bearing work.
('5', 279, 3, 12, 634865) A Kaffir, being a friendly boy, who was guiding a private of the D. L. I., was shot by him, under the belief, it is said, that the Native was misleading him.
('5', 279, 3, 13, 635023) The Native was badly wounded, and required carrying, which was entrusted to us.
('5', 279, 3, 14, 635103) Orders were given that we were to take him the same day to Mapumulo, and we were given four friendly Natives to help us, as also to guide us.
('5', 279, 3, 15, 635245) Three of them, however, as soon as the troops were out of sight, deserted us, and the fourth, though he remained with us, declined flatly to go with us to Mapumulo, as he feared that, without an escort, we might be cut to pieces by the enemy.
('5', 279, 3, 16, 635488) Fortunately, the troops were yet within reach.
('5', 279, 3, 17, 635535) The Sergeant Major, therefore, reported the matter to the proper officer, and fresh orders were given that the wounded Kaffir should be taken the next day, and that in the meanwhile we should nurse and feed him.
('5', 279, 3, 18, 635747) The whole of the troops encamped for the night in the valley, and the following day we resumed our march with our precious charge, with orders to go to Mapumulo.
('5', 279, 3, 19, 635909) We were given about 20 Kaffir levies to help us.
('5', 279, 3, 20, 635958) They did so with much difficulty over part of the way, and then, too, because Doctor Savage happened to be with us.
('5', 279, 3, 21, 636074) The Natives in our hands proved to be most unreliable and obstinate.
('5', 279, 3, 22, 636143) Without constant attention, they would as soon have dropped the wounded man as not, and they seemed to bestow no care on their suffering countryman.
('5', 279, 3, 23, 636292) INDIAN RESOURCEFULNESS However, the Indian bearers carried him to Mapumulo in splendid style.
('5', 279, 3, 24, 636386) All our resourcefulness was put to the test during the march.
('5', 279, 3, 25, 636448) After we had finished the most difficult part of our journey along a narrow and steep pathway, the Japanese stretcher on which we were carrying the patient, who was very bulky, gave way, fortunately
('5', 280, 0, 1, 636647) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 281
('5', 280, 1, 2, 636694) without hurting him.
('5', 280, 1, 3, 636715) The railway stretcher, on which he was first carried, had already broken under his weight.
('5', 280, 1, 4, 636806) What were we to do?
('5', 280, 1, 5, 636826) Luckily, we had skilled men among us.
('5', 280, 1, 6, 636864) We temporarily mended the railway stretcher, and took our charge safely to Mapumulo, reaching there about 4 p.m., a distance probably of over 15 miles.
('5', 280, 1, 7, 637016) After a day’s rest in Mapumulo, we returned, on the 13th, to Thring’s Post, only to retrace our steps on the 14th to a spot near Mapumulo, where we are encamped for the present.
('5', 280, 1, 8, 637194) With the capture of Messini and his fellow chief, the rebellion seems to be over, and we are now resting, expecting orders every day to be disbanded.
('5', 280, 1, 9, 637344) Thus, since the 3rd day of July, our Corps has accompanied all the important operations; and at the end of them, the writer of these notes is able to confidently assert that the little band is capable of performing any work that may be entrusted to it, and that can be done by any other such Corps.
('5', 280, 2, 10, 637643) Indian Opinion, 28 7 1906
('5', 280, 3, 11, 637669) 263. SPEECH AT RECEPTION TO AMBULANCE CORPS
('5', 280, 4, 12, 637713) The Natal Indian Congress gave a reception to the Indian Stretcher Bearer Corps which was disbanded on July 19, after six weeks at the front.
('5', 280, 4, 13, 637855) Tributes were paid to the work of the Corps, to which Gandhiji replied.
('5', 280, 4, 14, 637927) The following is an extract from a report of the proceedings.
('5', 280, 5, 15, 637989) DURBAN, July 20, 1906 Thanking the organization on behalf of the Corps, Mr. Gandhi said that what the Corps had done was only its duty.
('5', 280, 5, 16, 638125) If the Indians really wanted to show their appreciation of the work of the Corps, they should try through the Government to have a permanent Corps set up and should also exert themselves to improve their physique in order to qualify for admission.
('5', 280, 5, 17, 638373) He said that if, for any reason, the traders could not enlist, other educated Indians as well as the servants and clerks of traders could easily do so.
('5', 280, 5, 18, 638525) From experience gained during the fighting, he could say that the whites treated the Indians very cordially, and distinctions based on colour had ceased to exist.
('5', 280, 5, 19, 638688) If a larger Indian Corps was formed on a permanent footing, such fellow feeling would increase, and it was likely that in the processwhite prejudice against Indians might altogether disappear.
('5', 280, 5, 20, 638881) He therefore
('5', 281, 0, 1, 638894) 282 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 281, 1, 2, 638936) very strongly recommended the formation of such a Corps.
('5', 281, 1, 3, 638993) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 28 7 1906
('5', 281, 2, 4, 639035) 264. STATEMENT ON THE DIAMOND JUBILEE LIBRARY
('5', 281, 3, 5, 639081) At a meeting of the Natal Indian Congress held in the Congress Hall it was decided, among other things, to present silver medals to members of the Stretcher Bearer Corps.
('5', 281, 3, 6, 639252) The question of the management of the Diamond Jubilee Library also came up for discussion.
('5', 281, 3, 7, 639343) Gandhiji made the following statement, which is an extract from the report of the proceedings.
('5', 281, 3, 8, 639438) DURBAN, July 23, 1906 The Diamond Jubilee Library was started to mark the Diamond Jubilee of Queen Victoria’s rule.
('5', 281, 3, 9, 639554) The ownership of the Library was vested in a special committee, which was also entrusted with its management, and the books were kept in the Congress Hall.
('5', 281, 3, 10, 639710) 1 As the Lallubhai Library is not functioning at the moment, I saw the President of the Library, Mr. Ravishankar Bhatt, about bringing the books back to the Congress Hall, and he has agreed to return them.
('5', 281, 3, 11, 639916) I have still to see one or two other gentlemen in this connection, and after securing their consent, the requisite transport will be sent to fetch the books.

('5', 281, 4, 13, 640116) 265. TRANSVAAL PERMITS
('5', 281, 5, 14, 640139) In view of the recent decisions 2 of the Supreme Court of the Transvaal on the Peace Preservation Ordinance, it is necessary still further to examine the legal position created by those decisions.
('5', 281, 5, 15, 640336) The dismissal by the Supreme Court of the application by the Attorney General for a review of the Bhyat case leaves the question raised in that case undecided.
('5', 281, 5, 16, 640496) Whilst, therefore, the Magistrate at Volksrust is bound by his own decision, and to recognise the Dutch Registration Certificates as equivalent to permits, we have no pronouncement from the Supreme Court endorsing the magisterial
('5', 281, 6, 17, 640726) 1 Vide “The Plague”, 7 1 1905
('5', 281, 7, 18, 640756) 2 Vide “An Important Permit Case”, 23 6 1906
('5', 282, 0, 1, 640801) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 283
('5', 282, 1, 2, 640848) And in the face of the contention raised by the Attorney General, the state of the law is one of painful uncertainty to the Indian refugees.
('5', 282, 1, 3, 640989) Other magistrates may unconsciously attach weight to the argument advanced on behalf of the Crown.
('5', 282, 1, 4, 641088) It may then come to pass that an Indian holding the Dutch certificate may safelyre enter the Transvaal through Volksrust, and another equally qualified, passing through, say, Komatipoort, may be prevented from so doing.
('5', 282, 1, 5, 641308) Not even the most violent anti Asiatic would, we presume, be able to justify such a deplorable state of things.
('5', 282, 1, 6, 641420) The Supreme Court decision on the registration law bears out the whole contention of the Indian community.
('5', 282, 1, 7, 641527) Can Lord Selborne still claim for the Transvaal administration a reasonable spirit in the enforcement of the Peace Preservation Ordinance and Law 3 of 1885?
('5', 282, 1, 8, 641684) We trust that the ever vigilant British Indian Association will invite His Excellency’s answer to the query.

('5', 282, 2, 10, 641819) 266. LETTER TO W. WEDDERBURN
('5', 282, 3, 11, 641848) [JOHANNESBURG,] July 30, 1906 SIR WILLIAM WEDDERBURN, BARONET 84 5 PALACE CHAMBERS LONDON, ENGLAND
('5', 282, 4, 12, 641947) DEAR SIR, I have just returned from the front.
('5', 282, 4, 13, 641994) Although I cannot now be of any use in connection with the Report of the Constitution Committee, it is still the opinion of the British Indian Association that I should proceed to England accompanied by one or two merchants, not necessarily to influence the letters patent that will be granted but to place the British Indian position personally before the authorities.
('5', 282, 4, 14, 642364) I shall, therefore, be obliged if you will kindly let me know by cable whether such a deputation is likely to be of any use whatsoever.
('5', 282, 4, 15, 642500) If it is considered unnecessary, the word “needless” would explain the meaning.
('5', 282, 4, 16, 642580) If you think that a deputation such as the above should proceed, please cable “yes”.
('5', 282, 4, 17, 642665) I do not know whether the end of September or October will be a suitable time.
('5', 282, 5, 18, 642744) I remain,
('5', 282, 6, 19, 642754) Yours truly,

('5', 284, 1, 2, 643784) 268. LETTER TO PRINCIPAL MEDICAL OFFICER 1
('5', 284, 2, 3, 643827) [JOHANNESBURG, July 31, 1906]4
('5', 284, 3, 4, 643858) TO COL.
('5', 284, 3, 5, 643866) J. HYSLOP PRINCIPAL MEDICAL OFFICER NATAL MILITIA PIETERMARITZBURG NATAL SIR, The Indian Stretcher Bearer Corps was disbanded on the 19th inst., and the Corps reached Durban on the 20th.
('5', 284, 3, 6, 644053) The Corps was called upon to do the work of disinfecting the camp at Mapumulo, of dressing injuries and wounds, and of marching with the troops and doing stretcher work.
('5', 284, 3, 7, 644223) Most of the bearers accompanied the troops during the operations at the Tugela, the Otimati and the Umvoti Valleys.
('5', 284, 3, 8, 644339) In my humble opinion, the men did the work willingly and skilfully.
('5', 284, 3, 9, 644407) The object of the Natal IndianCongress, in offering to form the Corps, was to show that Indians recognized their responsibilities as settlers in Natal, and to induce the Government to utilise Indians as a permanent portion of the Natal Militia.
('5', 284, 3, 10, 644652) I venture to think that my countrymen are essentially fit for ambulance and hospital work.
('5', 284, 3, 11, 644743) Trooper Forder, whom we carried from Otimati, had, in addition to being carried, to be nursed by us, and he was so satisfied that he sought me out specially on his recovery to express his appreciation of the men’s work.
('5', 284, 3, 12, 644963) The Corps consisted of some skilled English educated Indians, as also of Indians of the labourer type, but all of them were intelligent workers, and capable in civil life of earning much more than what would be paid to them by the Indian community.
('5', 284, 3, 13, 645212) As the community was anxious that its offer should be accepted, in order to avoid any difficulty, the men were induced to accept only one shilling and six pence per day, which they gladly did; but, in my opinion, it is not possible to get intelligent men for less than £1 per week.
('5', 284, 4, 14, 645494) 1 In his reply, Col.
('5', 284, 4, 15, 645515) Hyslop, acknowledging Gandhiji’s letter as of this date, conveyed the Militia Commander’s thanks to the members of the Ambulance Corps and expressed his own appreciation “of the very valuable services afforded to the Medical Department of the Militia, not only as stretcher bearers, but also in connection with the more important work of sanitation”.
('5', 285, 0, 1, 645866) 286 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 285, 1, 2, 645908) I also think that those who may be called leaders of stretcher parties should receive five shillings per day.
('5', 285, 1, 3, 646018) Members of the Corps were all untrained and untried men; they were called upon, too, to do responsible and independent work, and to face danger unarmed.
('5', 285, 1, 4, 646171) If the Government would form a permanent Ambulance Corps, I think that special training is absolutely necessary, and that they should all be armed for self protection.
('5', 285, 1, 5, 646339) As one who has been intimately connected with the Indian community for the last thirteen years, I have ventured to place the above views before you for your consideration.
('5', 285, 2, 6, 646511) [Yours faithfully,] M. K. GANDHI Indian Opinion, 11 8 1906

('5', 285, 5, 9, 646621) [Before August 4, 1906] A meeting of the Committee of the British Indian Association was held last Friday, the 27th.
('5', 285, 5, 10, 646738) Messrs Abdul Gani, Essop Mian, Coovadia, Mahomed Shahbuddin, Gulam Saheb, Mahomed Hoosain, Bhikhubhai; also Messrs Haji Habib and Amod Tayob of Pretoria, Messrs Amod Bhayat of Heidelberg and Omar Haji Amod Zaveri of Durban were present among others.
('5', 285, 5, 11, 646988) It was decided, after some discussion, that it was still necessary to send a deputation to England, as we were concerned more with the laws that would be enacted in the Transvaal after the Constitution had come into effect than with the Report of the Constitution Committee.
('5', 285, 5, 12, 647263) On a proposal made by Haji Habib, it was resolved to ask for a grant of £250 out of the £1,000 sanctioned by the Natal Indian Congress towards the expenses of the deputation.
('5', 285, 5, 13, 647438) Each member could draw up to £6120 as expenses, and the rest of the amount might be used to defray the expenses of the deputation as a whole.
('5', 285, 5, 14, 647580) Furthermore, the Congress might avail itself of any aid received from the Cape.
('5', 285, 5, 15, 647660) The Secretary has been asked to write a letter to that effect.
('5', 285, 5, 16, 647723) If two persons go on deputations the expenses would be about £500. The Committee is of the opinion that the deputation should include Mr. Gandhi and a member from the trading class to represent the Transvaal.
('5', 285, 5, 17, 647932) It has been decided to call for subscriptions at every place; the names of the members who should visit different places for the purpose have also

('5', 286, 1, 2, 648126) been drawn up.
('5', 286, 1, 3, 648141) The Secretary has been asked to write letters to various places, and these have actually reached all the principal towns in the Transvaal.
('5', 286, 1, 4, 648280) If therefore the requisite amount is raised; if the Natal Indian Congress agrees to contribute from it up to £250 towards expenses; and if no instructions to the contrary are received from England, the deputation will, in all probability, leave in September 1.

('5', 286, 6, 15, 649324) 270. SECRET JUSTICE
('5', 286, 7, 16, 649344) Our Johannesburg Correspondent last week drew pointed attention to Mr. Loveday’s approval of the work of the Permit Department regarding Asiatics, 3 and his endorsement of the appointment of an inspecting officer at the coast.
('5', 286, 7, 17, 649571) There is much more behind this incident than appears on the surface.
('5', 286, 7, 18, 649640) The public have no knowledge of the fact that there are what are practically secret advisory boards, which control the action of the Registrar of Asiatics who has charge of the issue of permits.
('5', 286, 7, 19, 649835) For all practical purposes, therefore, the Registrar, although nominally the responsible officer for issuing permits, is merely an agent of the advisory boards, mechanically following their directions.
('5', 286, 7, 20, 650037) Evidently, Mr. Loveday is the
('5', 286, 8, 21, 650067) 1 It actually left in October.
('5', 286, 8, 22, 650098) 2 Of compensation for losses suffered during the Boer War 3 In “Johannesburg Jottings”, Indian Opinion, 28 7 1906
('5', 287, 0, 1, 650212) 288 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 287, 1, 2, 650254) chief of these advisory boards, without being publicly appointed by the Government.
('5', 287, 1, 3, 650338) Hence the innumerable difficulties placed in the way of British Indians, who have a bona fide right to re enter the Transvaal.
('5', 287, 1, 4, 650465) We do not object to the greatest strictness being exercised in connection with applications of refugees, but we do emphatically object to the secrecy that shrouds the doings of these advisory boards.
('5', 287, 1, 5, 650665) We are not aware that the parties who are immediately interested are heard before the boards or allowed to be represented.
('5', 287, 1, 6, 650788) The boards alone know what evidence they take and what evidence they consider sufficient for establishing claims on the part of British Indians to re enter the Colony.
('5', 287, 1, 7, 650956) Under a system such as this, favouritism—it may be quite unconscious—must exist.
('5', 287, 1, 8, 651037) Bitter complaints reach us from all sides as to the rejection of claims that are easily provable.
('5', 287, 1, 9, 651135) Boys of tender years are kept out of the Colony by these boards, which have been arbitrarily armed with powers to decide upon the applications of British Indian refugees.
('5', 287, 1, 10, 651306) It is a strange method of dealing out justice to entrust avowed partisans with the duty of judging their opponents or persons whom they have hitherto traduced in unmeasured terms.
('5', 287, 1, 11, 651486) The least that the Transvaal Administration owes to British Indians is that they should be able to know their position definitely.
('5', 287, 1, 12, 651617) Severest rules of procedure, if well defined and well understood, would be preferable to the hole and corner enquiry that is now being held as to British Indian permits.
('5', 287, 1, 13, 651787) No Indian can today feel safe that he can re enter the Transvaal without difficulty, on production of evidence of his prior residence.
('5', 287, 1, 14, 651922) The conditions which the Transvaal Administration has created for the unfortunate British Indian refugees are most unsatisfactory, and discreditable in the extreme.
('5', 287, 1, 15, 652087) It has gone very much further than Natal or Cape Colony, where, no matter what the restrictions are on immigration, everyone knows the legal position, and everyone is capable of asserting it in a Court of Law.
('5', 287, 1, 16, 652297) It is a stateof things which it is the duty of every lover of justice and fairplay to see ended.
('5', 287, 1, 17, 652394) Indian Opinion, 4 8 1906
('5', 287, 2, 18, 652419) 271. MR. BYTE’S WILL
('5', 287, 3, 19, 652440) We published in our last issue a brief account of the late Mr. Byte’s will 1 which deserves to be taken note of by rich Indians.
('5', 287, 4, 20, 652569) 1 A Gujarati news item in Indian Opinion, dated July 28, 1906, said that, under
('5', 288, 0, 1, 652649) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 289
('5', 288, 1, 2, 652696) Mr. Byte earned millions of pounds in South Africa, and gave away the best part of that fortune to that country.
('5', 288, 1, 3, 652809) Being an alien and having earned his name and fortune under the aegis of the British flag, he has provided for the widespread spending of a considerable part of his fortune in England as well.
('5', 288, 1, 4, 653002) He has thus directed that his millions be used for deserving causes.
('5', 288, 1, 5, 653071) The major portion of his legacy is to be spent on education.
('5', 288, 1, 6, 653132) He has donated hundreds of acres of land in Johannesburg where a huge educational centre is to be set up; it is due exclusively to his munificence that the University of the Transvaal has come into existence.
('5', 288, 1, 7, 653341) Such generosity has been an important factor in the progress of the whites.
('5', 288, 1, 8, 653417) They know how to make money and also how best to spend it.
('5', 288, 1, 9, 653476) We are backward in both respects, particularly in spending money aright.
('5', 288, 1, 10, 653549) Even when we spend it, we do so indiscriminately, and largely for selfish ends or on personal pleasures.
('5', 288, 1, 11, 653654) To take the example of South Africa, there are few among us who have spent their money on the proper education of Indian children.
('5', 288, 1, 12, 653785) It behoves us therefore to bear in mind such examples as Mr. Byte’s.
('5', 288, 1, 13, 653854) It is our prime duty to provide all the necessary means for the education of Indian children in South Africa.
('5', 288, 1, 14, 653964) Our second duty is towards women’s education.
('5', 288, 1, 15, 654010) As long as our women do not realise their duty as mothers, the Indian people are bound to remain backward.
('5', 288, 1, 16, 654117) And, thirdly, it is the duty of all gainfully employed, adult Indians to find some time at night to receive education.
('5', 288, 1, 17, 654236) To do all this, money is needed.
('5', 288, 1, 18, 654269) If Indians would come forward to emulate Mr. Byte, these things could easily be done.
('5', 288, 1, 19, 654355) It is quite proper that we demand rights in South Africa and it is unjust that we should be denied those rights.
('5', 288, 1, 20, 654468) We must, however, admit that we do not deserve them fully.
('5', 288, 1, 21, 654527) It takes two to make a quarrel, and had we been without faults, we would not suffer in this land the hardships that we do.
('5', 288, 1, 22, 654650) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 4 8 1906
('5', 288, 2, 23, 654691) Mr. Byte’s will, £1,200,000 had been donated for improving transport and communications in South Africa, £200,000 for founding a University in Johannesburg, £20,000 for education in the Transvaal, £15,000 for education at Kimberley and £15,000 for education in the Cape Colony.

('5', 289, 1, 2, 655011) 272. EGYPT AND NATAL—A COMPARISON
('5', 289, 2, 3, 655045) IS THIS CIVILIZATION ?
('5', 289, 3, 4, 655068) A controversy is going on in England about what the Natal army did during the Kaffir rebellion.
('5', 289, 3, 5, 655164) The people there believe that the whites of Natal perpetrated great atrocities on the Kaffirs.
('5', 289, 3, 6, 655259) In reply to such critics, The Star has pointed to the doings of the Imperial army in Egypt.
('5', 289, 3, 7, 655351) Those among the Egyptian rebels who had been captured were ordered to be flogged.
('5', 289, 3, 8, 655433) The flogging was continued to the limits of the victims’ endurance; it took place in public and was watched by thousands of people.
('5', 289, 3, 9, 655565) Those sentenced to death were also hanged at the same time.
('5', 289, 3, 10, 655625) While those sentenced to death were hanging, the flogging of the others was taken up.
('5', 289, 3, 11, 655711) While the sentences were being executed, the relatives of the victims cried and wept until many of them swooned.
('5', 289, 3, 12, 655824) If this be true, there is no reason why there should be such an outcry in England against the Natal outrage.

('5', 289, 5, 15, 655974) 273. JOHANNESBURG LETTER August 4, 1906
('5', 289, 6, 16, 656014) THE ELGIN CONSTITUTION
('5', 289, 7, 17, 656037) The resolution to grant a new Constitution to the Transvaal and the details that have been published regarding it are at present a subject of public discussion.
('5', 289, 7, 18, 656198) There is, of course, a good deal of difference between the Constitution awarded last year by Mr. Lyttelton and the one now proposed by Lord Elgin.
('5', 289, 7, 19, 656345) According to the Lyttelton Constitution, the governance of the country was to continue in the hands of the British bureaucracy.
('5', 289, 7, 20, 656473) According to Lord Elgin’s, it will be carried on by the party which has a majority of elected members [in the Legislature].
('5', 289, 7, 21, 656597) This is the main difference between the two.
('5', 289, 7, 22, 656642) The Lyttelton Constitution envisaged representative government, that is, a government consisting of men who understand the wishes of the people, while the Elgin Constitution proposes responsible government, wherein the executive will be responsible to elected members; so that the latter can, if they will, remove it from power.
('5', 289, 7, 23, 656971) In Ceylon and Mauritius, there is
('5', 290, 0, 1, 657005) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 291
('5', 290, 1, 2, 657052) representative government, Natal and the Cape Colony have responsible government.
('5', 290, 1, 3, 657134) Another great difference is that Lord Elgin’s Constitution places the Boers in a position in which they can form a government.
('5', 290, 1, 4, 657261) Thus either the Boers or the British can come to power in the Transvaal, asindeed they can in the Cape.
('5', 290, 1, 5, 657365) The Constitution has not yet been drafted, but Mr. Churchill has said that this would soon be done.
('5', 290, 1, 6, 657465) The drafting will take about three weeks, and the Parliament elected under the new Constitution is not likely to meet before January.
('5', 290, 1, 7, 657599) PLACE OF INDIANS What will be our position under the new set up?
('5', 290, 1, 8, 657664) It is a very difficult question to answer.
('5', 290, 1, 9, 657707) Nothing definite can be learnt from reports of Mr. Churchill’s speech cabled here.
('5', 290, 1, 10, 657790) Our situation could not be worse.
('5', 290, 1, 11, 657824) In any case, it is certain that, whatever new laws are made, they will not be enacted before January next.
('5', 290, 1, 12, 657931) NATAL AND THE TRANSVAAL The unification of Natal and the Transvaal is being discussed.
('5', 290, 1, 13, 658018) Some men of experience and influence favour this course of action.
('5', 290, 1, 14, 658085) A gentleman named Mr. Soutter has expressed his views on the subject in The Daily Mail.
('5', 290, 1, 15, 658173) He says that, if the two are united, the “Indian Policy” of Natal will have to be revised.
('5', 290, 1, 16, 658264) The Editor of The Daily Mail thinks that it will be very difficult for Natal to merge in other States so long as it imports indentured labour.
('5', 290, 1, 17, 658407) THE STATE OF SOUTH AFRICA Underlying all the thoughts in people’s minds is the poverty of South Africa.
('5', 290, 1, 18, 658511) At present, trade is slack and land prices are very low.
('5', 290, 1, 19, 658568) People are desperately looking around to see how matters can be improved.
('5', 290, 1, 20, 658642) But all things considered, one is driven to the conclusion that, for another two years, there can be no hope of any appreciable change.
('5', 290, 1, 21, 658778) According to what economists call natural laws and men of faith, the will of God, it appears that conditions change from moment to moment.
('5', 290, 1, 22, 658917) He who rises must fall.
('5', 290, 1, 23, 658941) This is true of a country as well.
('5', 290, 1, 24, 658976) In the vicissitudes of life, South Africa has seen good days, and now it is her turn to go through bad ones.
('5', 290, 1, 25, 659085) She has not yet passed through even two lean years.
('5', 290, 1, 26, 659137) Sometimes it takes three, five or even seven years for a change to set in.
('5', 290, 1, 27, 659212) If this is true, it will take at least another year and a half for present conditions to change.
('5', 290, 1, 28, 659309) In the meanwhile, those who are patient and live within their means 1 will win through.
('5', 290, 1, 29, 659397) The rest will be
('5', 290, 2, 30, 659414) 1 The Gujarati idiom literally means “...draw the sheet and stretch or huddle according to its size”.

('5', 291, 2, 3, 659585) A DISCUSSION IN THE LEGISLATURE ABOUT ASIATICS
('5', 291, 3, 4, 659632) In the Legislative Council today, Mr. Duncan gave the following information: 1
('5', 291, 4, 5, 659711) When the Council meets again, the Government proposes to introduce a Bill for the registration of Asiatics.
('5', 291, 4, 6, 659819) That legislation would be in fulfilment of the policy of the Imperial Government with regard to Asiatics in this Colony: first, to afford just and fair treatment to those Asiatics who are already here and settled in this country; and secondly, to leave to the responsible government the question whether or not to allow new Asiatics to enter the country, and if they are to be allowed, under what restrictions.
('5', 291, 4, 7, 660230) That is the policy the present Government has been attempting to carry out with the approval of the Imperial Government, and in doing so, it has had to rely upon the law passed by the Boer Government as well as the permit law 2 of the present Government.
('5', 291, 4, 8, 660485) Experience has shown that these laws are not adequate to prevent the Asiatics from entering the Colony; for doubtless many Asiatics who had no title to enter the Colony have entered it on false evidence.
('5', 291, 4, 9, 660689) Those who have never been in the Transvaal before have made false declarations in order to come in.
('5', 291, 4, 10, 660789) The law regarding registration is vague; whenever a serious attempt was made to apply it, it led to litigation in the courts.
('5', 291, 4, 11, 660915) We have therefore to accomplish two things: give fair and just treatment to those who were here before the war; and prevent an influx of Asiatics into this country before a responsible government is established.
('5', 291, 4, 12, 661127) We should therefore get all the Asiatics now resident in the Transvaal registered afresh.
('5', 291, 4, 13, 661217) They should take out [fresh] registration certificates, so that nobody may question their bona fides.
('5', 291, 4, 14, 661319) Simultaneously, it is proposed to remove certain disabilities under which these Asiatics labour.
('5', 291, 4, 15, 661416) No material changes in the law regarding ownership of land are envisaged.
('5', 291, 4, 16, 661490) But it is proposed to enact a law which will enable Asiatics to hold the land on which their places of worship are built; again, the heirs of those who held land before the passing of Law 3 of 1885 will be enabled to inherit it.
('5', 291, 4, 17, 661719) Furthermore, it is also proposed to make certain modifications in the existing permit law which will enable Asiatics to visit the country temporarily.
('5', 291, 4, 18, 661870) The statement is so important and disturbing that the Committee of the British Indian Association proposes to take immediate action on it.
('5', 291, 4, 19, 662009) It is very doubtful now if the deputation can proceed to England in

('5', 292, 4, 6, 662376) THE DEPUTATION
('5', 292, 5, 7, 662391) The deputation to England has for the present been postponed as a result of Mr. Duncan’s statement, which I sent last week.
('5', 292, 5, 8, 662515) 2 Some persons were under the impression that the deputation was to visit England only in connection with the Report of the Constitution Committee, and that, since the nature of the Constitution to be granted to the Transvaal had been decidedm upon, there was no longer any point in sending the deputation.
('5', 292, 5, 9, 662822) This is a mistaken view.
('5', 292, 5, 10, 662847) For, in the matter of the Constitution, there was little that the deputation could have done.
('5', 292, 5, 11, 662941) Whatever laws are contemplated will be enacted later [that is, after the Constitution comes into force].
('5', 292, 5, 12, 663046) Even now we can approach the Imperial Government and represent before them our case regarding those laws.
('5', 292, 5, 13, 663152) The deputation can therefore go to England to some advantage only so long as the Transvaal Parliament has not met and it is not known what new laws are going to be enacted.
('5', 292, 5, 14, 663325) So far I have referred to the Transvaal only; but if and when the deputation does go, it will be its duty to take up the entire South African problem.
('5', 292, 5, 15, 663476) This can be done whenever it may be that the deputation visits England.
('5', 292, 5, 16, 663548) Moreover, if our case is put before our sympathisers who are already working on our behalf, they will understand it the better and will be better able to lend us active support.
('5', 292, 5, 17, 663726) Furthermore, we would then get help from all parties.
('5', 292, 5, 18, 663780) The Congress Committee 3, the East India Association and other bodies are agitating on our behalf.
('5', 292, 5, 19, 663879) If all of them could be brought together and a committee formed, it would help us a great deal.
('5', 292, 5, 20, 663975) It is thus clear that the deputation, if sent, is bound to have some effect.
('5', 292, 5, 21, 664052) Mr. Duncan’s statement, as I have pointed out, has served to discourage the idea of sending a deputation.
('5', 292, 5, 22, 664158) A communication in the matter had already reached England last week.

('5', 293, 1, 18, 666210) (3) A permit was refused to Sakoor Nanjee despite the evidence of a disinterested physician and of the District Surgeon of Pretoria that he was only 16 years old.
('5', 293, 1, 19, 666373) (4) Though medical evidence has been produced to prove that Ebrahim Amod is only 12 years old, the Permit Office insists that the boy’s age is 16. Mr. Lichtenstein has cited 14 such examples.
('5', 293, 1, 20, 666565) It remains to be seen what kind of a reply he will receive.

('5', 295, 1, 2, 669335) Government towards an individual British subject.
('5', 295, 1, 3, 669385) If the proposed legislation is passed, the position of the British Indian will, as a matter of fact, be much worse than it is now.
('5', 295, 1, 4, 669516) It should not be forgotten that the £3 registration is not an annual tax.

('5', 295, 1, 8, 670117) That they are not granted where they ought to be is a discredit attached to the Government from which it cannot free itself by passing new legislation.
('5', 295, 1, 9, 670269) I very much fear that the real situation is not understood by the Imperial Government, and that the local Government has evidently convinced the Imperial Government that, by passing legislation in the direction sketched by Mr. Duncan, they would be really granting concessions.
('5', 295, 1, 10, 670547) I have said before that, under the proposed legislation, the position would be much worse.
('5', 295, 1, 11, 670638) I say so because I know that endless mischief is likely to be caused by new legislation.
('5', 295, 1, 12, 670727) Indians were registered during the [rule of the] Dutch Government; registration then was simple.
('5', 295, 1, 13, 670824) They were again registered after British rule was established; registration was then much more complex, and respectable Indians have been called upon to put their thumb impressions.
('5', 295, 1, 14, 671006) The third registration, if it comes at all, will, it is needless to say, be stricter still.
('5', 295, 1, 15, 671098) All this because a few Indians who were not resident before war have stolen into the Colony and if they have done so, it is owing to the corrupt officials who were in charge at one time of the Permit Department.
('5', 295, 1, 16, 671310) The matter had become so serious that, on the initiative taken by the British Indian Association, these officials were arrested and criminally tried.
('5', 295, 1, 17, 671460) They were discharged by an indulgent jury but the Government was so satisfied of their guilt, that both these officials were discharged.
('5', 295, 1, 18, 671597) I hope, therefore, that unless some substantial justice can be done to British Indians before Responsible Government is granted, and unless the British Government will, in accordance with pre war promises, put them, in its own words, on the same footing as British Indians at the Cape, it will be infinitely better that Law 3 of 1885 remained as it was and that the whole question was considered by Responsible Government.

('5', 296, 6, 9, 672896) 276. LETTER TO “THE RAND DAILY MAIL” 2
('5', 296, 7, 10, 672935) [JOHANNESBURG, Before August 9, 1906]
('5', 296, 8, 11, 672973) [TO THE EDITOR The Rand Daily Mail]
('5', 296, 9, 12, 673009) SIR, I trust you will permit me to offer a few remarks on your leading article regarding the Asiatic legislation foreshadowed by Mr. Duncan in what I would venture to term his extraordinary statement.
('5', 296, 9, 13, 673210) In his brief pronouncement he thrice told his hearers that it was the desire of the Government to accord to the resident Asiatic population.
('5', 296, 9, 14, 673351) “Just and fair treatment” and that it was for that reason that the legislation described by him was to be introduced, on the Legislative Council reassembling.
('5', 296, 10, 15, 673510) 1 This is in Gandhiji’s hand.
('5', 296, 10, 16, 673540) 2 This was reproduced in Indian Opinion, 11 8 1906.
('5', 297, 0, 1, 673592) 298 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 297, 1, 2, 673634) You have considered that the Ordinance to be passed will mean generous treatment of the resident Asiatic population.
('5', 297, 1, 3, 673751) I very much fear that there is absolutely no generosity about the proposed legislation, but that it will fall very far short of even “just and fair treatment”.
('5', 297, 1, 4, 673911) Re registration is certainly not part of such treatment, and it is perfectly meaningless.
('5', 297, 1, 5, 674001) Every Indian who has entered the Colony is supposed to have been registered for the most part for the second time.
('5', 297, 1, 6, 674116) The second registration was, in reality, a concession to the Permit Department, which was at the time very much appreciated.
('5', 297, 1, 7, 674241) A third registration is not a remedy for the evil of alleged fraudulent entrance of Asiatics into the Colony.
('5', 297, 1, 8, 674351) It is easy enough to examine the present registration certificates of the resident Asiatic population, and to prosecute those who are without them.
('5', 297, 1, 9, 674499) The British Indian Association has denied the charge of any wholesale fraudulent entrance.
('5', 297, 1, 10, 674590) There will always be a few people prepared to break laws, no matter how stringently devised and how well enforced.
('5', 297, 1, 11, 674705) To brand as criminals a whole community—for that is what re registration implies—is hardly “just” or “fair”.
('5', 297, 1, 12, 674814) But Mr. Duncan says, in consideration for a fresh registration, he would give four things to the Asiatics, namely: (1) abolition of the £3 tax; (2) permission to the Asiatics to hold land for religious purposes; (3) permission for those Asiatics who held land before Law 3 of 1885 came into force to transmit same to their heirs; (4) authority to issue temporary permits to Asiatic visitors.
('5', 297, 1, 13, 675206) Now the first concession is, shall I say, a mere blind.
('5', 297, 1, 14, 675262) It should be remembered that it applies to those only who are resident in the Colony, or perhaps to those who, being pre war residents of the Transvaal, have a right to re enter.
('5', 297, 1, 15, 675441) The resident population has already paid the £3 and the majority of those who are still outside the Colony have also done likewise.
('5', 297, 1, 16, 675573) There is no warrant in the existing legislation to charge the £3 fee twice.
('5', 297, 1, 17, 675649) It is not an annual tax, but it is a fee that has to be paid once for all under Law 3 of l885 by Asiatics who wish to settle in the Colony.
('5', 297, 1, 18, 675789) Nor is there any merit about the proposed authority to be given for holding land for religious purposes because it is possible to do so under the existing law.
('5', 297, 1, 19, 675949) The Superior Courts have decided that Coloured persons can, as a corporate body, hold land for religious purposes.
('5', 297, 1, 20, 676064) The third grant would have been a concession, if it was applicable to any large body of Asiatics.
('5', 297, 1, 21, 676162) Mr. Duncan well knows that there is only one such piece of land.
('5', 297, 1, 22, 676227) It would be a performance of
('5', 298, 0, 1, 676256) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 299
('5', 298, 1, 2, 676303) simple duty to allow the heirs to hold their two fifths of an erf in the Transvaal, and in any case, in doing so, it is not the community that will receive justice but an individual.
('5', 298, 1, 3, 676486) The fourth, of course, is again no concession.
('5', 298, 1, 4, 676533) Mr. Nomura and Mr. Manga suffered not because there was no authority to issue temporary permits, but because there was a disinclination to exercise the authority.
('5', 298, 1, 5, 676696) The difficulty, therefore, lies not in the law but in its administration.
('5', 298, 1, 6, 676770) I hope I have thus clearly shown that there is no question of “just and fair treatment” of the resident Asiatic population behind the forecast given by the Colonial Secretary on Saturday last.
('5', 298, 1, 7, 676963) On thecontrary, Damocles has again raised his sword [sic] over the heads of the poor Asiatics who, because of their belief in the sanctity of the British subject idea, have ventured to migrate to the Transvaal.
('5', 298, 1, 8, 677174) There is no trace in Mr. Duncan’s statement of the fulfilment of the promises made before the war and, even after it, by Lord Milner and other representatives of the Crown.
('5', 298, 1, 9, 677347) And if I may repeat what I have already said, what is it that British Indians (to distinguish them from other Asiatics) want?
('5', 298, 1, 10, 677473) They accept the doctrine of the Transvaal having the right to regulate immigration, and they—although such was not the case during the Dutch Government—are quite willing that restrictions after the Cape or the Australian Immigration Law applying to British subjects may be imposed on them; but as against that, they claim that those British Indians, who have settled in the country, ought to have full civil liberty, namely, the right to move about freely, the right to own land subject to such general restrictions as may be imposed to provide against speculative acquisition, and the right to trade subject again to such municipal restriction as may be deemed advisable in the interests of sanitation and of fair trade.
('5', 298, 1, 11, 678195) It will be only when this elementary right of the British Indian is recognised, and not till then, that it will be possible for any representative of the Crown to say that British Indians are receiving “just and fair treatment”.
('5', 298, 1, 12, 678424) Remember, there is no attempt in the above statement to claim any political rights.
('5', 298, 1, 13, 678508) British Indians only ask for what can easily be given, even by those who believe in the gospel of a white South Africa, if, that is to say, South Africa, to paraphrase Lord Selborne’s words, is to be white not only in the exterior but also in the interior.
('5', 298, 2, 14, 678765) Yours, etc., M. K. GANDHI The Rand Daily Mail, 9 8 1906
('5', 299, 0, 1, 678821) 300 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 299, 1, 2, 678863) 277. “FAIR AND JUST TREATMENT”
('5', 299, 2, 3, 678894) On the adjournment of the Legislative Council of the Transvaal on Saturday last, the Colonial Secretary, Mr. Duncan, made an important statement on the proposed Asiatic legislation.
('5', 299, 2, 4, 679076) In the course of his statement, which occupies only half a column of the Transvaal Leader, Mr. Duncan has thrice repeated that Asiatics resident in the Transvaal are entitled to “fair and just treatment”.
('5', 299, 2, 5, 679281) The honourable gentleman then proceeds to expound his meaning of such treatment.
('5', 299, 2, 6, 679362) We have never seen a pronouncement so misleading as Mr. Duncan’s and we can only hope that he is himself labouring under a mistaken view of the Law 3 of 1885, and has therefore come to the conclusion that, by the legislation he foreshadowed on Saturday last, he is really granting substantial relief.
('5', 299, 2, 7, 679663) We will now proceed to shew that, instead of the legislation in question granting any relief at all to the Asiatic community settled in the Transvaal, it will simply cause intense irritation, and probably take away from the community what it already possesses.
('5', 299, 2, 8, 679924) Mr. Duncan has promised four things: (1) Fresh registration of all Asiatics in the Colony.
('5', 299, 2, 9, 680015) (2) Abolition of the £3 registration fee.
('5', 299, 2, 10, 680057) (3) Permission to the Asiatic religious communities to hold land for religious purposes.
('5', 299, 2, 11, 680146) (4) Permission to the heirs of those Asiatics, who held land before the Law 3 of 1885 was passed, to get the same transferred in their own names.
('5', 299, 2, 12, 680292) The first proposal is most mischievous and most dangerous, and it is because the Government wishes to push it through that the last three are to be given as a sop, although even the first has been so cleverly put by Mr. Duncan as to give the impression that it is to be undertaken in the interests of the Asiatic community.
('5', 299, 2, 13, 680616) Let us go back to the past.
('5', 299, 2, 14, 680644) Indians who held registration certificates from the Dutch Government were not called upon by law to take out any fresh registration certificates, but in order to have the same system applicable to all, when Lord Milner decided to enforce the Law 3 of 1885 as to the £3 fee, on representations made by the then Chief Secretary for Permits, British Indians consented to have fresh registration certificates on which were to be impressed thumb prints.
('5', 299, 2, 15, 681093) This procedure has since been uniformly followed.
('5', 299, 2, 16, 681143) Let it be remembered that it was admitted by the Chief Secretary for
('5', 300, 0, 1, 681212) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 301
('5', 300, 1, 2, 681259) Permits, acting under legal advice, that there was no legal obligation on the part of the Indian community to take out fresh registration certificates.
('5', 300, 1, 3, 681411) When, therefore, the British Indian Association consented to the proposal, it was naturally gratefully appreciated.
('5', 300, 1, 4, 681527) The hardships that the community had to undergo, when fresh registration took place, are still vivid in the minds of many Indians.
('5', 300, 1, 5, 681658) They have not forgotten that they were practically pulled out of their houses in the early hours of the morning.
('5', 300, 1, 6, 681771) Mr. Duncan now says that this registration is useless.
('5', 300, 1, 7, 681826) Why, we do not know.
('5', 300, 1, 8, 681847) It is therefore proposed to register the whole of the Asiatics [sic] over again, as if they were criminals.
('5', 300, 1, 9, 681955) Mr. Duncan says that many Asiatics—one could wish he had discriminated between Asiatics and Asiatics, and said whether in his remarks he referred to British Indians, or Chinese, or other Asiatics—who had not previously resided in the Transvaal, entered the Colony under false declarations.
('5', 300, 1, 10, 682245) We grant, for the sake of argument, that this is so.
('5', 300, 1, 11, 682298) How is fresh registration to remedy the evil, and why should the majority of innocent men suffer because of the guilty few?
('5', 300, 1, 12, 682422) And may we here remind Mr. Duncan that, if some Asiatics have so entered the Colony, they have done so because of the corruption that was at one time rampant in one of the Chief Asiatic Offices.
('5', 300, 1, 13, 682617) But, as a matter of fact, the British Indian Association has stoutly denied the charge that an appreciable number of Asiatics have entered the Colony under false declarations.
('5', 300, 1, 14, 682793) In any case, it is a matter for judicial enquiry, and the Peace Preservation Ordinance is clear enough to meet cases of such description.
('5', 300, 1, 15, 682931) The second concession is again no concession at all.
('5', 300, 1, 16, 682984) We hope Mr. Duncan is not thinking of the registration fee as if it were an annual charge.
('5', 300, 1, 17, 683075) It is a fee only to be paid once.
('5', 300, 1, 18, 683109) All Indians who are resident in the Colony, and who are by law required to pay the registration fee, have already paid it.
('5', 300, 1, 19, 683232) Wherein, then, does the remission come into play?
('5', 300, 1, 20, 683282) It certainly does not apply to the future new immigrants, because the door is to be completely barred against them until it is opened by the Responsible Government, under such conditions as it chooses to lay down.
('5', 300, 1, 21, 683496) The abolition of the £3 fee, therefore, is totally meaningless.
('5', 300, 1, 22, 683560) Dealing with this subject, Mr. Duncan was pleased to say that the registration law proved a failure each time an attempt was made to seriously administer it.
('5', 300, 1, 23, 683718) This is hardly correct.
('5', 300, 1, 24, 683742) It has undoubtedly proved a failure when the Government has attempted to import into the law a meaning which the late Dutch Government never intended to give it.
('5', 300, 1, 25, 683904) The law requires registration of those Asiatics who intend to
('5', 301, 0, 1, 683966) 302 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 301, 1, 2, 684008) settle in the Transvaal for purposes of trade or otherwise.
('5', 301, 1, 3, 684068) The local Government wanted to go further, and wished to register Indians, whether they were children or wives, or whether they wanted to trade or not.
('5', 301, 1, 4, 684220) In this attempt, the Supreme Court has frustrated the Government.
('5', 301, 1, 5, 684286) Is the law, therefore, vague and uncertain ?
('5', 301, 1, 6, 684331) The answer, from any unbiased person, would be an emphatic “No”.
('5', 301, 1, 7, 684396) It is uncertain only to those partisans who wish to impose on Indians disabilities which the late President Kruger and his Government never even dreamed of.
('5', 301, 1, 8, 684553) The third concession is that relating to land held for religious purposes.
('5', 301, 1, 9, 684628) The Witwatersrand High Court has laid it down that such land can be held by any Coloured persons, and as a matter of fact, British Indians have now ceased to trouble the Government for any such permission, and are preparing to have Mosque properties in the Transvaal duly registered in the names of Indian trustees.
('5', 301, 1, 10, 684944) They, therefore, do not require any authority or protection from the Government.
('5', 301, 1, 11, 685025) Thus, here again there is absolutely no concession given to the Asiatics.
('5', 301, 1, 12, 685099) The fourth is undoubtedly a concession, but it does not affect the Asiatic community as such.
('5', 301, 1, 13, 685193) It is meant to give relief in only one individual case.
('5', 301, 1, 14, 685249) There is only one piece of property in the Transvaal that was held by an Indian before Law 3 of 1885 came into force— two thirds 1 of an erf in extent—and if relief is granted in that case, and the property is allowed to be held by the heirs, it will be a case of the British Government performing its simple duty to an individual British subject.
('5', 301, 1, 15, 685597) To dignify such a proposal by the name of a concession to the Asiatic community is to offer an insult to its intelligence.
('5', 301, 1, 16, 685720) So far, therefore, as Law 3 of 1885 is concerned, its repeal in the manner foreshadowed by Mr. Duncan is totally unnecessary, and will give rise to endless difficulties, from which perhaps British Indians are at present free.
('5', 301, 1, 17, 685946) Regarding the Peace Preservation Ordinance, Mr. Duncan mentioned that provision would be made for permits being granted to visitors.
('5', 301, 1, 18, 686079) This again is, we would say with deference, a mere blind.
('5', 301, 1, 19, 686137) Hitherto, no provision has been found necessary for granting such permits.
('5', 301, 1, 20, 686212) It is true that the Government have raised difficulties in granting them, and it is, on that account, the greater discredit to them.
('5', 301, 1, 21, 686345) They cannot free themselves from it by now sweetly talking of providing for temporary permits, which the law has ever allowed them
('5', 301, 2, 22, 686476) 1 On “Letter to The Rand Daily Mail”, Before 9 8 1906 the area is mentioned as two fifths of an erf.
('5', 302, 0, 1, 686577) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 303
('5', 302, 1, 2, 686624) to grant, but which, from fear of anti Indian agitators, they have hitherto declined to do.
('5', 302, 1, 3, 686716) Mr. Duncan, again, says that the policy defined in his statement has been the policy of the Imperial Government, as also the local Government.
('5', 302, 1, 4, 686859) This is hardly consistent with facts, because the policy of Lord Milner was that, even before the Responsible Government was granted, Asiatic legislation should be brought into line with British traditions, and Indians, who were either qualified by education or other attainments, should be placed on an equality with the other subjects of the Crown in the Transvaal.
('5', 302, 1, 5, 687227) Such also was the policy laid down in Mr. Lyttelton’s dispatch.
('5', 302, 1, 6, 687291) Mr. Duncan’s statement, therefore, is a distinct retrogression from what was intended either by Lord Milner or, later on, by Mr. Lyttelton.
('5', 302, 1, 7, 687431) We ask whether the thrice repeated declaration of “fair and just treatment” has any foundation in fact, or is it that, in Lord Lytton’s words, “promises given to the ear are to be broken in practice”, and that the effect of Mr. Duncan’s declaration is to be exhausted in mere words?
('5', 302, 1, 8, 687714) Indian Opinion, 11 8 1906
('5', 302, 2, 9, 687740) 278. SPEECH AT HAMIDIYA ISLAMIC SOCIETY
('5', 302, 3, 10, 687780) A meeting of Indians was held in the 17th Street Hall in the Malay Location, under the auspices of the Hamidiya Islamic Society of Johannesburg, then recently formed.

('5', 302, 3, 13, 688425) He regretted the controversy that was going on among the people over the question whether the Society had been formed in opposition to the British Indian Association.
('5', 302, 3, 14, 688592) He declared that this impression was absolutely incorrect and added that, on the contrary, the new Society would serve to strengthen the British Indian Association and the two would help each other in future.
('5', 302, 3, 15, 688801) Speaking on the present political condition of Indians in the
('5', 303, 0, 1, 688863) 304 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('5', 303, 1, 3, 689015) Pointing out the need for organizing a strong protest against this statement, he advised that the deputation to England be postponed.
('5', 303, 1, 4, 689149) Adverting to the weak financial position of the British Indian Association, Mr. Gandhi called upon all those present to contribute to its funds.
('5', 303, 1, 5, 689294) He also expressed the hope that the formation of such societies would greatly help the Muslims, who were backward in education, and appealed to them to do their best to overcome this disadvantage.

('5', 303, 2, 7, 689533) 279. LETTER TO DADABHAI NAOROJI 1
('5', 303, 3, 8, 689567) P. O. BOX 968, JOHANNESBURG, August 13, 1906
('5', 303, 4, 9, 689612) DEAR SIR, The current issue of Indian Opinion 2 gives fullest information about the proposed change by Mr. Duncan in the Law 3 of 1885. Portions of Mr. Lyttelton’s and Lord Milner’s despatches and the full text of Law 3 of 1885 are also given.
('5', 303, 4, 10, 689856) It will be seen at a glance that Mr. Duncan is very much restricting the scope of the despatches in his proposed legislation.
('5', 303, 4, 11, 689982) Neither Mr. Lyttelton nor Lord Milner have [sic] even mentioned anything about re registration, and both of them have laid down that better class Indians should, at least have full rights, so that for Mr. Duncan to state that he is carrying out the intentions of the Imperial Government is wide of the mark unless the Liberal ministers have veered round entirely and propose still farther to curtail the liberty of the British Indians than what the Conservative ministry was prepared to do.

('5', 306, 1, 2, 694408) 281. LETTER TO HAJI ISMAIL HAJI ABOOBAKER JOHARI
('5', 306, 2, 3, 694457) P. O. BOX 6522, JOHANNESBURG, August 14, 1906
('5', 306, 3, 4, 694503) MY DEAR SHETH SHRI HAJI ISMAIL HAJI ABOOBAKER, Now there seems to be very solid ground for hoping that, within a short time, the land in Pretoria will be transferred to the names of both of you!
('5', 306, 3, 5, 694698) Since Omar Sheth has already written to you of this, I need not dilate upon it.
('5', 306, 3, 6, 694778) I have always complained to Omar Sheth about the expenses there.
('5', 306, 3, 7, 694843) These are hard times now in South Africa, and they are likely to become harder still.
('5', 306, 3, 8, 694929) The prices of land have gone down by 66 per cent., and it would be no matter for surprise if they fell still further.
('5', 306, 3, 9, 695047) The rent you used to get has decreased by a half and will further decrease.
('5', 306, 3, 10, 695123) Even a well furnished shop on the first floor in a place like West Street remains untenanted.
('5', 306, 3, 11, 695217) If, in such bad times, you do not reduce your household and other expenditure, whatever property you have will be eroded.
('5', 306, 3, 12, 695339) As it is, you are living, so to speak, on capital.
('5', 306, 3, 13, 695390) That we are making some profit in trade is, however, a matter for satisfaction.
('5', 306, 3, 14, 695470) But, then, that profit consists of stocks and of arrears collected from clients.
('5', 306, 3, 15, 695551) The actual profit from trade cannot be reckoned precisely unless the final accounts are made up and goods converted into cash.
('5', 306, 3, 16, 695678) I must say that Omar Sheth is living a very simple life.
('5', 306, 3, 17, 695735) The house he lives in does not become a man of your status and reputation.
('5', 306, 3, 18, 695810) The food is likewise simple.
('5', 306, 3, 19, 695839) Besides, heis at present staying with me and living a more than usually austere life.
('5', 306, 3, 20, 695925) I am sometimes pained at this, but allow things to continue in the hope that he will ultimately benefit by it.
('5', 306, 3, 21, 696036) For example, last evening he only had bread, butter, papad and cocoa for dinner, and walked with me three and a half miles before turning in for the night.
('5', 306, 3, 22, 696192) I do not mean to suggest that you yourself should go to these lengths; but I do wish to say that your monthly expenses should not exceed £25. People will criticise you for cutting down on expenses, but such critics are really no friends at all, for they will not help you to run your household.
('5', 306, 3, 23, 696487) It is therefore the duty of those who realize their condition to think of the hard times and live accordingly.
('5', 306, 3, 24, 696598) What more shall I say?
('5', 306, 3, 25, 696621) I write in this strain because I wish well of you.
('5', 306, 3, 26, 696672) I hope you are all right.
('5', 306, 3, 27, 696698) The document pertaining to the sale deed which you have

('5', 307, 4, 9, 697334) 282. INDIA FOR INDIANS This today is the cry of thousands of voices in India.
('5', 307, 4, 10, 697412) No one can say that India is today the home of a single people, but all of us wish it were.
('5', 307, 4, 11, 697504) To bring this about, patriotic Indians have been suggesting all manner of remedies that occur to them.
('5', 307, 4, 12, 697607) Among such Indians is the editor of the Indian World—a well known monthly published from Calcutta.
('5', 307, 4, 13, 697706) He says that India will not become a single nation until most of the people in the various parts of the country speak a common language.
('5', 307, 4, 14, 697843) Though English speaking people are found in the different regions, their number is as yet small and will always remain so, for the main reason that, since it is a foreign language and a difficult one at that, the common people will not be able to learn it.
('5', 307, 4, 15, 698100) There is therefore little likelihood of India achieving nationhood through that language.
('5', 307, 4, 16, 698190) For this purpose, Indians will have to choose one of the Indian languages.
('5', 307, 4, 17, 698265) There are, of course, many Indians who can speak Gujarati, Bengali, Tamil and other languages; but there is hardly any chance of any of these spreading throughout the country.
('5', 307, 4, 18, 698441) One language remains, namely, Hindustani, which is spoken by North Indians.
('5', 307, 4, 19, 698517) Derived as it is from Sanskrit and Persian, it suits Hindus and Muslims alike.
('5', 307, 4, 20, 698596) Moreover, since the fakirs and the sanyasis both speak it, they help to propagate it throughout the land.
('5', 307, 4, 21, 698702) Many Englishmen too study it.
('5', 307, 4, 22, 698732) It is thus spoken over an extensive area.
('5', 307, 4, 23, 698774) The language itself is very sweet, polite and spirited.
('5', 307, 4, 24, 698830) Many books have been, and are still being, written in it.
('5', 307, 4, 25, 698888) The editor of the
('5', 308, 0, 1, 698906) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 309
('5', 308, 1, 2, 698953) Indian World therefore suggests that it should be taught in every school in India in addition to the mother tongue.
('5', 308, 1, 3, 699069) Parents too should inculcate the habit of speaking Hindustani to their children from their formative years.
('5', 308, 1, 4, 699177) Only then can India truly become a nation.
('5', 308, 1, 5, 699220) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 18 8 1906
('5', 308, 2, 6, 699262) 283. JOHANNESBURG LETTER
('5', 308, 3, 7, 699287) August 18, 1906
('5', 308, 4, 8, 699303) MR. BHABHA’S CASE
('5', 308, 5, 9, 699321) In deference to the counsel’s unfavourable opinion, the appeal in Mr. Mahomed Suliman Bhabha’s permit case, which was decided at Volksrust, has been withdrawn.
('5', 308, 5, 10, 699481) On the advice of his counsel, Mr. Bhabha refused to leave the Transvaal within the notified time and was therefore prosecuted again.
('5', 308, 5, 11, 699614) It was argued that the order passed by him could not prevent Mr. Bhabha from staying on in the Transvaal, as he had the right to enter the territory.
('5', 308, 5, 12, 699764) But the Magistrate did not accept this plea and sentenced Mr. Bhabha to a month’s simple imprisonment, the minimum laid down.
('5', 308, 5, 13, 699890) Mr. Bhabha has now appealed again, and it is believed that he will win.
('5', 308, 6, 14, 699962) IMPORTANT JUDGMENT IN LAND SUIT
('5', 308, 7, 15, 699994) This week, Sir William Smith has given an important decision on a petition presented to him.
('5', 308, 7, 16, 700087) The well known Sheth Mahomed Kasim Camroodeen of Johannesburg, whose entire land stood in the name of the late Mr. Chamberlain, wanted, on the latter’s death, to get it transferred to the name of another European.
('5', 308, 7, 17, 700301) On the Registrar’s refusal to do so, the Sheth approached the court for an order of transfer.
('5', 308, 7, 18, 700395) To begin with, Mr. Justice Smith himself raised an objection saying that the consent of the heir was necessary.
('5', 308, 7, 19, 700507) It was argued before Mr. Justice Smith that the heir had no claim on the land.
('5', 308, 7, 20, 700586) His Worship admitted the plea and issued orders for the transfer of the land to the name of the other European.
('5', 308, 7, 21, 700698) It will be seen from this that, if proper precautions are taken in keeping the land in the name of a European, the true owner does not have to suffer in any way.
('5', 308, 8, 22, 700860) THE MALAY LOCATION

('5', 309, 1, 3, 701265) The Committee has decided to challenge this reply [in a court of law].

('5', 309, 2, 5, 701378) 284. THE LATE MR. W. C. BONNERJEE
('5', 309, 3, 6, 701412) We regret to announce the death of Mr. Womesh Chunder Bonnerjee, one of the greatest Indian patriots of modern times.
('5', 309, 3, 7, 701530) The late Mr. Bonnerjee belonged to what may be called the Naoroji school of patriots, who devoted their time and talents to their country’s good.
('5', 309, 3, 8, 701676) Mr. Bonnerjee was one of the foremost barristers in Bengal, and at a very early stage of his career rose to fame by his forensic eloquence and legal acumen.
('5', 309, 3, 9, 701833) The unusual influence he thereby gained was used for the benefit of his country.
('5', 309, 3, 10, 701914) The deceased was one of the founders of the Indian National Congress, of which he was the first President, and which he served up to the last day of his life, using his purse freely for the public cause.
('5', 309, 3, 11, 702118) Mr. Bonnerjee had an abundant faith in western education, of which he was so fine a product.
('5', 309, 3, 12, 702211) He, therefore, bought a house in Croydon, where he passed half his time looking after the education of his children, with the result that the deceased statesman’s sons and daughters have received a liberal education, of which they have been making, like their father, a public use.
('5', 309, 3, 13, 702493) A life, such as Mr. Bonnerjee’s, teaches many a lesson to the present generation of Indian youth, and the best tribute that any Indian can render to the memory of the deceased is to copy his example.
('5', 309, 3, 14, 702693) We tender to the late Mr. Bonnerjee’s family our respectful sympathy.
('5', 309, 3, 15, 702763) Their loss is also India’s.
('5', 309, 3, 16, 702791) Indian Opinion, 25 8 1906
('5', 309, 4, 17, 702817) 285. A PLEA FOR DISTINCTION
('5', 309, 5, 18, 702845) The Johannesburg Star has lately had a very severe leader on “Coloured Hooliganism”.
('5', 309, 5, 19, 702930) The reflections of the leader writer arose out of the recent riots which have taken place in Cape Town.
('5', 309, 5, 20, 703034) Our contemporary has taken care to distinguish the “Coloured people” from the Malays and others who are also universally labelled
('5', 310, 0, 1, 703164) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 311
('5', 310, 1, 2, 703211) “Coloured”.
('5', 310, 1, 3, 703223) But there can be no doubt that, to the average newspaper reader, the term “Coloured people” has meant Malays, British Indians and all other Asiatics.
('5', 310, 1, 4, 703373) The very distinction drawn by The Star presupposes such a confusion in the public mind.
('5', 310, 1, 5, 703461) The result of classing Asiatics and others as “Coloured people” has caused a great deal of undeserved injustice to the British Indians in South Africa.
('5', 310, 1, 6, 703613) The most glaring instance is that given by Mr. Winston Churchill.
('5', 310, 1, 7, 703679) The deprivation of the franchise from the British Indians has been justified by the Colonial Under Secretary, on the ground that the Dutch understood the term “Natives”, that is, in this instance, “Coloured people”, to mean natives of any non European country.
('5', 310, 1, 8, 703940) Lord Milner, we know, has protested against any such use, or rather abuse, of the term, but his protest has not availed to protect them from the above mentioned injustice.
('5', 310, 1, 9, 704112) There are, at present, in the Statute books of the Transvaal and the Orange River Colony, laws which apply to British Indians, because, according to usage, the term “Coloured people” is applied to British Indians, although, from the nature of the legislation, one would consider it totally unnecessary to apply it to British Indians, who suffer doubly.
('5', 310, 1, 10, 704465) They labour under disabilities imposed upon “Coloured people” as also because they are Asiatics.
('5', 310, 1, 11, 704562) Thus, the illicit gold law and the foot path regulations of the Transvaal apply to them, because they are “Coloured people”, and the Law 3 of 1885 applies to them as Asiatics.
('5', 310, 1, 12, 704738) Their position, therefore, is actually worse than that of the “Coloured people” who are not Asiatics.
('5', 310, 1, 13, 704840) We think, in the illustrations given above, we have shown sufficiently clearly that, if justice is to be done to the British Indians, they should be no longer classed with the “Coloured people”.
('5', 310, 1, 14, 705035) And this we say without wishing to make any odious comparisons.
('5', 310, 1, 15, 705099) “Coloured people” and British Indians have different points of attack in their struggle for freedom of existence.
('5', 310, 1, 16, 705213) They have to secure justice through different channels and it were well if the Government and the publicists were to recognise the importance of distinguishing between the two.
('5', 310, 1, 17, 705390) Indian Opinion, 25 8 1906

('5', 311, 4, 18, 707169) The country’s entire revenue is at his disposal.

('5', 311, 4, 20, 707333) It is estimated that not only all this private wealth but the country’s annual revenue of a million and a half pounds has been squandered.
('5', 311, 4, 21, 707472) The country is daily being thus impoverished.
('5', 311, 4, 22, 707518) The main source of revenue is the working classes.
