('5', 312, 2, 4, 708127) 288. LETTER TO COLONIAL SECRETARY
('5', 312, 3, 5, 708161) JOHANNESBURG, August 25, 1906
('5', 312, 4, 6, 708191) TO THE HON.
('5', 312, 4, 7, 708203) THE COLONIAL SECRETARY PRETORIA SIR, I have the honour, on behalf of the British Indian Association, to enter its respectful protest against the Draft Asiatic Law Amendment Ordinance published in the Government Gazette dated the 22nd instant.
('5', 312, 4, 8, 708446) In the humble opinion of my Association, the Draft Ordinance in question is calculated to provoke the bitterest irritation among the Indian community and to wound its susceptibilities to an extent which it is difficult to measure.
('5', 312, 4, 9, 708677) The Draft, it is respectfully submitted, is a complete reversal of solemn promises repeatedly made by British administrators, and is in contravention of the despatches of Mr. Lyttelton and Lord Milner.
('5', 312, 4, 10, 708879) The Draft gives to the British Indians in the Transvaal absolutely nothing, and takes away from them much, and that too in a manner which, to use Mr. Chamberlain’s words, “puts an unnecessary affront” upon British Indian settlers in the Transvaal.
('5', 312, 4, 11, 709127) My Association respectfully urges that, if the object of the Draft Ordinance is to remove from the Colony any British Indians who may not be residing in it by lawful authority, an inspection of the documents at present possessed by them would absolutely meet the case without hurting the feelings of British Indians and without causing to the Colony a heavy expense which the machinery proposed by the Draft Ordinance must necessarily do.
('5', 312, 4, 12, 709566) My Association has no hesitation in saying that the Draft under discussion shews unmistakably the power possessed by a strong party
('5', 313, 0, 1, 709698) 314 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 313, 1, 2, 709740) over helpless men who have done nothing to offend the former and it shews a desire to wield that power with the greatest rigour and in total disregard of the feelings of the helpless victims.
('5', 313, 1, 3, 709932) This would appear to be strong language, but, examining it from the British Indian standpoint, the language used represents the honest convictions of those British Indians who have studied the Ordinance.
('5', 313, 1, 4, 710136) My Association draws the earnest attention of the Government to the following among other most objectionable features of the Draft Ordinance: (a) Section 2 sets the seal of approval on the part of the British Government on the insulting and false definition of the term “Asiatic” given by Law 3 of 1885, which ignorantly includes “the so called Coolies, Arabs, Malays, and Mahomedan subjects of the Turkish Dominion”.
('5', 313, 1, 5, 710554) Such a definition is degrading to the Asiatics, in that it takes note only of coolies and perpetuates the use of the term as applied to all the inhabitants of Asia.
('5', 313, 1, 6, 710719) The definition is false because there are hardly any Arabs and Mahomedan subjects of the Turkish Dominion, and does grave injustice to the Malays who have never yet been molested under Law 3 of 1885 and who have not suffered the misfortune in common with British Indians of being classed as competitors in trade with the Europeans.
('5', 313, 1, 7, 711051) (b) While the Draft subjects to innumerable pinpricks every Asiatic resident in the Colony, it leaves the position of the pre war residents of the Transvaal who have not yet returned to the Colony as indefinite, as vague and as painful as heretofore.
('5', 313, 1, 8, 711302) (c) It takes no note whatsoever of the elaborate registration carriedon by Captain Hamilton Fowle.
('5', 313, 1, 9, 711401) It may be here mentioned thatthe registration carried out by Captain Fowle was arranged in consultation with the Indian community, which, courteously and gracefully bowing to the advice given by Lord Milner, consented to the registration although, as was acknowledged, there was no legal sanction for it so far as those who had already paid the £3 to the old Government were concerned.
('5', 313, 1, 10, 711787) Of this, and all such voluntary acts of the community, the Draft Ordinance makes no acknowledgement.
('5', 313, 1, 11, 711888) (d) Section 3 deliberately narrows even the advantages enjoyed by the Indian community under the Peace Preservation Ordinance.
('5', 313, 1, 12, 712015) As the Government is well aware, there is a magisterial decision to the effect that possession of old Dutch registration certificates by a British Indian entitles him to enter the Colony without any further permit.
('5', 313, 1, 13, 712230) The effect of the decision would be nullified by sub section 2 of Section 3. (e) Whereas under Law 3 of 1885 and under the recent decision of the Supreme Court, only male adults who intend to settle in the
('5', 314, 0, 1, 712436) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 315
('5', 314, 1, 2, 712483) Transvaal for purposes of trade are required to undergo registration, the present Ordinance would compel every Indian, male and female, over the age of eight to be registered.
('5', 314, 1, 3, 712659) If the apprehension of my Association is correct, the Law will needlessly violate female modesty, as it is understood by millions of British Indians, and would ride roughshod over sentiments cherished dearly for ages by the community represented by my Association.
('5', 314, 1, 4, 712924) This law of registration, if it is carried into effect, would mean that His Majesty’s Government condemned every Indian as a criminal.
('5', 314, 1, 5, 713059) So far as my Association is aware, such a law is unknown within British Dominions so far as the free Indian population is concerned.
('5', 314, 1, 6, 713192) (f) The so called remission of the £3 fee is tantamount, in the humble opinion of my Association, to adding insult to injury, in that, almost all the Asiatics at present residing in the Colony are registered and have paid £3, in many cases twice over.
('5', 314, 1, 7, 713444) (g) Sub section 4 of Section 17, authorising the Lieutenant Governor to exempt a British Indian holder of a temporary permit from the provisions of the Liquor Licensing Ordinance, is an instance of another added insult to injury.
('5', 314, 1, 8, 713674) My Association is not aware of any self respecting Indian who would want the precious exemption.
('5', 314, 1, 9, 713771) It is possible to enumerate still further objectionable features of the proposed Ordinance, but my Association trusts that sufficient has been given above to shew what the Ordinance means to British Indians.
('5', 314, 1, 10, 713979) My Association will be pardoned for stating that the relief sought to be given by Section 21 is not recognised by the Indian community as such.
('5', 314, 1, 11, 714123) If the Government chooses to perform a simple duty towards a British subject by allowing him to own his inheritance, it is no relief to the community in general.
('5', 314, 1, 12, 714285) As to permitting fixed property to be held by British Indians for religious uses, my Association is advised that no provision is necessary in view of a decision given by the Witwatersrand High Court in a case recently adjudicated.
('5', 314, 1, 13, 714516) Responsible Government will soon be established in the Colony.
('5', 314, 1, 14, 714579) My Association, therefore, respectfully urges that, if the Government does not intend to grant any real and substantial relief in accordance with the oft plighted word of British administrators, Law 3 of 1885 may be allowed to remain undisturbed, and the Responsible Government may be left to deal with the whole position in

('5', 315, 2, 4, 715119) 289. LONG LIVE THE GRAND OLD MAN 1
('5', 315, 3, 5, 715154) The fourth of September will be the eighty second birthday of the Honourable Dadabhai Naoroji, the veteran patriot of India, who is its “Grand Old Man” as not even the late Mr. Gladstone was of England.
('5', 315, 3, 6, 715357) The spectacle of Mr. Naoroji tirelessly fighting India’s battles, hoping against hope, living a life of self imposed exile and of incessant energy that would do credit to a youth of twenty five, is magnificent, ennobling and inspiring.
('5', 315, 3, 7, 715593) No one can, with any justification, talk of India as in its decline when it produces even one such life as Mr. Naoroji’s.
('5', 315, 3, 8, 715715) To him, India’s service is the breath of life.
('5', 315, 3, 9, 715762) It is his religion and it is his one occupation.
('5', 315, 3, 10, 715811) He has dedicated his all to India as no one else has.
('5', 315, 3, 11, 715865) We cannot but think that it is his intense love and devotion to the cause which enable him to bear his years so lightly as he has done.
('5', 315, 3, 12, 716001) Shall we say it is also a result of divine pleasure over so much pure sacrifice of self?
('5', 315, 3, 13, 716090) To us in South Africa, a life such as this teaches many a lesson and we can render no greater homage and offer no more sincere prayer for yet more divine pleasure to be bestowed upon the Grand Old Man than by endeavouring to copy the life that Mr. Naoroji has placed before all India.
('5', 315, 3, 14, 716375) We feel certain, in fact we know, that nothing will give him greater pleasure than to know that we cherish his life’s work and that we want to follow in his footsteps, and that even after the grave has closed over him, he will live in our memories and in our deeds.
('5', 315, 3, 15, 716641) Those that are connected with this journal have in many of their trials been uplifted by the remembrance of this one name.
('5', 315, 3, 16, 716764) Indeed, the enterprise has been possible only because of the great example set by the noblest Indian patriot living.
('5', 315, 3, 17, 716881) Our heartfelt prayer goes to the Almighty for a long life to the Grand Old Man of India.

('5', 316, 1, 2, 717168) 290. ABOMINABLE!
('5', 316, 2, 3, 717185) Abominable is a very strong adjective to use in respect of any act, and yet we can find, even after calmly considering it, no other term equally fitting to characterise the Draft Asiatic Ordinance published in the Transvaal Government Gazette Extraordinary dated the 22nd inst.
('5', 316, 2, 4, 717463) This is in compliance with Mr. Duncan’s forecast given at the time of the adjournment of the Legislative Council of the Transvaal.
('5', 316, 2, 5, 717594) The worst fears of the Indian community of the Transvaal have been realised by the Bill under discussion.
('5', 316, 2, 6, 717700) It is in violation of many a sacred promise made to the unfortunate Indians residing in that Colony.
('5', 316, 2, 7, 717801) It sets at nought the British principle of justice and fairplay, and it tramples upon the ordinary ideas of right and wrong as they have been known 1 to mankind for ages past.
('5', 316, 2, 8, 717977) We give in another column the strongly worded protest of the British Indian Association 2 but the language used in it is none too strong even for an official document.
('5', 316, 2, 9, 718145) The Ordinance goes much further than we had anticipated from Mr. Duncan’s language.
('5', 316, 2, 10, 718229) It unsettles the Indian mind as no other measure in South Africa has ever done before.
('5', 316, 2, 11, 718316) It threatens to invade the sanctity of home life.
('5', 316, 2, 12, 718366) Before it, Law 3 of 1885 pales into utter insignificance.
('5', 316, 2, 13, 718424) The most pitiful part of it consists in the fact that what the Boer Government did in ignorance of facts and without meaning to do much harm and in respect of persons not its own subjects, the British Government is doing with the fullest knowledge of facts with the deliberate intention of injuring the Indian community and in respect of British subjects.
('5', 316, 2, 14, 718780) In its method, the present Government intends to surpass the Boer Government and it would now bring under the clutches of the law those who were outside it under the Dutch rule, namely, women, children and non traders.
('5', 316, 2, 15, 718999) We are much pained to notice that our contemporary, the Johannesburg Star, welcomes the measure and actually gloats over its stringency.
('5', 316, 2, 16, 719136) It betrays ignorance of the existing law and, therefore, deals with generalities, dignifying by the name of `’concession” that which the Indian community interprets as an insult.
('5', 316, 2, 17, 719315) In The Star language, exemption from the Liquor Licensing Ordinance vouchsafed to “distinguished Asiatic visitors” is a “sensible modification”.
('5', 316, 2, 18, 719460) Such language in a paper edited by an ex private secretary of an ex High Commissioner for South Africa leaves little hope of justice being done by the present

('5', 316, 3, 21, 719654) 2 Vide “Letter to Colonial Secretary”, 25 8 1906

('5', 317, 2, 7, 720427) 291. COLONIAL INDIANS, NOTE!
('5', 317, 3, 8, 720456) Herr Adolph Stein speaks as follows of the trials of the German soldier: The lack of railways (in South West Africa) has made it impossible for bigger supplies to be taken to the front and the troops have been on short rations since the beginning of the campaign which has now continued for two years and a half.
('5', 317, 3, 9, 720769) The men have been without bread and salt for months together and there have been times when they have lived on the flesh of mules.
('5', 317, 3, 10, 720900) These mules which were intended to drag the artillery had to be slaughtered to supply the starving soldiers with rations.
('5', 317, 3, 11, 721022) The men have frequently fought or marched for forty hours without a drop of water or other beverage.
('5', 317, 3, 12, 721123) Their uniforms are torn to shreds and have been replaced by all sorts of odds and ends of clothing, giving the troops a shabby appearance.
('5', 317, 3, 13, 721262) Their shoes are worn out and have been replaced by sandals made from the hides of slaughtered oxen.
('5', 317, 3, 14, 721362) Notwithstanding all these hardships, the troops have performed their duty without flinching.
('5', 317, 3, 15, 721455) There is a world of meaning to be read into these sentences by Indians in South Africa and particularly those who have been born and bred in this sub continent.
('5', 317, 3, 16, 721616) It must be remembered that these soldiers are, some of them, drawn from men ordinarily engaged in civil occupation.
('5', 317, 3, 17, 721732) No country has become great without its inhabitants undergoing hardships and self sacrifice.
('5', 317, 3, 18, 721825) We often talk of the disabilities of British Indians in South Africa and we have a right to complain about them and to seek redress, but, as an esteemed friend wrote in these columns a few months ago, salvation of British Indians will ultimately have to come from within, and that will only be done when the rising generation of Indians recognise their communal duty and are prepared to undergo trials and difficulties even as German soldiers are now doing in South West Africa.
('5', 317, 3, 19, 722304) Indian Opinion, 1 9 1906
('5', 318, 0, 1, 722329) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 319
('5', 318, 1, 2, 722376) 292. THE CAPE LICENCES ACT
('5', 318, 2, 3, 722403) From the Cape Government Gazette of the 21st inst., we notice that the Cape Licences Bill has become an Act of Parliament and henceforth Indian traders, as indeed all other traders, will come under its operation.
('5', 318, 2, 4, 722616) The Bill has undergone so many alterations that it is no longer possible to detect the original measure in the Act.
('5', 318, 2, 5, 722732) In some respects it is undoubtedly harsh.
('5', 318, 2, 6, 722774) The right of appeal to the Supreme Court has not been definitely taken away, but it is a moot question whether the decision that may be given by the Licensing Boards will be capable of being reviewed by the Supreme Court.
('5', 318, 2, 7, 722996) Moreover, the safeguard that was left to intending applicants by the original Bill, by way of securing the consent of a majority of rate payers, has been taken away.
('5', 318, 2, 8, 723162) At the same time, the requirement as to the books being kept in English has been removed.
('5', 318, 2, 9, 723252) We, however, never attached any importance to the clause; it was harmless, and we may here point out that, although there is nothing stated as to the keeping of books, it will be quite proper for the Municipal authorities to decline to grant licences if the applicants could not shew to their satisfaction that they are able to keep an intelligible record of their transactions.
('5', 318, 2, 10, 723631) We have always recognised as legitimate a well regulated control over trading licences.
('5', 318, 2, 11, 723719) We, therefore, think that the Act should receive a fair trial.
('5', 318, 2, 12, 723782) Much will, however, depend upon the manner [in] which the Licensing Boards will use their newly acquired powers.
('5', 318, 2, 13, 723895) In the words of the late Mr. Escombe, we trust that, having received “a giant’s strength”, they will not use it as giants, but temper justice with mercy.
('5', 318, 2, 14, 724049) Indian Opinion, 1 9 1906

('5', 320, 1, 2, 726117) 295. KODAMA, THE HERO OF JAPAN
('5', 320, 2, 3, 726148) General Kodama died suddenly last month in Tokyo without suffering any illness.
('5', 320, 2, 4, 726228) He was born in the Samurai or Kshatriya class of Japan, and was naturally therefore an able soldier.
('5', 320, 2, 5, 726329) He was moreover a well known strategist.
('5', 320, 2, 6, 726370) By his death the Japanese army has suffered a great loss.
('5', 320, 2, 7, 726428) Kodama joined the Japanese army in 1872, where his ability quickly attracted notice and he rose rapidly, becoming Lieutenant Colonel in 1880. He became General in 1904. During the last Russo Japanese’ War, he was Marshal Oyama’s chief lieutenant.
('5', 320, 2, 8, 726675) True to the nature of the Japanese people, he remained very patient and serene in war and was never impetuous.
('5', 320, 2, 9, 726786) When, in the bloody battle of Layoyang, the Russian army made a fierce charge on the Japanese, he was at breakfast.
('5', 320, 2, 10, 726902) As the Russians were marching towards General Kodama’s camp:, his men, concerned for the safety of their General, requested him to shift to another place.
('5', 320, 2, 11, 727057) He replied that this he could never do, adding that, if his soldiers came to know he had left the front line, they might waver and lose heart.
('5', 320, 2, 12, 727200) It was therefore better for him to remain where he was.
('5', 320, 2, 13, 727256) This brave conduct of the leader gave the soldiers courage and enabled them to repel the Russian attack.
('5', 320, 2, 14, 727361) In build and appearance, General Kodama resembled an Englishman.
('5', 320, 2, 15, 727426) Sixteen years ago, he was sent to Europe by the Japanese Government to study western techniques of warfare.
('5', 320, 2, 16, 727534) He gave proof of his proficiency during the last Chinese War.
('5', 320, 2, 17, 727596) In appreciation of his services in that war, the Mikado made him a Baron.
('5', 320, 2, 18, 727670) He was considered a capable man in Japan and it was expected that he would one day become Prime Minister.
('5', 320, 2, 19, 727776) He was 53 when he died.
('5', 320, 2, 20, 727800) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 1 9 1906

('5', 322, 5, 9, 731353) 297. JOHANNESBURG LETTER
('5', 322, 6, 10, 731378) September 3, 1906 THE INTERVIEW WITH MR. DUNCAN On Mr. Duncan expressing a desire to meet the Indian deputation regarding the Asiatic Act, Messrs Abdul Gani, Essop Mian, Hajee Ojer Ally, Peter Moonlight and Gandhi, who were deputed by the Committee of the British Indian Association for this purpose, went to Pretoria last Saturday; there they were joined by Mr. Haji Habib on behalf of the Pretoria Committee.
('5', 322, 6, 11, 731789) Mr. Duncan saw them at 11 a.m.
('5', 322, 6, 12, 731820) Before writing further on the subject, I must say that their troubles began even as they got into the morning train that leaves at 8 30. Mr. Chamney, who had agreed to make all the arrangements at the station, had for his part no doubt done so.
('5', 322, 6, 13, 732065) But neither the station master nor the conductor knew anything about them.
('5', 322, 6, 14, 732140) The latter became obstructive, arguing that they had come without previous notice.
('5', 322, 6, 15, 732223) Finally, however, the members were accommodated in a second class compartment up to Germiston, whence they were able to have a first class carriage.
('5', 322, 6, 16, 732372) There ensued a long discussion with Mr. Duncan.
('5', 322, 6, 17, 732420) The deputation told him that the Asiatic Act would be unacceptable to the Indian community under any circumstances and that re registration would simply not take place.
('5', 322, 6, 18, 732589) It was tyrannical that, in response to the community’s plea for relief, the Government should attempt to enforce a harsher law.
('5', 322, 6, 19, 732717) It was unthinkable that women and children should be registered.
('5', 322, 6, 20, 732782) Registration was not necessary during the Dutch regime, and besides, the practice does not obtain elsewhere
('5', 322, 7, 21, 732890) 1 The postscript, in Gujarati, is in Gandhiji’s hand.

('5', 323, 6, 16, 734159) 299. CRIMINAL
('5', 323, 7, 17, 734173) We have already described the Asiatic Draft Ordinance of the Transvaal Government as abominable.
('5', 323, 7, 18, 734270) 2 A closer examination of the Ordinance and the complaints we have received about it require the use of an even stronger epithet regarding the proposed action of the Government.
('5', 323, 7, 19, 734448) It will be a crime against humanity if it is persisted in.
('5', 323, 8, 20, 734507) 1 The letter, though begun on September 3, was completed on or after September 4. 2 Vide “Abominable!”, 1 9 1906
('5', 324, 0, 1, 734620) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 325
('5', 324, 1, 2, 734667) There are, to day, not more than 13,000 Indians all told, including women and children, in the Transvaal.
('5', 324, 1, 3, 734773) Women and children do not possess any documents authorising them to enter the country because the permit regulations do not require them.
('5', 324, 1, 4, 734911) They are, however, not lawful residents of the Transvaal, according to the definition given to permits by the Ordinance.
('5', 324, 1, 5, 735032) Will they, then, be banished from the Colony and torn from their husbands, or parents, as the case may be?
('5', 324, 1, 6, 735139) Perhaps not.
('5', 324, 1, 7, 735152) All the same, power is given to the department concerned with the administration of the Ordinance to subject women and children to indignities, and even to banish them.
('5', 324, 1, 8, 735321) Immemorial experience shews that arbitrary power left in the hands of the best possible men tends to lower their humanity and makes them, very often in spite of themselves, do things which, under other circumstances of greater responsibility, they would not have done.
('5', 324, 1, 9, 735590) The Christian Teacher, whose tenets the Government of the Transvaal, we suppose, professes to follow, only uttered simple truth when He decried temptation.
('5', 324, 1, 10, 735746) Nor is this all.
('5', 324, 1, 11, 735763) The effect of the Ordinance will be to impugn the validity of every permit and registration certificate issued before the date of the Ordinance, that is to say, every holder of these documents will have to appear before the Registrar of Asiatics and satisfy that official that he is the lawful holder.
('5', 324, 1, 12, 736065) Indians in the Transvaal know what this means; they will be subjected to all kinds of unnecessary and often insulting questions, and they will have to undergo a very strict examination before they receive a third certificate.
('5', 324, 1, 13, 736291) And what is the reason for all this?
('5', 324, 1, 14, 736328) Why, [it is] that some few Indians, whose moral sensibilities have been blunted by official folly and needless severity, have entered the Colony of the Transvaal without authority.
('5', 324, 1, 15, 736509) The only apparent reason for this Ordinance is to cover hopeless incompetence in the administration of the present laws, which, we maintain, are sufficient to meet all cases of fraudulent entrance.
('5', 324, 1, 16, 736707) There is, in the Peace Preservation Ordinance, a clause which enables officials appointed thereunder to inspect permits, and non production of same renders persons inspected liable to be arrested and ultimately deported from the Colony.
('5', 324, 1, 17, 736944) Failure to leave the Colony carries with it a very heavy penalty.
('5', 324, 1, 18, 737010) We hold that these clauses, wisely employed, would soon shew how far the statements of the anti Asiatic agitators are borne out.
('5', 324, 1, 19, 737139) It is curious that, instead of employing this efficient instrument at its disposal, the Government has devised degrading legislation in order to find out whether there are any persons who have surreptitiously entered the Colony.
('5', 324, 1, 20, 737368) A correspondent, of nineteen years’ standing in the Transvaal, has asked a pertinent question in the Gujarati columns which we
('5', 325, 0, 1, 737495) 326 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 325, 1, 2, 737537) translate in another place in this issue, asking what is the difference between Russian rule and British rule a la Transvaal.
('5', 325, 1, 3, 737663) The difference, in our opinion, lies in the fact that, whereas, in Russia, when it suits the authorities, they do not hesitate to murder people openly and directly, in the Transvaal, because the authorities wish to do away with Indians, but cannot do so openly and honestly, instead of resorting to the direct method of murdering them or banishing them from the Colony, they intend to kill them by inches.
('5', 325, 1, 4, 738069) They would devise means which exasperate even the mild Indian into leaving the country of his own accord or adopting means which serve the same purpose.
('5', 325, 1, 5, 738222) And so the authorities are able unctuously to declare: “We are not guilty of the civil murder of these men—they left of their own accord.” We present this thought to the Government for its earnest consideration, and ask it now, whilst there is yet time, to withdraw from an utterly false position.
('5', 325, 1, 6, 738520) Indian Opinion, 8 9 1906
('5', 325, 2, 7, 738545) 300. THE GRAND OLD MAN
('5', 325, 3, 8, 738568) The various associations in South Africa have simply done their duty by forwarding congratulatory messages to the Honourable Dadabhai Naoroji on his eighty second birthday.
('5', 325, 3, 9, 738741) 1 This birthday anniversary has become a day of national rejoicing throughout India, and Indian life in South Africa seems to us to be incomplete without a reproduction, on however humble a scale, of what has been going on in India for years in connection with the birthday anniversary of the one man who is enshrined in the hearts of millions of Indians as is no other man at the present day.
('5', 325, 3, 10, 739135) These voluntary offerings must be a matter of very great solace to the aged patriot, and it cannot but further the work that he has been doing so ungrudgingly for over half a century.
('5', 325, 3, 11, 739319) We hope that, having commenced it, Indians in South Africa will make the sending of these messages an annual feature, and hope that they will be privileged, for many years to come, to be able to commemorate the day.
('5', 325, 3, 12, 739535) We publish with this issue a supplement, containing a portrait of the Hon.
('5', 325, 3, 13, 739610) Dadabhai Naoroji.

('5', 326, 1, 2, 739755) 301. RUSSIA AND INDIA
('5', 326, 2, 3, 739777) Mr. Essop Mian recently compared [conditions under] British rule in the Transvaal with the state of affairs prevailing in Russia.
('5', 326, 2, 4, 739907) 1 Such a comparison is indeed worth making.
('5', 326, 2, 5, 739951) Just as the Russian people are tyrannised over by government officials, so are Indians in the Transvaal.
('5', 326, 2, 6, 740056) People are openly assaulted and killed in Russia.
('5', 326, 2, 7, 740106) Under British rule, the harm inflicted on the people is, as in the case of a rat bite, not immediately noticeable, but it may be said that the ultimate effect is just as bad.
('5', 326, 2, 8, 740281) It is interesting to compare the reactions of the Russian people to tyranny with our own reaction to it.
('5', 326, 2, 9, 740386) Under British rule, we draft petitions, carry on a struggle through the Press, and seek justice from the King.
('5', 326, 2, 10, 740497) All this is perfectly proper.
('5', 326, 2, 11, 740527) It is necessary, and it also brings us some relief.
('5', 326, 2, 12, 740579) But is there anything else that we should do?
('5', 326, 2, 13, 740625) And, can we do it?
('5', 326, 2, 14, 740644) We shall think of these questions later.
('5', 326, 2, 15, 740685) For the present, let us see what Russia is doing.
('5', 326, 2, 16, 740735) The people there, both rich and poor, do not send petitions and stop there.
('5', 326, 2, 17, 740811) The oppression there is such that it has given rise to a number of anarchists.
('5', 326, 2, 18, 740890) They believe that all rulers are oppressive, and the State should therefore be done away with.
('5', 326, 2, 19, 740985) To achieve this end, people in Russia kill the officials openly as well as secretly.
('5', 326, 2, 20, 741070) In this, however, they are making a mistake.
('5', 326, 2, 21, 741115) Such thoughtless adventures only serve to keep the minds of both the rulers and the ruled in a state of constant tension.
('5', 326, 2, 22, 741237) All the same, it is admitted on all hands that men taking such risks must be brave and patriotic.
('5', 326, 2, 23, 741335) Even young girls set out on such adventures and court risks.
('5', 326, 2, 24, 741396) A book was recently published about the lives of young women who have thus made themselves immortal.
('5', 326, 2, 25, 741497) Knowing that death is certain, these fearless girls, actuated by patriotism and a spirit of self sacrifice, take the lives of those whom they believe to be the enemies of the country, and themselves meet an agonising death at the hands of officials.
('5', 326, 2, 26, 741747) Facing such risks, they serve their country selflessly.
('5', 326, 2, 27, 741803) It will be no wonder if such a country succeeds in achieving freedom from tyranny.
('5', 326, 2, 28, 741886) The only reason why it has not become free immediately is that such patriotism is misdirected, as we have pointed out before, and results in bloodshed.
('5', 326, 2, 29, 742038) In consequence, these people cannot, according to divine law, obtain any immediate benefit.
('5', 326, 2, 30, 742130) Do our people display patriotism of this order?
('5', 326, 2, 31, 742178) We have regretfully to say “No”.
('5', 326, 2, 32, 742211) No one can be blamed, for we have not yet
('5', 326, 3, 33, 742253) 1 Vide Indian Opinion, 8 9 1906.
('5', 327, 0, 1, 742286) 328 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 327, 1, 2, 742328) been trained for this.
('5', 327, 1, 3, 742351) We are children in political matters.
('5', 327, 1, 4, 742389) We do not understand the principle that the public good is also one’s own good.
('5', 327, 1, 5, 742469) But the time has now come for us to outgrow this state of mind.
('5', 327, 1, 6, 742533) We need not, however, resort to violence.
('5', 327, 1, 7, 742575) Neither need we set out on adventures, risking our lives.
('5', 327, 1, 8, 742633) We must, however, submit our bodies topain, and the new Transvaal Ordinance offers an excellent opportunity.
('5', 327, 1, 9, 742742) The Ordinance represents the limit of oppression.
('5', 327, 1, 10, 742792) It is not for us to punish those who made that Ordinance.
('5', 327, 1, 11, 742850) If we did that, we would be as much at fault as the Russians.
('5', 327, 1, 12, 742912) Indians are a meek people, and we wish they will always remain so.
('5', 327, 1, 13, 742979) What, then, should we do?
('5', 327, 1, 14, 743005) The answer to this question has been given by the Indian deputation to Mr. Duncan.
('5', 327, 1, 15, 743088) They have told him that if, disregarding our attempts at gentle persuasion, the Government enforces the Ordinance, Indians will not abide by it; they will not [re ]register themselves, nor will they pay fines; they will rather go to gaol.
('5', 327, 1, 16, 743327) We believe that, if the Indians in the Transvaal firmly stick to this resolution, they will at once be free of their shackles.
('5', 327, 1, 17, 743454) The gaol will then be like a palace to them.
('5', 327, 1, 18, 743499) Instead of being a disgrace, going to gaol will enhance their prestige.
('5', 327, 1, 19, 743571) And the Government, for its part, will realize that it cannot with impunity go on humiliating Indians.
('5', 327, 1, 20, 743674) What we do not do, besides addressing petitions—though we ought to do it—is that we will not sacrifice our bodily comforts.
('5', 327, 1, 21, 743798) We give ourselves over to physical pleasures and cannot give them up.
('5', 327, 1, 22, 743868) It is our duty to make some sacrifice for the sake of others.
('5', 327, 1, 23, 743930) We do not realize that there is real beauty in this: that it is thus that we please God and do our true duty.
('5', 327, 1, 24, 744040) The resolution 1 about the deputation [to England] is an excellent step.
('5', 327, 1, 25, 744113) We hope that the Indians will not miss this golden opportunity and that every one of them in South Africa will support it.
('5', 327, 1, 26, 744236) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 8 9 1906

('5', 330, 1, 2, 747891) 307. SPEECH ON THE “BLACK ACT”
('5', 330, 2, 3, 747922) At a meeting of some leading Indians held to consider the draft Asiatic Law Amendment Ordinance, Gandhiji explained its full implications.
('5', 330, 2, 4, 748061) It shocked them as it had shocked Gandhiji.
('5', 330, 2, 5, 748105) All present then resolved to hold a public meeting and consider and adopt measures to fight the “Black Act”.
('5', 330, 2, 6, 748214) The following is Gandhiji’s own reconstruction of the speech which, like the one at the mass meeting on September 11, (vide pp.
('5', 330, 2, 7, 748342) 419 22), brings out the importance he attached to defiance of an unjust law.
('5', 330, 2, 8, 748419) [JOHANNESBURG, Before September 9, 1906] This is a very serious crisis.
('5', 330, 2, 9, 748491) If the Ordinance were passed and if we acquiesced in it, it would be imitated all over South Africa.
('5', 330, 2, 10, 748592) As it seems to me, it is designed to strike at the very root of our existence in South Africa.
('5', 330, 2, 11, 748687) It is not the last step, but the first step with a view to hound us out of the country.
('5', 330, 2, 12, 748775) We are therefore responsible for the safety, not only of the ten or fifteen thousand Indians in the Transvaal but of the entire Indian community in South Africa.
('5', 330, 2, 13, 748937) Again, if we fully understand all the implications of this legislation, we shall find that India’s honour is in our keeping.
('5', 330, 2, 14, 749062) For the Ordinance seeks to humiliate not only ourselves but also the motherland.
('5', 330, 2, 15, 749143) The humiliation consists in the degradation of innocent men.
('5', 330, 2, 16, 749204) No one will take it upon himself to say that we have done anything to deserve such legislation.
('5', 330, 2, 17, 749300) We are innocent, and insult offered to a single innocent member of a nation is tantamount to insulting the nation as a whole.
('5', 330, 2, 18, 749426) It will not, therefore, do to be hasty, impatient or angry.
('5', 330, 2, 19, 749486) That cannot save us from this onslaught.
('5', 330, 2, 20, 749527) But God will come to our help, if we calmly think out and carry out in time measures of resistance, presenting a united front and bearing the hardship, which such resistance brings in its train.
('5', 330, 3, 21, 749722) M. K. Gandhi: Satyagraha in South Africa, Chapter XI; S. Ganesan, Madras; 1928

('5', 331, 0, 1, 750082) 332 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 331, 1, 2, 750124) JOHANNESBURG, September 9, 1906 We have received a reply to our cable 1 to the Colonial Secretary.
('5', 331, 1, 3, 750223) (Mr. Gandhi here read out the reply.) I have also cabled to London 2 according to instructions.
('5', 331, 1, 4, 750319) There is now no alternative to sending a deputation, because an intolerable and wicked law is being forced upon us; and we must not put up with it.
('5', 331, 1, 5, 750467) As it is, our plight in the Transvaal is very bad, and now comes this vicious Draft Ordinance.
('5', 331, 1, 6, 750562) My advice, therefore, is that we should not seek fresh registration.
('5', 331, 1, 7, 750631) Let the accusation of breaking the law fall on us.
('5', 331, 1, 8, 750682) Let us cheerfully suffer imprisonment.
('5', 331, 1, 9, 750721) There is nothing wrong in that.
('5', 331, 1, 10, 750753) The distinctive virtue of the British is bravery.
('5', 331, 1, 11, 750803) If therefore we also unite and offer resistance with courage and firmness, I am sure there is nothing that the Government can do.
('5', 331, 1, 12, 750933) Even the half castes and Kaffirs, who are less advanced than we, have resisted the Government.
('5', 331, 1, 13, 751028) The pass law applies to them as well, but they do not take out passes.
('5', 331, 1, 14, 751099) I do not want to say more.
('5', 331, 1, 15, 751126) I would only advise you not to register yourselves again.
('5', 331, 1, 16, 751184) If the Government sends us to gaol, I shall be the first to court imprisonment.
('5', 331, 1, 17, 751264) And if any Indian is put to trouble because of his refusal to register afresh in accordance with the Draft Ordinance, I will appear in his case free of charge.
('5', 331, 1, 18, 751424) On Tuesday next, we are holding a mass meeting, and I expect you all to close your business on that day and attend it.
('5', 331, 1, 19, 751543) Having explained all this at length, Mr. Gandhi made a few suggestions for collecting funds quickly, appointing a new committee to look after the funds and publishing the accounts every month.
('5', 331, 1, 20, 751736) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 22 9 1906
('5', 331, 2, 21, 751778) 309. THE MASS MEETING
('5', 331, 3, 22, 751800) A mass meeting of British Indians was held to protest against the draft Asiatic Law Amendment Ordinance.
('5', 331, 3, 23, 751905) Abdul Gani, Chairman, British Indian Association, presided.
('5', 331, 3, 24, 751965) Several speakers opposed the Ordinance and called for non compliance in case it became law.
('5', 331, 3, 25, 752057) The following is a report of Gandhiji’s speech:
('5', 331, 4, 26, 752105) 1 This is not available.
('5', 331, 4, 27, 752130) 2 Vide “Cable to Secretary of State for Colonies”, 8 9 1906
('5', 332, 0, 1, 752190) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 333
('5', 332, 1, 2, 752237) JOHANNESBURG, September 11, 1906 Mr. M. K. Gandhi, (Johannesburg), Hony.
('5', 332, 1, 3, 752310) Secretary of the British Indian Association, then addressed the meeting.
('5', 332, 1, 4, 752383) He pointed out that by some critics it might be thought that there was a defect in the chain of reasoning as outlined by their resolutions, because they asked for redress of their grievances, and then went on immediately to threaten to go to gaol if their prayer was not granted.
('5', 332, 1, 5, 752663) He contended, however, that there was no real flaw in the chain, because they were not holding out a threat.
('5', 332, 1, 6, 752772) It was merely a question of one ounce of practice which was worth whole tons of speeches and writings.
('5', 332, 1, 7, 752875) He had thought the matter over seriously and earnestly before he had given his opinion upon the step they should take, and he felt that it was their bounden duty to adopt the course laid down if their prayer was not granted.
('5', 332, 1, 8, 753100) He contended that every adjective used that day was justified for the occasion, and said that if he could find a stronger adjective he would use it.
('5', 332, 1, 9, 753249) He had studied the whole of the anti Asiatic legislation throughout South Africa; but he never, in the whole course of his experience, came across anything like this present Ordinance.
('5', 332, 1, 10, 753434) Even the legislation of the O.R.C., drastic as it was, was far superior to that now introduced here, which was so bad that no self respecting Indian could live under it.
('5', 332, 1, 11, 753604) He admitted that the responsibility for the serious step he had taken was upon his shoulders, and he took the responsibility in its entirety.
('5', 332, 1, 12, 753746) He felt he had done the right thing in advising them to take this step as loyal British subjects.
('5', 332, 1, 13, 753844) In all their action in this respect they were full of loyalty.
('5', 332, 1, 14, 753907) No shadow of disloyalty could rest upon them.
('5', 332, 1, 15, 753953) Some people might say that they were foolish, and he would say that their action was foolish if he had not full confidence in his fellow countrymen.
('5', 332, 1, 16, 754102) But he knew them; he knew that he could trust them, and he knew also that, when occasion required an heroic step to be taken,—he knew that every man among them would take it.
('5', 332, 1, 17, 754277) (Loud Cheers.) Indian Opinion, 22 9 1906
('5', 332, 2, 18, 754318) At the meeting, Haji Habib proposed that they should take a solemn oath to oppose the Ordinance.
('5', 332, 2, 19, 754415) Explaining the implications of the suggestion, Gandhiji made a speech, which he recapitulates in Satyagraha in South Africa: I wish to explain to this meeting that there is a vast difference between this resolution and every other resolution we have passed upto date and that there is a wide divergence also in the manner of making it.
('5', 332, 2, 20, 754751) It is a very grave resolution we are making, as our existence in South Africa depends upon our fully observing it.
('5', 332, 2, 21, 754866) The manner of making the resolution suggested by our friend is as much of a novelty as of a solemnity.
('5', 332, 2, 22, 754969) I did not come to the meeting with a view to getting
('5', 333, 0, 1, 755022) 334 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 333, 1, 2, 755064) the resolution passed in that manner, which redounds to the credit of Sheth Haji Habib as well as it [sic] lays a burden of responsibility upon him.
('5', 333, 1, 3, 755213) I tender my congratulations to him.
('5', 333, 1, 4, 755249) I deeply appreciate his suggestion, but if you adopt it you too will share his responsibility.
('5', 333, 1, 5, 755344) You must understand what is this responsibility, and as an adviser and servant of the community, it is my duty fully to explain it to you.
('5', 333, 1, 6, 755483) We all believe in one and the same God, the differences of nomenclature in Hinduism and Islam notwithstanding.
('5', 333, 1, 7, 755594) To pledge ourselves or to take an oath in the name of that God or with Him as witness is not something to be trifled with.
('5', 333, 1, 8, 755717) If having taken such an oath we violate our pledge we are guilty before God and man.
('5', 333, 1, 9, 755802) Personally I hold that a man, who deliberately and intelligently takes a pledge and then breaks it, forfeits his manhood.
('5', 333, 1, 10, 755924) And just as a copper coin treated with mercury not only becomes valueless when found out but also makes its owner liable to punishment, in the same way a man who lightly pledges his word and then breaks it becomes a man of straw and fits himself for punishment here as well as hereafter.
('5', 333, 1, 11, 756212) Sheth Haji Habib is proposing to administer an oath of such a serious character.
('5', 333, 1, 12, 756293) There is no one in this meeting who can be classed as an infant or as wanting in understanding.
('5', 333, 1, 13, 756389) You are all well advanced in age and have seen the world; many of you are delegates and have discharged responsibilities in a greater or lesser measure.
('5', 333, 1, 14, 756542) No one present, therefore, can ever hope to excuse himself by saying that he did not know what he was about when he took the oath.
('5', 333, 1, 15, 756673) I know that pledges and vows are, and should be, taken on rare occasions.
('5', 333, 1, 16, 756747) A man who takes a vow every now and then is sure to stumble.
('5', 333, 1, 17, 756808) But if I can imagine a crisis in the history of the Indian community of South Africa when it would be in the fitness of things to take pledges, that crisis is surely now.
('5', 333, 1, 18, 756979) There is wisdom in taking serious steps with great caution and hesitation.
('5', 333, 1, 19, 757054) But caution and hesitation have their limits, which we have now passed.
('5', 333, 1, 20, 757126) The Government has taken leave of all sense of decency.
('5', 333, 1, 21, 757182) We would only be betraying our unworthiness and cowardice, if we cannot stake our all in the face of the conflagration which envelopes us and sit watching it with folded hands.
('5', 333, 1, 22, 757359) There is no doubt, therefore, that the present is a proper occasion for taking pledges.
('5', 333, 1, 23, 757447) But every one of us must think out for himself if he has the will and the ability to pledge himself.
('5', 333, 1, 24, 757548) Resolutions of this nature cannot be passed by a majority vote.
('5', 333, 1, 25, 757612) Only those who take a pledge can be bound by it.
('5', 333, 1, 26, 757661) This pledge must not be taken with a view to produce an effect on outsiders.
('5', 333, 1, 27, 757738) No one should trouble to consider what impression it might have upon the local Government, the Imperial Government, or the Government of India.
('5', 333, 1, 28, 757882) Every one must only search his own heart, and if the inner
('5', 334, 0, 1, 757941) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 335
('5', 334, 1, 2, 757988) voice assures him that he has the requisite strength to carry him through, then only should he pledge himself and then only would his pledge bear fruit.
('5', 334, 1, 3, 758141) A few words now as to the consequences.
('5', 334, 1, 4, 758181) Hoping for the best, we may say that, if a majority of the Indians pledge themselves to resistance and if all who take the pledge prove true to themselves, the Ordinance may not even be passed and, if passed, may be soon repealed.
('5', 334, 1, 5, 758412) It may be that we may not be called upon to suffer at all.
('5', 334, 1, 6, 758471) But if on the one hand one who takes a pledge must be a robust optimist, on the other hand he must be prepared for the worst.
('5', 334, 1, 7, 758597) It is therefore that I would give you an idea of the worst that might happen to us in the present struggle.
('5', 334, 1, 8, 758705) Imagine that all of us present here numbering 3,000 at the most pledge ourselves.
('5', 334, 1, 9, 758787) Imagine again that the remaining 10,000 Indians take no such pledge.
('5', 334, 1, 10, 758856) We will only provoke ridicule in the beginning.
('5', 334, 1, 11, 758904) Again, it is quite possible that in spite of the present warning some or many of those who pledge themselves might weaken at the very first trial.
('5', 334, 1, 12, 759051) We might have to go to gaol, where we might be insulted.
('5', 334, 1, 13, 759108) We might have to go hungry and suffer extreme heat or cold.
('5', 334, 1, 14, 759168) Hard labour might be imposed upon us.
('5', 334, 1, 15, 759206) We might be flogged by rude warders.
('5', 334, 1, 16, 759243) We might be fined heavily and our property might be attached and held up to auction if there are only a few resisters left.
('5', 334, 1, 17, 759367) Opulent today, we might be reduced to abject poverty tomorrow.
('5', 334, 1, 18, 759430) We might be deported.
('5', 334, 1, 19, 759452) Suffering from starvation and similar hardships in gaol, some of us might fall ill and even die.
('5', 334, 1, 20, 759549) In short, therefore, it is not at all impossible that we might have to endure every hardship that we can imagine, and wisdom lies in pledging ourselves on the understanding that we shall have to suffer all that and worse.
('5', 334, 1, 21, 759771) If someone asks me when and how the struggle may end, I may say that, if the entire community manfully stands the test, the end will be near.
('5', 334, 1, 22, 759913) If many of us fall back under storm and stress, the struggle will be prolonged.
('5', 334, 1, 23, 759993) But I can boldly declare, and with certainty, that so long as there is even a handful of men true to their pledge, there can only be one end to the struggle, and that is victory.
('5', 334, 1, 24, 760172) A word about my personal responsibility.
('5', 334, 1, 25, 760213) If I am warning you of the risks attendant upon the pledge, I am at the same time inviting you to pledge yourselves, and I am fully conscious of my respons ibility in the matter.
('5', 334, 1, 26, 760392) It is possible that a majority of those present here might take the pledge in a fit of enthusiasm or indignation but might weaken under the ordeal, and only a handful might be left to face the final test.
('5', 334, 1, 27, 760597) Even then there is only one course open to the like of me, to die but not to submit to the law.
('5', 334, 1, 28, 760693) It is quite unlikely but even if every one else flinched leaving me alone to face the music, I am confident that I would never violate my pledge.
('5', 334, 1, 29, 760839) Please do not
('5', 335, 0, 1, 760853) 336 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 335, 1, 2, 760895) misunderstand me.
('5', 335, 1, 3, 760913) I am not saying this out of vanity, but I wish to put you, especially the leaders upon the platform, on your guard.
('5', 335, 1, 4, 761029) I wish respectfully to suggest it to you that, if you have not the will or the ability to stand firm even when you are perfectly isolated, you must not only not take the pledge yourselves, but you must declare your opposition before the resolution is put to the meeting and before its members begin to take pledges and you must not make yourselves parties to the resolution.
('5', 335, 1, 5, 761404) Although we are going to take the pledge in a body, no one should imagine that default on the part of one or many can absolve the rest from their obligation.
('5', 335, 1, 6, 761562) Every one should fully realize his responsibility, then only pledge himself independently of others and understand that he himself must be true to his pledge even unto death, no matter what others do.

('5', 335, 3, 8, 761879) RESOLUTION I This mass meeting of British Indians here assembled, respectfully urges the Honourable the President and Members of the Legislative Council of the Transvaal not to pass the Draft Asiatic Ordinance to amend Law No.
('5', 335, 3, 9, 762106) 3 of 1885, now before that Honourable House, in view of the facts that : (1) It is, so far as the Indian community of the Transvaal is concerned, a highly contentious measure.
('5', 335, 3, 10, 762282) (2) It subjects the British Indian community of the Transvaal to degradation and insult totally undeserved by its past history.
('5', 335, 3, 11, 762410) (3) The present machinery is sufficient for checking the alleged influx of Asiatics.
('5', 335, 3, 12, 762495) (4) The statements as to the alleged influx are denied by the British Indian community.
('5', 335, 3, 13, 762583) (5) If the Honourable House is not satisfied with the denial, this meeting invites [an] open, judicial, and British enquiry into the question of the alleged influx.

('5', 335, 4, 15, 762824) 1 In accordance with Resolution V, copies of Resolutions II, III and IV were sent to the Secretary of State for India through the Governor of the Transvaal, who was also requested to telegraph their substance to the Viceroy of India.

('5', 336, 1, 2, 763177) ully protests against the Draft Asiatic Law Amendment Ordinance now being considered by the Legislative Council of the Transvaal, and humbly requests the local Government and the Imperial Authorities to withdraw the Draft Ordinance, for the reasons that : (1) It is manifestly in conflict with the past declarations of His Majesty’s representatives.
('5', 336, 1, 3, 763527) (2) It recognises no distinction between British and alien Asiatics.
('5', 336, 1, 4, 763596) (3) It reduces British Indians to a status lower than that of the aboriginal races of South Africa and the Coloured people.
('5', 336, 1, 5, 763720) (4) It renders the position of British Indians in the Transvaal much worse than under Law 3 of 1885, and, therefore, than under the Boer regime.
('5', 336, 1, 6, 763865) (5) It sets up a system of passes and espionage unknown in any other British territory.
('5', 336, 1, 7, 763953) (6) It brands the communities to which it is applied as criminals or suspects.
('5', 336, 1, 8, 764032) (7) The alleged influx of unauthorised British Indians into the Transvaal is denied.
('5', 336, 1, 9, 764117) (8) If such denial is not accepted, a judicial, open and British enquiry should be instituted before such drastic and uncalled for legislation is enforced.
('5', 336, 1, 10, 764273) (9) The measure is otherwise un British and unduly restricts the liberty of inoffensive British subjects and constitutes a compulsory invitation to British Indians in the Transvaal to leave the country.
('5', 336, 1, 11, 764476) (10) This meeting further and especially requests the Right Honourable the Secretary of State for the Colonies and the Right Honourable the Secretary of State for India to suspend the Royal sanction and to receive a deputation on behalf of the British Indian community of the Transvaal in connection with this Draft Ordinance.
('5', 336, 1, 12, 764803) RESOLUTION III This meeting hereby appoints a delegation with power from the Committee of the British Indian Association to add to its membership or to change its personnel, to proceed to England and to lay before the Imperial Authorities the complaint of the British Indian community of the Transvaal regarding the Draft Asiatic Law Amendment Ordinance.

('5', 337, 2, 6, 766322) 310. JOHANNESBURG LETTER
('5', 337, 3, 7, 766347) September 11, 1906 A mammoth meeting was held under the presidentship of Mr. Abdul Gani, at two o’clock on Tuesday afternoon at the Empire Theatre, in connection with the agitation at present going on in the Transvaal against the Asiatic law 1. About three thousand Indians attended.
('5', 337, 3, 8, 766631) An invitation was sent to the Colonial Secretary, who sent Mr. Chamney.
('5', 337, 3, 9, 766703) In the course of his speech, Mr. Abdul Gani made the following points: We in the Transvaal have never had to face such critical times before.
('5', 337, 3, 10, 766845) On this occasion, we have to put in a mighty effort.
('5', 337, 3, 11, 766898) I do not want to make a long speech; there is much work for us to do.
('5', 337, 3, 12, 766968) At the time of the Boer War, Lord Selborne said that the need to protect the rights of Indians was one of the causes of the War.
('5', 337, 3, 13, 767097) For, under the Union Jack, no one should suffer any disability; all must have equal rights.
('5', 337, 4, 14, 767189) 1 Draft Asiatic Law Amendment Ordinance
('5', 338, 0, 1, 767229) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 339
('5', 338, 1, 2, 767276) Again, at a meeting of Jews held a few days ago, he said that it was the duty of the British Government to redress the grievances of alien peoples as well.
('5', 338, 1, 3, 767432) There should be no restrictions, he said, on living, no prohibition of acquisition of land in the British Empire.
('5', 338, 1, 4, 767546) We have a right to ask how such speeches of Lord Selborne can be reconciled with the oppressive law directed against us.
('5', 338, 1, 5, 767667) We have already represented to the Government how drastic and offensive the law is.
('5', 338, 1, 6, 767751) But, today, I want to read out to you Mr. Gregorowski’s opinion on the subject.
('5', 338, 1, 7, 767831) He writes: The act is far more severe than the Dutch Law.
('5', 338, 1, 8, 767889) There is not a single provision in it that is favourable to the Indians.
('5', 338, 1, 9, 767962) The act makes the position of the Indian worse than that of the Kaffir.
('5', 338, 1, 10, 768034) Not every Kaffir is required to carry a pass on him; but now every Indian will have to do so.
('5', 338, 1, 11, 768128) Educated Kaffirs are exempt from such restrictive laws.
('5', 338, 1, 12, 768184) But the Indian, whatever his education and standing, will have to carry a pass.
('5', 338, 1, 13, 768264) The pass, it seems to us, will be like the one carried by prisoners, etc.
('5', 338, 1, 14, 768338) Whatever loop holes there existed in the Law [3] of 1885 have been closed in this Act.
('5', 338, 1, 15, 768425) While Kaffirs can own land, Indians cannot.
('5', 338, 1, 16, 768469) It does not seem probable that the Liberal Government will approve such a law.
('5', 338, 1, 17, 768548) What we have been saying is by no means more strongly worded than what Mr. Gregorowski has said.
('5', 338, 1, 18, 768645) Now that a serious situation has arisen, we should think about what we ought to do if the Imperial Government does not heed our grievances.
('5', 338, 1, 19, 768785) Today some resolutions will be placed before you.
('5', 338, 1, 20, 768835) According to one of them, we shall resolve to send a deputation to England, of which I need say no more.
('5', 338, 1, 21, 768940) But there is only one very important resolution for today.
('5', 338, 1, 22, 768999) What shall we do if we fail to secure relief?
('5', 338, 1, 23, 769045) We have patiently endured the hardships, which have continuedunmitigated.
('5', 338, 1, 24, 769119) But the further disability proposed by this law is insufferable.
('5', 338, 1, 25, 769184) We therefore want to resolve that, if the Imperial Government too intends to heap more oppressions on us, we will rather go to gaol than put up with it.
('5', 338, 1, 26, 769337) It always happens that one hits upon the true remedy only when one goes through extreme suffering, and it is our duty firmly to resolve to defy the law and go to gaol.
('5', 338, 1, 27, 769505) There is nothing to be ashamed of in going to gaol.
('5', 338, 1, 28, 769557) And I pray to God to give us the strength and the good sense to adhere to our determination.
('5', 338, 1, 29, 769650) This is for us the time for deeds, not words.
('5', 338, 1, 30, 769696) We have to act boldly; and in doing so, we have to be humble and non violent.
('5', 338, 1, 31, 769774) We should not speak or listen to any bitter words.
('5', 338, 1, 32, 769825) After the President’s speech, the following resolutions were passed.

('5', 339, 1, 2, 769936) RESOLUTION I 1
('5', 339, 2, 3, 769951) This mass meeting respectfully urges the Legislative Council not to pass the Asiatic Ordinance in view of the fact that (1) it is, according to the Indian community, a highly objectionable measure; (2) it subjects the Indian community to degradation and insult without any cause whatever; (3) if it is supposed that Indians enter the Transvaal without permits, there is adequate provision in the existing law to prevent them from so doing; (4) the Indian community denies the allegation that there is any large influx of permitless Indians into the Transvaal; (5) if the Legislative Council disbelieves these statements, the Indian community demands that a judicial inquiry, which accords with British practice, be held.

('5', 342, 12, 12, 775561) 313. REPLY TO “ THE RAND DAILY MAIL”
('5', 342, 13, 13, 775598) [JOHANNESBURG, September 12, 1906] [THE EDITOR] The Rand Daily Mail
('5', 342, 14, 14, 775666) SIR, You have accused me in your leading article of the confusion of the issues in connection with the British Indian mass meeting 1 held yesterday.
('5', 342, 14, 15, 775815) I fear, however, that it is rather on your side than on mine.
('5', 342, 14, 16, 775877) The point that I, and every other speaker, made was perfectly clear.
('5', 342, 14, 17, 775946) Here is what I stated, as reported in your paper:
('5', 342, 15, 18, 775996) They did not ask to bring the 350 millions into this country, but they said that those who had entered the country were entitled to the same protection and
('5', 342, 16, 19, 776152) 1 Vide “The Mass Meeting”,11 9 1906
('5', 343, 0, 1, 776188) 344 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 343, 1, 2, 776230) rights and privileges as all the Europeans who had come in.
('5', 343, 1, 3, 776290) While the meeting earnestly pleaded for a reasonable treatment of the resident British Indian population, you, Sir, shall I say, deliberately have confused the issue by dragging in all Asiatics, British and otherwise, and by raising the question of immigration.
('5', 343, 1, 4, 776552) How can we raise any such question when it is a matter of life and death for the handful of British Indians that are in the Transvaal?
('5', 343, 1, 5, 776687) In order to accentuate my point, I did indeed say that, if aliens, not always of a desirable character, could enter the Transvaal freely and without permits, and enjoy all the privileges, it was reasonable that Indians, who are accepted as British subjects, should have a prior right.
('5', 343, 1, 6, 776972) You again talk of a suspicious disinclination to descend to details!
('5', 343, 1, 7, 777041) There was no occasion for it as they are embodied in the British Indian protest which you have already published.
('5', 343, 1, 8, 777155) No amount of amending the Ordinance as to details can make it acceptable when the very principle of it is bad, namely, to ask every Indian without exception to carry a pass under a system of identification applied only to criminals.
('5', 343, 1, 9, 777388) We would be unworthy sons of India if, mild as we are, we submitted to the contemplated degradation.
('5', 343, 2, 10, 777489) [Yours, etc., M. K. GANDHI] Indian Opinion, 22 9 1906
('5', 343, 3, 11, 777543) 314. LETTER TO “ THE STAR”
('5', 343, 4, 12, 777570) [JOHANNESBURG, Before September 14, 1906]
('5', 343, 5, 13, 777612) TO THE EDITOR THE STAR
('5', 343, 6, 14, 777635) SIR, You have been good enough, in your leading article on the British Indian protest regarding the Asiatic Draft Ordinance, to give advice to the British Indian Association which, in your opinion, is not very “judiciously” led.
('5', 343, 6, 15, 777864) It is a trite saying that “our neighbours always know best what is good for us,” and I have no doubt that, on the principle, your opinion, that the British Indian community is badly led, is also correct.
('5', 343, 6, 16, 778068) However, for the present, I am more concerned with the attitude you have taken up regarding the British Indian protest than with your judgement about the leaders of the Association.

('5', 344, 1, 2, 778297) You think that the community has no case whatever against the new Ordinance, because it is purely a matter of fresh registration and that it imposes no fresh disabilities on any class of His Majesty’s subjects.

('5', 344, 1, 4, 778541) Just as the administration of the Peace Preservation Ordinance has been distorted in order to prohibit Indian immigration, so also the scope of Law 3 of 1885 has been distorted by the new Ordinance to meet a demand that was never made during the Dutch regime.
('5', 344, 1, 5, 778801) The Dutch law was aimed at the traders.
('5', 344, 1, 6, 778841) It policy was not to restrict immigration, but to penalise the immigrants who wanted to trade, and it was for that reason that, originally, it fixed a registration fee of £25, which was reduced to £3 on the intervention of the British Government.
('5', 344, 1, 7, 779088) The present Ordinance, which is supposed merely to amend Law 3 of 1885, and therefore, to continue its scope and not entirely change it, as a matter of fact, provides for a system of identification which, in its operation, cannot but be most galling to those who have to submit to it.
('5', 344, 1, 8, 779373) Re registration does not mean taking a census of the Indian population, but it means the following : Every Indian resident in the Colony has to carry with him a registration certificate containing degrading identification particulars.
('5', 344, 1, 9, 779608) He has to have his new born child provisionally registered, giving such particulars as to identification as may be required by the regulation to be framed by the Lieutenant Governor.
('5', 344, 1, 10, 779791) He has to take out a registration for children above the age of eight years with similar conditions as to identification.
('5', 344, 1, 11, 779913) All this is absolutely new and never contemplated by Law 3 of 1885. And yet you have no hesitation in saying that the Ordinancedoes not impose any disability on the resident Indian population.
('5', 344, 1, 12, 780106) Let me assure you that the policy of passive resistance is not a brutum fulmen.

('5', 352, 2, 18, 799980) 322. TRANSVAAL PERMIT ORDINANCE
('5', 352, 3, 19, 800012) In another place, we print the full text 2 of the judgment of the Supreme Court in the case of Rex v.
('5', 352, 3, 20, 800114) Bhabha.
('5', 352, 3, 21, 800122) It will be remembered that, some time ago, Mr. E. M. Bhyat entered the Transvaal on the
('5', 352, 4, 22, 800210) 1 The original has “ .
('5', 352, 4, 23, 800233) misinterpreted by the Government into.
('5', 352, 4, 24, 800272) 2 Not reproduced here
('5', 353, 0, 1, 800294) 354 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 353, 1, 2, 800336) strength of possession by him of an old Dutch registration certificate.
('5', 353, 1, 3, 800408) The Magistrate at Volksrust decided that such a certificate was a formal authorisation to reside in the Transvaal, in terms of the Peace Preservation Ordinance.
('5', 353, 1, 4, 800569) This case was brought in review at the instance of the Attorney General, but the Supreme Court dismissed the application for review, and the point raised in Mr. Bhyat’s case remained undecided.
('5', 353, 2, 5, 800763) The same point was brought before the Supreme Court in the case we have mentioned above, and this time there was no difficulty in getting a judicial decision from the highest tribunal of justice in the Transvaal.
('5', 353, 2, 6, 800976) The decision has gone against the British Indian contention, nor are we surprised at it, but the Supreme Court has decided the main point raised in this case in favour of the appellant, namely, that an expulsion order granted by a Magistrate at the investigation of an application for exemption from having to hold a permit does not prevent the Magistrate from reconsidering his decision on further evidence being brought before him.
('5', 353, 2, 7, 801410) However, as the Court held that the Magistrate’s judgment in Mr. Bhabha’s case was right though based on wrong premises, the result was that the sentence of civil imprisonment passed by the Magistrate was reluctantly confirmed by the Bench, though the Supreme Court expressed a great deal of sympathy with the appellant.
('5', 353, 2, 8, 801731) The Chief Justice suggested that the Crown should remit the sentence, as the case was in the nature of a test case, and both the Chief Justice and Justice Mason thought that Mr. Bhabha, being in possession of the old Dutch certificate, should have a permit issued to him.
('5', 353, 2, 9, 802003) The Lieutenant Governor has exercised the prerogative of mercy and remitted the sentence passed on Mr. Bhabha, and it is highly probable that Mr. Bhabha will be allowed to remain undisturbed in the Transvaal.
('5', 353, 2, 10, 802212) So far, therefore, as the individual is concerned, at last justice will have been done.
('5', 353, 2, 11, 802300) But this case has important bearings on the Indian position.
('5', 353, 2, 12, 802361) Itshews that there is something very seriously wrong with the administration of the Peace Preservation Ordinance.
('5', 353, 2, 13, 802475) We have the solemn word of Lord Selborne, given to the British Indian deputation at Middelburg, that all pre war Indian residents of the Transvaal shall be allowed to enter the country.
('5', 353, 2, 14, 802661) 2 We have the assurance of the Colonial Secretary that such residents have a right to enter the country, and yet, we find that Mr. Bhabha had a very great deal of
('5', 353, 3, 15, 802824) 1 Vide “Transvaal Permits”, 28 7 1906
('5', 353, 4, 16, 802862) 2 Lord Selborne gave this assurance when an address was presented to him at Middelburg on September 4; vide Indian Opinion, 8 9 1906.
('5', 354, 0, 1, 802996) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 355
('5', 354, 1, 2, 803043) difficulty about entering the Transvaal.
('5', 354, 1, 3, 803084) There are many such cases in which, in spite of proof of registration certificates, men are still without their permits.
('5', 354, 1, 4, 803205) May we not then hope that Lord Selborne’s assurance will be translated into practice, and such men who have waited long enough at the coast will be permitted to re enter the Transvaal?
('5', 354, 1, 5, 803390) Indian Opinion, 22 9 1906
('5', 354, 2, 6, 803416) 323. DIFFICULTIES OF INDIAN WOMEN IN THE TRANSVAAL
('5', 354, 3, 7, 803467) The permit difficulties of women continue unabated in the Transvaal.
('5', 354, 3, 8, 803536) We give details of one such case in our English columns.
('5', 354, 3, 9, 803593) Mangare and his wife, Punia, were both travelling to the Transvaal on September 14. The Police Inspector at Volksrust forced the wife to detrain as she did not have a separate permit.
('5', 354, 3, 10, 803777) Mangare produced his own permit and registration certificate.
('5', 354, 3, 11, 803839) And though the wife’s name was also mentioned in the register, she was not allowed to proceed.
('5', 354, 3, 12, 803934) So the husband and the wife both got off the train and had to stay in the lock up.
('5', 354, 3, 13, 804017) When the case was heard on the 15th, the Police Officer deposed that his orders were to arrest permitless women and children whether or not they were accompanied by their husbands or parents and whatever the age of the children.
('5', 354, 3, 14, 804246) The evidence also revealed that the wife was in the Transvaal on May 31, 1902. Nevertheless, on the ground that the woman did not come forward to give evidence, the Magistrate ordered her to leave the Colony before seven o’clock that very evening.
('5', 354, 3, 15, 804494) Thus are wives separated from husbands and children from parents under this Government.
('5', 354, 3, 16, 804582) It is necessary for us to take effective measures in this matter.
('5', 354, 3, 17, 804648) We hope this case will, if necessary, be taken to the Supreme Court.
('5', 354, 3, 18, 804717) We believe that it is a thousand times better for men to suffer imprisonment than to submit to such a law.
('5', 354, 3, 19, 804824) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 22 9 1906

('5', 355, 1, 2, 804908) 324. JOHANNESBURG LETTER 1
('5', 355, 2, 3, 804935) THE MASS MEETING IN THE TRANSVAAL The Rand Daily Mail says that no meeting has ever taken place in the Transvaal like the one held by the Indians in the Empire Theatre.
('5', 355, 2, 4, 805104) The Theatre was packed, at least three thousand persons attending.
('5', 355, 2, 5, 805171) Many people could not get in for want of room.
('5', 355, 2, 6, 805218) The shopkeepers and hawkers had all closed business at ten in the morning.
('5', 355, 2, 7, 805293) Though the Theatre gates were due to be opened at two, people began collecting from eleven onwards and the Theatre had to be opened at twelve.
('5', 355, 2, 8, 805436) By 1.30 there was no room for anyone to enter the spacious Theatre.
('5', 355, 2, 9, 805504) Though such a large number of persons had assembled, there was no untoward incident, and quiet prevailed everywhere.
('5', 355, 2, 10, 805621) The people sat or stood patiently, waiting for the proceedings to start.
('5', 355, 2, 11, 805694) Such a meeting and such enthusiasm have never before been seen among Indians.
('5', 355, 2, 12, 805772) Though all this shows the extent of oppression to which Indians are subjected, it must be admitted that much of the credit for holding such a meeting goes to the Hamidiya Islamic Society.
('5', 355, 2, 13, 805960) The Society’s Hall was thrown open to all, Hindus and Muslims alike.
('5', 355, 2, 14, 806029) For a week past, meetings had been held there during which all the leading Indians held consultations.
('5', 355, 2, 15, 806132) Very often, the meetings continued till midnight.
('5', 355, 2, 16, 806182) Younger associations in South Africa would do well to follow the example of the Hamidiya Society.
('5', 355, 2, 17, 806280) The meeting was attended by representatives from a number of places.
('5', 355, 2, 18, 806349) Telegrams or letters expressing sympathy and agreement with the aims of the meeting were received from Middelburg, Standerton, Klerksdorp and other places.
('5', 355, 2, 19, 806505) Both the Colonial Secretary and Mr. Chamney were invited.
('5', 355, 2, 20, 806563) Mr. Chamney attended and sat to the right of the President.
('5', 355, 2, 21, 806623) In addition, white gentlemen like Mr. Lichtenstein, a lawyer from Pretoria, Mr. Israelstram, Mr. Littmann Landsberg and Mr. Stuart Campbell’s manager were present.
('5', 355, 2, 22, 806787) Reporters from all the three newspapers also came.
('5', 355, 2, 23, 806838) The President, Mr. Abdul Gani, began his speech exactly at three o’clock.
('5', 355, 2, 24, 806912) Everyone felt that Mr. Abdul Gani was at his best.
('5', 355, 2, 25, 806963) His speech in excellent Hindustani was brief and eloquent.
('5', 355, 2, 26, 807022) His narration of the facts was quite moderate, yet forceful.
('5', 355, 2, 27, 807083) His voice was loud and so audible everywhere.
('5', 355, 2, 28, 807129) His speech was received with acclamation.
('5', 355, 2, 29, 807171) When he spoke of gaol going, the audience shouted in one voice,
