('5', 363, 3, 5, 824333) 327. JOHANNESBURG LETTER
('5', 363, 4, 6, 824358) September 25, 1906 For the Indian community in the Transvaal the last week was full of restlessness, like that of a delirious patient tossing from side to side.
('5', 363, 4, 7, 824519) Just when the deputation was to leave and all preparations had been finally made, came the bomb shell—a letter from Lord Selborne which, as is now known, was full of ambiguities.
('5', 363, 4, 8, 824698) It caused a split.
('5', 363, 4, 9, 824717) Everybody took it that the Bill for re registration had become law.
('5', 363, 4, 10, 824785) It was therefore decided that the deputation should not sail.
('5', 363, 4, 11, 824847) This was the state of affairs till Tuesday noon.
('5', 363, 4, 12, 824896) In the afternoon on that day, a telephone message was received from the High Commissioner saying that Lord Elgin’s approval did not mean that formal sanction had been given to the law.
('5', 363, 4, 13, 825081) This again led to a new course of action.
('5', 363, 4, 14, 825123) Thesame night some Indians met together, called on Mr. Haji Ojer Ally, obtained his consent, and considered recommending that the Indian community send him alone as a one man deputation.
('5', 363, 4, 15, 825310) On Wednesday that idea was put into execution; but it was shown last week to every Indian how and when man is rendered powerless.
('5', 363, 4, 16, 825440) Messrs Gregorowski and Lichtenstein were of the emphatic opinion that it was absolutely essential to include Mr. Gandhi in the deputation, and that the deputation should certainly be sent.
('5', 363, 4, 17, 825629) The Indian community in Pretoria, on the other hand, emphasized the need of Mr. Gandhi remaining in the Transvaal, lest through fear or temptation people should waver and take out new registration certificates.
('5', 363, 4, 18, 825840) Strongly worded telegrams were received from Natal to say that it was quite necessary to send the deputation as decided earlier.
('5', 363, 4, 19, 825969) A meeting was therefore held on Friday, and it was unanimously decided that both Mr. Ally and Mr. Gandhi should go.
('5', 363, 4, 20, 826085) The consensus of opinion was that Mr. Adbul Gani should also go,
('5', 363, 5, 21, 826150) 1 Vide “Letter to Leader”, 22 9 1906
('5', 364, 0, 1, 826187) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 365
('5', 364, 1, 2, 826234) but the idea had to be reluctantly given up as there were strong reasons why he could not go.
('5', 364, 1, 3, 826328) Before agreeing to go, Mr. Gandhi got the leading men to give a written undertaking that, notwithstanding difficulties that might arise, they would adhere to the Fourth Resolution.
('5', 364, 1, 4, 826509) This document will be published next week.
('5', 364, 2, 5, 826552) ANOTHER LETTER FROM LORD SELBORNE About the time this decision was taken, another letter was received from Lord Selborne.
('5', 364, 2, 6, 826674) Clarifying the situation further, he said that the new Ordinance would be despatched that week to England, and that the Royal assent, if given at all, would naturally be after it had reached there.
('5', 364, 2, 7, 826872) Under the circumstances, there was no cause for apprehension, It is likely that the Royal assent will not be given and the Bill cannot become law before the deputation returns.
('5', 364, 3, 8, 827049) DEPUTATION EXPENSES The Committee has sanctioned up to £900 towards the expenses of the deputation of which £300 have been sanctioned for Mr. Ally for his domestic and other expenses.
('5', 364, 3, 9, 827233) Mr. Ally has indicated that he will, if necessary, spend a portion of this sum on public work in England.
('5', 364, 3, 10, 827339) The remaining £600 will be spent on the deputation, and a detailed statement of expenses will be submitted to the Committee.
('5', 364, 4, 11, 827464) MEMBERS OF THE DEPUTATION Of one of the members of the deputation, Mr. Gandhi, it is needless to write here.
('5', 364, 4, 12, 827573) The other, Mr. Haji Ojer Ally was born in l853 in Mauritius, where he had his education.
('5', 364, 4, 13, 827662) He started work in 1868 and took up the job of a printer in the office of the Commercial Gazette.
('5', 364, 4, 14, 827760) In 1873 he got employed as a clerk in a wharf, and joined the firm of Messrs Charles Jacob and Son as a shipping clerk in 1876. He then went on a pilgrimage to Mecca and became a Haji.
('5', 364, 4, 15, 827945) In 1884 he landedat Cape Town and set up business as a manufacturer of aerated water.
('5', 364, 4, 16, 828031) He began doing public work in 1885. The Government proposed to remove the Malay cemetery to a place far away from town.
('5', 364, 4, 17, 828151) The Malays opposed the move and a disturbance was feared.
('5', 364, 4, 18, 828209) Mr. Ally then intervened.
('5', 364, 4, 19, 828235) A settlement was effected and a nearer site fixed for the cemetery.
('5', 364, 4, 20, 828303) In Cape Town, Mr. Ally was a voter both for Parliament and the Municipality and always took a prominent part in the elections.
('5', 364, 4, 21, 828430) In 1892 he went to Kimberley and other places, where he was elected Chairman of the Coloured Peoples’ Organization.
('5', 364, 4, 22, 828546) He took a leading part in the movement against the Franchise Law Amendment Act of the Cape, when a petition signed by 22,000 Coloured people was sent to London.
('5', 364, 4, 23, 828707) After 1892 Mr. Ally went to Johannesburg and settled there.
('5', 364, 4, 24, 828767) Mr. Ally interviewed the British Agent
('5', 365, 0, 1, 828806) 366 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 365, 1, 2, 828848) and other public men in the Transvaal in connection with the condition of British Indians there.
('5', 365, 1, 3, 828945) He is the founder of the Hamidiya Islamic Society and is at present its President.
('5', 365, 1, 4, 829028) The Society is doing excellent work.
('5', 365, 1, 5, 829065) As is well known, it has a large membership and its work is being carried on with great enthusiasm.
('5', 365, 1, 6, 829165) Mr. Ally has a large family; he is the father of eleven children whom he has been giving a good education.

('5', 368, 5, 7, 833165) 333. ON TRIAL
('5', 368, 6, 8, 833179) We are enabled to publish copies of communications from Lord Selborne addressed to the British Indian Association, in connection with the new Asiatic Ordinance of the Transvaal.
('5', 368, 6, 9, 833357) One of them states that Lord Elgin has already approved of the Ordinance, and that His Excellency does not consider that any useful purpose is likely to be served by sending the proposed deputation to England.
('5', 368, 6, 10, 833567) We offer our sincere congratulations to the British Indians in the Transvaal on the decision of Lord Elgin.
('5', 368, 6, 11, 833675) The decision reflects no credit on a liberal Secretary of State for the Colonies, especially when one realizes that the Secretary of State for the Colonies has, at one time, occupied the Viceregal throne in India.
('5', 368, 6, 12, 833889) But Lord Selborne has told us that out of evil very often cometh good, and if the British Indian community is true to itself, good will most assuredly result from the momentous decision of Lord Elgin.
('5', 368, 6, 13, 834090) His Excellency has clothed with life the historic fourth resolution 2 of the great meeting, held in the now extinct Empire Theatre in Johannesburg.
('5', 368, 6, 14, 834238) That resolution will be the touchstone by which the national and self respecting spirit of Indians in the Transvaal is to be tested.
('5', 368, 6, 15, 834371) LordElgin, evidently under the inspiration of Lord Selborne, has accepted the Indian challenge.
('5', 368, 6, 16, 834467) On one side has now to be ranged brute force; on the other, simple passive resistance.
('5', 368, 6, 17, 834554) British Indians have a just cause; it will become infinitely juster and more sanctified by their putting into force the fourth resolution and declining, in spite of Lord Elgin’s approval of the Ordinance, to submit to its galling conditions, and to the “serious and wanton injustice” which the Ordinance contemplates.
('5', 368, 6, 18, 834872) We have no hesitation in very respectfully repeating the last expression, although Lord Selborne, in one of his letters, does not agree that the Ordinance inflicts any such injustice.
('5', 368, 6, 19, 835056) We must accept His Excellency’s assurance that the Ordinance is not in conflict with the views expressed by His Excellency from time to time.
('5', 368, 6, 20, 835198) He alone knew with what mental reservations he uttered the lofty
('5', 368, 7, 21, 835263) 1 Gandhiji’s eldest son 2 Vide “The Mass Meeting”, 11 9 1906
('5', 369, 0, 1, 835324) 370 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 369, 1, 2, 835366) sentiments before the Zionist meeting, and spoke of the trusteeship on the eve of the Boer war.
('5', 369, 2, 3, 835462) Similarly, we beg leave to take exception to His Excellency’s judgement as to the Ordinance; it is those who have to submit to it that are at all capable of knowing whether it is just or otherwise.
('5', 369, 2, 4, 835660) Lord Selborne’s reply to the British Indian protest bristles with points which can be argued from a British Indian standpoint, but enough of argument has already been devoted to the controversy.
('5', 369, 2, 5, 835855) It is now time, not for argument, but for action.
('5', 369, 3, 6, 835905) The first of January will be, for millions of His Majesty’s subjects, a day of gladsome prospect.
('5', 369, 3, 7, 836003) To British Indians in the Transvaal likewise, it will be a similar day, though not in the same sense.
('5', 369, 3, 8, 836105) They must marshal their forces and conserve their energy.
('5', 369, 3, 9, 836163) They will need to be ready to face the inevitable on that eventful day.
('5', 369, 3, 10, 836235) The community is now on its trial.
('5', 369, 3, 11, 836270) Let us hope it will emerge scatheless.
('5', 369, 3, 12, 836309) By its action will be judged Indian character, if not throughout the world, certainly in South Africa.
('5', 369, 3, 13, 836412) In having passed the historic resolution, the meeting has undertaken a trust which British Indians in the Transvaal must discharge, come what may.
('5', 369, 4, 14, 836559) Indian Opinion, 29 9 1906
('5', 369, 5, 15, 836585) 334. THE PUNIA CASE
('5', 369, 6, 16, 836605) Our contemporary, The Rand Daily Mail, by its spirited advocacy of the unfortunate British Indian woman, Punia, has given thematter a prominence which is thoroughly deserved by the circumstancesof the case.
('5', 369, 6, 17, 836812) 1 Indeed, it would appear that Mr. Gandhi
('5', 369, 7, 18, 836854) 1 The Rand Daily Mail, while publishing the “Letter to the Press”, 19 11 1906 wrote: “The harshness complained of touches the British Indian community in a particularly tender spot.
('5', 369, 7, 19, 837036) No nation is more careful of the women of its race than the mass of people of India.
('5', 369, 7, 20, 837121) No one in the Transvaal desires to create friction and make an admittedly difficult problem still more difficult by stirring up bad feeling over such a delicate matter.
('5', 369, 7, 21, 837290) We feel that the white people will demand an investigation and an explanation of the Punia affair as strongly as Mr. Gandhi.
('5', 369, 7, 22, 837415) There is a fixed determination to prevent an influx of Aiatics, but the government has received no mandate from the people to make war on women.”
('5', 370, 0, 1, 837561) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 371
('5', 370, 1, 2, 837608) has understated the gravity of the situation, in that he omitted to mention what is, perhaps, the most unpleasant feature of an unfortunate affair, namely, that the woman was made to give her ten finger prints at the Charge Office in Volksrust, and was obliged to do so again at Germiston.
('5', 370, 1, 3, 837898) The facts being undisputed, a discreditable attempt has been made to justify the regulations referred to by Constable McGregor who arrested the woman, and we are grieved to find that The Natal Mercury has lent itself, we have no doubt unconsciously, to such an attempt.
('5', 370, 1, 4, 838168) The Transvaal Leader had the substance of the paragraph in The Natal Mercury telegraphed to it, to which Mr. Gandhi has sent a reply 1 repudiating the vile charge made against Indian women, and characterising it as an infamous lie.
('5', 370, 1, 5, 838400) He then wired to the Registrar of Asiatics, who has promptly replied to the effect that no such statement as published in the papers had been made by any official connected with his department.
('5', 370, 1, 6, 838594) The Natal Mercury, which is always fair, will, we hope, in this case, publish the name of the official who made the statement attributed to him or withdraw the libel.
('5', 370, 1, 7, 838761) If the working of the Permit Ordinance was as well known to the public generally as it is to us, they would have realised the full significance of the Punia case, and the cruel wrong that has been inflicted not only on the woman in question, but on the whole of the Indian community.
('5', 370, 1, 8, 839045) The evidence given by the constable in this painful case was, we have reason to believe, the first authoritative pronouncement regarding British Indian women having to take out permits, even when they may be in the company of their husbands.
('5', 370, 1, 9, 839287) The husband of Punia stated emphatically that he knew nothing about a permit being required for his wife, but we will assume that the husband was aware that a separate permit was necessary.
('5', 370, 1, 10, 839477) It is still a legitimate question why Indian women should require any permits at all.
('5', 370, 1, 11, 839563) The printed instructions issued by the Chief Secretary for Permits lay down that wives of husbands holding permits are not required to take [out] permits apart from their husbands, nor are children under sixteen years apart from their parents.
('5', 370, 1, 12, 839807) If such be the case, why should separate instructions be issued for Indian wives, seeing that they, too, are governed by the same Permit Ordinance ?
('5', 370, 1, 13, 839956) Even if definite instructions were to be issued in writing regarding Indian women, we consider that it would be the paramount duty of British Indians to refrain from taking out any such permits for Indian women, and to protect them from the insult and degradation that attend the taking out of these permits.
('5', 370, 1, 14, 840265) Are Indian women to make
('5', 370, 2, 15, 840290) 1 Vide “Letter to Leader”, 22 11 1906
('5', 371, 0, 1, 840328) 372 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 371, 1, 2, 840370) separate applications, put down their thumb impressions, go half a dozen times to Justices of the Peace in order to make declarations required by the Asiatic Office, and to make affidavits that they are the wives of their husbands— perchance, also, to prove that they are refugees, for is it not the rule of the Asiatic Office not togrant permits to any but British Indian refugees?
('5', 371, 1, 3, 840753) Suppose, further, that the application of a wife is delayed or refused, is the husband, who is holder of a legitimate permit, to remain out of the Colony until after the application of his wife is granted, or, to remain out of the Colony entirely, in the event of a refusal of the application on behalf of the wife ?
('5', 371, 1, 4, 841070) There never has been any reproach against Indian womanhood in South Africa except now, for the first time, in the sinful imagination of an anonymous immigration official.
('5', 371, 1, 5, 841241) But even if a few miserable specimens of Indian humanity were to introduce into the Colony women of indifferent character, will that be any justification for submitting wives of hundreds of honest Indian settlers in Johannesburg to the painful processes required to be undergone by the Permit Office ?
('5', 371, 1, 6, 841543) If the authorities persist in the instructions said to have been issued, we have no hesitation in saying that they will be playing with fire, and they may give rise to a state of things for which they, and other South Africans, may have reason to be extremely sorry.
('5', 371, 1, 7, 841810) We can emphatically re echo the sentiments of the leader writer of The Rand Daily Mail that harshness of the kind that poor Punia had to undergo touches British Indian sentiment on its tenderest part.
('5', 371, 1, 8, 842011) We think that our contemporary has rendered a public service in drawing pointed attention to this case.
('5', 371, 1, 9, 842115) We hope that the authorities will issue definite instructions countermanding the orders referred to by Constable McGregor, and give those instructions as wide a publicity as possible.
('5', 371, 1, 10, 842299) Indian Opinion, 29 9 1906
('5', 371, 2, 11, 842325) 335. TRANSVAAL PERMIT ORDINANCE On the 15th inst., one Hafeji Moosa and his son, Mahomed Hafeji Moosa, were tried before the Magistrate at Volksrust under the Peace Preservation Ordinance; the father for having abetted his son (who was acknowledged to be under eleven years) in entering the Transvaal under a permit obtained by improper means, and the son with the offence of having entered the Colony on a permit obtained by improper means.
('5', 371, 2, 12, 842767) Evidence was given to the effect that the father and son travelled together on the 5th July and passed through Volksrust.
('5', 371, 2, 13, 842889) They were examined there.
('5', 371, 2, 14, 842915) The father produced his permit
('5', 372, 0, 1, 842946) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 373
('5', 372, 1, 2, 842993) and the son is alleged to have produced a permit issued in the name of one Bhaima.
('5', 372, 1, 3, 843076) The inspecting constable was unable to say that the boy produced the permit in question.
('5', 372, 1, 4, 843165) The boy’s thumb imprints were taken, sent to Pretoria, and as they did not tally with the thumb imprints on the counterfoil of the permit issued to Bhaima, both the father and son were arrested at Potchefstroom.
('5', 372, 1, 5, 843377) It further came out, in the evidence of Mr. Cody, Chief Clerk in the office of the Registrar of Asiatics, that the instructions from the Permit Office were to arrest all British Indians, whether male or female, of whatever age, in the case of wives, whether [or not] they were in the company of their husbands, and in the case of children, whether [or not] they were in the company of their parents, unless they could produce separate permits.
('5', 372, 1, 6, 843821) Both the father and son denied that the son had entered on the permit issued to Bhaima.
('5', 372, 1, 7, 843909) The Magistrate discharged the father, but found the son guilty, and sentenced him to pay a fine of £50 or suffer imprisonment without hard labour for three months.
('5', 372, 1, 8, 844073) Appeal has been noted.
('5', 372, 1, 9, 844096) The case is considered to be of considerable importance, in that a boy of tender years, travelling with his father, has been sentenced so heavily, in spite of the fact that Magistrates are guided in the punishment of juvenile offenders by special powers given to them to administer cuts.
('5', 372, 1, 10, 844384) Indian Opinion, 29 9 1906
('5', 372, 2, 11, 844410) 336. INDIANS IN DELAGOA BAY
('5', 372, 3, 12, 844438) The fear of an attack on the rights of Indians increases as more and more Englishmen crowd into Delagoa Bay.
('5', 372, 3, 13, 844547) According to our correspondent, a movement is afoot in that place to drive Indians into Locations.
('5', 372, 3, 14, 844646) It also appears that the Indians there will offer strong resistance.
('5', 372, 3, 15, 844715) Our correspondent adds that an Association has been formed to fight the measure.

('5', 373, 1, 2, 845360) 337. A WARNING
('5', 373, 2, 3, 845375) The report of an Indian case, published by the Town Council in the Krugersdorp Standard dated September 1, is regrettable, and puts the Indian community to shame.
('5', 373, 2, 4, 845538) A leading Indian of the place did not effect the necessary improvements to his premises despite a notice requiring him to do so.
('5', 373, 2, 5, 845667) His bedroom had a ceiling only of cloth; the lavatory floor was not proof against the seeping of dirty water; and the lavatory was used although it had no bucket.
('5', 373, 2, 6, 845830) Since the notice was ignored, the Town Council ordered proceedings to be instituted against him, with results so far unknown to us.
('5', 373, 2, 7, 845962) But that those who are considered leading Indians should keep their premises in the condition described here makes us hang our heads in shame.
('5', 373, 2, 8, 846105) One of the many charges the whites make against Indians is that of uncleanliness.
('5', 373, 2, 9, 846187) Such cases only prove the charge, and the outcome cannot but be unfavourable when these are found among moneyed and respectable Indians.
('5', 373, 2, 10, 846324) All Indians will, we hope, learn a lesson from this case and keep their premises clean.
('5', 373, 2, 11, 846412) No one can deny that the state of our houses is not all that it should be.
('5', 373, 2, 12, 846487) It is clear that we should be all the more cautious in matters where our shortcomings are only too apparent.

('5', 373, 5, 15, 846663) The huge meeting at the Empire Theatre is over.

('5', 373, 5, 19, 847004) They had declared that there would be no difficulty in collecting the necessary funds.
('5', 373, 5, 20, 847091) Your correspondent, who had full faith in the people had taken it for granted that men speaking such words could raise six to seven thousand pounds in a day.

('5', 374, 1, 2, 847467) deputation and fighting the Asiatic Ordinance.

('5', 374, 1, 4, 847620) A telegram from a certain place says that the collection is yet to be made.
('5', 374, 1, 5, 847696) News received from another says that remittances would be made only after a certain Sheth has made his contribution.
('5', 374, 1, 6, 847813) A message from a third town says that they do not mean to send anything because a certain community is not contributing.

('5', 374, 1, 8, 847992) No one can say that a proper organization has not been set up for the management of the Fund.

('5', 374, 2, 19, 849201) Three or four other Indians who had come in relying on Mr. Bhayat’s case have also got their permits.

('5', 374, 3, 23, 849827) In his evidence, the constable who had examined the father and son could not say that he had seen the son.
('5', 374, 3, 24, 849934) But it was established in the evidence that the son’s thumb impressions had been taken.

('5', 375, 5, 14, 851313) ASSENT OF IMPERIAL GOVERNMENT: DEPUTATION POSTPONED
('5', 375, 6, 15, 851365) The saying, “ Man proposes and God disposes”, 2 has proved true in the case of the Transvaal Indians.
('5', 375, 7, 16, 851467) LORD ELGIN’S REPLY
('5', 375, 8, 17, 851486) The deputation which was to proceed to England to represent our grievances [to the authorities there] was scheduled to sail on Monday, October l ; but owing to some obstacle, its departure has been postponed by a week.
('5', 375, 8, 18, 851705) Just as arrangements were being made for booking the passages of delegates by steamer and letters were despatched to all the places to say that the deputation would leave on Monday, a communication 3 was received from Lord Selborne on
('5', 375, 9, 19, 851940) 1 Vide “Difficulties of Indian Women in the Transvaal”, 22 9 1906
('5', 375, 10, 20, 852006) 2 The saying in Gujarati literally means, ‘Tasks begun by us remain unfinished; only God’s will be done.’ 3 The letter was dated September 24, 1906. This as well as the translation of Lord Selborne’s letter on”The Transvaal Ordinance”, 29 9 1906 has been collated with the English texts of the relevant letters.
('5', 376, 0, 1, 852318) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 377
('5', 376, 1, 2, 852365) Tuesday morning.
('5', 376, 1, 3, 852382) It said:
('5', 376, 2, 4, 852391) Lord Elgin desires Lord Selborne to inform you that though the former is aware that the new legislation does not effect all the improvements in the condition of the Indians which His Majesty’s Government would desire, he has approved it as removing some of the hardships to which Asiatics are subject and goes as far as is possible on the eve of responsible government.
('5', 376, 2, 5, 852761) Lord Elgin adds that, while delegates from the Transvaal, if sent, will be given every opportunity for stating their views, he does not consider that any useful purpose is likely to be served by sending the deputation.
('5', 376, 3, 6, 852980) MEANING OF THE LETTER
('5', 376, 4, 7, 853002) The implication of the letter is that Lord Elgin asks us not to send a deputation.
('5', 376, 4, 8, 853085) It is obvious that there is nothing to be gained by the deputation going to England after the Ordinance has been passed.
('5', 376, 4, 9, 853206) The other implication is that, since the Indian community has made a show of strength and has resolved to oppose the Ordinance, it should be suppressed.
('5', 376, 4, 10, 853359) This is the way of the British: to look at accretions of strength with a stern eye and to dash them to the ground.
('5', 376, 4, 11, 853474) Lord Selborne must have advised Lord Elgin that, if the deputation went to England and if he received it, the Indian community would be led to entertain hopes of the Ordinance being dropped and that the community would meanwhile go on gathering strength.
('5', 376, 4, 12, 853729) It would therefore be advisable to nip in the bud their growing strength.
('5', 376, 4, 13, 853803) Acting presumably on such advice, Lord Elgin has approved the Ordinance without listening to what the deputation has to say.
('5', 376, 4, 14, 853928) This has ever been the way of the British with a subject people.
('5', 376, 4, 15, 853993) They have succeeded in it for the most part, since a conquered and subdued people is brave only in words, and shrinks back at the time of action.
('5', 376, 5, 16, 854139) OUR DUTY
('5', 376, 6, 17, 854148) Let us consider what the duty of the Indian community now is.
('5', 376, 6, 18, 854210) Our resolve to resist the Ordinance can give strength; it can also take it away.
('5', 376, 6, 19, 854291) If the Indian community firmly adheres to the Resolution, not only will it rise in the esteem of the people in the Transvaal and put an end to its many troubles, but the beneficent effect will be seen all over South Africa, and hundreds of men in the land of our birth will gain from it.
('5', 376, 6, 20, 854579) If, on the other hand, the Resolution were not acted upon, those who took the pledge would lose face; the whole community would be disgraced; our petitions would in future carry no weight and our plight would become worse than at present.
('5', 376, 6, 21, 854818) The whites would moreover laugh at us.
('5', 376, 6, 22, 854857) They would spit upon us, spurn us and call us cowards.
('5', 376, 6, 23, 854912) Never shall we be regarded as a united people.
('5', 377, 0, 1, 854959) 378 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 377, 1, 2, 855001) NO ACHIEVEMENT WITHOUT ADVENTURE
('5', 377, 2, 3, 855034) Such risk is always there in great undertakings.
('5', 377, 2, 4, 855083) In trade entailing great risks, if there is profit, it is immense, and if there is loss, it reduces one to utter poverty.
('5', 377, 2, 5, 855205) As our poets 1 have said, it was through adventure that Alexander became an Emperor; it was through adventure that Columbus discovered America; nothing is achieved without adventure.
('5', 377, 2, 6, 855388) Themselves an adventurous people, the British admire only those who are adventurous.
('5', 377, 2, 7, 855473) It is therefore the clear duty of every Indian not to take out [a register] again, but to go to gaol and stand firm on the pledge taken at the Empire Theatre.
('5', 377, 3, 8, 855632) SECOND LETTER FROM LORD SELBORNE
('5', 377, 4, 9, 855665) Another letter has been received from Lord Selborne, which gives added force to our advice.
('5', 377, 4, 10, 855757) The earlier letter which we have already cited in translation was written by Lord Selborne on behalf of Lord Elgin.
('5', 377, 4, 11, 855873) Let us now see what His Excellency has to say for himself:
('5', 377, 5, 12, 855932) From the argument which your Association puts forward, it seems that you have not grasped the real significance of the new law, which merely provides for the verification of existing documents .
('5', 377, 5, 13, 856127) and for the substitution of more complete, authentic documents such as will relieve Asiatics from the inconveniences to which they are liable under the present system.
('5', 377, 5, 14, 856295) If there is to be a system of registration, which will fulfil its purpose and prevent a general influx of Asiatics into the country, pending the establishment of responsible government, it must be complete and thorough.
('5', 377, 6, 15, 856515) With regard to the definition of Asiatics and the position of pre war Indian residents, the Ordinance does not disturb the existing conditions.
('5', 377, 6, 16, 856659) The provision for exemption from the liquor law had no special reference to British Indians.
('5', 377, 6, 17, 856752) It is intended to apply to individual Asiatics in respect of whom the present provisions of the law are an anomaly.
('5', 377, 6, 18, 856868) The Ordinance will apply to males only.
('5', 377, 7, 19, 856908) Lord Selborne cannot agree that the Draft Ordinance will be an act of serious wanton injustice directed against the Indian community or that it is in conflict with the views expressed by His Excellency from time to time.
('5', 377, 7, 20, 857129) This reply shows that Lord Selborne has not taken the trouble to acquaint himself with the Ordinance thoroughly or to understand the present situation.
('5', 377, 7, 21, 857281) Where there is so much ignorance, our duty can only be this: to act up to the Fourth Resolution about gaol going.
('5', 377, 7, 22, 857395) The Government will then immediately see that, unless there were genuine difficulties, a thousand men would not court imprisonment.
('5', 377, 8, 23, 857527) 1 The reference is to Narmadashanker, a Gujarati poet.

('5', 380, 2, 20, 864521) 343. DIVINE WRATH ON HONG KONG
('5', 380, 3, 21, 864552) While the news of how a beautiful city like San Francisco was suddenly reduced to dust and thousands of men were buried alive in a trice is still green in our memory, a similar earthquake has occurred in Chile and lakhs of people in Valparaiso and other places have been
('5', 381, 0, 1, 864823) 382 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 381, 1, 2, 864865) rendered homeless and obliged to wander about without food.
('5', 381, 1, 3, 864925) Hardly is that woeful tale over when there comes a cry from Asia that its children are no less unfortunate than those of America.
('5', 381, 1, 4, 865055) Last week there appeared the news of a cyclone in the sea near Hong Kong to the south of China.
('5', 381, 1, 5, 865151) Several ships and steamers were driven ashore and some completely wrecked.
('5', 381, 1, 6, 865226) Small craft and fishing boats sank and thousands of precious lives were lost.
('5', 381, 1, 7, 865304) As the sea rushed into the harbour, rivers began to flow through the city streets and the people in distress struggled hard to save themselves by means of boats.
('5', 381, 1, 8, 865466) It is said that about fifty steamers and ships were engulfed in thestorm.
('5', 381, 1, 9, 865540) Traces have been found of only a few of the 600 fishing boats that were out on a cruise.
('5', 381, 1, 10, 865629) At least 10,000 men lost their lives.
('5', 381, 1, 11, 865667) All this happened within a couple of hours.
('5', 381, 1, 12, 865711) Thoughtful persons will be grieved to know this.
('5', 381, 1, 13, 865760) Stories told in text books of God making or unmaking a universe in a moment, we now see enacted before our very eyes.
('5', 381, 1, 14, 865878) Inscrutable are the ways of God.
('5', 381, 1, 15, 865911) Man has always some lesson to learn from His dispensations.
('5', 381, 1, 16, 865971) While such an event is fresh in the mind, the virtuous have promptings from their inner selves, “Good man, take to the true path.
('5', 381, 1, 17, 866101) We know not when Death will overtake us.
('5', 381, 1, 18, 866142) Do good deeds then and make provision for your journey hence.” The same event warns the erring: “You fool, cast off your pride and walk in fear of God.
('5', 381, 1, 19, 866294) For Death might swallow you in no time.” [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 6 10 1906
('5', 381, 2, 20, 866377) 344. THE DUTY OF TRANSVAAL INDIANS
('5', 381, 3, 21, 866412) Since we give elsewhere a full account of the Transvaal situation, it is needless for us to say anything more about it here.
('5', 381, 3, 22, 866537) The present time is so critical that even Indians outside the Transvaal have become alarmed.
('5', 381, 3, 23, 866630) All of them feel that the step taken by the Indians in the Transvaal is very difficult and arduous.
('5', 381, 3, 24, 866730) It will justify itself only if it succeeds.
('5', 381, 3, 25, 866774) The Resolution passed by Indians is, and at the same time is not, unique.
('5', 381, 3, 26, 866848) We consider it unique, because nowhere else in the world have Indians so far resolved, as they have done now, to go to gaol rather than submit to a law.
('5', 381, 3, 27, 867001) On the other hand, we do not consider it unique because a number of similar instances are found [in history].
('5', 381, 3, 28, 867111) When we are dissatisfied with anything, we often resort to hartal.
('5', 381, 3, 29, 867178) In India we often consider it our duty to do so, in order to obtain redress of our grievances, particularly in the Native States.
('5', 381, 3, 30, 867308) The hartal only means that we do not approve of a certain measure taken by the ruler.
('5', 381, 3, 31, 867394) This tradition of resisting a law has been in vogue among us from
('5', 382, 0, 1, 867460) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 383
('5', 382, 1, 2, 867507) very early days, when the English people were in a barbarous state.
('5', 382, 1, 3, 867575) Thus, really speaking, the Resolution passed by the Transvaal Indians is nothing extraordinary and there is no reason why we should feel nervous.
('5', 382, 1, 4, 867721) Moreover, such examples are to be found even in South Africa.
('5', 382, 1, 5, 867783) When President Kruger proposed to remove the Indians from the Malay Location and send them to the Tobianski Farm, Mr. Emrys Evans, the British Agent, gave Indians the specific advice that they should on no account submit to President Kruger’s order.
('5', 382, 1, 6, 868033) Hence, despite police investigations and detectives entering their homes, the people remained firm, and they won.
('5', 382, 1, 7, 868147) When there were difficulties about licences, the Indians carried on their business in the towns fearlessly without licences, did not bow to the Boer Government, and succeeded.
('5', 382, 1, 8, 868323) That Government tried hard to send us to the Locations, but failed.
('5', 382, 1, 9, 868391) Subsequent to the war too, instances are found.
('5', 382, 1, 10, 868439) When Lord Milner brandished the sword of the Bazaar Notice against the Indians, the people for once were scared, but later they thought over the matter and finally decided not to go to the Location.
('5', 382, 1, 11, 868638) The summons that had already been issued at Potchefstroom had to be withdrawn.
('5', 382, 1, 12, 868717) The Indian people refused to accept the passes bearing their photographs that Mr. Moore had issued, and the Regulation had to be withdrawn.
('5', 382, 1, 13, 868857) We can easily find such examples among other communities too.
('5', 382, 1, 14, 868919) The Pass Law applies to Hottentots, but they oppose it and do not take out passes and the Government is powerless to do anything.
('5', 382, 1, 15, 869049) A house tax is levied on the Kaffirs of Natal; but some of the Zulu tribes do not pay the tax at all.
('5', 382, 1, 16, 869151) It is an open secret that the Government does not collect the tax from them.
('5', 382, 1, 17, 869228) All these instances show that there is no cause for us to be afraid at all.
('5', 382, 1, 18, 869304) However, there is some difference between the instances quoted above and the Resolution of the Indian community.
('5', 382, 1, 19, 869417) In all these instances no community as a whole had passed any resolution.
('5', 382, 1, 20, 869491) Further, though the people chose not to submit to the laws in question, they had not decided on how to meet the consequences and bring the issue to a final conclusion.
('5', 382, 1, 21, 869659) For example, when the Hottentots are arrested for not taking out passes, some of them pay the fine and some go to gaol.
('5', 382, 1, 22, 869779) The Transvaal Indians are determined to go to gaol rather than take out a new Register.
('5', 382, 1, 23, 869867) Two other alternatives are open to them—either to pay the fine or to leave the Colony.
('5', 382, 1, 24, 869954) After giving serious thought to both, the Indian community has discarded them.
('5', 382, 1, 25, 870033) And herein lie its uniqueness, its beauty and its strength.
('5', 382, 1, 26, 870093) If we pay the fine, it will be just the thing the Government wants.
('5', 382, 1, 27, 870161) If we leave the
('5', 383, 0, 1, 870177) 384 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 383, 1, 2, 870219) Colony, the whites will rejoice, clap their hands and wave their flags.
('5', 383, 1, 3, 870291) We will do neither of these things, for it would be ignominious and cowardly to do either.
('5', 383, 1, 4, 870382) Going to gaol is a unique step, a sacred act, and only by doing so can the Indian community maintain its honour.
('5', 383, 1, 5, 870495) What does it matter if, in doing so, we lose our trade ?
('5', 383, 1, 6, 870552) If a fire destroys their houses and goods, traders accept it calmly and, being courageous, start their business afresh and earn their livelihood.
('5', 383, 1, 7, 870698) No one who has hands and feet and possesses ability and intelligence has need, at any rate in this country, to starve.
('5', 383, 1, 8, 870817) What if a hundred or more lose their all and become paupers in serving the community or the country?
('5', 383, 1, 9, 870918) The English honour only those who make such sacrifice.
('5', 383, 1, 10, 870973) Their shining glory has spread just because great heroes have been and are still born among them.
('5', 383, 1, 11, 871071) Such were Wat Tyler, John Hampden, John Bunyan and others.
('5', 383, 1, 12, 871130) They laid the foundations of England’s political supremacy.
('5', 383, 1, 13, 871190) Who they were and what they did we shall tell some other time.
('5', 383, 1, 14, 871253) 1 But we shall continue to be in our present abject condition till we follow their example.
('5', 383, 1, 15, 871345) The Indian community has a good opportunity today of proving its mettle.
('5', 383, 1, 16, 871418) We hope that it willnot let it slip, but will rush to the field, plunge in whole heartedly and fight to the last.
('5', 383, 1, 17, 871532) There was a time in India when the mother refused to look at the face of a son who returned vanquished from the battle field.
('5', 383, 1, 18, 871658) We pray to God that every Indian in the Transvaal will remember that time.
('5', 383, 1, 19, 871733) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 6 10 1906

('5', 384, 5, 7, 873181) (2) The Ordinance) your Petitioner notices, is not to take effect “unless and until the Governor shall proclaim in the Gazette that it is His Majesty’s pleasure not to disallow the same”.
('5', 384, 5, 8, 873369) Your petitioner, therefore, ventured to send Your Lordship a cable 3 requesting that the Royal pleasure may not be declared until the Association had the opportunity of making its submission to Your Lordship.
('5', 384, 5, 9, 873578) (3) The Association respectfully protests against sections 5, 8 and 9 of the second schedule to the Ordinance above named.
('5', 384, 5, 10, 873701) (4) The sections in question are as follows:
('5', 384, 6, 11, 873746) 5. This lease shall not be transferable to any coloured person and if registered in the name of any such person this lease shall ipso facto cease and determine.
('5', 384, 7, 12, 873907) 8. Neither the said stand nor any part thereof nor any building thereon shall be sub let to any coloured person or Asiatic.
('5', 384, 7, 13, 874031) Upon any breach of this condition the Council may forthwith by notice in writing given in the
('5', 384, 8, 14, 874125) 1 This was also published in Indian Opinion, 13 10 1906 and India, 2 11 1906. 2 Though this was submitted a week after Gandhiji’s departure for England, it is probable that, before he left, Gandhiji drafted this petition on an issue of vital concern to the Indians.
('5', 384, 8, 15, 874391) 3 Vide the preceding item.
('5', 385, 0, 1, 874418) 386 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 385, 1, 2, 874460) manner provided in Clause Four terminate this lease.
('5', 385, 1, 3, 874513) 9. The Lessee shall not permit any coloured person or Asiatic other than the servant bona fide of some white person for the time being residing on the said stand to reside thereon or to occupy the same or any part thereof.
('5', 385, 1, 4, 874736) If any coloured person or Asiatic other than such servant as aforesaid is at any time found residing on the said stand or occupying the same or any part thereof the Council may give notice to the Lessee in the manner provided in Clause Four requiring him to cause such person to cease to reside thereon or to occupy the same or any part thereof within a period of three weeks from the date of such notice and if at any time after the expiration of such period such person shall be found residing thereon or occupying the same or any part thereof, the Council may forthwith by notice to the Lessee given in the manner aforesaid terminate this lease.
('5', 385, 1, 5, 875385) (5) Thus, in effect, the Ordinance prohibits the residence of British Indians except as domestic servants.
('5', 385, 1, 6, 875492) (6) Such prohibition will create a fresh disability against British Indians.
('5', 385, 1, 7, 875569) (7) In the humble opinion of the Association, there is no justification for the contemplated restriction.
('5', 385, 1, 8, 875675) (8) The Association, moreover, draws Your Lordship’s attention to the fact that British Indians have, for years past, held stands within the area affected by the Ordinance, from the original grantees—the burghers of Vrededorp.
('5', 385, 1, 9, 875902) (9) Some British Indians have erected substantial structures on such stands, and some are at present either residing on the stands leased by them or carrying on trade.
('5', 385, 1, 10, 876070) (10) If the clauses objected to are sanctioned, all such persons as are here in before referred to and have acquired vested rights will be adversely affected and some of them ruined in business.
('5', 385, 1, 11, 876265) (11) The Association ventures to point out that, when the Vrededorp Commission sat some time ago to report upon the Draft Ordinance, objection to any such clauses as are before referred to was submitted to the Commission on behalf of British Indians.
('5', 385, 1, 12, 876516) (12) The Association draws Your Lordship’s attention to thefurther fact that the area affected by the Ordinance is contiguous to the Malay Location, which contains a large Asiatic, and principally British Indian, population.
('5', 385, 1, 13, 876741) The relations between the inhabitants of Vrededorp and the Malay Location have always been satisfactory.
('5', 385, 1, 14, 876846) (13) The Association feels that, if the clauses referred to are approved by Your Lordship, the acceptance will form a precedent for other bodies, and may lead to the ultimate reduction of British Indians
('5', 386, 0, 1, 877050) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 387
('5', 386, 1, 2, 877097) to the status of menials and their compulsory removal to Locations.
('5', 386, 1, 3, 877165) (14) Your petitioner, therefore, humbly prays that the Ordinance in question will be disallowed, or such other relief will be granted as to Your Lordship may seem meet.
('5', 386, 1, 4, 877334) And for this act of justice and mercy your petitioner shall for ever pray, etc., etc.

('5', 386, 3, 7, 877571) 347. THE DEPUTATION’S VOYAGE—I
('5', 386, 4, 8, 877602) [S. S. ARMADALE CASTLE, Before October 11, 1906] Readers of Indian Opinion are aware of the election of the deputation to England with regard to the new Asiatic Ordinance and of the difficulties experienced in that connection.
('5', 386, 4, 9, 877829) From the very beginning the people had decided that the deputation should consist of three men, viz., Messrs Abdul Gani, Ally and Gandhi; but at the last moment Mr. Abdul Gani withdrew and Messrs Ally and Gandhi had to go without him.
('5', 386, 5, 10, 878064) INITIAL DIFFICULTY
('5', 386, 6, 11, 878083) On Friday, September 28, a definite resolution was passed that the two members mentioned above should go.
('5', 386, 6, 12, 878189) It was decided that they should sail by the s.s.
('5', 386, 6, 13, 878238) Armadale Castle, and their passages were booked on Saturday, September 29. The delegates were to leave by the Cape Mail on Monday, October 1, and the tickets for that train were also purchased; but an hour later word was received from the Station Master that the deputation could not go by the Cape Mail, but only by the train leaving at 9 p.m.
('5', 386, 6, 14, 878583) This meant that the deputation, being thus unable to travel by the Cape Mail, would miss the Armadale Castle and hence be delayed by a week.
('5', 386, 6, 15, 878724) Mr. Gandhi immediately spoke to the General Manager over the ‘phone and explained to him how necessary it was for them to leave by the Cape Mail.
('5', 386, 6, 16, 878870) The General Manager could not understand the Station Master’s objection and told Mr. Gandhi that he would make inquiries and then telephone the result to him.
('5', 386, 6, 17, 879029) After an hour, a message was received saying that the Station Master had made a mistake and that there
('5', 387, 0, 1, 879132) 388 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 387, 1, 2, 879174) would be no difficulty in the deputation travelling by the Cape Mail
('5', 387, 2, 3, 879243) ON THE TRAIN
('5', 387, 3, 4, 879256) The deputation boarded the train at 6 15 p.m.
('5', 387, 3, 5, 879302) Certain persons, as previously decided, had come to the station to see the deputation off.
('5', 387, 3, 6, 879393) They were Messrs Abdul Gani, Essop Mian, Coovadia, Omarji, Shahbuddin, Fancy, Bhikhubhai and others.
('5', 387, 3, 7, 879494) Mr. Bhikhubhai had brought a coconut 1 and other things.
('5', 387, 3, 8, 879551) The members of the deputation shook hands with everyone before taking leave.
('5', 387, 4, 9, 879628) MR. HAJI OJER ALLY’S HEALTH
('5', 387, 5, 10, 879656) Mr. Haji Ojer Ally was feeling exhausted owing to over work during many days and he was ill and restless.
('5', 387, 5, 11, 879762) He has rheumatism and, even when the deputation was being discussed, he was afraid of being troubled by it on the way.
('5', 387, 5, 12, 879881) The fear came true on the train itself.
('5', 387, 5, 13, 879921) Pain started in the joints.
('5', 387, 5, 14, 879949) I pressed and massaged his joints and did whatever I could.
('5', 387, 5, 15, 880009) But that gave no lasting relief.
('5', 387, 5, 16, 880042) Mr. Ally took the food he had brought with him and also some coffee.
('5', 387, 5, 17, 880111) He had no appetite for anything else.
('5', 387, 5, 18, 880149) I went to the Saloon for meals, and took boiled potatoes and peas with bread.
('5', 387, 5, 19, 880227) I also took the fruit and nuts Mr. Bhikhubhai had given us.
('5', 387, 5, 20, 880287) I tin did my writing.
('5', 387, 5, 21, 880309) Mr. Ally went to bed at ten.
('5', 387, 5, 22, 880338) I retired at midnight after finishing my writing work.
('5', 387, 5, 23, 880393) Mr. Ally spent a restless night.
('5', 387, 5, 24, 880426) When he got up on Tuesday morning, he had a very severe pain, also slight fever and bronchitis.
('5', 387, 6, 25, 880522) ARRANGEMENTS ON THE CAPE MAIL
('5', 387, 7, 26, 880552) Amenities on the Cape Mail are almost the same as on a steamer.
('5', 387, 7, 27, 880616) Food is served from the morning onwards.
('5', 387, 7, 28, 880657) There is provision even for bathing.
('5', 387, 7, 29, 880694) The passengers can have a shower bath.
('5', 387, 7, 30, 880733) Only first class passengers can travel by this train.
('5', 387, 8, 31, 880787) IN CAPE TOWN
('5', 387, 9, 32, 880800) The train reached Cape Town at two o’clock on Wednesday.
('5', 387, 9, 33, 880857) Messrs Yusuf Hamid Gool, Amod Gool, Lachhiram and Abdul Kadar had come to the station to receive us.
('5', 387, 9, 34, 880958) Ma Yusuf Hamid Gool had arranged for our meal at his place.
('5', 387, 9, 35, 881018) We took it and left at 4 45. All these gentlemen also came to the steamer to see us off.
('5', 387, 10, 36, 881107) “THE ARMADALE CASTLE”
('5', 387, 11, 37, 881129) This steamer is one of the biggest among those belonging to the Union Casle Line.
('5', 387, 11, 38, 881211) Its tonnage is 12,973 and As horse power 12,500. It is 590’ 6” long, 64’ 6” broad and 42’ 3” high.
('5', 387, 12, 39, 881310) 1 The coconut is an auspicious symbol.
('5', 388, 0, 1, 881349) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 389
('5', 388, 1, 2, 881396) accommodation for 320 first class, 225 second class and 280 third class passengers.
('5', 388, 1, 3, 881480) For each of the classes there is a very large and beautiful dining hall.
('5', 388, 1, 4, 881553) It has excellent arrangements for ventilation.
('5', 388, 1, 5, 881600) There are books to read and a separate reading room for each class.
('5', 388, 1, 6, 881668) The bathing arrangements are very good; and one can have as much hot and cold water as one wants.
('5', 388, 1, 7, 881766) The lavatories are kept very clean, and there is a notice saying that passengers should not leave the seat dirty.
('5', 388, 1, 8, 881880) The first and the second classes have four sections each.
('5', 388, 1, 9, 881938) We hold first class tickets for the third section and had each to pay £79 15 0.
('5', 388, 2, 10, 882018) CATERING ARRANGEMENTS
('5', 388, 3, 11, 882040) Catering arrangements in these steamers are such that it would appear that the passengers had nothing to do but eat the whole day.
('5', 388, 3, 12, 882171) At six in the morning, the bearer brings coffee, bread and fruit.
('5', 388, 3, 13, 882237) At 8 30 one has breakfast in the Saloon, and some ten different items are served.
('5', 388, 3, 14, 882319) At eleven tea and biscuits are served on deck.
('5', 388, 3, 15, 882366) Again at 1 p.m.
('5', 388, 3, 16, 882382) lunch begins to be served in the Saloon; this again has ten to fifteen items.
('5', 388, 3, 17, 882460) At four in the afternoon again, tea, biscuits, bread, etc.; at six o’clock dinner in the Saloon and at nine or later, tea, coffee, biscuits, cheese, etc., as the passengers choose.
('5', 388, 3, 18, 882641) All this is covered by the steamer fare.
('5', 388, 3, 19, 882682) In addition, the passengers can have wine, etc.
('5', 388, 3, 20, 882730) between meals or at meal time for which they have of course to pay.
('5', 388, 3, 21, 882798) One seldom comes across passengers who do not take alcoholic drinks.
('5', 388, 4, 22, 882867) PASSENGERS
('5', 388, 5, 23, 882878) Among fellow passengers, there are three well known men who must be mentioned.
('5', 388, 5, 24, 882957) One is the Acting Lieutenant Governor of the Transvaal, Sir Richard Solomon, accompanied by Lady Solomon.
('5', 388, 5, 25, 883063) He is going especially to see Lord Elgin.
('5', 388, 5, 26, 883105) Another is Sir David Gill, the famous astronomer of South Africa, and the third is Sir John Buchanan, a Judge of the Cape Supreme Court.
('5', 388, 5, 27, 883242) Lord Wolmer is also with us.
('5', 388, 5, 28, 883271) In the next instalment, I shall describe Mr. Ally’s state of health, the way Mr. Ally and I spend our time, and the arrangements we have made for our meals.
('5', 388, 5, 29, 883428) Meanwhile, lest anyone should be anxious, I may say here straightaway that Mr. Ally’s health has improved and, as I write this, he is enjoying himself on the deck.
('5', 388, 5, 30, 883592) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 10 11 1906
('5', 389, 0, 1, 883635) 390 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 389, 1, 2, 883677) 348. THE DEPUTATION’S VOYAGE—II
('5', 389, 2, 3, 883709) [S. S. ARMADALE CASTLE October 11, 1906]
('5', 389, 3, 4, 883750) WHAT DID WE DO ?
('5', 389, 3, 5, 883767) I said in my first article that Mr. Ally’s health had not improved when we boarded the steamer.
('5', 389, 3, 6, 883863) He was obliged to stay in bed.
('5', 389, 3, 7, 883894) For two clays he took the pills he had brought with him and got me to rub in soap liniment.
('5', 389, 3, 8, 883986) This seemed to result in some improvement, but the pain did not stop altogether.
('5', 389, 3, 9, 884067) On the third day, the doctor was consulted, and he gave him Phenacetin, a medicine inducing perspiration.
('5', 389, 3, 10, 884173) That loosened the joints, and on the fourth day, Mr. Ally could leave his bed, but he was not yet completely cured.
('5', 389, 3, 11, 884289) I then recommended to him Dr. Kuhne’s treatment.
('5', 389, 3, 12, 884338) Accordingly, Mr. Ally now takes hot and cold baths and does without the morning meal.
('5', 389, 3, 13, 884424) Formerly he used to have coffee on getting up, and porridge, coffee and fruit at breakfast.
('5', 389, 3, 14, 884516) He has stopped all this, now has his first meal at 1 p.m.
('5', 389, 3, 15, 884574) and has given up all medicines.
('5', 389, 3, 16, 884606) It is now (October 11) three days since he began this treatment.
('5', 389, 3, 17, 884671) As a result, Mr. Ally feels better.
('5', 389, 3, 18, 884707) He is hungry at 1 p.m., and constipation and indigestion do not trouble him now.
('5', 389, 3, 19, 884788) He does not even smoke till 1 p.m.
('5', 389, 3, 20, 884823) And though his health cannot yet be said to have returned to normal, his rheumatism is certainly under control; and he has little difficulty in moving his limbs.
('5', 389, 3, 21, 884985) His food is simple.
('5', 389, 3, 22, 885005) At one, he takes fish and potatoes, pudding and coffee, and ginger ale.
('5', 389, 3, 23, 885077) He has a cup of tea at four in the afternoon and at 6 30 p.m., fish, green vegetables, ginger ale; pudding and coffee.
('5', 389, 3, 24, 885196) He does not seem to feel the need for anything more.
('5', 389, 3, 25, 885249) If the reader is curious to know what I eat, I may say that, for three days, I had three meals a day.
('5', 389, 3, 26, 885351) But finding these unnecessary, I now take milk, bread, potatoes, soda water or ginger ale, stewed fruit and cream at 1 p.m., cocoa at four and potatoes, boiled vegetables, stewed fruit and soda water or ginger ale at 6 30 in the evening.
('5', 389, 3, 27, 885589) I do not eat bread, raw fruit and nuts for the only reason that a loose molar has been hurting me.
('5', 389, 3, 28, 885688) I feel quite satisfied with this diet and can do a lot of work.
('5', 389, 3, 29, 885752) The main reason for this is, I think, that the stomach has rest till l p.m.
('5', 389, 3, 30, 885828) and finds this food satisfying and sufficient.
('5', 389, 3, 31, 885875) Some of these items are outside my usual menu.
('5', 389, 3, 32, 885922) the fact that I keep fit shows that food, on an empty stomach, never does harm.
('5', 389, 3, 33, 886002) Mr. Ally is reading Justice Amir Ali’s Spirit of Islam and Washington Irving’s Mahomet and His Successors.
('5', 389, 3, 34, 886109) I am studying Tamil, and reading Forbes’s Rasamala or A History of Gujarat, and
('5', 390, 0, 1, 886189) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 391
('5', 390, 1, 2, 886236) the Alien Immigration Report.
('5', 390, 1, 3, 886266) Now that Madeira is approaching, I have started writing my despatch for the Opinion.
('5', 390, 1, 4, 886351) We have very little contact with other passengers.
('5', 390, 1, 5, 886402) Occasionally a few words are exchanged with Sir Richard Solomon.
('5', 390, 1, 6, 886467) There are with us the Chinese Consul, his nine year old daughter, and Mr. James of the Chinese Deputation [going to England] in connection with the Asiatic Act.
('5', 390, 1, 7, 886628) The Chinese Consul wears official uniform.
('5', 390, 1, 8, 886671) By nature he is sociable, pleasing in his manner and intelligent.
('5', 390, 1, 9, 886737) Having had a good English education, his daughter enjoys herself and also amuses the passengers who are quite free with her.
('5', 390, 2, 10, 886862) GENERAL ATMOSPHERE ABOARD STEAMER
('5', 390, 3, 11, 886896) Other passengers spend the day in much merriment.
('5', 390, 3, 12, 886946) Sports have been going on for the last week.
('5', 390, 3, 13, 886991) Subscriptions were collected for awarding prizes, and we had to part with a guinea each.
('5', 390, 3, 14, 887080) Among the games are deck cricket, ring tennis, egg and spoon race, etc.

('5', 390, 3, 18, 887338) The chief reason why we have not been able to participate in them is Mr. Ally’s poor health and my own studies.
('5', 390, 3, 19, 887450) There are no sports on Sundays.

('5', 390, 4, 21, 887583) THOUGHTS ARISING PROM THIS
('5', 390, 5, 22, 887610) When I see all this I often ask myself why it is that the English rule.
('5', 390, 5, 23, 887682) I am reminded of a poem by the Gujarati poet Narmadashanker 1: The Englishman rules, The country is under his heel, The native remains subdued; Look at their bodies, brother, He is full five cubits tall, A host in himself, match for five hundred.
('5', 390, 5, 24, 887929) As I observe all this, I find that the Englishman is not only full five cubits tall, a host in himself, match for five hundred but is capable in every other way.
('5', 390, 5, 25, 888091) When he chooses to enjoy wealth and power, he excels in doing it and he makes the best of poverty, too.
('5', 390, 5, 26, 888195) He alone knows how to give orders; and he knows too how to take them.
('5', 390, 5, 27, 888265) In his behaviour he is great with the great and small with the small.
('5', 390, 5, 28, 888335) He knows how to earn money and he alone knows how to spend it.
('5', 390, 6, 29, 888398) 1 A late nineteenth century Gujarati poet whom Gandhiji often quotes
('5', 391, 0, 1, 888467) 392 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 391, 1, 2, 888509) knows how to converse and move in company.
('5', 391, 1, 3, 888552) He lives in the knowledge that his happiness depends on the happiness of others.
('5', 391, 1, 4, 888633) The [English]man I observed during the war seems to be an altogether different person now.
('5', 391, 1, 5, 888724) Then he did all his work himself, trekked over long distances and felt happy with dry bread.
('5', 391, 1, 6, 888817) Here on board the ship he does not do any work.
('5', 391, 1, 7, 888865) He presses a button, and an attendant stands before him.
('5', 391, 1, 8, 888922) He must have nice dishes of all kinds to eat.
('5', 391, 1, 9, 888968) Every day he puts on a new dress.
('5', 391, 1, 10, 889002) All this becomes him, but he does not lose his balance.
('5', 391, 1, 11, 889058) Like the sea, he can contain all within himself.
('5', 391, 1, 12, 889107) Though, generally speaking, he has little sense of religion, yet living in society, he is disciplined and observes sabbath.
('5', 391, 1, 13, 889231) Why indeed should such a people not rule?

('5', 392, 2, 6, 891282) 350. CONFLAGRATION ALL ROUND
('5', 392, 3, 7, 891311) A lot of discussion is nowadays going on about the Asiatic question among public bodies in South Africa.
('5', 392, 3, 8, 891416) In such discussions, Indians are held up to blame on the slightest pretext.
('5', 392, 3, 9, 891492) Among the fault finders, the foremost are the Chambers of Commerce.
('5', 392, 3, 10, 891560) At a meeting of the Chambers of Commerce held in Delagoa Bay, a suggestion was made that Indians should be removed to a Location.
('5', 392, 3, 11, 891690) We have referred to this matter earlier.
('5', 392, 3, 12, 891731) Recently 1 a meeting of the Chamber of Commerce took place at Maritzburg, at which opinions about Indian traders were expressed.
('5', 392, 3, 13, 891860) In his address the Chairman said that there had been an increase in the number of Coloured traders and a decrease in that of white traders.
('5', 392, 3, 14, 892000) In saying this, the Chairman, Mr. Griffin, does not seem to have bothered about the correctness of his figures.
('5', 392, 3, 15, 892112) Before asserting that the increase in the number of Indian traders was alarming, he should have offered precise proof of the increase.
('5', 392, 3, 16, 892247) Mr. Griffin further stated that in the rural areas Indians were so well established that they could send a representative of their own to the [local] board.
('5', 392, 3, 17, 892404) This statement, too, is as baseless as the earlier one.
('5', 392, 3, 18, 892460) But supposing it is true, what is wrong about it?
('5', 392, 3, 19, 892510) Do not the Indian traders contribute to the prosperity of the country?
('5', 392, 3, 20, 892581) They require protection quite as much as the European traders.
('5', 392, 3, 21, 892644) In the course of his speech, Mr. Griffin also blurted out that the Shops [Early Closing] Act had proved to be a weapon for crushing the Indians with.
('5', 392, 3, 22, 892794) Such talk betrays the fact that the Act is aimed at Indians only.
('5', 392, 3, 23, 892860) But the funny part of it is that, though the law was made to crush the Indians, the whites say that the Indians flourish in spite of it.
('5', 392, 3, 24, 892997) If this is true, there must be some innate merit in the Indian.
('5', 392, 3, 25, 893061) What then is to be gained by wasting time in finding fault with the Indian instead of learning from him?

('5', 393, 5, 7, 893526) 352. THE DEPUTATION’S VOYAGE—III
('5', 393, 6, 8, 893559) [S. S. ARMADALE CASTLE, Before October 20, 1906]
('5', 393, 7, 9, 893608) MORE REFLECTIONS
('5', 393, 8, 10, 893625) Writing about the voyage, we have reflected why the English prosper.
('5', 393, 8, 11, 893694) I am aware that, as every shield has two sides, so has the Englishman’s way of life.
('5', 393, 8, 12, 893779) It should not be our business to examine the reverse side.
('5', 393, 8, 13, 893838) Just as a swan, as the saying goes, separates milk from water and drinks only the former, so must we learn to recognize our rulers’ virtues, which alone we should follow.
('5', 393, 8, 14, 894009) Continuing this train of thought, we noticed that people on the boat did not merely enjoy themselves all day long.
('5', 393, 8, 15, 894124) Those who had work to do did it as if it was the most natural thing to do, without fuss.
('5', 393, 8, 16, 894213) On this steamer there are passengers who are always reading.
('5', 393, 8, 17, 894274) They read not for pleasure, but because it is necessary.
('5', 393, 8, 18, 894331) As soon as their reading is over, they join others in sport and merriment.
('5', 393, 8, 19, 894406) The crew discharge their duties punctually to the minute.
('5', 393, 8, 20, 894464) Looking at the vanities around them, they do not forget their station in life.
('5', 393, 8, 21, 894543) Envying none, they remain absorbed in their work.
('5', 393, 8, 22, 894593) We Indians, too, behave in much the same way, and in certain respects excel them.
('5', 393, 8, 23, 894675) But if we take an overall view, the balance sheet will show more to the Englishman’s credit.
('5', 393, 8, 24, 894768) We do not possess the ability to build steamers like the one we are sailing in.
('5', 393, 8, 25, 894848) Even if we can build one, we have not the ability to operate it.
('5', 393, 8, 26, 894913) We cannot match their record in public sanitation.
('5', 393, 8, 27, 894964) We rarely present the spectacle of a number of men working together without noise.
('5', 394, 0, 1, 895047) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 395
('5', 394, 1, 2, 895094) mode of life is such that they can save much time, and in the modern age to save time is to gain money.
('5', 394, 1, 3, 895198) On the steamer there is a printing press.
('5', 394, 1, 4, 895240) Programmes and menus are printed every day.
('5', 394, 1, 5, 895284) Typewriters are used for routine work.
('5', 394, 1, 6, 895323) Most of the cooking is done with machines.
('5', 394, 1, 7, 895366) Thus, cleanliness is maintained and time saved.
('5', 394, 1, 8, 895414) All this is necessary for the way they wish to live and do live.
('5', 394, 1, 9, 895479) Viewing things in this manner we should conclude, without looking at their faults or envying them, that they deserve all they have, and for the most part it is necessary to behave as they do.
('5', 394, 1, 10, 895671) This is not the place to consider how we can set about doing this.
('5', 394, 1, 11, 895738) Here I have put my thoughts before the reader as they occurred to me during the voyage.
('5', 394, 2, 12, 895826) STEAMERS SPEED AND THE WEATHER
('5', 394, 3, 13, 895857) A steamer belonging to this Line generally travels fast.
('5', 394, 3, 14, 895914) On an average we cover about 370 miles a day.
('5', 394, 3, 15, 895960) The weather was cold during the first four days, but as we proceeded it began to warm up.
('5', 394, 3, 16, 896050) At present we are near the Equator, and it is very hot; in these parts this heat is normal.
('5', 394, 3, 17, 896142) It will continue to be hot for another five or six days.
('5', 394, 3, 18, 896199) We do not feel this extreme heat because of the many cooling devices on the steamer.
('5', 394, 3, 19, 896284) In portholes there are arrangements to let in air so that it remains cool throughout the night.
('5', 394, 3, 20, 896380) Changes are also made in the food to suit passengers’ tastes.
('5', 394, 3, 21, 896442) Every passenger is provided with a fan.
('5', 394, 4, 22, 896482) A TALK WITH SIR RICHARD SOLOMON
('5', 394, 5, 23, 896514) We had a talk with Sir Richard Solomon as we were approaching Madeira.
('5', 394, 5, 24, 896585) After we had discussed the whole question he said that he would consider the idea of appointing a Commission at some future date.
('5', 394, 5, 25, 896715) His information was that the Indian community had engaged agents at every port to instruct the immigrants about the geography of the Transvaal and help them to enter, and that many men had entered in this manner.
('5', 394, 5, 26, 896928) This would mean that the whole Indian community was deceitful and that the new law had been enacted to punish it.
('5', 394, 5, 27, 897042) The next day, Sir Richard advised Mr. Ally to accept the new Act, which leads one to infer that Sir Richard has given up the idea of appointing a Commission.
('5', 394, 5, 28, 897200) The reason for this, I think, is that he aspires to be the Prime Minister under Responsible Government, and that his ambition would probably be thwarted if he accepted our plea and appointed a Commission.
('5', 394, 5, 29, 897405) He would therefore do nothing for us.

('5', 395, 1, 2, 897528) 353. SOME QUESTIONS
('5', 395, 2, 3, 897548) Many questions have been asked about the new Transvaal Ordinance.
('5', 395, 2, 4, 897614) We give below the important ones along with their replies.
('5', 395, 3, 5, 897673) QUESTIONS
('5', 395, 4, 6, 897683) How is one to disobey the law?
('5', 395, 4, 7, 897714) 2. What defence can one offer for doing so?
('5', 395, 4, 8, 897758) 3. May one seek release on bail or not?
('5', 395, 4, 9, 897798) 4. What is the likely sentence?
('5', 395, 4, 10, 897830) 5. Will they arrest the hawkers first or the others?
('5', 395, 4, 11, 897883) 6. How will it affect the traders?
('5', 395, 4, 12, 897918) 7. What will happen to licences next year?
('5', 395, 4, 13, 897961) 8. What shall we do if nothing is gained even by going to gaol?
('5', 395, 4, 14, 898025) 9. And if some take out new Registers?
('5', 395, 4, 15, 898064) 10. What is the harm in taking out a Register?
('5', 395, 5, 16, 898111) ANSWERS
('5', 395, 6, 17, 898119) 1. Many people believe that all Indians have to appear on January 1 at a Court or at the gate of a gaol and say, “We do not want to take out a Register.
('5', 395, 6, 18, 898272) Arrest us.” Resistance cannot be offered in this way.
('5', 395, 6, 19, 898326) Even if all people thus present themselves, the Government willnot arrest them.
('5', 395, 6, 20, 898406) Whether to arrest or not depends on the will of the Government.
('5', 395, 6, 21, 898470) They definitely want and expect most of the people to take out new Registers before January 1. The Government will be in a fix what to do if, no Indian has, by that date, taken out a Register.
('5', 395, 6, 22, 898663) It is probable that they might seek the opinion of the leaders.
('5', 395, 6, 23, 898727) Whether they do so or not, the [British Indian] Association will have to write to them intimating that no one from the community will take out the Register and that, if they intend prosecuting the offender, it will be proper for them to proceed against the leaders.
('5', 395, 6, 24, 898993) The Government may or may not pay heed to the letter.
('5', 395, 6, 25, 899047) When one or more men are arrested for not taking out Registers, Mr. Gandhi is bound to defend them, as he has promised.
('5', 395, 6, 26, 899167) There will be no other defence.
('5', 395, 6, 27, 899199) He will narrate the history of the matter and plead that the real culprit is not the person not taking out the Register, but that either Mr. Gandhi or the Association must be deemed guilty, for it was on their advice that people refrained from taking them out.
('5', 395, 6, 28, 899460) Then, Mr. Gandhi may perhaps be arrested for inciting the people, or the arrested persons may be fined or sentenced to short terms of imprisonment.
('5', 395, 6, 29, 899608) As paying the fine is out of the question, the only alternative will be to go to
('5', 396, 0, 1, 899689) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 397
('5', 396, 1, 2, 899736) Reports of these cases and of others that may be instituted will be cabled to the whole world.
('5', 396, 1, 3, 899831) 2. There is to be no legal defence other than the one described above.
('5', 396, 1, 4, 899902) If perchance the Prosecutor commits a mistake in law, advantage may no doubt be taken of it.
('5', 396, 1, 5, 899995) 3. When we have already passed a resolution to go to gaol, there can be no question of release on bail.
('5', 396, 1, 6, 900099) No disgrace attaches to this kind of imprisonment.
('5', 396, 1, 7, 900150) 4. The sentence generally will be either fine or imprisonment in lieu of fine, or both, and further imprisonment in lieu of a fine.
('5', 396, 1, 8, 900282) In no case is the fine to be paid.
('5', 396, 1, 9, 900317) No sentence can be passed under which a man can be seized by the arm and turned out.
('5', 396, 1, 10, 900402) Even after serving his sentence, if a man does not take out a new Register, he is again guilty and therefore the Government can, if it chooses, keep all these persons in gaol for all time.
('5', 396, 1, 11, 900591) 5. It is not possible to say who will be arrested first.

('5', 396, 1, 14, 900787) In that case, the shop should be closed or may be entrusted to a reliable white.
('5', 396, 1, 15, 900868) It is hardly likely that the Government will go to these lengths.
('5', 396, 1, 16, 900934) However, one must not assume that certain things will never happen.
('5', 396, 1, 17, 901002) 7. According to the new Act, those who do not take out the new Registers are not entitled to licences.
('5', 396, 1, 18, 901105) If licences are not issued, the fee for them may be tendered and the business continued.
('5', 396, 1, 19, 901194) Even if prosecuted for trading without a licence, one should not pay the fine, but serve the gaol sentence.
('5', 396, 1, 20, 901302) 8. Such a question cannot arise.

('5', 396, 1, 22, 901407) What could be worse than giving one’s finger prints and disgracing oneself?
('5', 396, 1, 23, 901483) How can we do that which we consider disgraceful?
('5', 396, 1, 24, 901533) Surely, we are not going to commit theft because others do so.
('5', 396, 1, 25, 901596) When Hampden refused to pay Ship Money, he did not argue in this strain.
('5', 396, 1, 26, 901669) 9. If some persons take out the new Register, they will lose their good name and earn the contempt of the Indian community.
('5', 396, 1, 27, 901793) 10. The disadvantage in taking out the new Register is that our condition will thereby become worse than that of the Kaffirs.
('5', 396, 1, 28, 901919) The question does not arise here whether men without permits gain or lose by taking out or not taking out the Register.

('5', 397, 2, 4, 902453) 354. A RAY OF HOPE
('5', 397, 3, 5, 902472) There have not been two opinions on how for the Resolutions of the mass meeting will produce results.
('5', 397, 3, 6, 902574) As for Resolutions 3 and 4, what will happen still remains to be seen.
('5', 397, 3, 7, 902645) Their fruit is a long time away yet; and this depends upon the determination of the Indian community.
('5', 397, 3, 8, 902747) Nothing but good can come of adhering staunchly to Resolution 4. However, who can say that it has not already begun to have effect?
('5', 397, 3, 9, 902879) At one time it was thought that Resolution 3, about the sending of the deputation, might be dropped.
('5', 397, 3, 10, 902980) Recent Press messages show that we did very well in sending the deputation in time.
('5', 397, 3, 11, 903064) Our Johannesburg Correspondent says that the Secretary of State has sent a cablegram to Lord Selborne asking him to inform the British Indian Association that sanction to the Asiatic Act will not be accorded before the representation of the Indian deputation has been heard.
('5', 397, 3, 12, 903339) This by itself shows that Resolution 3 has served its purpose.
('5', 397, 3, 13, 903402) Among the reasons that prompted the Secretary of State to attach weight to Indian protests, the impact of Resolution 4 may be considered to be the primary one.
('5', 397, 3, 14, 903562) Lord Elgin’s cablegram proves the usefulness of Resolution 3 and also shows the impact of Resolution 4. Whether the deputation succeeds or not, this much is established that the Imperial Government has taken some notice of the Transvaal Indians.
('5', 397, 3, 15, 903808) In these circumstances, the deputation will be able to do really good work.
('5', 397, 3, 16, 903884) If Resolution 4 has begun to tell in such a short time, can it fail to have effect in England and elsewhere once it is actually put into execution?
('5', 397, 3, 17, 904032) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 20 10 1906
('5', 397, 4, 18, 904075) 355. TYLER, HAMPDEN AND BUNYAN
('5', 397, 5, 19, 904106) We have, on an earlier occasion, cited the examples of these three men.
('5', 397, 5, 20, 904178) 1 The chains that bind us would certainly snap even if a single person from amongst us did in South Africa a hundredth part of what these men did for their country.
('5', 397, 6, 21, 904343) 1Vide “The Duty of Transvaal Indians”, 6 10 1906
('5', 398, 0, 1, 904392) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 399
('5', 398, 1, 2, 904439) Wat Tyler lived in the twelfth century 1. Once the King of England imposed a heavy tax on farmers.
('5', 398, 1, 3, 904538) The tax was unjust, and Tyler resolved not to pay it.
('5', 398, 1, 4, 904592) Many farmers joined him.
('5', 398, 1, 5, 904617) An army was sent against Tyler and his men.
('5', 398, 1, 6, 904661) Tyler was killed, but the burden of tax on the farmers was ultimately removed.
('5', 398, 1, 7, 904740) This event gave the people an awareness of their strength, further results of which were seen during the seventeenth century.
('5', 398, 1, 8, 904866) At that time, King Charles was the ruler of England and he wanted to wage wars in foreign lands.
('5', 398, 1, 9, 904963) As his treasury had become empty, he imposed Ship Money.
('5', 398, 1, 10, 905020) Hampden, a rich gentleman of great prestige, saw that, if Ship Money were paid, the King’s demands would go on increasing and the people would suffer.
('5', 398, 1, 11, 905171) He therefore refused to pay the tax, and many joined him in this.
('5', 398, 1, 12, 905237) Though some of them agreed to pay the tax, Hampden remained firm and was prosecuted.
('5', 398, 1, 13, 905322) The judges sentenced him, declaring that he had committed a crime in not paying the tax.
('5', 398, 1, 14, 905411) Despite the sentence, Hampden did not pay the tax.
('5', 398, 1, 15, 905462) Hampden and his companions went to gaol and the people congratulated them.
('5', 398, 1, 16, 905537) Like them, the people too remained firm.
('5', 398, 1, 17, 905578) Many did not pay the tax and there was a great revolt.
('5', 398, 1, 18, 905633) The King became nervous and the whole matter was reconsidered.
('5', 398, 1, 19, 905696) It was realized that thousands of people could not be sent to gaol.
('5', 398, 1, 20, 905764) He therefore got the earlier judgment reversed by other judges and Hampden was set free.
('5', 398, 1, 21, 905853) The seed of the struggle for freedom that he sowed grew into a mighty tree.
('5', 398, 1, 22, 905929) As a result of the struggle he put up, Cromwell emerged and England acquired real power and the people were given a large share in the governance of the country.
('5', 398, 1, 23, 906091) Hampden died fighting for his country; he remains immortal.
('5', 398, 1, 24, 906151) John Bunyan was a saintly man.
('5', 398, 1, 25, 906182) His only interest was prayer to God.
('5', 398, 1, 26, 906219) He saw the terrible religious oppression prevailing at the time, that is, in the seventeenth century.
('5', 398, 1, 27, 906321) He did not think it proper to do the bidding of the Bishops.
('5', 398, 1, 28, 906382) He hearkened only to the call of God.
('5', 398, 1, 29, 906420) Parted from his wife and children, he remained in Bedford Prison for twelve years.
('5', 398, 1, 30, 906503) There he wrote the most beautiful book 2 in the English language.
