('5', 399, 2, 7, 907457) 356. INTERVIEW TO “THE TRIBUNE” 1
('5', 399, 3, 8, 907491) The Deputation consisting of Gandhiji and Ally arrived in England on October 20, 1906. Interviewed on board ship at South ampton by a representative of The Tribune, Gandhiji said: [SOUTHAMPTON, October 20, 1906] We think that the position has not been properly placed before Lord Elgin.
('5', 399, 3, 9, 907778) An amendment Ordinance concerning Asiatics was recently passed by the Transvaal Government.
('5', 399, 3, 10, 907870) The law against which we are to make our submission to Lord Elgin is intended to make every Indian now settled in the Transvaal carry a pass, just as the Kaffirs 2 are required to do.
('5', 399, 3, 11, 908054) The Indian passes, however, will be much more rigorous and severe.
('5', 399, 3, 12, 908121) It is supposed that every pass will bear ten finger impressions of the holder.
('5', 399, 3, 13, 908200) All Indians in the Transvaal, no matter what their status may be, will have to submit to this, whether they can read and write English or any other European language.
('5', 399, 3, 14, 908367) The reason for introducing this law is, as the Colonial Secretary has stated, that there is an influx of Indians into the Transvaal.
('5', 399, 3, 15, 908500) The British Indian community has always denied this charge, and has invited a commission of inquiry to investigate it.
('5', 399, 3, 16, 908619) The number of Indians in the Transvaal, according to the permits, is 13,000, and by the census returns, 10,000. I may point out that they suffer from many other disabilities.
('5', 399, 3, 17, 908794) They cannot hold landed property except in Locations or wards that may be set apart for their residence.
('5', 399, 3, 18, 908899) They cannot ride in tram cars in Johannesburg or Pretoria, and there are difficulties even in railway travelling.
('5', 399, 3, 19, 909013) There are regulations which, though not at present in force, are still on the statute book, preventing British Indians, together with other Asiatics,

('5', 400, 1, 7, 909924) Our experience has invariably been that, wherever there has been class legislation, it has been far more difficult to secure relief than if there have been laws of general application, as, for instance, at the Cape and Natal.

('5', 400, 2, 12, 910451) 357. INTERVIEW TO “THE MORNING LEADER” 1
('5', 400, 3, 13, 910492) [October 20, 1906]
('5', 400, 4, 14, 910511) Mr. Gandhi, in a conversation [at Waterloo station] with a representative of The Morning Leader, asserted that, so far from the war having brought relief to the Indians, these British subjects were now worse off than they were under Boer rule.
('5', 400, 4, 15, 910755) The only things the Boers did were to deprive the British Indians of burgher rights and landownership, and to pass the Law [3] of 1885 under which those of them desiring to settle as traders in the country had to be registered and pay a fee of £3. Under the British regime, although a Kaffir may hold land, we are still debarred from the privilege, except in Locations or wards specially set apart for us, the idea being to reproduce the system of the Jewish ghettos.
('5', 400, 4, 16, 911223) ADDED DISABILITIES But other disabilities have been added.
('5', 400, 4, 17, 911282) There are, for example, difficulties as to travelling in trams.
('5', 400, 4, 18, 911346) In Johannesburg British Indians are only allowed to ride in trailer cars.
('5', 400, 4, 19, 911420) In Pretoria they are not allowed to travel on trams at all.
('5', 400, 4, 20, 911480) It is, however, more particularly in connection with the question of registration that we feel aggrieved.
('5', 400, 4, 21, 911586) Under the Boers, the immigration of British Indians was absolutely free and
('5', 400, 5, 22, 911662) 1 This report was reproduced in India, 26 10 1906 and in Indian Opinion, 1 12 1906.
('5', 401, 0, 1, 911746) 402 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 401, 1, 2, 911788) unrestricted.
('5', 401, 1, 3, 911802) But today, not only are Indians prevented from entering the country, but even old settlers find it difficult to regain admission.
('5', 401, 1, 4, 911932) It is true that, under Law 3 of 1885 passed by the Boers, Indians settling in the country for purposes of trade had to register themselves.
('5', 401, 1, 5, 912072) But the Legislative Council has now carried an amending law—the Asiatic Law Amendment Ordinance—which, the British Indians assert, is worse than the law which it seeks to amend.
('5', 401, 1, 6, 912250) It is in connection with this new piece of legislation that the Deputation has come to London.
('5', 401, 1, 7, 912345) HARDSHIPS OF THE PASS By virtue of that Ordinance, not only traders, but every Indian now resident in the Transvaal, must be registered and carry a pass (like the Kaffirs).This pass is euphemistically called a certificate of registra tion.
('5', 401, 1, 8, 912585) I must point out that this measure has been introduced in spite of the fact that Indians in the country are already in possession of permits which authorize them to reside there, while they also hold registration certificates for which they have each paid £3. When Great Britain took possession of the Transvaal, the Indians, on the advice of Lord Milner, exchanged their Boer registration for English registration, and even submitted to their thumb marks being impressed on their registration certificates.
('5', 401, 1, 9, 913093) This certificate, by the way, also contained particulars as to the age, height, and family of the person who carried it.
('5', 401, 1, 10, 913214) In reality it was an identification certificate.
('5', 401, 1, 11, 913263) “UNAUTHORIZED” IMMIGRATION And now the new Ordinance enacts yet a third registration.
('5', 401, 1, 12, 913349) The reason given is that there has been a large unauthorized immigration of Indians into the Transvaal, and it is proposed, by means of the new Ordinance, to ascertain who they are.
('5', 401, 1, 13, 913531) But this object could just as well be attained by inspecting the registration certificate now held.
('5', 401, 1, 14, 913631) As a matter of fact, the Indians stoutly deny that there is any unauthorized influx on a wholesale scale, as the Government asserts, and they have asked for the appointment of a commission to inquire into the question.
('5', 401, 1, 15, 913850) The amending law will require a much stricter identification than under the old system.
('5', 401, 1, 16, 913938) As the Assistant Colonial Secretary (Mr. Curtis) said, the Indian, no matter what his status, will have to have ten finger impressions on his certificate (instead of the thumb impression only).
('5', 401, 1, 17, 914132) Failure to register will carry with it very severe penalties.
('5', 401, 1, 18, 914194) Not only will the adult male population have to be registered, but also children of parents domiciled in the Transvaal, and even infants in arms.
('5', 402, 0, 1, 914340) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 403
('5', 402, 1, 2, 914387) PREJUDICE AGAINST COLOUR The Indian community recognize the prejudice against colour in the Transvaal, and have, therefore, accepted the principle of restriction of British Indian immigration—but on such terms as are not humiliating, and do not interfere with the liberty of those already settled in the country.
('5', 402, 1, 3, 914700) This can be easily done by passing legislation after the Natal or Cape style.
('5', 402, 1, 4, 914778) Legislation of this character ought to be general, and applicable to all.
('5', 402, 1, 5, 914852) Throughout the self governing colonies, hitherto, special class legislation has been vetoed by the home Government.
('5', 402, 1, 6, 914968) An attempt made by Natal to pass legislation specially affecting Asiatics was disallowed by Mr. Chamberlain; and we have come here to try and induce Lord Elgin to withhold the royal sanction to the amending law, and to appoint a commission to inquire into the allegation as to the Indian influx.
('5', 402, 1, 7, 915264) Mr. Gandhi states that the Indians are greatly stirred over the matter, and are prepared to go to gaol rather than submit.
('5', 402, 1, 8, 915387) The Morning Leader, 22 10 1906

('5', 406, 1, 2, 922647) 360. “INTERVIEW TO “SOUTH AFRICA” 1
('5', 406, 2, 3, 922683) [HOTEL CECIL, LONDON, October 25, 1906]
('5', 406, 3, 4, 922723) [REPORTER:] Will you please give me your views on this question which has brought you so many thousand miles, Mr. Gandhi?
('5', 406, 3, 5, 922845) [GANDHIJI:] With pleasure, I had better begin at the beginning.
('5', 406, 4, 6, 922909) If you please.
('5', 406, 4, 7, 922924) Well, Mr. H. O. Ally, the Chairman of the Hamidiya Islamic Society, and myself have come over as an appointed Deputation from the British Indian Association of the Transvaal in virtue of the resolution passed by the great Indian mass meeting held at the Old Empire Theatre in Johannesburg last month.
('5', 406, 5, 8, 923225) And your object?
('5', 406, 5, 9, 923242) Our object is to place before the authorities here what we consider to be a true statement of the facts with a view to securing a disallowance of the Asiatic Law Amendment Ordinance of the Transvaal.
('5', 406, 6, 10, 923442) You consider, then, that the information so far available to the Colonial Secretary and the Secretary of State for India is inadequate?
('5', 406, 6, 11, 923578) That is so.
('5', 406, 6, 12, 923590) I notice that you, as well as the London Times, have been misinformed regarding the Ordinance and the objection to it.
('5', 406, 7, 13, 923709) In what respect, may I ask?
('5', 406, 7, 14, 923737) For instance, it has been supposed that there is a very great unauthorized influx, [in] to the Transvaal, of British Indians, and that this influx is actually countenanced by the British Indian community as a body.
('5', 406, 8, 15, 923952) Then are those suppositions incorrect?
('5', 406, 8, 16, 923991) If those two statements were at all true, there would be some excuse for what is, after all, panic legislation; but the British Indian community has repeatedly denied the alleged unauthorized influx.
('5', 406, 9, 17, 924191) I take it that you agree with those denials, Mr. Gandhi?
('5', 406, 9, 18, 924248) Certainly.
('5', 406, 9, 19, 924259) I claim personally to have a very wide experience of the working of the Permit Department, and I have no hesitation in saying that there is absolutely no unauthorized influx of British
('5', 406, 10, 20, 924444) 1 This appeared in South Africa, 27 10 1906, and was reproduced in Indian Opinion.
('5', 407, 0, 1, 924527) 408 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 407, 1, 2, 924569) Indians [in] to the Colony, except [in] isolated cases; and those cases can be most effectively dealt with even under the present Peace Preservation Ordinance and Law No.
('5', 407, 1, 3, 924740) 3 of 1885. AS THE LAW STANDS AT PRESENT Indeed, successful prosecutions have taken place in connection with any Indians who have tried to enter the Colony, either without permits, or on permits not belonging to them.
('5', 407, 1, 4, 924957) Such persons can usually be detected by comparing the thumb impressions of those who may present permits or registration certificates with the thumb imprints on those documents.
('5', 407, 2, 5, 925135) And if they do not agree, a prosecution follows?
('5', 407, 2, 6, 925184) If the thumb impressions do not tally, the unlawful holders of such documents are liable to very heavy penalties.
('5', 407, 2, 7, 925298) If an Indian is found in the Colony without a permit, he has either to leave the Transvaal on a summary notice, under pain of imprisonment, or to show that he belongs to one of the exempted classes mentioned in the Peace Preservation Ordinance.
('5', 407, 2, 8, 925543) So you will see that the present machinery is absolutely complete.
('5', 407, 2, 9, 925610) It therefore came to me as a painful surprise when I read a long cablegram in The Times last Monday to the effect that there was an unauthorized influx of British Indians [in]to the Transvaal, and that there was a great deal of personation going on which it was difficult to detect.

('5', 407, 3, 13, 926198) In that case, as is now well known, an Indian woman was torn away from her husband who held a proper permit.

('5', 407, 4, 15, 926352) By no means.
('5', 407, 4, 16, 926365) In another case a child under eleven years of age was taken away from his parent because he was supposed to have come into the Transvaal on a permit not his own.

('5', 408, 1, 2, 926887) ridicule and contempt upon the administration of the law.
('5', 408, 2, 3, 926945) SCOPE OF NEW ORDINANCE If, therefore, the Asiatic Law Amendment Ordinance now before Lord Elgin is passed, one can easily understand how much more difficult the position of British Indians in the Transvaal is likely to be.
('5', 408, 3, 4, 927168) Does it represent, then, such very exceptional legislation ?
('5', 408, 3, 5, 927229) Indeed it does.
('5', 408, 3, 6, 927245) The new Ordinance goes much further than anything I have seen in the legislation of any of the British Colonies.
('5', 408, 4, 7, 927358) But in what does the head and front of its offending consist?
('5', 408, 4, 8, 927420) I will tell you.
('5', 408, 4, 9, 927437) It is most humiliating, in that it will require every Indian, irrespective of status, to put down the impression of his ten digits, and such a pass will have to be produced to every policeman who cares to demand it.
('5', 408, 4, 10, 927653) All Indians, including children, will have to be registered in this manner, or, as it is called in the case of infants under eight years of age, provisionally registered.
('5', 408, 5, 11, 927824) And this is quite a new provision?
('5', 408, 5, 12, 927859) All this used not to be so under the Dutch regime, and we could always rely upon British protection whenever there was anything harsh or unjust in the administration of Law No.
('5', 408, 5, 13, 928036) 3 of 1885.
('5', 408, 6, 14, 928047) But this Ordinance only amends the former Law?
('5', 408, 6, 15, 928094) No; it is a mistake to call the new Ordinance an amending ordinance, because its scope is entirely different from that of Law No.
('5', 408, 6, 16, 928224) 3 of 1885. The latter penalises Indian traders to the extent only of one single payment of £3, whilst the former entirely restricts the immigration of British Indians.
('5', 408, 7, 17, 928392) Then do you take strong objection to that restriction?
('5', 408, 7, 18, 928447) No, with the restriction we do not quarrel, but the manner of it is, as I have shown, most humiliating and totally uncalled for.
('5', 408, 8, 19, 928576) The restriction itself, then, is not the bone of contention?
('5', 408, 8, 20, 928637) It is like this.
('5', 408, 8, 21, 928654) We recognize the prejudice that exists in the Transvaal against British Indians and men of colour generally.
('5', 408, 8, 22, 928763) We have, therefore, accepted the principle of restriction on the Cape or the Natal basis.
('5', 408, 8, 23, 928853) After profound consideration, that has been the line of legislation adopted for all the colonies which have to face similar problems.
('5', 408, 9, 24, 928987) AN ENLIGHTENED INDIAN VIEW There is not the slightest reason, why the Transvaal should be allowed to go any further than the other Colonies, or why the people
('5', 408, 10, 25, 929146) 1 Vide “British Indians in the Transvaal”, 8 11 1906
('5', 409, 0, 1, 929199) 410 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 409, 1, 2, 929241) of the Transvaal themselves should wish for any further powers, unless they intend—which I for one do not believe—to drive the Indians already in the country out of the Colony.
('5', 409, 2, 3, 929418) Has there not been considerable agitation against the Indian trader We hear often of trade competition by British Indians, certainly, but I personally consider that new traders’ licences may be regulated by the Town Councils or Licensing Boards, somewhat after the fashion of the Cape Dealers’ Act; only such legislation, in order to be just, ought to be of general application, and not class legislation.
('5', 409, 2, 4, 929824) You will therefore see that the British Indian community is perfectly willing to satisfy all reasonable objections raised to its presence, but, after that has been done, I think that all fair minded men must admit that those at least who are [already] resident in the Colony should have freedom to move about, freedom to own landed property, and freedom to trade under the regulations I have referred to.
('5', 409, 2, 5, 930229) I cannot conceive what exception any South African can take to a programme such as this.
('5', 409, 3, 6, 930318) Then the statement you have just made may be taken as embodying the case for the British Indians in the Transvaal, Mr. Gandhi?
('5', 409, 3, 7, 930445) Yes it is because we believe that there is a great deal of misunderstanding and exaggeration about our position that Mr. Ally and I have travelled all the Way from South Africa to endeavour to place our case fairly before the authorities.
('5', 409, 3, 8, 930684) We are anxious to reconcile local opinions as much as possible.
('5', 409, 4, 9, 930748) You have not yet been received by Lord Elgin ?
('5', 409, 4, 10, 930795) Not yet; but all arrangements are being made, and we hope to see him in a few days.
('5', 409, 4, 11, 930879) We should like the Deputation to be led and introduced by a number of British Members of Parliament and other prominent men who sympathize with the British Indians of the Transvaal on this question; and I thank South Africa from my heart for allowing me to give expression to our views in its columns.
('5', 409, 4, 12, 931181) Indian Opinion, 24 11 1906

('5', 418, 2, 9, 942752) I gave an interview to The Tribune 2 man on board, and to The Morning Leader 3 man, whom your father had brought with him, at the station immediately I got on to the platform.

I have not gone to bed before one o’clock, except on Wednesday night: interviewing people takes up a lot of time.
('5', 418, 2, 11, 943240) So far as I have progressed, it seems that Sir George Birdwood, supported by Sir Muncherji, Sir Henry Cotton and others, will introduce us to Lord Elgin.
('5', 418, 2, 12, 943394) It will therefore be a very good movement.
('5', 418, 2, 13, 943437) Mr. Ameer Ali has telegraphed to me saying he also would join in introducing the Deputation.

('5', 418, 2, 21, 943983) I hardly think it is.
('5', 418, 2, 22, 944005) You should have given me the necessary stops.

('5', 418, 2, 26, 944431) The whole

('5', 419, 1, 3, 944845) You may, therefore, assure Mr. Abdool Gani that there was no such binding statement made by me.
('5', 419, 1, 4, 944941) I now come to the most important part of my letter.
('5', 419, 1, 5, 944993) I think that it is quite possible to have here a very strong committee solely devoted to the affairs of British Indians in South Africa.
('5', 419, 1, 6, 945130) Sir Muncherji is very enthusiastic.
('5', 419, 1, 7, 945166) Sir William has approved of the suggestion.
('5', 419, 1, 8, 945210) The way is therefore paved.
('5', 419, 1, 9, 945238) Ritch’s hands will be free.
('5', 419, 1, 10, 945266) No matter whether the Deputation succeeds or not, its work must be continued, and there is not the slightest doubt that we will have legislation as soon as Responsible Government is established.
('5', 419, 1, 11, 945461) We will then be able to avoid a Deputation, which will be almost [un]necessary if we have an effective working committee.
('5', 419, 1, 12, 945583) We would not only then do more through it than through a temporary deputation, but would do it at perhaps one tenth of the cost of a deputation; but if it requires the proper man, it requires funds also.
('5', 419, 1, 13, 945787) I think that at the most—or perhaps at the least — have not yet all the figures before me—we would want to spend £25 per month.
('5', 419, 1, 14, 945915) The committee will probably last two years.
('5', 419, 1, 15, 945959) Anyhow we shall guarantee a year’s expenses, viz., £300. We would not be able to take up offices cheaply on less than a year’s lease.
('5', 419, 1, 16, 946093) We would have to pay something to Ritch, as he cannot be expected in the present state of his finances to do the work gratis.
('5', 419, 1, 17, 946219) After he returns to South Africa, it is my intention to offer the post to your father, if he will take it.
('5', 419, 1, 18, 946326) I am going to discuss it today with him at luncheon time.
('5', 419, 1, 19, 946384) Please therefore call a meeting of the Association British Indian Committee 1 and place the whole position before them.
('5', 419, 1, 20, 946504) If they agree, let me have a cable saying, Yes.
('5', 419, 1, 21, 946552) At the same time you should have funds ready.
('5', 419, 1, 22, 946598) Do not send me the affirmative cable unless you get the funds there in your possession, or unless you feel absolutely certain of getting them.
('5', 419, 1, 23, 946741) Mr. Ally entirely approves of the idea; probably he will be writing.

('5', 423, 1, 2, 953864) 376. LETTER TO SIR HENRY COTTON
('5', 423, 2, 3, 953896) HOTEL CECIL, LONDON, October 26, 1906
('5', 423, 3, 4, 953934) DEAR SIR, I beg to report that Sir Lepel Griffin has declined to lead the deputation that is to introduce the Indian Deputation from South Africa.
('5', 423, 3, 5, 954081) I waited on Sir William and Mr. Naoroji this morning with the news.
('5', 423, 3, 6, 954149) When I received an answer in the negative from Sir Lepel, not knowing all the local circumstances, I immediately telegraphed to Sir George Birdwood, 1 thinking he being a neutral man would be the next best person, asking him whether he would join the deputation and be the spokesman.
('5', 423, 3, 7, 954433) He telegraphed saying he would if Sir Muncherji agreed.
('5', 423, 3, 8, 954489) Sir William thought that I had done a rash act in asking Sir George Birdwood to be the spokesman, as the proposition might not be acceptable to the other members of the deputation.
('5', 423, 3, 9, 954670) I realized my mistake too late.
('5', 423, 3, 10, 954702) Sir William and Mr. Naoroji think that Sir Muncherji, who has been uniformly and zealously working in connection with the matter of the British Indians in South Africa, should be asked to be the spokesman, but they suggested that I was to secure your permission before I moved further.
('5', 423, 3, 11, 954988) I, therefore, went to the House of Commons to see you, but a constable informed me that you were not in the House.
('5', 423, 3, 12, 955103) I now write this asking you kindly to wire me whether you approve of the proposal that Sir Muncherji should be the spokesman.
('5', 423, 4, 13, 955229) I remain,
('5', 423, 5, 14, 955239) Yours faithfully, SIR HENRY COTTON, M.P. 45, ST.

('5', 425, 4, 15, 957966) 379. LETTER TO PROFESSOR PARMANAND
('5', 425, 5, 16, 958001) HOTEL CECIL, LONDON, October 26, 1906
('5', 425, 6, 17, 958039) DEAR PROFESSOR PARMANAND, I had a chat with Ratnam 2 when he was here with my luggage.
('5', 425, 6, 18, 958126) Ever since that I have been thinking of him during spare moments.
('5', 425, 6, 19, 958192) To me every one from South Africa is a valuable asset and to be converted into a still more valuable asset by proper nursing.
('5', 425, 6, 20, 958318) I think that, even from a material standpoint, Ratnam’s life is being very much wasted.
('5', 425, 6, 21, 958406) His preliminary education being very poor, he will find it hard to battle in his profession; more so in South Africa where he will have to live down a great deal of prejudice.
('5', 425, 6, 22, 958582) I know of no practitioner in South Africa with so little equipment as he will have at the time he is finished.
('5', 425, 6, 23, 958693) It is not enough that he will know English perhaps fairly well; he must have, in my opinion, a good grounding in mathematics.
('5', 425, 6, 24, 958819) The leader of the South African Bar considers that a knowledge of French, Latin and Dutch (especially Latin) is almost indispensable for success
('5', 425, 7, 25, 958964) 1 G. J. Adam; vide “Interview to Reuter”, 27 10 1906
('5', 425, 8, 26, 959017) 2 Ruthnam Pather, who was studying for the Bar
('5', 426, 0, 1, 959064) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 427
('5', 426, 1, 2, 959111) at the Bar.
('5', 426, 1, 3, 959123) Some scientific training also is necessary; otherwise Ratnam will find himself very greatly handicapped when his opponents make use of scientific expressions, or the Court does so.
('5', 426, 1, 4, 959304) Also, if ever he is going to dedicate his knowledge of law to the good of his country and does not wish to use it commercially, he must have a knowledge of some technical art as a means of living.
('5', 426, 1, 5, 959501) He is young enough to do all these things.

('5', 428, 0, 1, 962617) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 429
('5', 428, 1, 2, 962664) 382. THE DEPUTATION’S VOYAGE—IV
('5', 428, 2, 3, 962696) HOTEL CECIL, LONDON, October 26, 1906 I have already given an account of our voyage up to the time we were about to reach Madeira.
('5', 428, 2, 4, 962827) MADEIRA We reached Madeira on the morning of Tuesday, October 16. Generally all passengers land at Madeira and go for a stroll, and we too went ashore.
('5', 428, 2, 5, 962979) This island is very beautiful.
('5', 428, 2, 6, 963010) Situated upon a hill, Madeira is inhabited, tier upon tier up to a height of 2,500 feet.
('5', 428, 2, 7, 963099) There is greenery all round, with hardly an uncultivated patch.
('5', 428, 2, 8, 963163) All over the island the paths are paved, and no wheeled carriages are used, only sledgelike barrows, drawn along the way.
('5', 428, 2, 9, 963285) These barrows go down the slopes at great speed but without the least danger.
('5', 428, 2, 10, 963363) The barrow is so light that a man can carry it on his head.
('5', 428, 2, 11, 963423) The island is in the possession of the Portuguese and is inhabited entirely by them.
('5', 428, 2, 12, 963508) No Indian was to be seen.
('5', 428, 2, 13, 963534) The view of the island is lovely and charming.
('5', 428, 2, 14, 963581) ARRIVAL IN LONDON On the morning of the 20th, we reached Southampton Docks where we were met by Mr. West and his sister.
('5', 428, 2, 15, 963702) From here one has to take a train [to London].
('5', 428, 2, 16, 963749) A reporter of The Tribune, a well known paper, came to see us on board the steamer.
('5', 428, 2, 17, 963833) We told him all the facts.
('5', 428, 2, 18, 963860) He published the whole account in his paper on Monday.
('5', 428, 2, 19, 963915) The train reached Waterloo Station at 12.30. Messrs Ritch, Godfrey and Joseph Royeppen met us at the station and Mr. Henry Polak’s father had also come there with a reporter of The Morning Leader.
('5', 428, 2, 20, 964112) We gave him the story.
('5', 428, 2, 21, 964135) The report 1 published by The Morning Leader on Monday was much better than that 2 in The Tribune.
('5', 428, 2, 22, 964234) Thus, our work began even before we reached London.
('5', 428, 2, 23, 964286) We went to India House, as Mr. Ritch had made arrangements for our stay there.
('5', 428, 2, 24, 964365) There is not enough space this time for an account of India House.
('5', 428, 2, 25, 964432) I propose to give one the next time.
('5', 428, 2, 26, 964469) 3 We ate our meal and left forthwith for the meeting of the London Indian Society, where we had the good fortune of meeting Mr. Dadabhai Naoroji.

('5', 429, 1, 4, 965026) MONDAY TO FRIDAY I do not get a moment’s leisure here.
('5', 429, 1, 5, 965081) As I write this it is 11 p.m.
('5', 429, 1, 6, 965111) We have had interviews with Sir Muncherji, Sir William Wedderburn, Sir Henry Cotton, Mr. Cotton 2, Mr. Hall, Mr. Robertson, Mr. Arathoon, 3 Mr. Scott and other gentlemen.

('5', 429, 1, 8, 965427) Mr. Dadabhai Naoroji, Sir Muncherji Bhownaggree, Mr. Harold Cox, Mr. Justice Ameer Ali and Sir George Birdwood are already with us.
('5', 429, 1, 9, 965559) Very probably the interview will take place next week.
('5', 429, 1, 10, 965614) We have informed Lord Elgin of our arrival and his acknowledgement too has been received.
('5', 429, 1, 11, 965704) “THE TIMES” CORRESPONDENT The Times correspondent in the Transvaal, as if by previous arrangement, cabled just on Monday to his paper saying that many Indians had entered the Colony.
('5', 429, 1, 12, 965887) If they continued to enter in this way, the whites would have to leave bag and baggage.
('5', 429, 1, 13, 965975) As the new act gave the Indians the right to hold land and other rights, it was hoped that Lord Elgin would give his assent to it.
('5', 429, 1, 14, 966106) If he did not, the whites would be very much offended.
('5', 429, 1, 15, 966161) Again, the correspondent hoped that Sir Richard Solomon would fully champion the cause of the whites in regard to the act.
('5', 429, 1, 16, 966284) Moreover, he added, Mr. Gandhi, a member of the Deputation, was a clever lawyer, who was responsible for the entry of Indians into the Transvaal and who had made much money thereby.
('5', 429, 1, 17, 966466) Such a cablegram was despatched from there to throw dust into the eyes of people here.
('5', 429, 1, 18, 966553) The same day, we sent The Times a reply 4 from which important paragraphs were published on Thursday.
('5', 429, 1, 19, 966655) The whole reply was published in India on Friday.
('5', 429, 1, 20, 966705) In our reply we had said that, even if any Indians entered without permits, their number was very small, that the Government had even now the authority to expel them and that the new law was oppressive.
('5', 429, 1, 21, 966908) No Indian wants that the whole of India should migrate to South Africa.
('5', 429, 1, 22, 966980) Nor does anyone wish that the whites should be deprived of all their trade.

('5', 430, 2, 4, 967648) 383. DEEDS BETTER THAN WORDS 1
('5', 430, 3, 5, 967679) [October 26, 1906] Two things are now being widely discussed in England.
('5', 430, 3, 6, 967752) One relates to the decision of the soap manufacturers who, like their American opposite numbers, have combined and resolved to increase the price of soap.
('5', 430, 3, 7, 967907) The dealers in soap and the public naturally did not relish the decision.
('5', 430, 3, 8, 967981) But they did not approach the Government for help; neither did they appeal to the manufacturers; but they resorted to direct action.
('5', 430, 3, 9, 968114) They notified the manufacturers that they would not buy their soap even if it meant a great loss to them.
('5', 430, 3, 10, 968220) The result was that Lever Brothers, of Sunlight Soap fame, who used till now to have fifteen ounces of soap in their one pound cake, will henceforth give the full sixteen.
('5', 430, 3, 11, 968392) The lesson from this is that deeds are better than words.
('5', 430, 3, 12, 968450) The action of the dealers proved more fruitful than mere words.
('5', 430, 3, 13, 968514) The second example illustrating this saying is more remarkable.
('5', 430, 3, 14, 968578) It is the movement in England for women’s right to vote, which the Government is unwilling to concede.
('5', 430, 3, 15, 968681) The women therefore go to the House of Commons and harass the Members.
('5', 430, 3, 16, 968752) They have sent petitions, written letters, delivered speeches and tried many other means.
('5', 430, 3, 17, 968842) Last Wednesday, they went to the House of Commons as soon as it opened and demanded the right to vote; they caused some damage also, for which they were prosecuted and sentenced to furnish a security of £5 each.
('5', 430, 3, 18, 969054) On their refusing to do so, they were sentenced to imprisonment, and they are now in gaol.
('5', 430, 3, 19, 969145) Most of the women have got three months.
('5', 430, 3, 20, 969186) All of them come from respectable families and some are very well educated.
('5', 430, 3, 21, 969262) One of these is the daughter of the late Mr. Cobden who was highly respected by the people.
('5', 430, 3, 22, 969354) She is serving her term in gaol.
('5', 430, 3, 23, 969387) Another is the wife of Mr. Lawrence.
('5', 430, 3, 24, 969424) A third is an LL.B. On the very day these women went to gaol there was a huge meeting here in support of the resolve adopted by the brave ladies, and a sum of £650 was collected on the spot.
('5', 430, 3, 25, 969615) Mr. Lawrence announced that he would pay £10 a day as long as his wife was in gaol.
('5', 430, 3, 26, 969699) Some persons regard these women as insane; the police use
('5', 430, 4, 27, 969757) 1 This article was promised to Polak in Gandhiji’s letter to him; vide “Letter to H.S.L. Polak, 26 10 1906
('5', 431, 0, 1, 969864) 432 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 431, 1, 2, 969906) force against them; the magistrate looks upon them with a stern eye.
('5', 431, 1, 3, 969975) Cobden’s brave daughter said, “I shall never obey any law in the making of which I have no hand; I will not accept the authority of the court executing those laws; if you send me to gaol, I will go there, but I shall on no account pay a fine.
('5', 431, 1, 4, 970218) I will not furnish any security either.” It is no wonder that a people which produces such daughters and mothers should hold the sceptre.
('5', 431, 1, 5, 970356) Today the whole country is laughing at them, and they have only a few people on their side.
('5', 431, 1, 6, 970448) But undaunted, these women work on steadfast in their cause.
('5', 431, 1, 7, 970509) They are bound to succeed and gain the franchise, for the simple reason that deeds are better than words.
('5', 431, 1, 8, 970615) Even those who laughed at them would be left wondering.
('5', 431, 1, 9, 970671) If even women display such courage, will the Transvaal Indians fail in their duty and be afraid of gaol ?
('5', 431, 1, 10, 970777) Or would they rather consider the gaol a palace and readily go there?
('5', 431, 1, 11, 970847) When that time comes, India’s bonds will snap of themselves.
('5', 431, 1, 12, 970908) We have sent petitions; made speeches; and we shall continue to do so.
('5', 431, 1, 13, 970979) But we shall gain our object only if we have the kind of strength we have spoken of.
('5', 431, 1, 14, 971064) People do not have much faith in articles and speeches.
('5', 431, 1, 15, 971120) Anyone can do that, they call for no courage.
('5', 431, 1, 16, 971166) Deeds after all better than words.
('5', 431, 1, 17, 971201) All other things are unavailing, and no one is afraid of them.
('5', 431, 1, 18, 971264) The only way therefore is to sacrifice oneself and take the plunge.
('5', 431, 1, 19, 971332) We have much to do yet, no doubt of that.
('5', 431, 1, 20, 971374) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 24 11 1906

('5', 444, 4, 6, 991089) I venture to think that the Association has a very strong and just case.

('5', 447, 7, 11, 995135) 407. REPRESENTATION TO LORD ELGIN 2
('5', 447, 8, 12, 995171) HOTEL CECIL, LONDON, October 31, 1906
('5', 447, 9, 13, 995209) TO THE RIGHT HON’BLE THE EARL OF ELGIN HIS MAJESTY’S PRINCIPAL SECRETARY OF STATE FOR THE COLONIES COLONIAL OFFICE LONDON
('5', 447, 10, 14, 995331) MY LORD, APPOINTMENT OF DELEGATES 1. We, the undersigned, have been appointed by the British Indian Association of the Transvaal to lay before you the views of the Indian community of the Transvaal regarding the Asiatic Law Amendment Ordinance of the Transvaal Legislative Council published in the Transvaal Government Gazette dated the 28th day of September, 1906. At a mass meeting of British Indians, numbering nearly 3,000 British Indian residents of the Transvaal, held at the old
('5', 447, 11, 15, 995817) 1 Vide “Letter to F. H. Brown”, 30 10 1906
('5', 447, 12, 16, 995860) 2This was drawn up by Gandhiji on or before October 31 and forwarded with the “Letter to Private Secretary to Lord Elgin”, 2 11 1906
('5', 448, 0, 1, 995993) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 449
('5', 448, 1, 2, 996040) Empire Theatre in Johannesburg on the 11th day of September, 1906, it was among other things resolved to send a Deputation to attend on Your Lordship.
('5', 448, 1, 3, 996191) The selection of the delegates was left to the Committee of the Association and, as said before 1, we were selected by the Committee.
('5', 448, 1, 4, 996325) WHO ARE THE DELEGATES?
('5', 448, 1, 5, 996348) 2. The first undersigned is the Honorary Secretary of the Association, was one of the organizers of the Natal Indian Volunteer Ambulance Corps formed at the time of the Boer War, and was the organizer and in charge of the Indian Stretcher Bearer Corps formed under the auspices of the Natal Indian Congress in connection with the recent Native rebellion of Natal.
('5', 448, 1, 6, 996712) He is a Barrister of the Inner Temple and has since 1903 practised as a solicitor in Johannesburg.
('5', 448, 1, 7, 996811) 3. The second undersigned is a merchant by profession, and besides being a member of the British Indian Association, is the founder and Chairman of the Hamidia Islamic Society of Johannesburg.
('5', 448, 1, 8, 997004) 4. Both the undersigned are old settlers of South Africa; the first undersigned settled in South Africa in 1893 and is father of four children, all of whom are in South Africa.
('5', 448, 1, 9, 997181) The second undersigned has settled in South Africa for the last twenty three years and is the father of eleven children all born in South Africa.
('5', 448, 1, 10, 997327) INDIAN POPULATION OF THE TRANSVAAL 5. The present Indian population of the Transvaal is about 13,000 according to permit returns, and over 10,000 according to census returns, as against a white population of over 280,000. The Indians of the Transvaal are merchants, traders, their assistants, hawkers and domestic servants—the great majority being merchants or hawkers.
('5', 448, 1, 11, 997697) LAW 3 OF 1885 6. Law 3 [of] 1885 as amended in 1886 is applicable to Asiatics, including “coolies, Malays, Arabs, and Mahomedan subjects of the Turkish Empire”, and as interpreted by the Supreme Court of the Transvaal, (1) confines as to residence those who come under it to locations or streets set specially apart for them, for a breach of which provision there is no sanction provided in the law and which is therefore nugatory in effect, (2) deprives them of burgher rights, (3) deprives them of right of ownership of fixed property except in locations and streets before referred to,
('5', 448, 2, 12, 998286) 1 Vide “Letter to Private Secretary to Lord Elgin”, 25 10 1906
('5', 449, 0, 1, 998349) 450 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 449, 1, 2, 998391) (4) and requires those who may settle in the Transvaal for purposes of trade or otherwise to pay a fee of £3 and be registered within eight days of their arrival.
('5', 449, 1, 3, 998554) (The Law as interpreted by the courts does not require eregistration of children of such settlers, their wives and those who are not traders.) 7. The above Law is not restrictive of immigration but it is meant to penalize traders to the extent of £3. During the Boer regime it formed the subject of representations by the British Government and was therefore never then strictly enforced.
('5', 449, 1, 4, 998943) For its administration there was no separate department of the State, and registration merely consisted in passing to the payer a receipt for £3. UNDER THE BRITISH REGIME 8. After the advent of British rule, contrary to promises and expectations, separate Asiatic Offices were established.
('5', 449, 1, 5, 999233) The Peace Preservation Ordinance, which was admittedly a measure calculated to safeguard the State from dangerous characters, was misapplied to restrict Indian immigration, and under it permits were only granted to British Indians on the recommendation of the officers in charge.
('5', 449, 1, 6, 999513) This practice gave rise to much abuse and corruption.
('5', 449, 1, 7, 999567) These officers accepted bribes on a wholesale system, and Indian refugees who had a right to immediate return to the Transvaal had difficulty in doing so, and were often obliged to pay as much as £30. This was brought to the notice of the local Government more than once by the British Indian Association, with the result ultimately that two officials were criminally tried, and although the jury discharged them for want of evidence, they were dismissed from Government service.
('5', 449, 1, 8, 1000047) The Asiatic Offices were then abolished and the granting of permits was transferred, as it should have been, to the Chief Secretary for Permits.
('5', 449, 1, 9, 1000192) 1 Though under this regime permits to British Indians were granted only sparingly and after a great deal of delay and searching examination, there was no corruption.
('5', 449, 1, 10, 1000358) In the meanwhile an official was appointed under the designation of Protector of Asiatics in the Colonial Department.
('5', 449, 1, 11, 1000476) INDIANS REGISTERED 9. While the Permit Department was under the Chief Secretary for Permits, Lord Milner thought fit to enforce Law 3 of 1885 rigorously, and appointed the Permit Secretary to be Registrar of Asiatics.
('5', 449, 1, 12, 1000694) The British Indian Association respectfully protested against the step, 2 but although it was not obligatory on the British Indians who had paid £3 to the Boer Government to re register, on the urgent
('5', 449, 2, 13, 1000895) 1 Vide “Deputation to Lord Selborne”, 29 11 1905
('5', 449, 3, 14, 1000944) 2 Vide “The British Indian Association and Lord Milner”,11 6 1903
('5', 450, 0, 1, 1001010) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 451
('5', 450, 1, 2, 1001057) advice of Lord Milner they allowed themselves to be re registered.
('5', 450, 1, 3, 1001124) These certificates contain names of holders, their wives, number of children, the age of the holders, their distinctive marks and thumb prints.
('5', 450, 1, 4, 1001268) 10. The following was the assurance given by Lord Milner at the time the advice was offered: I think that registration is a protection to them.
('5', 450, 1, 5, 1001412) To that registration there is attached a £3 tax.
('5', 450, 1, 6, 1001461) It is only asked for once.
('5', 450, 1, 7, 1001488) Those who have paid it to the old Government have only to prove that they have done so and they have not to pay it again.
('5', 450, 1, 8, 1001610) Again, once on the register, their position is established and no further registration is necessary, nor is a fresh permit required.
('5', 450, 1, 9, 1001743) That registration gives you a right to be here and a right to come and go.
('5', 450, 2, 10, 1001818) 11. At the present day, save women and children, almost every Indian in the Transvaal is in possession of a permit bearing the holder’s name, place of birth, occupation, last address, his signature and as a rule thumb impression and in most if not all cases, registration certificates above described.
('5', 450, 2, 11, 1002120) If, therefore, there are any Indians in the Transvaal who are without permits and do not fall within the exemption clauses of the Peace Preservation Ordinance, they are unauthorized residents and liable to be expelled under that Ordinance.
('5', 450, 2, 12, 1002360) Those who cannot produce permits have the burden thrown on them of proving that they come within the exemption clauses.
('5', 450, 2, 13, 1002480) If they do not obey expulsion orders, they are liable to suffer imprisonment.
('5', 450, 2, 14, 1002558) The Peace Preservation Ordinance moreover makes it a criminal offence to obtain a permit by fraudulent representations, or to abet one in so obtaining a permit, or to enter on a permit obtained by fraud.
('5', 450, 2, 15, 1002762) PRESENT MACHINERY FOR DETECTION OF UNAUTHORIZED ENTRY COMPLETE 12. Thus the machinery for punishing unauthorized Indian residents in the Transvaal is complete and effective.
('5', 450, 2, 16, 1002936) And by its voluntary act above referred to, the Indian community has furnished the authorities with complete means of identification of a double character.
('5', 450, 2, 17, 1003092) Those Indians who have tried to enter on permits belonging to other Indians have been heavily punished.
('5', 450, 2, 18, 1003196) Many such cases are on record.
('5', 450, 2, 19, 1003227) 13. There would appear therefore to be no occasion for any further measure of law to prevent fraud, or impersonation, or unauthorized entry.
('5', 450, 2, 20, 1003368) Under the present permit regulations, according to the testimony given by an official,
('5', 450, 3, 21, 1003455) 1 Vide“The British Indian Association and Lord Milner”,11 6 1903
('5', 451, 0, 1, 1003520) 452 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 451, 1, 2, 1003562) (1) women, whether they accompany their husbands or not, [and] (2) children of whatever age, even infants, whether in company of their parents or not, are required to produce permits.
('5', 451, 1, 3, 1003746) Cases have happened where tender children five years old have been torn away from their parents, and wives from their husbands, although the fathers or the husbands accompanying the children or wives have produced permits.
('5', 451, 1, 4, 1003969) 14. Old residents of the Transvaal who have paid £3 as the price of their residence experience a delay of months before they receive their permits, and that after an investigation which is over severe in character and carried on secretly, and by boards which sit at their leisure to conduct their examination.
('5', 451, 1, 5, 1004279) NEW ORDINANCE 15. On the top of all these disabilities has come like a thunderbolt upon the Indian community the amending Ordinance.
('5', 451, 1, 6, 1004412) It sets up a humiliating system of passes to be carried by every Indian resident in the Transvaal.
('5', 451, 1, 7, 1004511) It establishes a system of identification which may vary from time to time.
('5', 451, 1, 8, 1004587) The Assistant Colonial Secretary informed a deputation of Indians that the imprints of all the digits should be required and passes containing such imprints should be produced by the holders to every police official who may wish to challenge the Indians.
('5', 451, 1, 9, 1004842) The permits and registration certificates, obtained after a great deal of trouble, are to be surrendered in exchange for the new certificates.
('5', 451, 1, 10, 1004985) We may state that, in order to carry out the above registration, people were dragged from their rooms in the early morning and subjected to much hard treatment.
('5', 451, 1, 11, 1005146) ITS REAL NATURE 16. The Ordinance in fact is not one for registration but for identification, of a type applied to the worst criminals.
('5', 451, 1, 12, 1005282) So far as we are aware such a law is unknown in any of the British Colonies.
('5', 451, 1, 13, 1005359) It is hardly an amendment of the Law 3 of 1885, because its scope is admittedly totally different from that of the latter.
('5', 451, 1, 14, 1005482) 17. The amending law condemns every permit unless the holder of it can prove it to be not tainted with fraud.
('5', 451, 1, 15, 1005592) It leaves the children of parents, though the latter may be in possession of bona fide permits, to the tender mercy of the officer in charge of its administration.
('5', 451, 1, 16, 1005756) It is class legislation of the worst type.
('5', 451, 1, 17, 1005799) While it is calculated to submit the Indians to intense irritation and humiliation, it gives absolutely nothing.
('5', 451, 1, 18, 1005912) THE SO CALLED RELIEF 18. For the remission of £3 fee is superfluous, as every adult male Indian and in many cases even children at present resident in the Transvaal have already paid it.
('5', 451, 1, 19, 1006099) According to the statement by the
('5', 452, 0, 1, 1006133) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 453
('5', 452, 1, 2, 1006180) Transvaal Colonial Secretary, no Indians who are not pre war residents of the Transvaal will be allowed to enter the Colony until the Responsible Government has considered the question of immigration.
('5', 452, 1, 3, 1006381) And as the present Indian residents have already paid the £3, and as the pre war residents who have still to re enter have also mostly paid the £3 to the Dutch Government, the remission of the £3 payment is no concession at all.
('5', 452, 1, 4, 1006610) 19. The authority for temporary permits is also not required as they have been granted at the discretion of the authorities under the Peace Preservation Ordinance.
('5', 452, 1, 5, 1006774) 20. The relief as to the supply of liquor is, so far as it may be applicable to Indians, a direct insult.
('5', 452, 1, 6, 1006880) 21. The relief to the heirs of those Indians who may have held fixed property before the date of Law 3 of 1885 is individual in character and is meant only to affect one small piece of land in the Transvaal.
('5', 452, 1, 7, 1007088) 22. The Ordinance therefore is in no way a relief or protection to the Indian community.
('5', 452, 1, 8, 1007177) COMPARISON 23. We cannot lay too much stress on the fact that the amending Ordinance, while it leaves untouched all the disabilities of Law 3 of 1885, makes the position of British Indians much worse than under Law 3 of 1885, as will appear more clearly from the following comparison: UNDER LAW 3 OF 1885 UNDER NEW ORDINANCE 1. Traders only were required to pay £3 and take out receipts.
('5', 452, 1, 9, 1007565) All male Indians (they have already paid £3) are now to take out certificates of registration.
('5', 452, 1, 10, 1007660) 2. No particulars of identification had to be furnished.
('5', 452, 1, 11, 1007717) Most humiliating particulars of identification are to be furnished.
('5', 452, 1, 12, 1007785) 3. Registration was not in restriction of immigration.
('5', 452, 1, 13, 1007840) This registration is essentially for restricting immigration.
('5', 452, 1, 14, 1007902) 4. Children of registered parents were not required to register.
('5', 452, 1, 15, 1007967) Children of registered parents must all be registered: (a) Children under eight years to be provisionally registered, and parents to furnish means of identification.
('5', 452, 1, 16, 1008133) (A baby eight days old will have to give ten digit prints and be carried to the registering officer.)
('5', 453, 0, 1, 1008235) 454 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 453, 1, 2, 1008277) (b) Children over eight years must be separately registered, subject to the same requirement as to identification.
('5', 453, 1, 3, 1008392) (c) If the children are not so registered after they attain the age of 16 years, they are liable to expulsion under severe penalty unless they get themselves registered.
('5', 453, 2, 4, 1008562) (d) Any Asiatic without authority bringing into the Colony a child under 16 years is liable to a severe penalty and cancellation of his registration and to expulsion.
('5', 453, 2, 5, 1008729) (This probably applies to parents bringing their babies in arms and certainly to lawfully resident Asiatics bringing the baby of another resident Asiatic.) (e) Any Asiatic employing (even ignorantly!) such a child is liable to like penalties.
('5', 453, 2, 6, 1008972) (f) Failure on the part of parent or guardian to make application under (a) and (b) renders him liable to a fine of £100 or 3 months’ imprisonment.
('5', 453, 3, 7, 1009120) 5. Failure to register never carried with it expulsion.
('5', 453, 3, 8, 1009176) Failure to register carries with it expulsion although the Asiatic in question be in possession of permit and registration, and therefore doubly a lawful resident of the Transvaal, even according to the amending Ordinance.
('5', 453, 3, 9, 1009399) Thus by a stroke of the pen the present title to residence is to be rendered of no effect and value.
('5', 453, 3, 10, 1009500) In other words,
('5', 454, 0, 1, 1009516) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 455
('5', 454, 1, 2, 1009563) vested interests, hitherto considered so sacred, are to be taken away to satisfy a caprice.
('5', 454, 1, 3, 1009655) 6. Malays were subject to registration under Law 3 of 1885. Malays are exempt from the operation of the new Ordinance.
('5', 454, 1, 4, 1009774) 7. Law 3 of 1885 was a law passed by an ignorant Government, and was under promise of total repeal by the British Government.
('5', 454, 2, 5, 1009900) The present Ordinance has been passed deliberately by an enlightened Government in possession of full knowledge of the history of India and its civilization.
('5', 454, 2, 6, 1010058) 8. Responsible Government could not use Law 3 of 1885 as a precedent for class legislation.
('5', 454, 3, 7, 1010150) Responsible Government would be perfectly justified in using this Ordinance as a precedent for class legislation.
('5', 454, 4, 8, 1010264) 9. Law 3 of 1885 was passed by a Government in respect of people not its own subjects.
('5', 454, 5, 9, 1010351) The present Ordinance has been passed by a Government belonging to the same Imperial fold as the Indians.
('5', 454, 5, 10, 1010457) 10. There could be no question of exemption as registration was not humiliating.
('5', 454, 6, 11, 1010538) The present Ordinance reduces Indians to a lower level than the Kaffirs: (a) because Kaffirs who carry passes do not have to supply humiliating identification particulars contemplated by the Ordinance,
('5', 454, 7, 12, 1010740) (b) Kaffirs having reached a certain status are exempted from liability to carry passes, whereas Indians, no matter what status they may enjoy or how well educated they may be, must be registered and carry passes.
('5', 454, 8, 13, 1010954) REASONS FOR THE NEW ORDINANCE 24. We learn that the reasons for passing the Ordinance are that: (a) the local Government wishes to stop the alleged large, unauthorized influx of Indians, against whom there is a great deal of prejudice on the part of the white residents of the Transvaal; (b) the local Government believes that there is on the part
('5', 455, 0, 1, 1011302) 456 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 455, 1, 2, 1011344) of the Indian community an organized attempt to flood the country with British Indians without authority.
('5', 455, 1, 3, 1011450) 25. It is not denied that there are Indians who attempt to enter the Transvaal without authority.
('5', 455, 1, 4, 1011548) To meet such cases the present laws are, as shown above, amply sufficient.
('5', 455, 1, 5, 1011623) A large unauthorized influx has been repeatedly denied by the Indians, and never proved.
('5', 455, 1, 6, 1011712) The allegation as to an organized attempt by the community is a pure fabrication.
('5', 455, 1, 7, 1011794) LOCAL PREJUDICE 26. The prejudice on the part of many white men, especially of the petty trading class, is admitted.
('5', 455, 1, 8, 1011911) We would at the same time respectfully state that the general body of white people are indifferent.
('5', 455, 1, 9, 1012011) The Indian trader and the hawker—the former relying on the support of wholesale European houses and the latter on the white households of all descriptions—would not be able to exist in the Transvaal but for such support.
('5', 455, 1, 10, 1012232) The petition 1 presented on behalf of Indians by Mr. Hosken and other representatives of leading houses bears out this contention.
('5', 455, 1, 11, 1012363) REMEDY FOR MEETING THE PREJUDICE 27. But recognizing the prejudice, the Indian community has all along accepted the principle of restriction of immigration along the Cape or Natal line, subject to permission to import assistants and servants, and since it is the traders who arouse hostility and jealousy, the community has also accepted the principle of control and regulation of new trade licences by municipal bodies, their decisions being subject in gross cases to review by the Supreme Court.
('5', 455, 1, 12, 1012861) These two enactment’s, if adopted, would dispel all fear of an inordinate influx of Asiatics, or their competition in trade.
('5', 455, 1, 13, 1012986) But any such legislation should, by repealing Law 3 of 1885, restore to the resident Indian population the right of ownership of fixed property and freedom of movement and locomotion.
('5', 455, 1, 14, 1013170) 28. Legislation of the above mentioned type, being applicable to all, would obviate gross abuse of authority, which experience has shown always takes place wherever there is class legislation specially applicable to weaker races.
('5', 455, 1, 15, 1013400) It will moreover continue the policy laid down by Mr. Chamberlain at the Conference of the Colonial Premiers and since re affirmed by him in practice.
('5', 455, 1, 16, 1013551) It was that policy which dictated a veto of the first Disfranchising Bill of the Natal Legislative Assembly 2 and the Immigration Restriction Draft Bill 3 specially
('5', 455, 2, 17, 1013716) 1 Vide “Letter to Lieutenant Governor”, 1 5 1903
('5', 455, 3, 18, 1013765) 2 Vide”A brief Chronicle of South Africa”; &.”Speech at Publim Meeting, Bombay”, 26 9 1896 3 ibid
('5', 456, 0, 1, 1013863) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 457
('5', 456, 1, 2, 1013910) applied to Asiatics and submitted by the late Mr. Harry Escombe 1. Such non class legislation can be effectively passed now.
('5', 456, 1, 3, 1014035) It will then place before the incoming Responsible Government the Imperial idea of restrictive legislation and throw on it the burden of showing the necessity for any further restrictions.
('5', 456, 2, 4, 1014224) 29. If, however, such a step be not practicable at present, the whole question should, in the humble opinion of the Deputation, be left over until the newly formed Transvaal legislature under the new constitution has met.
('5', 456, 3, 5, 1014446) A COMMISSION AS AN ALTERNATIVE
('5', 456, 4, 6, 1014477) 30. In the meanwhile, the least that is due to the Indian community is the appointment of a strong and impartial commission to investigate the allegations as to the unauthorized entry of British Indians into the Transvaal, and to report upon the administration of the Peace Preservation Ordinance as affecting British Indians, and also to report upon the adequacy or otherwise of the present laws to meet unlawful entry of Indians, and generally upon the legislation affecting British Indians.
('5', 456, 4, 7, 1014971) If those who have been making the allegations are sincere, the deliberations of the commission need not take a long time.
('5', 456, 5, 8, 1015093) BRITISH INDIANS AS APART FROM OTHER ASIATICS
('5', 456, 6, 9, 1015138) 31. The Deputation has been specially directed to secure an insistence on the consideration of the question affecting British Indians as such, instead of their being mixed up with non British Asiatics.
('5', 456, 6, 10, 1015340) Special promises have been made to British Indians, both in India and outside it, even in connection with the Transvaal laws.
('5', 456, 6, 11, 1015466) It may not be considered too much on the part of the Indians to ask for a proper fulfilment of such promises.
('5', 456, 7, 12, 1015576) 32. Above all, the integrity of the community is at stake.
('5', 456, 7, 13, 1015635) The amending Ordinance is a punitive measure.
('5', 456, 7, 14, 1015681) It has been brought in to meet the alleged organized attempt of the community to introduce into the Transvaal unauthorized Indians.
('5', 456, 7, 15, 1015813) If His Majesty’s Government sanctions such a measure, it will be party to a wholesale condemnation of the Indian community, without any proof whatsoever having been
('5', 456, 8, 16, 1015978) 1 (1838 99): Prime Minister of Natal, 1897;
('5', 457, 0, 1, 1016022) 458 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 457, 1, 2, 1016064) publicly brought forward to substantiate such a serious accusation.
('5', 457, 2, 3, 1016132) We have the honour to remain,
('5', 457, 3, 4, 1016162) Your Lordship's humble servants,
('5', 457, 4, 5, 1016195) M. K. GANDHI

('5', 462, 3, 6, 1023723) 415. DRAFT FOR CHINESE AMBASSADOR 1
('5', 462, 4, 7, 1023759) [After October 31, 1906]
('5', 462, 5, 8, 1023784) FROM HIS EXCELLENCY THE ENVOY EXTRAORDINARY AND MINISTER
('5', 462, 6, 9, 1023841) PLENIPOTENTIARY OF HIS MAJESTY THE EMPEROR OF CHINA LONDON
('5', 462, 7, 10, 1023900) TO HIS EXCELLENCY SIR EDWARD GREY HIS BRITANNIC MAJESTY’S PRINCIPAL SECRETARY OF
('5', 462, 8, 11, 1023981) STATE FOR FOREIGN AFFAIRS
('5', 462, 9, 12, 1024007) SIR, I beg to forward herewith a true translation of a Petition received by me from the free Chinese subjects resident in the Transvaal in connection with their grievances in that Colony, and particularly with reference to an Ordinance called “The Asiatic Law Amendment Ordinance” numbered 29 and passed by the Legislative Council of that Colony.
('5', 462, 9, 13, 1024354) I granted audience to Mr. L. M. James, the delegate who has been specially deputed by the Chinese subjects aforementioned to present in person the Petition above referred to, and to place before me their case.
('5', 462, 9, 14, 1024564) It appears to me that, if the statements made in the Petition are correct, and from investigation made by me and from what I have learnt through the Chinese Consul General for South Africa I have no doubt as to the truth of these statements, the Chinese subjects have a very real grievance.
('5', 462, 9, 15, 1024855) I am aware that the objectionable features referred to in paragraph 7 of the Petition do not appear in the Ordinance itself, but I am informed that it is the intention of the Transvaal Government to
('5', 462, 10, 16, 1025054) 1 This representation was drafted by Gandhiji; vide “Letter to Yuk Lin Lew” 26 10 1906 and “Letter to H. O. Ally”, 31 10 1906
('5', 463, 0, 1, 1025180) 464 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 463, 1, 2, 1025222) pass regulations requiring finger impressions and other particulars of identification, which the Petitioners would properly resent.
('5', 463, 1, 3, 1025354) Apart, however, from any such regulations the Ordinance in question undoubtedly appears to be open to very serious objections, and exposes Chinese subjects to unnecessary hardships, inconvenience and degradation.
('5', 463, 1, 4, 1025567) I invite your attention to the fact that the most amicable relations exist between His Majesty King Edward VII and the Emperor of China, and that British subjects are entitled to the most favoured nation treatment throughout the Chinese Empire.
('5', 463, 1, 5, 1025812) I therefore trust that Your Excellency will deem it fit to secure for the Chinese subjects in the Transvaal proper treatment to which I apprehend, as subjects of an independent nation in alliance with Great Britain, they are entitled.
('5', 463, 2, 6, 1026047) I have the honour to remain,
('5', 463, 3, 7, 1026076) Your Excellency’s obedient servant.

('5', 463, 5, 9, 1026172) 416. INTERVIEW TO “SOUTH AFRICA” 1
('5', 463, 6, 10, 1026207) [LONDON, November 1, 1906]
('5', 463, 7, 11, 1026234) In conversation with a representative of South Africa, Mr. Advocate Gandhi...
('5', 463, 7, 12, 1026312) stated that the Natal Indian Congress had passed a resolution sympathizing with the objects of the Deputation, similar to the one recently adopted by the British Indians at the Cape.
('5', 463, 8, 13, 1026495) [GANDHI:] While on the subject of Natal, I may mention that 1 have received a cablegram 2 asking me to place before the authorities here the questions arising out of the Bill to be introduced in the Natal legislature by Mr. Ralph Tatham.
('5', 463, 9, 14, 1026733) [REPORTER:] What are the main objections to that measure from the Indian point of view?
('5', 463, 10, 15, 1026821) [GANDHI :] Well, the net result of that Bill, supposing it becomes law—which I cannot for a moment conceive—will be to deprive hundreds of Indian traders of their means of livelihood.
('5', 463, 10, 16, 1027005) It will mean the sweeping away of vested rights by a stroke of the pen.
('5', 463, 10, 17, 1027077) In Durban there are only about 250 Indian voters out of a List of 7,000, and in
('5', 463, 11, 18, 1027157) 1 Published in South Africa, 3 11 1906 and republished in Indian Opinion, 15 12 l90G 2 Vide “Letter to T.H. Thornton”, 2 11 1906
('5', 464, 0, 1, 1027286) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 465
('5', 464, 1, 2, 1027333) Maritzburg, about 31 out of nearly 3,000, and all those Indian voters are not by any means merchant traders.
('5', 464, 1, 3, 1027442) Some of them are professional men, and at present many of them are not in Natal at all, so that the Bill, if passed into law, will make a clean sweep of the Indian traders both in Durban and Maritzburg.
('5', 464, 1, 4, 1027645) Moreover, the Voters’ Roll, so far as Indians are concerned, is now a closed book for any future Indians because of the Franchise Act, which prevents all those who do not come from countries possessing Parliamentary institutions being placed on the Roll.
('5', 464, 2, 5, 1027900) But the matter of licences is in the hands of the licensing authorities at present ?
('5', 464, 2, 6, 1027985) Yes, that is so, and it makes the reason for bringing in such a Bill as this all the more inconceivable to me.
('5', 464, 2, 7, 1028096) The present Dealers’ Licenses Act of Natal leaves [it] at the discretion of the licensing officers either to grant licenses or to refuse them.
('5', 464, 3, 8, 1028239) And that discretion, I presume, is used fairly ?
('5', 464, 3, 9, 1028288) On the contrary, the licensing officers have exercised that discretion sometimes in a most high handed manner, without any relief being obtainable from the Supreme Court.
('5', 464, 4, 10, 1028459) Can you mention a specific instance, Mr. Gandhi?
('5', 464, 4, 11, 1028508) Certainly I can.
('5', 464, 4, 12, 1028525) In Vryheid the only Indian merchant, Dada Osman, was deprived of his licence to trade, although he was trading on his own ground, and had been doing so for a long time during the Boer regime.
('5', 464, 4, 13, 1028717) 1 Had Vryheid remained part of the Transvaal, Mr. Dada Osman would have been trading to day; but as Vryheid has been taken over by Natal, subject to the anti Asiatic laws of the Transvaal, there are two sets of laws in operation there against Indians, of which the Natal law is the more drastic, so far as the licensing of Indian traders is concerned.
('5', 464, 5, 14, 1029069) How does that affect Mr. Osman?
('5', 464, 5, 15, 1029101) The result is that, in virtue of the Transvaal law, he cannot hold landed property in Vryheid; whilst in virtue of the Natal law, he is at the mercy of the licensing officer for his trade.
('5', 464, 5, 16, 1029290) He has therefore been obliged to quit the district altogether.
('5', 464, 6, 17, 1029353) Is not that an isolated case, resulting from the particular circumstances at Vryheid ?
('5', 464, 6, 18, 1029440) Not so.
('5', 464, 6, 19, 1029448) The licensing officer in Durban refused to transfer the license of a well known Indian silk merchant from one place of business to another, although the merchant referred to has been in
('5', 464, 7, 20, 1029634) 1 Vide “ Dada Osman’s Appeal”, 4 11 1905
('5', 465, 0, 1, 1029675) 466 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 465, 1, 2, 1029717) business for a very long time, and his store was in no way in competition with European trade.
('5', 465, 1, 3, 1029812) 1 It seems to me in fact, that Mr. Tatham’s Bill is quite uncalled for, and is really an attempt to drive the Indians out of Natal altogether.
('5', 465, 2, 4, 1029955) But you know there is a strong prejudice growing against the Indian community in Natal?
('5', 465, 2, 5, 1030043) I fail to see why there should be any such feeling.
('5', 465, 2, 6, 1030095) Natal has incurred a threefold obligation in favour of Indians.
('5', 465, 2, 7, 1030159) One is that it owes its prosperity to the existence of indentured Indian labour; the second is that it was the Natal Indians who raised an Ambulance Corps of over 1,000 Indians at the time of the Boer War, 2 whose work was specially mentioned in General Buller’s despatches, and the third is that, during the recent native rebellion, the Indians, recognizing their duty ascitizens, irrespective altogether of their political opinions,offer ed the Government services of an Indian Stretcher bearer Corps, 3 whose work was highly appreciated by Sir Henry McCallum.
('5', 465, 3, 8, 1030722) Reverting for a moment to the question of the Transvaal Ordinance, our representative pointed out to Mr. Gandhi that the enactment contained no provisions necessitating the identification of Indians by means of digital impressions.
('5', 465, 3, 9, 1030954) That is so.
('5', 465, 3, 10, 1030966) But Mr. Lionel Curtis, who was then Assistant Colonial Secretary for Urban Affairs in the Transvaal, told a British Indian deputation about three months ago that it was the Government’s intention to establish a system of identification under which all Indians would be required to put down on their passes the impressions of their ten fingers, a provision which the Deputation naturally very strongly protest against.
('5', 465, 4, 11, 1031384) But there is no such provision in the Ordinance?
('5', 465, 4, 12, 1031433) No; but the Ordinance provides that the Lieutenant Governor may from time to time make regulations under it, prescribing, amongst other things, the means of identification to be furnished by Indians.
('5', 465, 4, 13, 1031633) It is also laid down in the Ordinance that police officers shall have the right not only to demand from all Asiatics over the age of 16 years production of their passes, but to insist on their furnishing such means of identification as may be prescribed by the regulations, which, according to Mr. Curtis’s declaration, means finger impressions.
('5', 465, 4, 14, 1031979) Such a system is not in force, so far as I am aware, in any
('5', 465, 5, 15, 1032039) 1 The case of Hoondamal; vide “Indian Licences: Need for Vigilance —I”, 18 2 1905 2 Vide “Indian Ambulance Corps in Natal”, 14 3 1900
('5', 465, 6, 16, 1032173) 3 Vide “The Case of Suliman Manga”, 23 6 1906 and “Indian Stretcher Bearer Corps”, Before 19 7 1906.
('5', 466, 0, 1, 1032274) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 467
('5', 466, 1, 2, 1032321) part of the world, at any rate with regard to British Indians.
('5', 466, 1, 3, 1032384) It does not apply even to the indentured Indians in Natal.
('5', 466, 1, 4, 1032443) Indian Opinion, 15 12 1906

('5', 481, 12, 20, 1054201) 1 Under Secretary and later Secretary of State for India
('5', 482, 0, 1, 1054258) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 483
('5', 482, 1, 2, 1054305) 444. JUVENILE SMOKING
('5', 482, 2, 3, 1054327) We have drawn the attention of our readers more than once to the fact that the habit of smoking bidis or cigars is harmful.
('5', 482, 2, 4, 1054451) 1 Now we have yet another occasion to refer to it.
('5', 482, 2, 5, 1054502) A law has been enacted in the Victoria Province of Australia to check the evil habit; under this law none below sixteen may smoke.
('5', 482, 2, 6, 1054633) A shopkeeper found selling or giving a bidi to a boy below that age may be fined 20 shillings for the first offence and 40 shillings for the second; if he is caught a third time, his licence may be cancelled for five years.
('5', 482, 2, 7, 1054857) It is not for the first time in the history of the world that such strict measures have been adopted for the prevention of smoking.
('5', 482, 2, 8, 1054989) Such laws are in force in some civilized countries like Japan and Germany and, nearer home, the Cape Colony.
('5', 482, 2, 9, 1055098) A short time ago, a similar bill was introduced in Natal also.
('5', 482, 2, 10, 1055161) But the usefulness of a juvenile smoking bill is not recognized in a land where enthusiasm is misused for getting rich by ruining others and, if possible, driving them out.
('5', 482, 2, 11, 1055334) Tobacco does nothing but harm.
('5', 482, 2, 12, 1055365) It weakens body and mind.
('5', 482, 2, 13, 1055391) It is obvious that its harmful effect is felt all the more in youth.
('5', 482, 2, 14, 1055460) In certain places, religion forbids the use of tobacco, and it is true that many Indians do not smoke for that reason.
('5', 482, 2, 15, 1055579) But in some places the habit is so firmly rooted that we feel no hesitation in writing against it again and again.
('5', 482, 2, 16, 1055694) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 3 11 1906
('5', 482, 3, 17, 1055736) 1 Vide “The Evils of Smoking”, 21 10 1905
('5', 483, 0, 1, 1055778) 484 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 483, 1, 2, 1055820) 445. REPRESENTATION TO LORD ELGIN 1
('5', 483, 2, 3, 1055856) COMMON ROOM, LINCOLN’S INN, W.C. November 3, 1906
('5', 483, 3, 4, 1055906) TO THE RIGHT HON’BLE THE EARL OF ELGIN HIS MAJESTY’S PRINCIPAL SECRETARY OF STATE FOR THE COLONIES LONDON
('5', 483, 4, 5, 1056012) MAY IT PLEASE YOUR LORDSHIP, We, the undersigned British Indians domiciled in South Africa, have read with a great deal of pain and anxiety the Asiatic Law Amendment Ordinance of the Transvaal, and we have naturally followed with great interest the movements of the British Indian Deputation that has arrived from the Transvaal.
('5', 483, 4, 6, 1056341) We are all students from South Africa, four of us studying for the Bar, and one of us studying medicine, and while we cannot but sympathize with the struggles of our countrymen in the Transvaal for liberty, our chief anxiety is regarding ourselves and persons placed in a position similar to our own, and we venture respectfully to approach your Lordship to explain our position in the light of the new Ordinance.
('5', 483, 4, 7, 1056755) We are all of us either born or brought up in South Africa, and to us South Africa is more our home than India.
('5', 483, 4, 8, 1056867) Even our mother tongue is English, our parents having brought us up to speak that language from our infancy.
('5', 483, 4, 9, 1056976) Three of us are Christians, one a Mahommedan, and one a Hindoo.
('5', 483, 4, 10, 1057040) According to the information received by us, and in accordance with the personal knowledge of the first undersigned, the effect of the Peace Preservation Ordinance of the Transvaal, the declaration made by Lord Selborne to the White Leagues of the Transvaal, and the present Asiatic Law Amendment Ordinance which has brought the Indian Deputation to wait on your Lordship (with the exception of the first undersigned, who has lived in the Transvaal and who was practising as a sworn Translator and Interpreter in the English and
('5', 483, 5, 11, 1057569) 1 This is the final form of the representation which Gandhiji drafted.
('5', 483, 5, 12, 1057640) Vide footnote to “Letter to G. Godfrey's, 31 10 1906 and “Circular Letter”, 2 11 1906 The representation was reproduced in Indian Opinion, 8 12 1906.
('5', 484, 0, 1, 1057790) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 485
('5', 484, 1, 2, 1057837) Hindustani languages of the Honourable the Supreme Court of the Transvaal, and who came into very close contact with the Asiatic Department), all of us would be unable to proceed to the Transvaal because we are not pre war residents of the Transvaal.
('5', 484, 1, 3, 1058088) The net result of this disability would be that, although the certificates we would receive on our being called to the Bar, or on our receiving the Medical Diploma, which [sic] would entitle us to carry on our professions in any part of the British Dominions on the production of those certificates and of evidence of good character, our diplomas or certificates would be valueless, so far as the Transvaal is concerned.
('5', 484, 1, 4, 1058509) We would moreover on the one hand be able, although being without the Transvaal border, on application to receive from the Court or from the Medical Society a license to carry on our profession, but we would be debarred from making use thereof by reason of the want of a permit to enter the Transvaal Most of us, and many others born in South Africa and elsewhere, and equally well educated, would be required to submit to registration, and to produce a permit to any policeman who may demand to see it and to be marched off to the police station, or to the Criminal Investigation Department office to furnish means of identification in order to show that we are lawful possessors of those passes.
('5', 484, 1, 5, 1059207) We would also, we apprehend, be liable to be called upon to furnish means of identification at the time of taking out the passes in question, and be called upon to give the imprints of our ten digits and any other particulars that may be required under regulations to be framed by the Lieutenant Governor.
('5', 484, 1, 6, 1059513) Having lived in England, and having breathed its free atmo sphere, and having received every consideration from Englishmen in this country, your Lordship will easily appreciate the anxiety the prospect of the above Ordinance engenders.
('5', 484, 1, 7, 1059749) We are here being nurtured in the teachings of Bentham, Austin, and other English writers whose names are a watchword for liberty and independence, and we could hardly believe that anything of the kind referred to above would possibly be applicable to us.
('5', 484, 1, 8, 1060005) We would not have troubled your Lordship with this representation if it was a matter affecting and ending only with ourselves, but we are aware that the desire on the part of the Indians to give a good education to their children is daily growing.
('5', 484, 1, 9, 1060253) There are to day Indians in South Africa occupying a status similar to our own.
('5', 484, 1, 10, 1060333) We therefore think, it is but right that we should bring to the notice of your Lordship and, through this humble representation, to the attention of every public man in the Empire the intensity of the feeling aroused by the present status of British Indians
('5', 485, 0, 1, 1060591) 486 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 485, 1, 2, 1060633) in the Transvaal.
('5', 485, 1, 3, 1060651) We therefore humbly pray and hope that your Lordship will be able to grant us, and those similarly placed as we are, the protection that we venture to believe we are entitled to.
('5', 485, 2, 4, 1060830) We beg to remain,
('5', 485, 3, 5, 1060848) Your Lordship's humble and obedient servants,
('5', 485, 4, 6, 1060894) GEORGE V. GODFREY
('5', 485, 5, 7, 1060912) JOSEPH ROYEPPEN
('5', 485, 6, 8, 1060928) W. GODFREY
('5', 485, 7, 9, 1060939) A. H. GOOL
('5', 485, 8, 10, 1060950) S. RUTHNUM PATHER
('5', 485, 9, 11, 1060968) From a photostat of the printed copy: G. N. 2307
('5', 485, 10, 12, 1061017) 446. LETTER TO A. W. ARATHOON
('5', 485, 11, 13, 1061047) [HOTEL CECIL, LONDON,] November 3, 1906
