('5', 489, 0, 1, 1064871) 490 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 489, 1, 2, 1064913) 453. THE DEPUTATION'S VOYAGE—V 1
('5', 489, 2, 3, 1064946) LONDON, November 3, 1906
('5', 489, 3, 4, 1064971) SHYAMJI KRISHNAVARMA AND INDIA HOUSE As I promised in my last despatch, I now write about Mr. Shyamji Krishnavarma and India House.
('5', 489, 3, 5, 1065103) Mr. Shyamji Krishnavarma is a barrister from Bombay, and a son in law of Mr. Chhabildas Bhansali.
('5', 489, 3, 6, 1065201) As hisknowledge of Sanskrit was of a very high order, the late Prof.
('5', 489, 3, 7, 1065270) Monier Williams took him to Oxford where, because of his ability, he was made a professor and earned a lot of money.
('5', 489, 3, 8, 1065387) Meanwhile he studied law and was called to the bar, took a degree at Oxford and studied Greek, Latin and other languages.
('5', 489, 3, 9, 1065509) When he returned to India, he took with him £2,000 which he had saved—a thing which, it is said, no other Indian had done before.
('5', 489, 3, 10, 1065639) In India he served as Dewan in Ajmer 2 and other States.
('5', 489, 3, 11, 1065696) Later, his ideas changed and he decided to spend his earnings for the benefit of the country.
('5', 489, 3, 12, 1065790) With this end in view he came to England and settled here.
('5', 489, 3, 13, 1065849) He lives on the land which he has purchased.
('5', 489, 3, 14, 1065894) Though he can afford to live in comfort, he lives in poverty.
('5', 489, 3, 15, 1065956) He dresses simply and lives like an ascetic.
('5', 489, 3, 16, 1066001) His mission is service to his country.
('5', 489, 3, 17, 1066040) The idea underlying his service is that there should be complete swaraj for India and that the British should quit the country, handing over power to Indians.
('5', 489, 3, 18, 1066199) If they do not do so, the Indians should refuse them all help so that they become unable to carry on the administration and are forced to leave.
('5', 489, 3, 19, 1066344) He holds that unless this is done the people of India will never be happy.
('5', 489, 3, 20, 1066419) Everything else will follow swaraj.
('5', 489, 3, 21, 1066455) INDIA HOUSE In order to seek support for these views and win people over to his faith, he has founded India House at his own cost.
('5', 489, 3, 22, 1066586) Any Indian student is allowed to stay there against a very small weekly payment.
('5', 489, 3, 23, 1066667) All Indians, whether Hindus, Muslims or others, can and do stay there.
('5', 489, 3, 24, 1066738) The expenses of some students are borne by Shyamji himself.
('5', 489, 3, 25, 1066798) There is full freedom for everyone in the matter of food and drink.
('5', 489, 4, 26, 1066866) 1 This and the previous instalment, “The Deputation's Voyage lV”, 26 10 1906 , appeared together in the same issue of Indian Opinion.
('5', 489, 4, 27, 1067000) As this was, however, written later and meant to be a separate despatch, it is here printed separately in its proper sequence.
('5', 489, 4, 28, 1067127) 2 Ajmer was British territory, not a Native State.
('5', 489, 4, 29, 1067178) Gandhiji seems to have mistaken it for Udaipur where Krishnavarma was Dewan.
('5', 490, 0, 1, 1067255) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 491
('5', 490, 1, 2, 1067302) situated in fine surroundings, the place has a very good atmosphere.
('5', 490, 1, 3, 1067371) On the first day of our arrival, both Mr. Ally and I went to stay at India House, and we were very well looked after.
('5', 490, 1, 4, 1067489) But as our work requires our getting in touch with important people and as India House is rather remote, we have been obliged to come and live at this Hotel at great expense.
('5', 490, 1, 5, 1067664) EXPENSES IN ENGLAND I had believed a man could live here on £1 a day, but my estimate has proved wrong.
('5', 490, 1, 6, 1067768) Here a bed sitting room costs 12s 6d a day, with extra charge for a bath.
('5', 490, 1, 7, 1067842) These charges are for a single person.
('5', 490, 1, 8, 1067881) For reasons of health, Mr. Ally sleeps in Dr. Oldfield’s home.
('5', 490, 1, 9, 1067944) If one eats at the Hotel, a meal costs as much as 5s.
('5', 490, 1, 10, 1067998) We therefore eat at a vegetarian restaurant.
('5', 490, 1, 11, 1068043) We have a meal at the Hotel only when we ask an acquaintance over or invite an important person to lunch or dinner.
('5', 490, 1, 12, 1068159) Today, for instance, we had Mr. James, the Chinese delegate, and a Chinese lawyer.
('5', 490, 1, 13, 1068242) Mr. Ritch was also with us.
('5', 490, 1, 14, 1068270) The bill for a single meal came to £1.11s.
('5', 490, 1, 15, 1068313) At the vegetarian restaurant a meal hardly costs more than 1s 6d for a person.
('5', 490, 1, 16, 1068392) And as Mr. Godfrey or some other assistant is always with us, the cost for a meal comes to three to four shillings.
('5', 490, 1, 17, 1068508) As all the important persons live at distant places, we have to spend a great deal on transport.
('5', 490, 1, 18, 1068605) We go sometimes by train, sometimes by bus and often by cab.
('5', 490, 1, 19, 1068666) There is hardly time for walking.
('5', 490, 1, 20, 1068700) In spite of all this hurrying, we cannot see more than two persons a day.
('5', 490, 1, 21, 1068774) Often at the House of Commons we have to wait an hour before we can see a Member.
('5', 490, 1, 22, 1068856) However, we hope to be able to keep the expenses within the limits set by the Committee.
('5', 490, 1, 23, 1068945) INSUFFICIENT TIME We had intended to stay here for a month.
('5', 490, 1, 24, 1069005) But from experience I see that there would be work enough for us to do if we were to stay six months and that it would not all be fruitless.
('5', 490, 1, 25, 1069146) We find many people coming forward who sympathize with our cause and are ready to work for it.
('5', 490, 1, 26, 1069241) INTERVIEW WITH LORD ELGIN The meeting with Lord Elgin has been fixed for November 8, when Sir Lepel Griffin, Lord Stanley, Sir Muncherji Bhownaggree, Mr. Dadabhai Naoroji, Sir Henry Cotton, Mr. Thornton, Mr. Justice Ameer Ali, Mr. Harold Cox, Sir George Birdwood and Sir Charles Dilke will join us.
('5', 490, 1, 27, 1069540) Sir Lepel Griffin will act as the leader.
('5', 490, 1, 28, 1069582) A petition setting out the facts in brief has been printed and sent today to Lord Elgin.
('5', 490, 1, 29, 1069671) As it consists mostly of the arguments we have been advancing there, I do not give its translation here.
('5', 491, 0, 1, 1069776) 492 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('5', 491, 1, 2, 1069818) PRESS COMMENTS Interviews [with the Press] have been published in South Africa, The Morning Leader and The Tribune.
('5', 491, 1, 3, 1069934) South Africa, which used to be bitterly critical, has now written somewhat in our favour.
('5', 491, 1, 4, 1070024) Our letter to The Times has been published in substance.
('5', 491, 1, 5, 1070081) Notice has been taken of it in other papers also.
('5', 491, 2, 6, 1070131) MEMBERS OF HOUSE OF COMMONS
('5', 491, 3, 7, 1070159) Efforts are being made to bring together some Members of the House of Commons so that they may hear us and pass a resolution expressing sympathy with our cause.
('5', 491, 3, 8, 1070320) In this matter we have received great assistance from Mr. Polak’s father and Mr. Ritch.
('5', 491, 3, 9, 1070408) I cannot say more just yet.
('5', 491, 3, 10, 1070436) Efforts are also being made to arrange an interview with Lord George Hamilton, former Secretary of State for India, which most likely will materialize.
('5', 491, 3, 11, 1070588) Whatever happens, I at any rate expect to return before January 1. Mr. Ally has sought an interview with the Turkish Ambassador.
('5', 491, 3, 12, 1070717) A reply is expected on Monday.
('5', 491, 4, 13, 1070748) NEED FOR A PERMANENT COMMITTEE
('5', 491, 5, 14, 1070779) Sir Muncherji has been working hard in our behalf.
('5', 491, 5, 15, 1070830) He and some others are of the opinion that, for a few years at least, it is necessary to have a standing committee here.
('5', 491, 5, 16, 1070951) Even if Lord Elgin rejects the Ordinance, it is certain that, when the Transvaal gets self government, new laws will be enacted, and some vigilant work will have to be put in here.
('5', 491, 5, 17, 1071132) Unless there is a person who gives all his time to a single cause, it is difficult to carry on public work in this city.
('5', 491, 5, 18, 1071253) Many may express sympathy, but if work is to be got out of them, they must be supplied with prepared material.
('5', 491, 5, 19, 1071364) Only then can they do something, for they have many other matters to attend to.
('5', 491, 5, 20, 1071444) The expenses for a committee of this kind may come to at least £300 a year.
('5', 491, 5, 21, 1071520) It can be formed only if the Transvaal Indian community undertakes to find the money.
('5', 491, 5, 22, 1071606) It will need an office, for which more than £50 a year will be required.
('5', 491, 5, 23, 1071679) Mr. Ritch has now done his final examination and as long as he is here, he can do a lot for us.
('5', 491, 5, 24, 1071775) He should be given an allowance of at least £10 a month.
('5', 491, 5, 25, 1071832) He is a poor man.
('5', 491, 5, 26, 1071850) Otherwise, he is so good that he would work for us free of
('5', 492, 0, 1, 1071909) VOL. 5 : 6 NOVEMBER, 1905 3 NOVEMBER, 1906 493
('5', 492, 1, 2, 1071956) charge.
('5', 492, 1, 3, 1071964) Thus, £170 will be spent on the office and the Secretary.
('5', 492, 1, 4, 1072022) The furniture is expected to cost £30. The remaining £100 to be spent on house rent, conveyance, printing, dinners, etc., is a small amount.
('5', 492, 1, 5, 1072163) But I believe that, with this expenditure, much can be accomplished here.
('5', 492, 1, 6, 1072237) Such committees for big causes are to be found all over London.
('5', 492, 1, 7, 1072301) We find that a Committee of the Chinese League is already functioning here.
('5', 492, 1, 8, 1072377) As the committee can be formed only while we are here and as the work is urgent, a cablegram has been sent to South Africa.
('5', 492, 1, 9, 1072501) Natal and the Cape can both join in this.
('5', 492, 1, 10, 1072543) As there is not much to do for the Cape Indians just now and as their leaders have been passing through hard times, we have not suggested collection of any funds from the Cape.
('5', 492, 1, 11, 1072720) Many prominent Britishers have agreed to work on this committee, if it is formed.
('5', 492, 1, 12, 1072802) BRAVE WOMEN A vigorous movement is going on here for securing the franchise for women.
('5', 492, 1, 13, 1072889) When the Government showed willingness to grant special treatment in gaol to the brave daughter of the late Mr. Cobden, she replied, ‘No matter how I suffer, I shall seek no favour from you.
('5', 492, 1, 14, 1073080) I am in gaol for my own and my sisters’ rights, and I will live like a common prisoner till the franchise is granted.’ Such words have stirred up public feeling in their favour, and the papers which used to ridicule them before have stopped doing so.
('5', 492, 1, 15, 1073331) Every Indian in the Transvaal should take to heart the example of these brave women.
('5', 492, 2, 16, 1073416) [From Gujarati]
('5', 492, 3, 17, 1073432) Indian Opinion, 1 12 1906
